24
2.1.1
Viewing System Parameters
Viewing system parameters can aid in troubleshooting. For example, 
if your calls are not being routed to the proper day or night Admin 
Station, you should check that the system parameters settings for day 
start and night start time are correct.
To view System Parameters:
From the navigation bar, select System Parameters.
The System Parameters page appears. 
2.1.1.1
Using the System Parameters Page
From the System Parameters page, you can view many of the settings 
for the entire facility and perform the following tasks:
• Export a report. (See "Exporting a Report” on page 32.)
• Enter a product license. (See "Entering a Product License Activation 
Key” on page 35.)
Figure 2-1, System Parameters Page
25
• Sort the menu. (See "Changing the Navigation Bar Order” on 
page 37.)
• Restart the server. (See "Restarting the Server” on page 38.)
• Monitor stations and set station supervision criteria. (See "Station 
Supervision” on page 38.)
• Configure settings for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) email 
notifications. (See "Email Configuration” on page 41.)
• Perform a system update. (See "Performing a System Update” on 
page 43.)
• Configure Automatic Software Download. (See "Configuring Auto-
matic Software Download” on page 48.)
• Shut down the server. (See "Shutting Down the Server” on 
page 51.)
The following table details the parameters that you can view from the 
System Parameters page:
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page
Name
Specifies the name given to the entire facility. The name 
can be up to 30 characters.
Day Start
Identifies when the system switches to its “Day” mode of 
operation and specifies the time period for which the day 
Admin Station is active. Telephones with night-only outside 
line access are prevented from placing outside line calls 
during this time. Valid times range from 00:00 to 23:58, but 
must be less than the Night Start time.
Night Start
Identifies when the system switches to its “Night” mode of 
operation and specifies the time period for which the night 
Admin Station is active. During this time, telephones with 
the night-only outside line access can place outside line 
calls. Valid times range from 00:01 to 23:59; but must be 
larger than the Day Start time.
Emergency-All-Call 
Multicast RTP IP 
Address
Identifies the IP address to use for multicast RTP paging for 
Emergency-All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have 
this IP address configured. Emergency all-call is a top prior-
ity all-call page. An all-call page is a simultaneous page to 
all speakers within a facility.
26
Emergency-All-Call 
Multicast RTP Port
Identifies the RTP port to use for multicast RTP paging for 
Emergency-All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have 
this RTP port configured.
Emergency-All-Call Cut 
Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for Emergency-All-Call audio. The cut 
volume range is 0 to -42.
All-Call Multicast RTP 
IP Address
Identifies the All-Call Multicast RTP IP address. Receiving IP 
telephones must also have this IP address configured. 
All-Call Multicast RTP 
Port
Identifies the RTP port to use for multicast RTP paging for 
All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have this RTP 
port configured.
All-Call Cut Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for All-Call audio. The cut volume 
range is 0 to -42. 
Audio Distribution 
Multicast IP Address
Identifies the RPT multicast IP address to use for audio dis-
tribution to all stations. For more information about audio 
distribution, see "Managing Audio” on page 247.
Audio Distribution 
Multicast Port
Identifies the RTP multicast port to use for audio distribu-
tion to all stations.
Audio Distribution Cut 
Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for audio distribution. The cut volume 
range is 0 to -42.
Default Cut Level (dB)
Defines the default cut volume level for a new zone. The cut 
volume range is 0 to -42. For information about zones, see 
"Viewing Zone Information” on page 168.
Ambient Noise Sensor 
Multicast IP Address
Identifies the multicast IP address to use by ambient noise 
sensors (ANSs) to send volume data.
Ambient Noise Sensor 
Multicast Port
Identifies the multicast port number to be used by ANSs to 
send volume data.
Network Time Server
Identifies the IP address or the domain name of the NTP 
server to be used.
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page (Continued)
27
Appliances Network 
Time Server Source
Identifies the time source for all appliances on the Nyquist 
network. The appliances may use one of the following 
sources:
• nyquist
When this option is selected, all Nyquist appliances will 
use the Nyquist system server as the NTP server; this is 
the default option.
• dhcp
When this option is selected, all Nyquist appliances will 
use the NTP server provided via DHCP Option 42.
• ntpserver
When this option is selected, all Nyquist appliances will 
use the Network Time Server defined in System Parame-
ters.
Time Zone
Sets the time zone for the server.
Disable Preannounce 
Tone
Indicates if the preannounce tone is disabled. If disabled, 
the tone is not heard when connecting to a speaker or prior 
to a page.
Privacy Beep
Indicates if the privacy beep feature is on. 
Use Network Time 
Server defined by 
DHCP
When enabled, the Network Time Server will be defined by 
DHCP.
Emergency Tone
Identifies the preannounce tone played before an Emer-
gency-All-Call is made.
All Call Tone
Identifies the preannounce tone played before an All-Call is 
made.
Intercom Tone
Identifies the preannounce tone played before an intercom 
call is made.
Dialing Length
Specifies the number of digits required to dial within the 
system. Valid values are 3, 4, 5, or 6. If you change the dial-
ing length, all Nyquist appliances and IP phones must be 
rebooted. A system backup is automatically created.
Default Codecs 
Allowed
Provides the default list of media CODECs to be used. A 
CODEC, or coder-decoder, is a device or computer program 
for encoding or decoding a digital data stream or signal. 
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page (Continued)
28
Admin Queue Timeout
Specifies the maximum amount of minutes that a call 
switch or handset station can remain in an administrative 
queue. When the time is exceeded, the call switch or hand-
set station is removed from the queue. Valid timeout values 
range from 1 to 999 minutes.
Night Ring Enabled
Indicates if a night ring is enabled. When enabled, you can 
optionally set a Night Ring Admin and option set one 
additional option from the following list:
• Night Ring All Stations
• Night Ring Admin Group
• Night Ring Zones
(For more information on night ring behavior, see "Setting 
Night Call Options” on page 31.)
Night Ring Admin
Identifies the specific Admin Station that handles outside 
line calls received during night hours. Outside line calls not 
answered with 15 seconds trigger ringing to all or selected 
stations. If Night Ring Admin is the only option set, then 
the specified Admin extension rings for 30 minutes and 
hangs up if the call is not answered within that time. 
Note: If Night Admin is also included in the call, both 
Night Admin and Night Ring Admin ring. An analog 
phone cannot be used as a Night Ring Admin even if the 
station has the admin Class of Service (CoS) enabled.
Night Ring All Stations
Indicates if all stations receive night rings during night 
hours. When enabled, any ringing station can answer the 
call. The specified stations will ring for up to 30 minutes, 
then hang up if the call is not answered within that time.
Note: NQ-P0100 Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp stations will also 
ring.
Night Ring Admin 
Group
Identifies the Admin Group that handles outside line calls 
received during night hours. The Admin Group is called if 
the Night Admin and Night Ring Admin do not answer 
within 15 seconds. The specified stations will ring for up to 
30 minutes, then hang up if the call is not answered within 
that time.
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page (Continued)
29
Night Ring Zones
Identifies which zones receive night rings when outside 
calls are received during night hours. The specified stations 
will ring for up to 30 minutes, then hang up if the call is not 
answered within that time.
Server IP Address
Identifies the server’s IP address. To change the server’s IP 
address, select Change Server IP Address and then select 
the correct IP address from the menu that appears.
Parking Lot
Defines the range of numbers to use for call parking. The 
first number listed is used to initiate call parking, which is a 
feature that allows you to put a call on hold at one tele-
phone set and continue the conversation from any other 
telephone set.
Record Monitoring
Indicates if call and location monitoring will be recorded.
Emergency Link
Specifies the station that functions as the system’s Emer-
gency Link Station. An Emergency Link Station is the station 
that an emergency call (but not a 911 call) is routed to if the 
station’s associated Admin Station is busy, rejects the call, 
or fails to answer within 15 seconds. A value of 999 means 
that this feature is disabled.
If the Emergency Link Station is a ringable device (a Nyquist 
phone), the station will ring and the call will be displayed 
on the station’s display (if so equipped) as an “Emergency 
Call.” If the Emergency Link Station is not a ringable device 
(a Nyquist VoIP speaker), the station will auto-answer, pre-
announcing the call as an “Emergency.” The Admin Station 
will continue to ring if an emergency call is auto-answered 
by a non-ringable Emergency Link Station device. The 
Admin Station can retrieve the call by answering it, and the 
Emergency Link Station device will then drop the call. As 
with any Emergency Call, all calls to an Emergency Link Sta-
tion will be recorded.
Max Restricted Digits
Specifies the maximum number of digits that can be dialed 
if a station has been assigned restricted outside line access.
CDR Storage Duration
Identifies the number of days that a record of call details 
will be kept. CDR is an acronym for Call Detail Record.
Trunk Priority
Identifies the first trunk type to use for placing outbound 
calls.
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page (Continued)
30
Bump on Emergency
Indicates if emergency calls to the Admin Station will bump 
existing non-emergency calls.
Bump on 911
Indicates if outbound calls to 911 will bump trunk calls if no 
available outbound trunk is available.
Allow Local Emer-
gency-All-Call Page 
Interrupt
When enabled, allows an Emergency-All-Call page to be 
interrupted after the user enters a PIN.
Allow Multi-Site-Emer-
gency-All-Call Inter-
rupt
When enabled, Emergency-All-Call pages can be inter-
rupted by Multi-Site-Emergency-All-Call pages.
Auth Code
Allows you to enable additional features on a telephone 
when the walking CoS feature is enabled. The four-digit 
code activates features from the associated phone to the 
phone being used. (Auth is an abbreviation for Authoriza-
tion.) If set to 0000, the walking CoS feature is disabled.
Call Assurance Audio
Identifies the audio to be played to the caller to indicate 
that the call has been placed.
Remote Facility CoS
Identifies the CoS for remote facility access.
Facility Password
Identifies the password to be used by facility servers that 
are registering with this server. The maximum password size 
is 12 characters.
RTP Start Port
Identifies the start port number for UDP RTP traffic. The 
default is 10000.
RTP End Port
Identifies the stop port number for UDP RTP traffic. The 
default is 20000.
Enable RTP Checksums
Indicates if UDP checksums are enabled for RTP traffic.
Enable ICE Support
Indicates if ICE support is enabled.
Note: Disabling ICE support could result in audio issues when making 
calls using the Web Interface.
STUN Server
Identifies the host name or IP address for the STUN server 
that is used when determining the external IP address and 
port for an RTP session. (Port number is optional.) If omit-
ted, the default value of 3478 is used.
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page (Continued)
31
2.1.1.2
Setting Night Call Options
The way outside calls received during nighttime hours are handled 
depends on how you set up the Night Ring options on the System 
Parameters page. (See "Using the System Parameters Page” on 
page 24.) The following diagram illustrates how settings for these 
options affect night calls.
TURN Server
Identifies the host name or IP address for the TURN server 
that is to be used as a relay. (Port number is optional.) If 
omitted, the default value of 3478 will be used.
TURN Username
Identifies the user name used to authenticate with the 
TURN server.
TURN Password
Identifies the password used to authenticate with the TURN 
server.
Retention Recordings
Identifies the number of days to retain recordings. Record-
ings that are older than the retention period are automati-
cally deleted.
Backup Retention 
System
Identifies the number of days to retain system backup files. 
System backups that are older than the retention period are 
automatically deleted, provided at least one system backup 
file remains.
Backup Retention 
Recordings
Identifies the number of days that backups of recordings 
are retained. Backups that are older than the retention 
period are automatically deleted.
Backup Retention 
Voicemail
Identifies the number of days that voicemail backups are 
retailed. Backups that are older than the retention period 
are automatically deleted.
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page (Continued)

qas.question: What is the purpose of viewing system parameters in the troubleshooting process?

answers.text: Viewing system parameters is essential in the troubleshooting process as it allows administrators to verify critical settings, such as day and night start times, which affect call routing. Accurate parameters help ensure that calls are directed to the appropriate stations, thereby improving system functionality and resolving issues efficiently.

qas.question: How can you export a report from the System Parameters page?

answers.text: To export a report from the System Parameters page, select the "System Parameters" option from the navigation bar, then follow the instructions provided in the "Exporting a Report" section, which is detailed on page 32 of the documentation.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Day Start and Night Start times in system operation?

answers.text: The Day Start time indicates when the system transitions to "Day" mode, during which the day Admin Station is active, and calls with night-only outside line access are restricted. Conversely, the Night Start time marks the switch to "Night" mode, enabling night Admin Station access for outside line calls. Proper configuration of these times ensures calls are routed correctly based on the time of day.

qas.question: What does the Emergency-All-Call Multicast RTP IP Address specify?

answers.text: The Emergency-All-Call Multicast RTP IP Address specifies the IP address used for multicast RTP paging during an Emergency-All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also be configured with this IP address to ensure they can receive the emergency paging notifications.

qas.question: How can you configure settings for email notifications using the System Parameters page?

answers.text: To configure settings for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) email notifications using the System Parameters page, navigate to the System Parameters section and locate the Email Configuration setting. From there, you can enter and adjust the necessary SMTP settings for email notifications.

qas.question: What parameters determine how outside calls are handled during nighttime hours?

answers.text: The handling of outside calls during nighttime hours is determined by the Night Ring options, specifically the Night Ring Admin, Night Ring All Stations, Night Ring Admin Group, and Night Ring Zones settings. These parameters dictate which stations or groups are notified of incoming calls and how long they will ring before timing out.

qas.question: What is the default cut volume range for Emergency-All-Call audio?

answers.text: The default cut volume range for Emergency-All-Call audio is from 0 to -42 dB. This allows for the adjustment of audio levels during an emergency all-call paging situation.

qas.question: What is the function of the Network Time Server in system parameters?

answers.text: The Network Time Server in system parameters identifies the IP address or domain name of the NTP server used to synchronize the system's time. Accurate timekeeping is essential for the proper operation of the system and for ensuring timely responses during calls and operations.

qas.question: How do you define the maximum amount of time a call can remain in the administrative queue?

answers.text: To define the maximum amount of time a call can remain in the administrative queue, specify the timeout value in minutes under the "Admin Queue Timeout" parameter on the System Parameters page. Valid timeout values range from 1 to 999 minutes.

qas.question: What is the role of the Emergency Link Station in the system?

answers.text: The Emergency Link Station functions as a designated station for routing emergency calls when the associated Admin Station is busy, rejects the call, or does not answer within 15 seconds. If it is a ringable device, it will ring and display the call as an "Emergency Call"; if it's not ringable, it will auto-answer and announce the call. Emergency calls to this station are recorded.

qas.question: How does the Night Ring Admin option affect incoming calls at night?

answers.text: The Night Ring Admin option identifies a specific Admin Station that handles outside line calls received during night hours. If an incoming call is not answered within 15 seconds, it will trigger ringing to the specified Night Ring Admin, which will ring for up to 30 minutes before hanging up if not answered.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Authorization Code (Auth Code) parameter?

answers.text: The Authorization Code (Auth Code) parameter enables additional features on a telephone when the walking Class of Service (CoS) feature is activated. It is a four-digit code that activates features from the associated phone to the phone being used, while a code of 0000 disables the walking CoS feature.

qas.question: How can the server’s IP address be changed in system parameters?

answers.text: To change the server's IP address in system parameters, select "Change Server IP Address" on the System Parameters page and then choose the correct IP address from the menu that appears.

qas.question: What defines the dialing length required for calls within the system?

answers.text: The dialing length required for calls within the system specifies the number of digits needed to dial, with valid options being 3, 4, 5, or 6 digits. If the dialing length is changed, all Nyquist appliances and IP phones must be rebooted, and a system backup is automatically created.

qas.question: What happens to call detail records (CDR) after the specified storage duration?

answers.text: After the specified storage duration for call detail records (CDR) is reached, the records are automatically deleted. The CDR storage duration can be set to retain records for a specific number of days as indicated in the system parameters.

qas.question: How do you enable or disable preannounce tones for different types of calls?

answers.text: To enable or disable preannounce tones for different types of calls, navigate to the System Parameters page and adjust the settings for each tone category: Emergency Tone, All Call Tone, and Intercom Tone. You can set these tones to be played or silenced by changing their respective configuration options.

context: Client Requirements

qas.question: What specific client needs are identified in the requirements?

answers.text: The client needs include clear project deliverables, adherence to specific timelines, and budget constraints. Additionally, they require regular progress updates and effective communication to ensure alignment throughout the project.

qas.question: How do the client requirements impact the overall project timeline?

answers.text: Client requirements directly impact the overall project timeline by determining the scope of work, resource allocation, and potential need for revisions. If requirements are well-defined and stable, the timeline can be adhered to; however, changes or ambiguous requirements can lead to delays and increased project duration.

qas.question: Are there any constraints or limitations outlined in the client requirements?

answers.text: Yes, the client requirements outline constraints such as budget limits, project timelines, and specific regulatory compliance that must be adhered to throughout the project. Additionally, there are limitations regarding the technology stack and resources that can be utilized.

qas.question: What metrics will be used to measure the success of fulfilling the client requirements?

answers.text: Success in fulfilling the client requirements will be measured using key performance indicators (KPIs) such as client satisfaction scores, timely project delivery against agreed deadlines, and the rate of adherence to budget constraints. Additionally, feedback from stakeholders and the quality of deliverables will also be considered essential metrics.

qas.question: How will feedback from the client be integrated into the project development process?

answers.text: Client feedback will be gathered through regular check-ins and milestone reviews, ensuring their input is integrated into the project development process. This iterative approach allows for adjustments based on their suggestions, enhancing alignment with their expectations and goals.

qas.question: What resources are necessary to meet the client’s requirements effectively?

answers.text: To effectively meet the client's requirements, necessary resources include a skilled project team with relevant expertise, appropriate technology or tools to facilitate the work, and a clear communication strategy to ensure alignment and feedback throughout the process. Additionally, adequate budget and time allocation are essential for successful project execution.

qas.question: How will changes to client requirements be managed during the project?

answers.text: Changes to client requirements will be managed through a formal change request process, where any proposed modifications are documented, evaluated for impact on project scope, timeline, and budget, and then approved by both the project team and client stakeholders before implementation. Regular communication and feedback sessions will ensure alignment and address any concerns promptly.

qas.question: What are the expected outcomes upon successfully addressing the client requirements?

answers.text: The expected outcomes include enhanced client satisfaction through tailored solutions that meet their specific needs, improved operational efficiency, and increased loyalty and trust in the service provided. Additionally, successful implementation may lead to measurable performance improvements and potential for future collaboration.

2.1.1
Viewing System Parameters
Viewing system parameters can aid in troubleshooting. For example, 
if your calls are not being routed to the proper day or night Admin 
Station, you should check that the system parameters settings for day 
start and night start time are correct.
To view System Parameters:
From the navigation bar, select System Parameters.
The System Parameters page appears. 
2.1.1.1
Using the System Parameters Page
From the System Parameters page, you can view many of the settings 
for the entire facility and perform the following tasks:
• Export a report. (See "Exporting a Report” on page 32.)
• Enter a product license. (See "Entering a Product License Activation 
Key” on page 35.)
Figure 2-1, System Parameters Page
25
• Sort the menu. (See "Changing the Navigation Bar Order” on 
page 37.)
• Restart the server. (See "Restarting the Server” on page 38.)
• Monitor stations and set station supervision criteria. (See "Station 
Supervision” on page 38.)
• Configure settings for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) email 
notifications. (See "Email Configuration” on page 41.)
• Perform a system update. (See "Performing a System Update” on 
page 43.)
• Configure Automatic Software Download. (See "Configuring Auto-
matic Software Download” on page 48.)
• Shut down the server. (See "Shutting Down the Server” on 
page 51.)
The following table details the parameters that you can view from the 
System Parameters page:
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page
Name
Specifies the name given to the entire facility. The name 
can be up to 30 characters.
Day Start
Identifies when the system switches to its “Day” mode of 
operation and specifies the time period for which the day 
Admin Station is active. Telephones with night-only outside 
line access are prevented from placing outside line calls 
during this time. Valid times range from 00:00 to 23:58, but 
must be less than the Night Start time.
Night Start
Identifies when the system switches to its “Night” mode of 
operation and specifies the time period for which the night 
Admin Station is active. During this time, telephones with 
the night-only outside line access can place outside line 
calls. Valid times range from 00:01 to 23:59; but must be 
larger than the Day Start time.
Emergency-All-Call 
Multicast RTP IP 
Address
Identifies the IP address to use for multicast RTP paging for 
Emergency-All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have 
this IP address configured. Emergency all-call is a top prior-
ity all-call page. An all-call page is a simultaneous page to 
all speakers within a facility.
26
Emergency-All-Call 
Multicast RTP Port
Identifies the RTP port to use for multicast RTP paging for 
Emergency-All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have 
this RTP port configured.
Emergency-All-Call Cut 
Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for Emergency-All-Call audio. The cut 
volume range is 0 to -42.
All-Call Multicast RTP 
IP Address
Identifies the All-Call Multicast RTP IP address. Receiving IP 
telephones must also have this IP address configured. 
All-Call Multicast RTP 
Port
Identifies the RTP port to use for multicast RTP paging for 
All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have this RTP 
port configured.
All-Call Cut Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for All-Call audio. The cut volume 
range is 0 to -42. 
Audio Distribution 
Multicast IP Address
Identifies the RPT multicast IP address to use for audio dis-
tribution to all stations. For more information about audio 
distribution, see "Managing Audio” on page 247.
Audio Distribution 
Multicast Port

tion to all stations.
Audio Distribution Cut 
Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for audio distribution. The cut volume 
range is 0 to -42.

Defines the default cut volume level for a new zone. The cut 
volume range is 0 to -42. For information about zones, see 
"Viewing Zone Information” on page 168.
Ambient Noise Sensor 
Multicast IP Address
Identifies the multicast IP address to use by ambient noise

Network Time Server
Identifies the IP address or the domain name of the NTP 
server to be used.

27

Time Server Source
Identifies the time source for all appliances on the Nyquist

sources:
• nyquist
When this option is selected, all Nyquist appliances will

the default option.

• ntpserver

Specifies the maximum amount of minutes that a call 
switch or handset station can remain in an administrative 
queue. When the time is exceeded, the call switch or hand-
set station is removed from the queue. Valid timeout values 
range from 1 to 999 minutes.
Night Ring Enabled
Indicates if a night ring is enabled. When enabled, you can

• Night Ring Admin Group
• Night Ring Zones

Identifies the specific Admin Station that handles outside 
line calls received during night hours. Outside line calls not 
answered with 15 seconds trigger ringing to all or selected 
stations. If Night Ring Admin is the only option set, then 
the specified Admin extension rings for 30 minutes and 
hangs up if the call is not answered within that time. 
Note: If Night Admin is also included in the call, both 
Night Admin and Night Ring Admin ring. An analog 
phone cannot be used as a Night Ring Admin even if the 
station has the admin Class of Service (CoS) enabled.
Night Ring All Stations
Indicates if all stations receive night rings during night 
hours. When enabled, any ringing station can answer the 
call. The specified stations will ring for up to 30 minutes, 
then hang up if the call is not answered within that time.
Note: NQ-P0100 Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp stations will also 
ring.
Night Ring Admin 
Group
Identifies the Admin Group that handles outside line calls 
received during night hours. The Admin Group is called if 
the Night Admin and Night Ring Admin do not answer 
within 15 seconds. The specified stations will ring for up to 
30 minutes, then hang up if the call is not answered within 
that time.
Table 2-1,  System Parameters Page (Continued)
29

Identifies which zones receive night rings when outside 
calls are received during night hours. The specified stations 
will ring for up to 30 minutes, then hang up if the call is not

The Export Report feature creates a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet with

configuring the Nyquist system. Without a product license, you can 
only add a single station. You can only enter one product activation 
key. Your product license specifies the number of maximum concur-
rent calls that can be made and the maximum number of stations 
that can be added to a system.

qas.question: What tasks can be performed from the System Parameters page?

answers.text: From the System Parameters page, you can perform various tasks including exporting reports, entering a product license, sorting the menu, restarting or shutting down the server, monitoring stations, configuring SMTP email settings, and performing system updates. Additionally, you can set parameters for call behavior, audio distribution, and manage time settings for the system.

qas.question: How do you view the System Parameters in the navigation bar?

answers.text: To view the System Parameters, select "System Parameters" from the navigation bar. This will display the System Parameters page, where you can view various settings and perform related tasks.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Day Start and Night Start settings?

answers.text: The Day Start setting specifies when the system switches to "Day" mode, activating the day Admin Station and restricting telephones with night-only outside line access from making outside calls during that time. Conversely, the Night Start setting indicates when the system transitions to "Night" mode, allowing telephones with night-only access to place outside calls. The Day Start time must be earlier than the Night Start time.

qas.question: What is the valid time range for setting the Day Start time?

answers.text: The valid time range for setting the Day Start time is from 00:00 to 23:58. However, the Day Start time must be less than the Night Start time.

qas.question: What kind of notifications can be configured through the System Parameters?

answers.text: Through the System Parameters, you can configure settings for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) email notifications, set audio cut levels for emergency pages, and manage tones for different call types (Emergency-All-Call, All Call, and intercom calls). Additionally, you can enable features such as remote facility access and call monitoring.

qas.question: How is the Emergency-All-Call Multicast RTP IP Address utilized?

answers.text: The Emergency-All-Call Multicast RTP IP Address defines the IP address used for multicast RTP paging during an Emergency-All-Call. This address must be configured on receiving IP telephones to ensure they can receive the high-priority all-call page, which simultaneously alerts all speakers within a facility in emergency situations.

qas.question: What are the cut volume settings available for Emergency-All-Call audio?

answers.text: The cut volume settings available for Emergency-All-Call audio range from 0 to -42 dB. This setting allows you to adjust the audio volume for Emergency-All-Call pages, with 0 dB being the highest and -42 dB the lowest cut level.

qas.question: How can you identify the server’s IP address in the System Parameters?

answers.text: To identify the server’s IP address in the System Parameters, navigate to the System Parameters page where the Server IP Address is displayed. This section shows the current IP address of the server, and you can change it by selecting the "Change Server IP Address" option.

qas.question: What is the function of the Emergency Link Station?

answers.text: The Emergency Link Station functions as the designated station that receives emergency calls when the associated Admin Station is busy, rejects the call, or fails to answer within 15 seconds. If the Emergency Link Station is a ringable device, it will ring and display the call as an "Emergency Call"; if it is a non-ringable device, it will auto-answer and pre-announce the call.

qas.question: How is the Night Ring Admin configured within the System Parameters?

answers.text: The Night Ring Admin is configured within the System Parameters by specifying the specific Admin Station that handles outside line calls received during night hours. If this Admin Station does not answer within 15 seconds, calls are routed to designated stations for a maximum of 30 minutes before hanging up if unanswered.

qas.question: Which parameters are necessary for configuring the Network Time Server?

answers.text: To configure the Network Time Server, the following parameters are necessary: the Network Time Server IP address or domain name, the Appliances Network Time Server Source (which can be set to nyquist, dhcp, or ntpserver), and the Time Zone. Additionally, enabling DHCP for the Network Time Server is optional.

qas.question: How are recordings and backups retained and managed in the System Parameters?

answers.text: Recordings and backups are retained and managed in the System Parameters by specifying the number of days each type of data is retained. The settings for retaining recordings, system backups, voicemail backups, and their corresponding automatic deletion after the retention period expire are clearly defined within the parameters, ensuring that older data is regularly removed.

qas.question: What happens if the dialing length is changed in the system?

answers.text: If the dialing length is changed in the system, all Nyquist appliances and IP phones must be rebooted. Additionally, a system backup is automatically created when the dialing length is modified.

qas.question: How can you export a report from the System Parameters page?

answers.text: To export a report from the System Parameters page, select "Export Report" from the System Parameters page. Once the Excel icon and report name appear in the lower left section of the page, click the report to download it. Alternatively, you can click the "Show all" button and select the report you want to view.

qas.question: What does the Auth Code feature enable for telephone users?

answers.text: The Auth Code feature enables telephone users to access additional features when the walking Class of Service (CoS) feature is activated. It requires a four-digit code to activate features from the associated phone to the phone being used; if set to 0000, the walking CoS feature is disabled.

qas.question: What is the significance of the CDR Storage Duration parameter?

answers.text: The CDR Storage Duration parameter specifies the number of days that a record of call details (Call Detail Record) will be retained in the system. This duration is important for managing data storage and compliance, as it dictates how long call logs are available for review and analysis.

qas.question: What must you enter before configuring the Nyquist system?

answers.text: Before configuring the Nyquist system, you must enter your product license activation key. Without it, you can only add a single station and will have limited functionality.

qas.question: How many stations can you add without a product license?

answers.text: Without a product license, you can only add a single station to the Nyquist system. The product license specifies the maximum number of stations that can be added.

qas.question: What information does the Software Maintenance Expiration Date provide?

answers.text: The Software Maintenance Expiration Date indicates when the software maintenance for the Nyquist system will expire, presented in MMDDYYYY format. If the maintenance has expired, the system will not allow software updates.

qas.question: What does the Maximum Concurrent Calls parameter indicate?

answers.text: The Maximum Concurrent Calls parameter indicates the highest number of simultaneous calls that the Nyquist system can handle, including telephone calls, pages, tones, alarms, and announcements. This limit is specified by the installed product license.

qas.question: What is the function of the Nyquist station?

answers.text: A Nyquist station is a device used to access the web interface of the Nyquist system, which can include speakers, phones, or Nyquist appliances (excluding I/O Controllers). It serves as a point of interaction for users within the Nyquist system.

qas.question: How can you increase your station limit?

answers.text: To increase your station limit, you need to contact Tech Support for assistance. They can help facilitate the necessary changes to your Nyquist system's license.

qas.question: What are the steps to enter a product license activation key?

answers.text: To enter a product license activation key, go to the navigation bar and select System Parameters, then choose Product License. Type the activation key number, select either "Activate License" or "Update License," and finally click Done.

qas.question: When does the Activate License button become active?

answers.text: The Activate License button becomes active only when data is entered into the Activation Key field. Without entering the activation key, the button remains inactive.

qas.question: What does the Update License button do?

answers.text: The Update License button allows the Nyquist system server to check for any changes made to the product license, such as modifications to the maximum station count or maximum concurrent calls. It updates the system to reflect these changes accordingly.

qas.question: How can you release a license to move it to another server?

answers.text: To release a license for moving it to another server, navigate to the System Parameters page, select Product License, and then click the "Release License" button. This action allows the license to be transferred to a different server.

qas.question: What parameters are displayed under Licensing Information?

answers.text: The Licensing Information section displays the following parameters: Maximum Concurrent Calls, Current Call Count, Maximum Station Limit, Current Station Count, Maximum Zone Limit, Current Zone Count, and Maximum Intercom Calls. These parameters inform users about the limits and current usage related to calls, stations, zones, and intercom capabilities within the Nyquist system.

qas.question: What format is the Software License expiration date displayed in?

answers.text: The Software License expiration date is displayed in the format dd-mmm-yyyy. This format is applicable only if the system is in demo mode.

qas.question: What happens if your software maintenance has expired?

answers.text: If your software maintenance has expired, your system will not allow software updates. Additionally, you will be limited in functionality, which may impact system performance and security.

qas.question: How can you change the order of selections in the navigation bar?

answers.text: To change the order of selections in the navigation bar, select "System Parameters" from the navigation bar, then choose "Sort Menu" on the System Parameters page. This allows you to rearrange the selections that appear after the Dashboard.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Sort Menu option in System Parameters?

answers.text: The Sort Menu option in System Parameters allows users to change the order of selections that appear after the Dashboard in the navigation bar. This customization enhances user navigation by enabling a personalized arrangement of menu items.

qas.question: What does the Maximum Zone Limit describe?

answers.text: The Maximum Zone Limit describes the maximum number of zones allowed for your licensed Nyquist system, regardless of the type of zones. If you need to increase this limit, you must contact Tech Support.

qas.question: What does the Current Call Count display?

answers.text: The Current Call Count displays the number of open calls currently active in the Nyquist system. This includes telephone calls, pages, tones, alarms, and announcements.

qas.question: What does the Maximum Page Stacking Queues parameter show?

answers.text: The Maximum Page Stacking Queues parameter displays the maximum number of zone queues allowed for your licensed Nyquist system. If you need to increase this limit, you should contact Tech Support.

qas.question: What indicates that you are in demo mode?

answers.text: You are in demo mode if the software license expiration date field is displayed in the Product License page. This date is shown in the dd-mmm-yyyy format and only appears when the system is operating in demo mode.

qas.question: How can you check for changes made to the license?

answers.text: To check for changes made to the license, select the "Update License" button on the Product License page. This action prompts the Nyquist system server to verify and reflect any updates such as alterations to the maximum station count or maximum concurrent calls.

qas.question: What is the effect of entering an invalid activation key?

answers.text: Entering an invalid activation key will prevent the Nyquist system from being properly configured, and the system may restrict functionality, allowing only the addition of a single station. Additionally, the license features such as maximum concurrent calls and stations will not be accessible until a valid key is provided.

2.1.5
Restarting the Server
Restarting the server should take less than a minute and is provided 
as a troubleshooting tool to use if the Nyquist system is not function-
ing. For example, if you are unable to page or make calls, you proba-
bly want to restart the server.
To restart the server:
Step 1
From the navigation bar, select System Parameters.
Step 2
From the System Parameters page, select Restart 
Server and select one of the three options:
•Graceful – System will restart after all current calls are 
completed.
•Now – All current calls will be dropped.
•Force – Use only if Graceful and Now do not work. 
The Force option will resolve more issues than the 
Graceful and Now options, including issues involv-
ing Recorded Paging (Queues), Routines, and Audio 
Distribution. This option will cause any running Rou-
tines to be terminated and will then start all routines 
that include a Reboot trigger.

qas.question: How do you enter a product license activation key in the system?

answers.text: To enter a product license activation key, select "System Parameters" from the navigation bar, then choose "Product License" on the System Parameters page. Type the activation key number and select the "Activate License" button before clicking "Done."

qas.question: What options do you have for changing the navigation bar order?

answers.text: To change the navigation bar order, select "System Parameters" from the navigation bar, then choose "Sort Menu" to drag and drop menu items into your preferred order. To reset to the default settings, select "Reset Menu" in the same section. After making changes, select "Done" to save your preferences.

qas.question: What does the "Queue Count" display in the licensing information?

answers.text: The "Queue Count" displays the number of queues created for the system. This information helps users understand the current capacity and usage of the system's queuing features.

qas.question: When does the "Activate License" button become active?

answers.text: The "Activate License" button becomes active only when data is entered into the Activation Key field. Users must ensure that the activation key number is typed in before the button can be selected.

qas.question: How can you update the license in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To update the license in the Nyquist system, navigate to the System Parameters page and select Product License. Then, click the "Update License" button to have the Nyquist server check for any changes made to the license and update the system accordingly.

qas.question: What does selecting the "Release License" button do?

answers.text: Selecting the "Release License" button allows you to release the license from the current server, making it available to be moved to another server. This action is useful when transferring licenses between systems.

qas.question: What steps are involved in changing the menu order in the System Parameters?

answers.text: To change the menu order in the System Parameters, select System Parameters from the navigation bar, then choose Sort Menu. Drag and drop the menu items to your preferred order and select Done to save the changes.

qas.question: How do you reset the menu order to default settings?

answers.text: To reset the menu order to default settings, select System Parameters from the navigation bar, then choose Sort Menu and select Reset Menu. Finally, click Done to confirm the reset.

qas.question: What are the three options available for restarting the server?

answers.text: The three options available for restarting the server are: **Graceful** (restarts after current calls are completed), **Now** (immediately drops all current calls), and **Force** (used as a last resort if the other options fail, terminating running routines and rebooting the system).

qas.question: What consequences does selecting the "Force" option when restarting the server have?

answers.text: Selecting the "Force" option when restarting the server will terminate all running routines and active calls immediately, potentially leading to disruption in services such as Recorded Paging, Routines, and Audio Distribution. This option is recommended only when the Graceful and Now options do not resolve issues.

qas.question: What can you set up to receive alert notifications for devices going offline?

answers.text: You can set up parameters for alert notifications when a device or station goes offline by configuring email notifications and specifying the storage location for the records of these events. This allows for timely updates regarding the status of devices in the system.

qas.question: What is the process to reset the menu order to default settings in the system parameters?

answers.text: To reset the menu order to default settings, go to the System Parameters page from the navigation bar, select Sort Menu, and then choose Reset Menu. Finally, select Done to apply the changes.

qas.question: How can a user choose to restart the server in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To restart the server in the Nyquist system, navigate to System Parameters and select "Restart Server." Choose one of the three options: Graceful, Now, or Force, depending on the urgency and nature of the restart needed.

qas.question: What does the Graceful restart option do when restarting the server?

answers.text: The Graceful restart option allows the system to restart after all current calls are completed, ensuring that active sessions are not abruptly dropped. This option is preferable for maintaining call integrity during the restart process.

qas.question: What should be done if both the Graceful and Now restart options fail?

answers.text: If both the Graceful and Now restart options fail, you should use the Force option to restart the server. This option will resolve more issues, including those related to Recorded Paging, Routines, and Audio Distribution, but it will terminate any running routines.

qas.question: How can users set up alert notifications for when a device goes offline?

answers.text: Users can set up alert notifications for when a device goes offline by configuring parameters in the Station Supervision settings. This allows users to specify email notification settings, determine where records are stored, and select the type of alerts they wish to receive.

qas.question: What happens to all current calls during a server restart using the Now option?

answers.text: When a server restart is initiated using the Now option, all current calls will be dropped immediately. This option does not allow for ongoing calls to complete before the restart.

qas.question: What routine actions are triggered when using the Force restart option?

answers.text: Using the Force restart option will terminate any running routines and subsequently start all routines that include a Reboot trigger. This option is recommended when Graceful and Now options fail to resolve issues, particularly those related to Recorded Paging (Queues), Routines, and Audio Distribution.

qas.question: What are the steps to rearrange menu items in the system?

answers.text: To rearrange menu items in the system, select System Parameters from the navigation bar, then choose Sort Menu and drag and drop the menu items into your preferred order. Finally, select Done to save your changes.

qas.question: How can you reset the menu order to default settings?

answers.text: To reset the menu order to default settings, select System Parameters from the navigation bar, then choose Sort Menu and select Reset Menu. Finally, click Done to confirm the reset.

qas.question: What are the available options for restarting the server?

answers.text: The available options for restarting the server are: **Graceful**, which restarts the system after completing all current calls; **Now**, which drops all current calls for an immediate restart; and **Force**, which should only be used if the other options fail, and it will terminate running routines and restart those with a Reboot trigger.

qas.question: What steps should you follow to set up station supervision parameters?

answers.text: To set up station supervision parameters, select System Parameters from the navigation bar, then choose Station Supervision from the System Parameters page. From the Edit Station Supervision page, select your desired options and configurations, then click Save to apply the changes.

qas.question: What default setting is associated with the station supervision feature?

answers.text: The default setting for the station supervision feature is disabled. This means that alert notifications for offline devices are not activated unless the user enables the feature.

qas.question: How can you enable recording alerts in the syslog file?

answers.text: To enable recording alerts in the syslog file, navigate to System Parameters and select Station Supervision. On the Edit Station Supervision page, use the slider for "Syslog Enable" to select Yes, allowing alerts to be recorded in the syslog file.

qas.question: What configurations can you specify for email notifications in station supervision?

answers.text: In the station supervision configuration, you can specify email addresses for recipients of notifications when a station goes offline, select whether to use SMTP parameters from a specific file or a configuration list, and define an email subject line for notifications. Additionally, you can enable syslog logging for alerts and choose which types of stations to supervise or exclude from supervision.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the SMTP account in email configuration?

answers.text: The SMTP account in email configuration is used to specify the email account that will send alert notifications when a station is not responding to the server. This allows automated emails, such as notifications of offline devices, to be sent to designated recipients, ensuring timely alerts to facilities management or IT personnel.

qas.question: How can you select which types of stations to supervise?

answers.text: To select which types of stations to supervise, navigate to the System Parameters page and choose Station Supervision. From the Edit Station Supervision page, you can select the desired station types under the "Supervise Types" option.

qas.question: What happens if the "Excluded Stations" option is left blank in station supervision settings?

answers.text: If the "Excluded Stations" option is left blank in the station supervision settings, no stations with the selected Supervise Type are excluded from supervision. This means that all stations of the chosen type will be monitored for online status.

Table 2-5,  Edit Email Configuration
Account
Enter the user-defined name for this account. The default 
account name is Gmail.
Host
Enter the SMTP server to send the email to. The value may 
be either a host name or a network address.
Port
Enter the port that the SMTP server uses to receive email 
transmissions. Typically, this is set to 25 form SMTP, 465 for 
SMTPS, or 587 for submission.
Auth
Use the slider to enable or disable SMTP authentication. By 
default, Auth is set to On, which is the recommended set-
ting. When authentication is enabled, a user must provide 
a valid username and password to send email. 
User
Enter the user name for SMTP authentication.
Password
Enter the password for SMTP authentication.
Show Saved Password
Select this button to show the saved password for SMTP 
authentication.
From
Enter the name that is to appear in the From field for the 
email.
To
Enter the email addresses for the recipients. Separate each 
email address by a comma.
TLS
Use the slide to enable or disable the use of TLS. When 
you have one email server send a message to another 
email server over TLS, the connection itself is encrypted so 
no one can intercept the payload information. But, the 
actual data itself is still unencrypted. It’s secure and com-
pliant because it was sent over an encrypted channel.

for new versions of the software or set configuration options for 
automatic software downloads.

qas.question: What feature allows configuration of SMTP email notifications for unresponsive stations?

answers.text: The Email Configuration feature allows the setup of SMTP email notifications for when a station is not responding to the server. This configuration includes settings for account details, SMTP server information, authentication, and recipient email addresses.

qas.question: What steps are required to set up email configuration?

answers.text: To set up email configuration, navigate to System Parameters and select Email Configuration. From the Edit Email Configuration page, specify the desired settings such as account name, SMTP server details, authentication information, and recipient email addresses, then select Save.

qas.question: What is the default account name for the email configuration?

answers.text: The default account name for the email configuration is Gmail. This name can be user-defined during the configuration process.

qas.question: What port numbers are typically used for SMTP and SMTPS in email configuration?

answers.text: Typically, port 25 is used for SMTP, while port 465 is used for SMTPS. Additionally, port 587 is commonly used for email submission.

qas.question: What is the purpose of enabling SMTP authentication?

answers.text: Enabling SMTP authentication ensures that a user must provide valid credentials (username and password) before sending emails, enhancing security by preventing unauthorized access. By default, this setting is On, which is recommended to protect against spam and ensure that only authorized users can send notifications.

qas.question: How can a user view the saved password for SMTP authentication?

answers.text: To view the saved password for SMTP authentication, the user should select the "Show Saved Password" button on the Edit Email Configuration page. This action will display the saved password.

qas.question: What does the TLS setting ensure during email transmission?

answers.text: The TLS setting ensures that the connection between email servers is encrypted during email transmission, preventing unauthorized interception of the payload information. While it secures the channel, the actual data remains unencrypted.

qas.question: What is the significance of the STARTTLS command in email security?

answers.text: The STARTTLS command is an email protocol that enables an email client to request a secure connection by upgrading an existing insecure connection to a secure one. This helps protect email transmissions from being intercepted during transmission, enhancing overall email security.

qas.question: Where is the default location for the CA-Certificate trust file specified in the email configuration?

answers.text: The default location for the CA-Certificate trust file in the email configuration is /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt.

qas.question: What domain information is needed to avoid issues with anti-SPAM programs when initiating SMTP connections?

answers.text: To avoid issues with anti-SPAM programs when initiating SMTP connections, you need to specify the domain of the server that is making the connection. This domain name is used as the fully qualified domain name for the SMTP EHLO command.

qas.question: What must be done after installing a new software release regarding permissions?

answers.text: After installing a new software release, permissions for the features introduced by the release must be set for the roles that will use these features. This ensures proper access and functionality for users.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the STARTTLS command in email communications?

answers.text: STARTTLS is an email protocol command that allows an email client to request the upgrading of an existing insecure connection to a secure one. This enhances the security of email communications by encrypting the data transmitted between the client and the email server.

qas.question: How can you perform a system update on the Nyquist server?

answers.text: To perform a system update on the Nyquist server, navigate to System Parameters and select System Update. Choose "Check for Updates" to see available updates or "Upload" to upload a software file, then select the "Run Update" icon for the desired update file and follow the on-screen instructions until completion.

qas.question: What happens if the Software Maintenance package has expired?

answers.text: If the Software Maintenance package has expired, you will receive a dashboard message indicating that you must contact your Bogen dealer to purchase a maintenance renewal in order to access system updates. This means you will not be able to check for or download any software updates until the renewal is completed.

qas.question: What should you do if a PHP message appears after a system update?

answers.text: If a PHP message appears after a system update, press the refresh key (usually F5) repeatedly until the dashboard message appears. This indicates that the update process has completed successfully and you can check the new software version.

qas.question: Where is the default location for the CA-Certificate trust file?

answers.text: The default location for the CA-Certificate trust file is /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt. This file is used to establish trust for secure connections in email protocols.

qas.question: What does the System Update screen display when first accessed?

answers.text: When first accessed, the System Update screen displays a list of downloaded software, which initially shows only the default file that was installed. Users can then select "Check for Updates" to obtain a list of available software for download.

qas.question: How can you check for new software updates on the Nyquist server?

answers.text: To check for new software updates on the Nyquist server, navigate to the System Parameters page and select System Update. Then, click on "Check for Updates" to see if any new software updates are available for download.

qas.question: What should you avoid doing while the system update is running?

answers.text: While the system update is running, you should avoid closing the window or clicking anything on the computer screen to ensure the update completes successfully. Additionally, be aware that volume control levels will revert to factory defaults during the update process.

qas.question: What confirmation message appears after a successful system update?

answers.text: After a successful system update, a message appears indicating that the update has completed, along with an OK button to acknowledge the update. Additionally, the Nyquist dashboard provides a confirmation message that includes the date and time the update ran, along with the software version that was installed.

qas.question: How do you configure automatic software downloads on the Nyquist server?

answers.text: To configure automatic software downloads on the Nyquist server, access the Configure Automatic Software Download screen and set the schedule for the server to automatically check for and download updates for server or firmware software. Make sure to save your configuration settings after setting the schedule.

stop Nyquist processes and power down the Nyquist server. Power-
ing down the Nyquist server manually via the Power button the

From the navigation bar, select System Parameters.

2.1.11
Check Internet Site Access
You can use the Check Internet Site Access button to verify that you
Nyquist server can access URLs, commonly referred to as web
addresses, that are required for Nyquist to run properly. This infor-
mation can be used for resolving or debugging networking issues.
Note: If you are using the System Controller, the Shutdown Server 
button powers the component down but does not toggle the 
Power switch. To turn the System Controller back on, you must tog-
gle the switch to the Off position and then toggle it to the On 
position.

qas.question: What options can be configured under the Automatic Software Download settings?

answers.text: Under the Automatic Software Download settings, you can configure options for server software and firmware checks and auto downloads, specify recurrence settings for when automatic checks and downloads occur (minute, hour, day of the month, month, and day of the week). Each option can be set to Yes or No to enable or disable automatic actions.

qas.question: How do you access the Configure Automatic Software Download screen?

answers.text: To access the Configure Automatic Software Download screen, select System Parameters from the navigation bar, then choose System Update. Alternatively, you can select Firmware from the navigation bar.

qas.question: What is the recommended method for shutting down the Nyquist server?

answers.text: The recommended method for shutting down the Nyquist server is to use the Shut Down button, as it gracefully stops Nyquist processes. Manually powering down the server via the Power button is not advised.

qas.question: How can you verify if the Nyquist server has internet site access?

answers.text: To verify if the Nyquist server has internet site access, use the Check Internet Site Access button. This will allow you to confirm that the server can access the required URLs for proper operation and help troubleshoot any networking issues.

qas.question: What happens if you leave the Recurrence Day field blank in the automatic software download settings?

answers.text: If you leave the Recurrence Day field blank in the automatic software download settings, the setting defaults to automatic checks and downloads occurring every day of the month. This ensures that the server continuously checks for updates daily.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Server Software Check option?

answers.text: The Server Software Check option, when set to Yes, allows the Nyquist server to automatically check for software updates and post notifications to the dashboard when new updates are available. This ensures that the server remains up-to-date with the latest software enhancements and security patches.

qas.question: What should you do when prompted after selecting the Shut Down option from the System Parameters page?

answers.text: When prompted after selecting the Shut Down option from the System Parameters page, you should select Continue to proceed with shutting down the Nyquist server. This ensures that Nyquist processes are gracefully stopped before powering down.

qas.question: What does the Firmware Auto Download option do when set to Yes?

answers.text: When the Firmware Auto Download option is set to Yes, the Nyquist server automatically downloads firmware updates for Nyquist devices and posts notifications to the dashboard whenever new firmware is available. This ensures that the server remains updated without manual intervention.

qas.question: What is the effect of using the Power button to shut down the Nyquist server?

answers.text: Using the Power button to shut down the Nyquist server is not recommended as it may not gracefully stop Nyquist processes, potentially leading to data loss or system instability. The recommended method is to use the Shut Down button from the System Parameters menu to ensure proper shutdown procedures are followed.

qas.question: How do you manually toggle the power switch on the System Controller after shutdown?

answers.text: To manually toggle the power switch on the System Controller after shutdown, locate the power switch on the device and first switch it to the Off position. Then, after a brief moment, toggle it back to the On position to power it back up.

qas.question: How can you check Internet site access from the Nyquist server?

qas.question: What is the first step in checking the server status on the Android device?

qas.question: How can a user access the Edit System Parameters page?

answers.text: A user can access the Edit System Parameters page by selecting "System Parameters" from the navigation bar. Once on the System Parameters page, the user should click the Edit icon to make changes to the settings.

qas.question: What is the maximum number of characters allowed for naming the facility?

answers.text: The maximum number of characters allowed for naming the facility is 30 characters.

qas.question: What time range is valid for the Day Start parameter?

answers.text: The valid time range for the Day Start parameter is from 00:00 to 23:58. However, it must be less than the Night Start time.

qas.question: What happens to telephones with night-only outside line access during the day mode?

answers.text: During the day mode, telephones with night-only outside line access are prevented from placing outside line calls. The system restricts their functionality to ensure that they can only access outside lines during designated night hours.

qas.question: Where can system parameters for the entire facility be found?

answers.text: System parameters for the entire facility can be found on the System Parameters page, accessed from the navigation bar. The parameters can be modified by selecting the Edit icon on this page.

qas.question: What is the function of the Save button on the Edit System Parameters page?

answers.text: The Save button on the Edit System Parameters page is used to apply and store any changes made to the system parameters. Once selected, it ensures that the updates to settings are saved and will take effect in the facility's operations.

qas.question: How does one exit the Check Server Status display after viewing it?

answers.text: To exit the Check Server Status display after viewing it, simply select the "Close" option. This will return you to the previous page.

qas.question: What two types of settings can be adjusted on the Edit System Parameters page?

answers.text: On the Edit System Parameters page, users can adjust the facility name (up to 30 characters) and the timing settings for the system’s "Day" mode of operation, which includes specifying the Day Start time. These settings help define the operational status and access restrictions for telephones during designated periods.
