operation and specifies the time period for which the day 
Admin Station is active. Telephones with night-only outside 
line access are prevented from placing outside line calls 
during this time. Use the down arrows to select the Hour 
and Minute values. Valid times range from 00:00 to 23:58, 
but must be less than the Night Start time.
55
Night Start
Identifies when the system switches to its “Night” mode of 
operation and specifies the time period for which the night 
Admin Station is active. During this time, telephones with 
the night-only outside line access can place outside line 
calls. Use the down arrows to select the Hour and Minute 
values. Valid times range from 00:01 to 23:59; but must be 
larger than the Day Start time.
Emergency-All-Call 
Multicast RTP IP 
Address
Identifies the IP address to use for multicast RTP paging for 
Emergency-All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have 
this IP address configured.
Emergency-All-Call 
Multicast RTP Port
Identifies the RTP port to use for multicast RTP paging for 
Emergency-All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have 
this RTP port configured.
Emergency-All-Call Cut 
Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for Emergency-All-Call audio. The cut 
volume range is 0 to -42.
All-Call Multicast RTP 
IP Address
Identifies the All-Call Multicast RTP IP address. Receiving IP 
telephones must also have this IP address configured. 
All-Call Multicast RTP 
Port
Identifies the RTP port to use for multicast RTP paging for 
All-Call. Receiving IP telephones must also have this RTP 
port configured.
All-Call Cut Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for All-Call audio. The cut volume 
range is 0 to -42.
Audio Distribution 
Multicast IP Address
Identifies the RPT multicast IP address to use for audio dis-
tribution to all stations
Audio Distribution 
Multicast Port
Identifies the RPT multicast port to use for audio distribu-
tion to all stations.
Audio Distribution Cut 
Level (dB)
Sets the cut volume for audio distribution. The cut volume 
range is 0 to -42.
Default Cut Level (dB)
Defines the default cut volume level for a new zone. The cut 
volume range is 0 to -42. 
Ambient Noise Sensor 
Multicast IP Address
Identifies the multicast IP address to use by ambient noise 
senors to send volume data.
Ambient Noise Sensor 
Multicast Port
Identifies the multicast port number to be used by ambient 
noise senors to send volume data.
Table 2-7,  Edit System Parameters Page (Continued)
56
Disable Preannounce 
Tone
Indicates if the preannounce tone is disabled. If disabled, 
the tone is not heard when connecting to a speaker or prior 
to a page.
Privacy Beep
Indicates if the privacy beep feature is on.
Emergency Tone
Identifies the pre-announce tone played before an Emer-
gency-All-Call is made.
All Call Tone
Identifies the pre-announce tone played before an All-Call 
is made.
Intercom Tone
Identifies the pre-announce tone played before an inter-
com call is made.
Default Registration 
Password
Provides the default password to be used when adding a 
new station.
Default Codecs 
Allowed
Provides the default list of media codecs to be used.
Admin Queue Timeout
Specifies the maximum amount of minutes that a call 
switch or handset station can remain on an administrative 
queue. When the time is exceeded, the call switch or hand-
set station is removed from the queue. Valid timeout values 
range from 1 to 999.
Night Ring Enabled
Indicates if a night ring is enabled. When enabled, you can 
optionally set a Night Ring Admin and optionally set one 
additional option from the following list:
• Night Ring All Stations
• Night Ring Admin Group
• Night Ring Zones
(For more information on night ring behavior, see "Setting 
Night Call Options” on page 31.)
Table 2-7,  Edit System Parameters Page (Continued)
57
Night Ring Admin
Identifies the specific Admin Station that handles outside 
line calls received during night hours. Outside line calls not 
answered with 15 seconds trigger ringing to all or selected 
stations. If Night Ring Admin is the only option set, then 
the specified Admin extension rings for 30 minutes and 
hangs up if the call is not answered within that time. 
Note: If Night Admin is also included in the call, both 
Night Admin and Night Ring Admin ring. An analog 
phone cannot be used as a Night Ring Admin even if the 
station has the admin CoS enabled.
Night Ring All Stations
Indicates if all stations receive night rings during night 
hours. When enabled, any ringing station can answer the 
call. The specified stations will ring for up to 30 minutes, 
then hang up if the call is not answered within that time.
Note: NQ-P0100 Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp stations will also 
ring.
Night Ring Admin 
Group
Identifies the Admin Group that handles outside line calls 
received during night hours. The Admin Group is called if 
the Night Admin and Night Ring Admin do not answer 
within 15 seconds. The specified stations will ring for up to 
30 minutes, then hang up if the call is not answered within 
that time.
Night Ring Zones
Identifies which zones receive night rings when outside 
calls are received during night hours. The specified stations 
will ring for up to 30 minutes, then hang up if the call is not 
answered within that time.
Parking Lot
Defines the range of numbers to use for call parking. The 
first number listed is used to initiate call parking, which is a 
feature that allows you to put a call on hold at one tele-
phone set and continue the conversation from any other 
telephone set.
Record Monitoring
Indicates if call and location monitoring will be recorded.
Table 2-7,  Edit System Parameters Page (Continued)
58
Emergency Link
Specifies the station that functions as the system’s Emer-
gency Link Station. An Emergency Link Station is the station 
that an emergency call (but not a 911 call) is routed to if the 
station’s associated Admin Station is busy, rejects the call, 
or fails to answer within 15 seconds. A value of 999 means 
that this feature is disabled.
If the Emergency Link Station is a ringable device (a Nyquist 
phone), the station will ring and the call will be displayed 
on the station’s display (if so equipped) as an “Emergency 
Call.” If the Emergency Link Station is not a ringable device 
(a Nyquist VoIP speaker), the station will auto-answer, pre-
announcing the call as an “Emergency.” The Admin Station 
will continue to ring if an emergency call is auto-answered 
by a non-ringable Emergency Link Station device. The 
Admin Station can retrieve the call by answering it, and the 
Emergency Link Station device will then drop the call. As 
with any Emergency Call, all calls to an Emergency Link Sta-
tion will be recorded.
Max Restricted Digits
Specifies the maximum number of digits that can be dialed 
if a station has been assigned restricted outside line access.
DISA Password
Identifies the four-digit field used for Direct Inward Station 
Access (DISA). 
Security DISA Pass-
word
Identifies the four-digit field used to access Nyquist 
through a security DISA line. 
CDR Storage Duration
Identifies the number of days that a record of call details 
will be kept.
Trunk Priority
Identifies the first trunk type to use for placing outbound 
calls.
Bump on Emergency
Indicates if emergency calls to the Admin Station will bump 
existing non-emergency calls.
Bump on 911
Indicates if outbound calls to 911 will bump trunk calls if no 
available outbound trunk is available.
Auth Code
Allows you to enable additional features on a telephone 
when the walking CoS feature is enabled. The four-digit 
code activates features from the associated phone to the 
phone being used. 
Table 2-7,  Edit System Parameters Page (Continued)
59
Call Assurance Audio
Identifies the audio to be played to the caller to indicate 
that the call has been placed. To choose a new file, select 
Choose File and browse to select the new file to be used 
for the Call Assurance audio.
Facility Password
Identifies the password to be used by facility servers that 
are registering with this server. The maximum password size 
is 12 characters.
Remote Facility CoS
Identifies the CoS for remote facility access.
RTP Start Port
Identifies the start port number for UDP RTP traffic. The 
default is 10000.
RTP End Port
Identifies the stop port number for UDP RTP traffic. The 
default is 20000.
Enable RTP Checksums
Indicates if UDP checksums are enabled for RTP traffic. A 
checksum is a count of the number of bits in a transmission 
that is included with the transmission so that the receiver 
can check to see if the same number of bits arrived.
Enable ICE Support
Indicates if ICE support is enabled.
STUN Server
Identifies the host name or IP address for the STUN server 
that is used when determining the external IP address and 
port for a RTP session. (Port number is optional.) If omitted, 
the default value of 3478 will be used.
TURN Server
Identifies the host name or IP address for the TURN server 
that is to be used as a relay. (Port number is optional.) If 
omitted, the default value of 3478 will be used.
TURN Username
Identifies the user name used to authenticate with the 
TURN server.
TURN Password
Identifies the password used to authenticate with the TURN 
server.
Retention Recordings
Identifies the number of days to retain recordings. Record-
ings that are older than the retention period are automati-
cally deleted. You can set a maximum retention period of 
99,999 days.
Backup Retention 
System
Identifies the number of days to retain system backup files. 
System backups that are older than the retention period are 
automatically deleted, provided at least one system backup 
file remains. You can set a maximum retention period of 
99,999 days.
Table 2-7,  Edit System Parameters Page (Continued)
60
Backup Retention 
Recordings
Identifies the number of days that backups of recordings 
are retained. Backups that are older than the retention 
period are automatically deleted, provided at least one 
backup remains. You can set a maximum retention period 
of 99,999 days.
Backup Retention 
Voicemail
Identifies the number of days that voicemail backups are 
retailed. Backups that are older than the retention period 
are automatically deleted, provided at least one backup 
remains. You can set a maximum retention period of 99,999 
days.
System Password
Displays the password required if a user attempts to change 
an event schedule.
Multi-Site-Emergency-
All-Call Password
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required 
to enter a password when starting a Multi-Site-Emergency-
All-Call page. A four zero password (0000) requires the 
caller to enter 1 for confirmation when starting a Multi-
Site-Emergency-All-Call page. 
Multi-Site-All-Call 
Password
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required 
to enter a password when starting a Multi-Site-All-Call 
page. A four zero password (0000) requires the caller to 
enter 1 for confirmation when starting a Multi-Site-All-Call 
page.
Facility-Page Password
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required 
to enter a password when starting a Facility page. A four 
zero password (0000) requires the caller to enter 1 for con-
firmation when starting a Facility page.
Emergency-All-Call 
Password
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required 
to enter a password when starting an Emergency-All-Call 
page. A four zero password (0000) requires the caller to 
enter 1 for confirmation when starting an Emergency-All-
Call page.
All-Call Password 
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required 
to enter a password when starting an All-Call page. A four 
zero password (0000) requires the caller to enter 1 for con-
firmation when starting an All-Call page.
Table 2-7,  Edit System Parameters Page (Continued)
61
The Edit System Parameters page also contains a section called Sys-
tems Tools. The following table describes parameters for this section:
Emergency-Announce-
ment Password
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required 
to enter a password when starting or stopping an Emer-
gency Announcement. A four zero password (0000) 
requires the caller to enter 1 for confirmation when starting

Announcement Pass-
word
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required

an Announcement.
Zone-Page Password
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required

Alarm Password
Identifies the 4-digit password to use if a caller is required

Tone Password

Table 2-7,  Edit System Parameters Page (Continued)
Table 2-8,  System Tools
Server IP Address
Identifies the Nyquist system server’s IP address, which will 
be used by Nyquist devices to register with the Nyquist sys-
tem server. To change the Server IP Address, select Change

Use Network Time 
Server defined by 
DHCP
When enabled, the Network Time Server will be defined by

62
Network Time Server
Identifies the IP address or the domain name of the NTP

To change the NTP server, enter the IP address or the

Server.
Appliances Network 
Time Server Source
Identifies the time source for all appliances on the Nyquist

• nyquist
When this option is selected, all Nyquist appliances will

63
2.2
Using CoS Configuration
CoS configuration allows the setting of parameters for outgoing call 
privileges, extensions, and outside lines. You can configure and 
assign an unlimited number of CoS definitions. Once created, a CoS 
can be assigned to a station as a Day CoS and a Night CoS. (See "Edit-
ing Station Configuration Settings” on page 118.) Note that an analog 
phone cannot be used as a day or night admin.

Specifies the number of digits required to dial within the 
system. Valid values are 3, 4, 5, or 6.

You must reboot all Nyquist appliances and IP phones. A

qas.question: What is the maximum number of characters allowed for the facility name in the Edit System Parameters page?

answers.text: The maximum number of characters allowed for the facility name in the Edit System Parameters page is 30 characters.

qas.question: How does the Day Start and Night Start time impact outside line access for telephones?

answers.text: The Day Start time determines when the system enters "Day" mode, during which telephones with night-only outside line access cannot make outside line calls. Conversely, the Night Start time initiates "Night" mode, allowing those telephones to place outside line calls. The Night Start time must be set later than the Day Start time.

qas.question: What is the valid range for the Emergency-All-Call Cut Level (dB)?

answers.text: The valid range for the Emergency-All-Call Cut Level (dB) is from 0 to -42 dB. This parameter sets the cut volume for Emergency-All-Call audio.

qas.question: How can you disable the preannounce tone in the system parameters?

answers.text: To disable the preannounce tone in the system parameters, locate the "Disable Preannounce Tone" setting on the Edit System Parameters page and select it to disable the tone. When disabled, users will not hear the tone when connecting to a speaker or prior to a page.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Emergency Link Station in the context of emergency calls?

answers.text: The Emergency Link Station functions as the designated recipient for emergency calls when the associated Admin Station is busy, rejects the call, or fails to answer within 15 seconds. If it is a ringable device, it will ring; if not, it will auto-answer and announce the call as "Emergency," allowing the Admin Station to retrieve the call.

qas.question: What security feature can be enabled with the Auth Code?

answers.text: The Auth Code allows you to enable additional features on a telephone when the walking CoS (Class of Service) feature is activated. It requires a four-digit code to activate features from the associated phone to the phone being used.

qas.question: How long are recordings retained according to the Retention Recordings parameter?

answers.text: Recordings are retained for a specified number of days, with the retention period set by the user. The maximum retention period for recordings can be up to 99,999 days.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Emergency-All-Call Password?

answers.text: The Emergency-All-Call Password is a 4-digit password required for initiating an Emergency-All-Call page. If the password is set to 0000, confirmation is needed by entering 1 to start the page, enhancing security and preventing unauthorized use of the emergency communication feature.

qas.question: How do you change the Server Date/Time in the System Tools section?

answers.text: To change the Server Date/Time in the System Tools section, use the Calendar icon to select the new date and then select "Change Server Date/Time." This action updates the server's date and time settings accordingly.

qas.question: What happens if the Night Ring Admin does not answer an outside line call within 15 seconds?

answers.text: If the Night Ring Admin does not answer an outside line call within 15 seconds, the call will trigger ringing to all specified stations or to the Admin Group if set. If the call remains unanswered for 30 minutes, it will automatically hang up.

qas.question: What defines the range of numbers used for call parking in the system?

answers.text: The range of numbers used for call parking in the system is defined by a specified first number that initiates the call parking feature, allowing a call to be placed on hold at one telephone set and continued from any other telephone set.

qas.question: How is the default cut volume for a new zone determined in the system parameters?

answers.text: The default cut volume for a new zone is defined by the "Default Cut Level (dB)" parameter in the system parameters, which allows for a cut volume range between 0 to -42 dB. This setting determines the audio level for new zones created within the system.

qas.question: What is indicated by enabling RTP Checksums for RTP traffic?

answers.text: Enabling RTP Checksums for RTP traffic indicates that a checksum will be included with the transmission. This checksum allows the receiving party to verify that the same number of bits arrived correctly, helping to ensure the integrity of the data being transmitted.

qas.question: What time source do all Nyquist appliances use when 'nyquist' is selected?

answers.text: When 'nyquist' is selected as the time source, all Nyquist appliances will use the Nyquist system server as the NTP server. This is the default option for time synchronization across the appliances.

qas.question: How many digits are configurable for dialing length in the CoS configuration?

answers.text: In the CoS configuration, the dialing length is configurable for 3, 4, 5, or 6 digits. These are the valid values that can be set for dialing within the system.

qas.question: What happens to a call if Bump on Emergency is enabled?

answers.text: If Bump on Emergency is enabled, any emergency calls to the Admin Station will interrupt and disconnect existing non-emergency calls. This ensures that emergency communications have priority over regular calls.

The following table describes the CoS Parameters:
Table 2-9,  CoS Configuration Page Parameters
Name
User provided name for the CoS.
Call in Level
For call switch and handset station types, identifies the call 
as Normal+Emergency, Urgent+Emergency, Emergency 
only, or Normal only. The system defaults to Normal+Emer-
gency. Call in Levels are described as:
• Normal+Emergency. Initiates a normal or emergency-
level call. Pressing the call switch once or picking up the 
handset, triggers a normal-level call to the administrative 
phone. Pressing the call switch or flash hook four times, 
triggers an emergency-level call to the administrative 
phone.
• Urgent+Emergency. Initiates an urgent or emergency-
level call. Pressing the call switch or picking up the hand-
set, triggers an urgent-level call to the administrative 
phone. Pressing the call switch or flash hook four times, 
triggers an emergency-level call to the administrative 
phone.
• Emergency Only. Initiates an emergency level call by 
pressing the call switch one time or lifting the handset. 
Zone Paging 
Specifies if Zone Paging is enabled for the associated sta-
tion.
All-Call Paging
Specifies if the associated station can simultaneously page 
all speakers within the facility.
Emergency All-Call
Specifies if the associated station can place a top priority 
all-call page.
Inter-Facility Call/Page
Specifies if the associated station can call or page another 
facility.
Audio Distribution
Specifies if the associated station can use an audio source, 
such as a flash drive.
Remote Pickup
Specifies if the associated station can be answered 
remotely.
65
Join Conversation
Enables the caller to interrupt or join an existing call. If a call 
is placed to a busy station, the system waits 10 seconds and 
then bumps or interrupts the call with the new caller, or the 
caller can dial an access string to join the existing call. This 
feature applies to administrative display phones only.
Call Forwarding
Permits a user to redirect or route incoming calls to another 
station.
Walking Class of Ser-
vice
Enables the manual override of telephone restrictions.
External Call Routing
Enables the station to transfer a call to an outside line.
Call Transfer/3-way 
Calling
Allows the associated station user to contact a third-party 
while on a call, establish a three-way conversation and then 
drop off allowing the two other parties to remain con-
nected.
Manually Activate 
Tone Signals
Enables a user to initiate tones outside of the schedule.
Call Any Station
Enables a station to call any station.
Manage Recordings
Allows the station user to manage recordings, such as 
emergency call recordings.
Monitor Calls
Allows the station user to monitor active calls.
Monitor Locations
Allows the station user to monitor locations (not active 
calls).
Conference Admin
Allows the station user to join a conference as an adminis-
trator.
Conference User
Allows the station user to join a conference as a user.
Voicemail
Allows the station user to receive voicemail.
Record Calls
Allows the station user to begin recording an active call by 
pressing *3 any time during the call. This option is for use 
with admin phones when a Normal, Urgent, or Emergency 
intercom call is being made.
Activate Alarm Signals
Allows the station to activate alarms.
Disable Audio
Allows a station with contact closure to disable audio 
during a fire alarm or other emergency.

2.2.1
Editing CoS Parameters for a Station
To edit CoS Parameters for a station:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select CoS Configuration.
Step 2
For the station that you want to edit CoS settings, 
select the Edit icon.
Step 3
Make the desired changes. You can use the All On but-
ton to turn all features on or the All Off button to turn 
all features off. For information about the settings, see 
"CoS Configuration Page Parameters” on page 64. 
Step 4
After all changes are made, select Save.
2.2.2
Deleting CoS Parameters for a Station
To delete CoS Parameters for a station:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select CoS Configuration.
Step 2
For the station that you want to delete CoS settings, 
select the Delete icon.
Step 3
When prompted, select Delete.
Enable Audio
Allows enabling of audio previously disabled during an 
emergency event.
Allow Callee Auto-
answer
Allows call auto-answer by the callee for calls placed by this 
station.
Multi-Site Paging
Allows station to perform multiple site paging.
Inter-Facility Features
Allows the station to call extensions on remote facilities for 
voice mail and access to recorded calls and to stop audio. 
Manage Output Con-
tacts
Allows the station to activate or reset output contacts on 
I/O Controllers. For more information about managing out-
put contacts, see "Configuring I/O Controller Output Rules” 
on page 130.
Execute Routines
Allows the station to execute routines via DTMF codes. For 
more information about managing routines, see "Using 
Routines” on page 381.

qas.question: What does CoS configuration allow you to set for outgoing calls?

answers.text: CoS (Class of Service) configuration allows you to set parameters for outgoing call privileges, including extensions and outside lines. You can assign multiple CoS definitions to stations, designating specific features such as call forwarding, call transfer, and audio distribution for both Day and Night settings.

qas.question: How many CoS definitions can you configure and assign?

answers.text: You can configure and assign an unlimited number of CoS definitions. Each CoS definition can be assigned to a station as both a Day CoS and a Night CoS.

qas.question: What types of phones cannot be used as a day or night admin?

answers.text: Analog phones cannot be used as a day or night admin. Only IP phones or other compatible digital devices can serve in this administrative capacity.

qas.question: What are the valid values for dialing length in the system?

answers.text: Valid values for dialing length in the system are 3, 4, 5, or 6 digits. Users can select a new value from the drop-down menu to change the dialing length.

qas.question: What happens when you change the dialing length?

answers.text: Changing the dialing length specifies the number of digits required to dial within the system, with valid values being 3, 4, 5, or 6 digits. After adjusting the dialing length, all Nyquist appliances and IP phones must be rebooted, and a system backup is automatically created.

qas.question: What is displayed by the Teamviewer ID?

answers.text: The Teamviewer ID displays the unique remote control ID number assigned to the Nyquist server. This ID is used for remote manipulation and troubleshooting via the Teamviewer application.

qas.question: How does enabling Teamviewer affect remote control of the Nyquist server?

answers.text: Enabling Teamviewer allows the Nyquist server to be remotely controlled and troubleshot using Teamviewer software. This facilitates remote management by allowing users to access and manipulate the Nyquist server settings and resolve issues from a distance.

qas.question: What characters are allowed when setting a new Teamviewer password?

answers.text: Only alphanumeric characters are allowed when setting a new Teamviewer password for the Nyquist server.

qas.question: What are the available call in levels for the CoS?

answers.text: The available call in levels for the CoS are: Normal+Emergency, Urgent+Emergency, Emergency Only, and Normal only. Each level triggers different call types based on the actions taken by the user, such as pressing a call switch or lifting the handset. The default level is Normal+Emergency.

qas.question: How does the Emergency Only call in level function?

answers.text: The Emergency Only call in level allows the user to initiate an emergency-level call by pressing the call switch once or lifting the handset. This setting ensures that only emergency calls can be made from the station, enhancing response capabilities during critical situations.

qas.question: What does enabling Zone Paging do for a station?

answers.text: Enabling Zone Paging for a station allows it to send announcements or alerts to specific areas within the facility, targeting only designated zones instead of broadcasting to all areas. This feature is useful for making targeted communications without disturbing other zones.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the All-Call Paging feature?

answers.text: The All-Call Paging feature allows the associated station to simultaneously page all speakers within the facility. This enables efficient communication to all locations, ensuring important announcements or alerts are disseminated promptly.

qas.question: What does the Remote Pickup feature allow a user to do?

answers.text: The Remote Pickup feature allows a user to answer a call at their station remotely, enabling them to pick up an incoming call that is ringing on another station. This feature is useful for increased accessibility and responsiveness in a shared office environment.

qas.question: How can you allow a caller to join an existing call?

answers.text: To allow a caller to join an existing call, enable the "Join Conversation" feature for the associated station. This allows the system to wait 10 seconds and then bump or interrupt the call with the new caller, or the caller can dial an access string to join the ongoing conversation.

qas.question: What function does Call Forwarding serve for a user?

answers.text: Call Forwarding allows a user to redirect or route incoming calls to another station. This feature ensures that calls can still be received by the user even when they are unavailable at their primary station.

qas.question: How can a user manually activate tone signals?

answers.text: A user can manually activate tone signals by enabling the feature in the CoS configuration settings for their station. Once activated, they can initiate tones outside of the scheduled times as needed.

qas.question: What privileges does the Manage Recordings option provide?

answers.text: The Manage Recordings option allows the station user to manage recordings, such as emergency call recordings, enabling them to oversee and control audio documentation associated with their calls.

qas.question: What action does the Record Calls feature require during a call?

answers.text: The Record Calls feature allows the station user to begin recording an active call by pressing *3 at any time during the call. This option is specifically for use with admin phones when a Normal, Urgent, or Emergency intercom call is being made.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Disable Audio feature during an emergency?

answers.text: The Disable Audio feature during an emergency allows a station with contact closure to mute audio output, preventing distractions or interference during critical situations, such as a fire alarm. This ensures that emergency messages can be communicated clearly without interruptions from background noise.

qas.question: How do you edit CoS Parameters for a station?

answers.text: To edit CoS Parameters for a station, select CoS Configuration on the navigation bar, then click the Edit icon for the desired station. Make your changes and use the All On or All Off buttons as needed, then select Save to apply the changes.

qas.question: What occurs when you delete CoS Parameters for a station?

answers.text: When you delete CoS Parameters for a station, the associated configuration settings for that station will be removed, which can impact its call privileges and functionalities. To perform this action, you must select the Delete icon for the desired station and confirm the deletion when prompted.

qas.question: What does the Allow Callee Auto-answer feature enable?

answers.text: The Allow Callee Auto-answer feature enables a call to automatically answer when placed by the station, allowing the callee to receive incoming calls without needing to manually pick up the phone. This feature is useful for situations requiring immediate communication, such as emergency responses.

qas.question: How does Multi-Site Paging benefit the station?

answers.text: Multi-Site Paging allows the station to perform paging across multiple locations simultaneously, enhancing communication efficiency in larger facilities. This feature ensures that announcements can reach all necessary areas quickly, facilitating coordination and response in urgent situations.

qas.question: What are Inter-Facility Features used for in the station’s configuration?

answers.text: Inter-Facility Features enable a station to call extensions on remote facilities, allowing access to voicemail and recorded calls, as well as the ability to stop audio. This functionality facilitates communication and resource management across different locations within the system.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the "Multi-Site Paging" option in CoS Parameters?

answers.text: The "Multi-Site Paging" option in CoS Parameters allows a station to perform paging across multiple sites. This enables the station to broadcast messages to various locations simultaneously, enhancing communication capabilities within an organization.

qas.question: How do Inter-Facility Features benefit a station?

answers.text: Inter-Facility Features benefit a station by enabling it to call extensions on remote facilities, allowing access to voice mail and recorded calls. This functionality enhances communication across locations and improves operational efficiency.

qas.question: What role does the "Manage Output Contacts" feature play for a station?

answers.text: The "Manage Output Contacts" feature allows a station to activate or reset output contacts on I/O Controllers, enabling control over connected devices or systems. 2.3
Managing SIP Trunks
A SIP trunk is an IP based network connection between Nyquist and 
an Internet Telephony Service Provider (ITSP), which is also known as 
a VoIP telephone service provider. It allows you to use VoIP tele-
phony beyond the facility’s firewall without the need for a Public 
Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), providing a configuration that 
is easier and less expensive to operate and maintain. SIP trunks can 
carry VoIP calls, Enhanced 911, and other real-time communications 
services. 
A SIP Tie-Trunk (or a SIP Tie-Line) functions similarly to a SIP trunk, 
but serves as an IP based inter-connection between Nyquist and a 
local (premises-based) or hosted IP-PBX. For information about using 
SIP Tie-Trunks with Nyquist, refer to "SIP Trunk Custom Configuration 
Settings” on page 75.
Before you can set SIP parameters in Nyquist, you must first set up 
the system's DISA function by creating a station with the Type of 
DISA Line. (See "Adding a Station” on page 153.)
If you will require support from Bogen during the implementation 
process, you must install Teamviewer on the Nyquist system server 
and enable Remote access capabilities in the LAN to allow a remote 
connection to the server. In addition, Wireshark must be installed in 
the Nyquist system server to allow packet inspection during SIP 
implementation and troubleshooting. It is recommended that the 
technician performing the install be skilled with SIP implementation 
and testing. The Firewall setting must allow Port 5060 and Ports 
10000 – 20000 for the RTP traffic. Any other type of SIP connectivity 
could be available via an individual case basis process.

qas.question: What steps are required to edit CoS parameters for a station?

answers.text: To edit CoS parameters for a station, navigate to CoS Configuration, select the Edit icon for the desired station, make the necessary changes (using All On or All Off buttons if applicable), and then select Save to apply the changes.

qas.question: How can you delete CoS parameters for a station?

answers.text: To delete CoS parameters for a station, select CoS Configuration from the navigation bar, click the Delete icon for the desired station, and confirm by selecting Delete when prompted.

qas.question: What functionality does the "Enable Audio" option provide?

answers.text: The "Enable Audio" option allows the reactivation of audio that was previously disabled during an emergency event. This functionality ensures that audio can be restored for communication purposes in critical situations.

qas.question: What is the purpose of SIP trunks in a VoIP system?

answers.text: SIP trunks in a VoIP system provide an IP-based network connection between the VoIP service and an Internet Telephony Service Provider (ITSP), facilitating the transmission of VoIP calls and real-time communications beyond the facility's firewall. They simplify configuration and reduce operating costs by eliminating the need for traditional PSTN connections.

qas.question: How does a SIP Tie-Trunk differ from a standard SIP trunk?

answers.text: A SIP Tie-Trunk, or SIP Tie-Line, functions as an IP-based interconnection specifically between Nyquist and a local (premises-based) or hosted IP-PBX, while a standard SIP trunk connects Nyquist to an Internet Telephony Service Provider (ITSP) for broader VoIP services. Essentially, SIP Tie-Trunks are used for internal communications within a facility or between facilities, whereas standard SIP trunks extend VoIP beyond the local network.

qas.question: What prerequisites must be met before setting SIP parameters in Nyquist?

answers.text: Before setting SIP parameters in Nyquist, you must create a station with the Type of DISA Line. Additionally, ensure that Teamviewer is installed on the Nyquist system server for remote support, and Wireshark is set up for packet inspection. The firewall must also allow Port 5060 and Ports 10000-20000 for RTP traffic.

qas.question: What software tools are recommended for troubleshooting SIP implementation?

answers.text: For troubleshooting SIP implementation, it is recommended to install Wireshark on the Nyquist system server for packet inspection. Additionally, Teamviewer should be enabled for remote access support from Bogen during the implementation process.

qas.question: Which firewall ports need to be open for SIP connectivity?

answers.text: For SIP connectivity, the firewall must allow Port 5060 for SIP signaling and Ports 10000 – 20000 for RTP traffic.

qas.question: What options are available to manage output contacts on I/O Controllers?

answers.text: The options available to manage output contacts on I/O Controllers include activating or resetting the output contacts. For more information, you can refer to the section titled "Configuring I/O Controller Output Rules.”

qas.question: How do you add CoS parameters for a station?

answers.text: To add CoS parameters for a station, select CoS Configuration from the navigation bar, then click the Add icon. Complete the parameters for the station as needed, and finally, select Save after making all changes.

2.3.1
How Nyquist Handles Incoming SIP Calls
When a SIP trunk is enabled and Nyquist receives an incoming call on 
that SIP trunk, Nyquist routes the call based on the Access parameter 
set in the Nyquist SIP trunk’s parameters. The Access parameter is set 
when editing or adding SIP trunk configuration (see "Editing a SIP 
Trunk Configuration” on page 81 and "Adding SIP Trunk Configuration 
Parameters” on page 72) and must match the ITSP switch configura-
tion.
Based on the Access parameter setting, Nyquist does one of the fol-
lowing:
• Routes the call to a DISA function/station
• Routes the call to a Security DISA function/station
• Routes the call to a defined Day Admin or Night Admin
The following Access settings route the incoming SIP trunk call to the 
DISA functionality:
• DISA – Bi-directional – No password
• DISA – Bi-directional – Password
• DISA – Incoming only – No password
• DISA – Incoming only – Password
• PBX Connection – Incoming only. Allow DISA, No password
• PBX Connection – Incoming only. Allow DISA, Password
When the Nyquist system receives an incoming call, the caller will 
hear a dial tone. The caller can then dial any Nyquist extension or any 
Dual Tone Multi-Frequency (DTMF) code that is associated with a 
Nyquist feature. For example, after hearing the dial tone, the caller 
can dial #0911 to launch an Emergency All-Call page. (See "Nyquist 
DTMF Feature Dialing Codes” on page 477 for a list of DTMF codes.)
When incoming calls are routed to the DISA function, the SIP trunk 
Extension setting is used to map the SIP trunk to a station of type 
DISA Line; the associated station’s CoS configuration is used to 
determine what Nyquist functions the incoming DISA user is allowed 
to initiate. (See "Adding CoS Parameters for a Station” on page 67.) 
Note: If a SIP trunk is configured but disabled in the Nyquist Sys-
tem Parameters, then incoming calls from the SIP trunk are 
ignored.

answers.text: To add CoS Parameters for a station in Nyquist, select CoS Configuration on the navigation bar, click the Add icon, complete the station parameters as outlined in "Table 2-9, CoS Configuration Page Parameters," and then select Save after making all changes.

qas.question: What is the primary function of a SIP trunk in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The primary function of a SIP trunk in the Nyquist system is to provide an IP-based network connection between Nyquist and an Internet Telephony Service Provider (ITSP), enabling VoIP telephony beyond the facility's firewall. It facilitates the routing of VoIP calls, Enhanced 911, and other real-time communications services without requiring a Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN).

qas.question: How does a SIP Tie-Trunk differ from a standard SIP trunk?

answers.text: A SIP Tie-Trunk (or SIP Tie-Line) functions similarly to a standard SIP trunk but serves as an IP-based interconnection specifically between Nyquist and a local (premises-based) or hosted IP-PBX. In contrast, a standard SIP trunk connects Nyquist to an Internet Telephony Service Provider (ITSP) for VoIP services beyond the facility's firewall.

qas.question: What must be set up before configuring SIP parameters in Nyquist?

answers.text: Before configuring SIP parameters in Nyquist, you must first set up the system's DISA function by creating a station with the Type of DISA Line. Additionally, ensure that Teamviewer is installed for remote support and that Wireshark is available for packet inspection.

qas.question: What software installations are required for Bogen support during SIP implementation?

answers.text: For Bogen support during SIP implementation, Teamviewer must be installed on the Nyquist system server to enable remote access, and Wireshark should be installed for packet inspection. Additionally, the firewall settings must allow Port 5060 and Ports 10000 – 20000 for RTP traffic.

qas.question: Which firewall ports need to be open for proper SIP trunk operation?

answers.text: For proper SIP trunk operation, the firewall must allow Port 5060 for SIP signaling and Ports 10000 to 20000 for RTP traffic. These settings are essential for ensuring successful VoIP communication.

qas.question: What parameters determine how Nyquist routes incoming SIP calls?

answers.text: Nyquist routes incoming SIP calls based on the Access parameter set in the SIP trunk's configuration, which must match the ITSP switch configuration. This includes settings such as DISA (dial in) and PBX Connection, which determine whether the call is routed to a DISA function, Security DISA, or defined admin settings.

qas.question: What actions can be performed when an incoming call is routed to the DISA function?

answers.text: When an incoming call is routed to the DISA function, the caller hears a dial tone and can dial any Nyquist extension or DTMF code associated with Nyquist features, such as launching an Emergency All-Call page. The SIP trunk Extension setting maps the SIP trunk to a DISA Line station, and the associated station's CoS configuration determines the functions the incoming DISA user can initiate.

qas.question: What happens if a SIP trunk is configured but disabled in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: If a SIP trunk is configured but disabled in the Nyquist system, incoming calls from that SIP trunk are ignored. This means no calls will be routed or processed by the Nyquist system until the SIP trunk is enabled.

qas.question: How does the CoS configuration affect the capabilities of a DISA user?

answers.text: The CoS (Class of Service) configuration determines the specific functions that a DISA (Direct Inward System Access) user can access when routing incoming calls through the Nyquist system. The capabilities are dictated by the parameters set in the CoS configuration for the associated station, governing what features the DISA user is permitted to initiate.

69
The Extension parameter is also used as the caller ID when a DISA 
user dials a station extension.
The following Access settings route the incoming SIP trunk call to 
Security DISA functionality:
• Security DISA – Bi-directional – Listen only
• Security DISA – Incoming – Listen only
• PBX Connection – Incoming only, security DISA
The caller must enter a valid extension to be monitored and can only 
listen to calls or station locations.
The following Access settings route the incoming SIP trunk call to the 
defined Day or Night Admin:
• Unrestricted
• Incoming Only
If the Day or Night Admin does not answer the incoming call, the call 
is routed, or rolled over, to the Admin Group. (See "Using Admin 
Groups” on page 211.) 
If the call is not answered during night hours and the Night Ring 
option is enabled, the call is routed using the Night Ring functional-
ity. (See "Setting Night Call Options” on page 31.) 
2.3.2
How Nyquist Handles Outgoing SIP Calls
Nyquist users can initiate outside calls by dialing a number that starts 
with the outside call prefix (98). Outside calls are only sent to SIP 
Trunks that have one of the following Access settings:
• DISA – Bi-directional – No Password
• DISA – Bi-directional – Password
• Security DISA – Bi-directional – Listen only
• Unrestricted
• Outgoing Only
Note: Use the PBX Connection options only if the PBX accepts 7-
digit and 10-digit domestic and 12digit international PSTN tele-
phone numbers and can initiate outbound calls to specified tele-
phone numbers.

qas.question: What determines how Nyquist routes incoming SIP calls when a trunk is enabled?

answers.text: Nyquist routes incoming SIP calls based on the Access parameter set in the SIP trunk’s configuration, which must match the ITSP switch configuration. The call can be routed to DISA functions, Security DISA functions, or defined Day/Night Admin settings depending on the specific Access setting.

qas.question: Which Access settings allow incoming SIP trunk calls to route to DISA functionality?

answers.text: The Access settings that allow incoming SIP trunk calls to route to DISA functionality are: DISA – Bi-directional – No password, DISA – Bi-directional – Password, DISA – Incoming only – No password, DISA – Incoming only – Password, PBX Connection – Incoming only. Allow DISA, No password, and PBX Connection – Incoming only. Allow DISA, Password.

qas.question: What does a caller hear when an incoming call is received on the Nyquist system?

answers.text: When an incoming call is received on the Nyquist system, the caller hears a dial tone. After hearing the dial tone, the caller can then dial any Nyquist extension or DTMF code associated with a Nyquist feature.

qas.question: How is the SIP trunk Extension parameter utilized by Nyquist?

answers.text: The SIP trunk Extension parameter in Nyquist is used to map the SIP trunk to a DISA Line station, enabling incoming DISA users to initiate functions based on the station’s Class of Service (CoS) configuration. Additionally, this parameter serves as the caller ID when a DISA user dials a station extension.

qas.question: What happens to incoming calls if the SIP trunk is configured but disabled?

answers.text: If the SIP trunk is configured but disabled in the Nyquist System Parameters, incoming calls from that SIP trunk are ignored. These calls will not be processed or routed by the Nyquist system.

qas.question: What Access settings route incoming SIP trunk calls to Security DISA functionality?

answers.text: The Access settings that route incoming SIP trunk calls to Security DISA functionality are: Security DISA – Bi-directional – Listen only, Security DISA – Incoming – Listen only, and PBX Connection – Incoming only, security DISA. In this mode, the caller must enter a valid extension to be monitored and can only listen to calls or station locations.

qas.question: What subsequent action is taken if the Day or Night Admin does not answer an incoming call?

answers.text: If the Day or Night Admin does not answer an incoming call, the call is routed, or rolled over, to the Admin Group. If the call is not answered during night hours and the Night Ring option is enabled, it is routed using the Night Ring functionality.

qas.question: Which Access settings permit users to initiate outgoing SIP calls from the Nyquist system?

answers.text: Users can initiate outgoing SIP calls from the Nyquist system using the following Access settings: DISA – Bi-directional – No Password, DISA – Bi-directional – Password, Security DISA – Bi-directional – Listen only, Unrestricted, and Outgoing Only.

qas.question: What prefix must users dial to initiate outside calls using Nyquist?

answers.text: Users must dial the outside call prefix "98" to initiate outside calls using Nyquist. This prefix is required before the actual number they wish to call.

qas.question: Under what conditions should PBX Connection options be used when placing outgoing calls?

answers.text: PBX Connection options should be used when placing outgoing calls if the PBX accepts 7-digit and 10-digit domestic, as well as 12-digit international PSTN telephone numbers, and can initiate outbound calls to specified telephone numbers. They are not appropriate for calls routed through SIP trunks with access settings outside these parameters.

• DISA – Bi-directional – Password

• Outgoing Only

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Extension parameter in a DISA user call?

answers.text: The Extension parameter in a DISA user call serves as the caller ID when a user dials a station extension. It allows the caller to enter a valid extension to be monitored and enables them to listen to calls or station locations.

qas.question: Which Access settings enable incoming SIP trunk calls to utilize Security DISA functionality?

answers.text: The Access settings that enable incoming SIP trunk calls to utilize Security DISA functionality are: Security DISA – Bi-directional – Listen only, Security DISA – Incoming – Listen only, and PBX Connection – Incoming only, security DISA. These settings ensure that the caller can only listen to calls or station locations after entering a valid extension.

qas.question: How does the call routing change if the Day or Night Admin does not answer an incoming call?

answers.text: If the Day or Night Admin does not answer an incoming call, the call is routed or rolled over to the Admin Group. During night hours, if the Night Ring option is enabled, the call is routed using the Night Ring functionality.

qas.question: What is the prefix that Nyquist users must dial to initiate outside calls?

answers.text: Nyquist users must dial the prefix "98" to initiate outside calls. This prefix must be used when calling numbers that require routing through SIP trunks with specific access settings such as DISA or unrestricted access.

qas.question: What Access settings allow Nyquist users to make outgoing calls to SIP Trunks?

answers.text: Nyquist users can make outgoing calls to SIP Trunks using the following Access settings: DISA – Bi-directional – No Password, DISA – Bi-directional – Password, Security DISA – Bi-directional – Listen only, Unrestricted, and Outgoing Only. Additionally, PBX Connection settings, such as PBX Connection – Bi-directional, No DISA, and PBX Connection – Bi-directional, Allow DISA, are also applicable.

qas.question: How is the outbound caller ID determined when outside calls are made?

answers.text: The outbound caller ID for outside calls is set to the Direct Inward Dial (DID) defined for the SIP Trunk. This setting ensures that the correct caller identification is transmitted when calls are initiated through the SIP trunk.

qas.question: What settings can be adjusted for SIP trunks to comply with specific area code requirements when dialing 7-digit numbers?

answers.text: To comply with specific area code requirements when dialing 7-digit numbers, the Dial Prefix setting can be used to add a necessary prefix, and the Local Area Code setting can be adjusted to ensure that all called 7-digit numbers are prefixed with the specified local area code.

qas.question: What Access option should be selected to ensure that incoming calls from a PBX prompt for Nyquist dial codes?

answers.text: To ensure that incoming calls from a PBX prompt for Nyquist dial codes, you should select an Access option that starts with DISA, such as "DISA – Incoming only - No password." This configuration requires the user to enter the necessary dial codes upon receiving the call.

qas.question: How are outgoing 911 calls treated differently in terms of the DID parameter?

answers.text: Outgoing 911 calls utilize the SIP trunk without using the Direct Inward Dial (DID) parameter; instead, it is expected that the SIP trunk provider has mapped the Billing Telephone Number (BTN) to the E911 service. This means the DID is not applicable for 911 calls, ensuring compliance with emergency service requirements.

qas.question: What SIP trunk configuration parameters are required for routing outgoing calls through a SIP trunk provider?

answers.text: The required SIP trunk configuration parameters for routing outgoing calls through a SIP trunk provider are the Host IP Address, Username, and Password. Additionally, if the provider expects a specific dial prefix or local area code for 7-digit numbers, those settings can also be configured.

2.3.3
Configuring SIP Tie-Trunks Between Nyquist 
and PBX Systems
If you want all incoming calls from the PBX to always use DISA to 
prompt the user for Nyquist dial codes, then use one of the Access 
options that starts with DISA (for example, DISA – Incoming only - 
No password).
If you want all incoming calls from the PBX to directly pass in dial 
codes that have already been collected from the user by the PBX or 
created by the PBX, then choose one of the Access options that starts 
71
with PBX Connection (for example, PBX Connection – Incoming 
only, Allow DISA, No password).
When any of the following Access options are configured for the SIP 
Tie-Trunk, the Nyquist server expects that dialing digits are provided 
by the PBX system (the dialing digits should be included in the SIP 
INVITE from the PBX), and Nyquist will immediately initiate a Nyquist 
call based on the digits provided:
• PBX Connection – Incoming only, No DISA
• PBX Connection – Incoming only, Allow DISA, No password
• PBX Connection – Incoming only, Allow DISA, Password
• PBX Connection – Bi-directional, No DISA
• PBX Connection – Bi-directional, Allow DISA, No password
• PBX Connection – Bi-directional, Allow DISA, Password
If the PBX Connection option includes Allow DISA, the PBX may start 
the DISA function by sending dialing code 950. The DISA function will 
also be started if the PBX does not pass any dialing digits in the SIP 
INVITE.
If PBX Connection – Incoming only, No DISA is used, the SIP Trunk 
must still have a DISA station type linked to the SIP trunk extension to 
provide the Nyquist CoS settings to be used for incoming calls, but 
when incoming connections are made from the PBX, the Nyquist 
system will ignore dialing code 950. The DISA function cannot be 
requested if the No DISA option is used.
The dialing digits provided by the PBX can be any of the DTMF codes 
supported by the Nyquist system. Access to various Nyquist features 
is granted based on the Nyquist CoS settings of the DISA station 
extension defined in the SIP Trunk.
If the PBX is not able to pass through # in the dialing digits, alternate 
dialing codes may be used to replace Nyquist extensions that start 
with #. The following table describes the alternate dialing codes:

qas.question: What are the different bi-directional PBX connection options available in the system?

answers.text: The different bi-directional PBX connection options available in the system are: "PBX Connection – Bi-directional, No DISA"; "PBX Connection – Bi-directional, Allow DISA, No password"; "PBX Connection – Bi-directional, Allow DISA, Password"; and "PBX Connection – Bi-directional, Security DISA." These options dictate how incoming and outgoing calls are handled between the PBX and the Nyquist system, with variations in security and DISA access.

qas.question: How is the outbound caller ID determined for calls placed through the SIP trunk?

answers.text: The outbound caller ID for calls placed through the SIP trunk is set to the Direct Inward Dial (DID) number defined for the SIP trunk. This configuration ensures that the outgoing calls display the designated DID number as the caller ID.

qas.question: What happens when Access is set to 911 Only on a SIP trunk?

answers.text: When Access is set to 911 Only on a SIP trunk, only outgoing 911 calls can be routed through that trunk, and the Direct Inward Dial (DID) parameter is not utilized for these calls. Instead, it is expected that the SIP trunk provider has mapped the Billing Telephone Number (BTN) to E911 service.

qas.question: Which SIP trunk configuration parameters are required for routing all outgoing calls?

answers.text: The required SIP trunk configuration parameters for routing all outgoing calls are the Host IP Address, Username, and Password. Additionally, if the SIP trunk provider requires called numbers to be prefixed with a specific code, the Dial Prefix setting should also be configured.

qas.question: What settings can be used for prefixing called numbers as required by the SIP trunk provider?

answers.text: To prefix called numbers as required by the SIP trunk provider, the Dial Prefix setting can be used for a specific code, and the Local Area Code setting can be configured to prefix all called 7-digit numbers with the designated local area code.

qas.question: How can incoming calls from the PBX use DISA to prompt for Nyquist dial codes?

answers.text: Incoming calls from the PBX can use DISA to prompt for Nyquist dial codes by configuring the SIP Tie-Trunk with an Access option that starts with DISA, such as "DISA – Incoming only – No password." This setting ensures that the Nyquist system activates the DISA function to prompt the user for dial codes when calls are received from the PBX.

qas.question: What is the difference between the PBX Connection options with and without DISA?

answers.text: The PBX Connection options with DISA (Direct Inward System Access) allow users to enter dialing codes after the connection is established, enabling access to additional Nyquist features. In contrast, options without DISA require the PBX to provide dialing digits in the SIP INVITE, and the DISA function cannot be initiated, limiting user access to those features.

qas.question: When is the Security DISA function activated in a SIP Tie-Trunk configuration?

answers.text: The Security DISA function in a SIP Tie-Trunk configuration is activated when the access option is set to either "PBX Connection - Incoming only, Security DISA" or "PBX Connection - Bi-directional, Security DISA." In this case, the caller must enter an access PIN followed by the extension number of the station they wish to monitor.

qas.question: What parameters must be configured or known before adding a SIP trunk?

answers.text: Before adding a SIP trunk, the following parameters must be configured or known: the extension for the Nyquist DISA line station, the dial prefix and format for outside line connections, the local area code, the username and password for the DISA line, the DID phone number associated with the DISA line, allowed codecs, and the admin group setup for the SIP extension.

qas.question: What are the alternate dialing codes for Nyquist features that start with #?

answers.text: The alternate dialing codes for Nyquist features that start with # are as follows: for All-Call Page (#0), the alternate code is 0000000; for Emergency All-Call Page (#0911), the alternate code is 951; and for Zone Page (#<zone number>), the alternate code is 0000099<zone number>.

2.3.5
SIP Trunk Custom Configuration Settings
The Custom Settings parameter can be used if additional parame-
ters are needed during SIP trunk configuration to satisfy SIP trunk 
provider requirements. Bogen Technical Support will provide any 
necessary custom settings. In most cases, Custom Settings are not 
required.
Custom Settings can be entered when adding or editing SIP Trunk 
parameters (see "Adding SIP Trunk Configuration Parameters” on 
page 72 or "Editing a SIP Trunk Configuration” on page 81) using the 
following format:
:TABLE-NAME:<variable>=<value>:TABLE-NAME:
In this format, TABLE-NAME is one of the following:
• ENDPOINT
• AOR
• AUTH
• SIPTRUNK
Variable is a valid variable from one of the pjsip tables (ps_endpoints, 
ps_aors, ps_auths) or sip_trunk table.
DID
Enter the 10-digit DID telephone number that the SIP trunk 
or hosted VoIP provider has assigned the SIP trunk, using 
the format NPANXXxxxx (that is, no spaces or dashes).
Day Admin
Select the Admin Station to call during daytime hours.
Night Admin
Select the Admin Station to call during nighttime hours.
Admin Group
Select the Admin Group to call if the day or night Admin 
Stations do not answer the call.
Call Recording
Provide if incoming and outgoing calls are to be recorded.
Allow
Provide a list of media codecs that are allowed. PSTN stan-
dard codecs are G.711 or ULAW.
Description
Provide user provided description for the SIP trunk.
Custom Settings
Provide custom setting configurations that are provided by 
Technical Support. (See "SIP Trunk Custom Configuration 
Settings” on page 75.)
Table 2-11,  Add SIP Trunk Page Parameters (Continued)

qas.question: What options activate the Security DISA function for the SIP Tie-Trunk?

answers.text: The Security DISA function for the SIP Tie-Trunk is activated when the PBX connection is configured as either "Incoming only, security DISA" or "Bi-directional, Security DISA." Upon connection from the PBX system via SIP INVITE, the caller must enter an access PIN followed by the extension number they wish to monitor.

qas.question: What parameters must be configured before adding a SIP trunk?

answers.text: Before adding a SIP trunk, the following parameters must be configured: the extension for the Nyquist DISA line station associated with the SIP trunk, the dial prefix and format for connecting to an outside line, the local area code, the username and password for the DISA line, the DID phone number, allowed codecs, and the Admin Group for the SIP extension.

qas.question: How many characters can the name for the SIP trunk be?

answers.text: The name for the SIP trunk cannot contain spaces or a slash (/) and cannot exceed 16 characters in length.

qas.question: What does the 'Dial Prefix' field require from the ITSP?

answers.text: The 'Dial Prefix' field requires the prefix needed by the ITSP (Internet Telephony Service Provider) to complete an outbound call over the SIP trunk, such as "9" or "9+1." This prefix is necessary for properly routing outgoing calls.

qas.question: What access permissions can be selected for the SIP trunk?

answers.text: The access permissions that can be selected for the SIP trunk include: 911 Only, Incoming Only, Outgoing Only, No Access, and several options for DISA (both bi-directional and incoming only with or without passwords), as well as Unrestricted and PBX Connection types. Each option defines the call access allowed through the SIP trunk.

qas.question: What is the significance of the 'Enabled' option when configuring a SIP trunk?

answers.text: The 'Enabled' option specifies whether the SIP trunk is active and can be used for calls. Configuring the trunk before enabling it is important to prevent erratic system behavior, ensuring that all parameters are correctly set up before the trunk goes live.

qas.question: What format should be used for entering the DID telephone number?

answers.text: The format for entering the DID telephone number is NPANXXxxxx, which means it should be a 10-digit number without any spaces or dashes.

qas.question: What information is required under 'Username' and 'Password' fields for accessing the SIP trunk?

answers.text: For accessing the SIP trunk, the 'Username' field requires the username provided by the SIP trunk or hosted VoIP provider, while the 'Password' field requires the corresponding password given by the same provider. The password must be confirmed by re-entering it in the 'Password Confirmed' field.

qas.question: What role do the Day Admin and Night Admin settings serve during SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: The Day Admin and Night Admin settings specify which Admin Stations are to be called during daytime and nighttime hours, respectively, if the primary Admin Station does not answer the call. These settings ensure that calls are directed to the appropriate personnel based on the time of day for effective management.

qas.question: Under what circumstances are Custom Settings needed during SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: Custom Settings are needed during SIP trunk configuration if additional parameters are required to meet the specific requirements of the SIP trunk provider. Typically, these settings are not required, and Bogen Technical Support will provide any necessary custom configurations.

qas.question: Which codecs are considered standard for PSTN when allowed during SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: The standard codecs for PSTN during SIP trunk configuration are G.711 and ULAW. These codecs are typically allowed for high-quality audio during calls.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Admin Group in the SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: The Admin Group in the SIP trunk configuration is used to designate a group of stations that will be alerted if the designated Day or Night Admin stations do not answer incoming calls. This ensures that calls are routed to an alternative administration point for further handling or support.

2.3.6
Registering as a Third-Party SIP Endpoint
You can configure a Nyquist SIP trunk to register with a third-party 
SIP endpoint with an IP-PBX. This will allow users to dial an IP-PBX 
defined extension to initiate Nyquist features, such as paging.
The steps to register the Nyquist SIP trunk as a third-party SIP end-
point for an IP-PBX are:
1 Define a Third-Party SIP Phone/Endpoint on your IP-PBX sys-
tem. On the IP-PBX system, set up a third-party SIP phone/end-
point as you would for a standard single-line basic SIP IP phone 
with a username and password to use for authentication. Typically, 
the username would be the extension number. The Nyquist system 
will attempt to register with your IP-PBX system as a SIP endpoint 
extension using the provided username (extension) and password 
pair. Your IP-PBX users will dial the provided IP-PBX extension to 
access the Nyquist system.
2 Define a DISA station on Nyquist system. On the Nyquist Sys-
tem, create a DISA Line station Type. This station’s extension will 
define the feature CoS permissions to be used when the IP-PBX 
calls into the Nyquist system. 
3 Define a SIP Trunk on Nyquist system. Configure a Nyquist SIP 
Trunk using the username (PBX extension) and password that was 
defined on your IP-PBX in step 1.
For example, suppose the IP-PBX has defined extension 511 as the 
SIP endpoint with password testpassword. The Nyquist SIP trunk 
must use 511 in the Name, Username, and DID parameters on the 
Add SIP Trunk page. Nyquist station extension 500 is defined as a 
DISA station. 
When an IP-PBX user calls 511, the Nyquist system will see an incom-
ing call to extension 511. Nyquist converts to the DISA station exten-
sion 500 (to provide CoS definitions for 511 and Caller-ID to the 
Nyquist system). DISA will be started, allowing the IP-PBX caller to 
initiate a feature on the Nyquist system. When DISA starts, the IP-PBX 
Note: The station extension used for the DISA Line must be differ-
ent than the extension being used by your IP-PBX.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Custom Settings parameter in SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: The Custom Settings parameter in SIP trunk configuration is used to specify additional parameters required by the SIP trunk provider. It allows for the inclusion of custom configurations as provided by Bogen Technical Support, although such settings are not typically necessary.

qas.question: Which table names can be used in the Custom Settings format?

answers.text: The table names that can be used in the Custom Settings format are ENDPOINT, AOR, AUTH, and SIPTRUNK. Each of these corresponds to valid variables from the respective pjsip tables or the sip_trunk table.

qas.question: What format should the 10-digit DID telephone number be entered in?

answers.text: The 10-digit DID telephone number should be entered in the format NPANXXxxxx, meaning no spaces or dashes.

qas.question: How can you select an Admin Station for daytime and nighttime calls?

answers.text: To select an Admin Station for daytime calls, choose from the available options in the "Day Admin" parameter during SIP trunk configuration. For nighttime calls, select an Admin Station in the "Night Admin" parameter. If neither Admin Station answers, the "Admin Group" will be called.

qas.question: What are the standard PSTN media codecs mentioned for SIP trunks?

answers.text: The standard PSTN media codecs mentioned for SIP trunks are G.711 and ULAW. These codecs are allowed for media transmission during SIP trunk configuration.

qas.question: Who should you contact for information regarding Custom Settings for specific IP-PBX configurations?

answers.text: You should contact Technical Support for information regarding Custom Settings for your specific IP-PBX type and configuration. They will provide any necessary custom settings needed for SIP trunk configuration.

qas.question: What is the first step to register a Nyquist SIP trunk as a third-party SIP endpoint?

answers.text: The first step to register a Nyquist SIP trunk as a third-party SIP endpoint is to define a Third-Party SIP Phone/Endpoint on your IP-PBX system. This setup involves creating a standard SIP phone with a username (typically the extension number) and a password for authentication.

qas.question: How is the DISA station defined on the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The DISA station is defined on the Nyquist system by creating a DISA Line station type. This station’s extension determines the feature Class of Service (CoS) permissions used when the IP-PBX calls into the Nyquist system, and it must have a different extension than the one being used by the IP-PBX.

qas.question: What parameters must be configured for a Nyquist SIP trunk during registration with an IP-PBX?

answers.text: To register a Nyquist SIP trunk with an IP-PBX, you must configure the username (extension), password, and DID parameters on the Nyquist system to match those defined on the IP-PBX. Additionally, a DISA station must be defined on the Nyquist system, with its extension differing from the SIP endpoint extension used on the IP-PBX.

qas.question: Why must the DISA Line station extension differ from the IP-PBX extension being used?

answers.text: The DISA Line station extension must differ from the IP-PBX extension to avoid conflicts and ensure proper identification of calls. This separation allows the Nyquist system to correctly convert the incoming call to the appropriate DISA station, enabling the necessary feature access without confusion between the two extensions.

qas.question: What is the purpose of configuring a Nyquist SIP trunk with a third-party SIP endpoint?

answers.text: Configuring a Nyquist SIP trunk with a third-party SIP endpoint allows users to dial an IP-PBX defined extension to access Nyquist features, such as paging. This setup facilitates communication between the IP-PBX and Nyquist system, enabling users to initiate features on Nyquist by entering DTMF commands after dialing the designated extension.

qas.question: What initial step must be taken on an IP-PBX system to set up a third-party SIP phone?

answers.text: The initial step on an IP-PBX system to set up a third-party SIP phone is to define a Third-Party SIP Phone/Endpoint. This involves configuring it as you would for a standard SIP IP phone, including assigning a username (typically the extension number) and password for authentication.

qas.question: How is the DISA station defined on the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The DISA station on the Nyquist system is defined by creating a DISA Line station type, which specifies an extension that will provide the Class of Service (CoS) permissions for incoming calls from the IP-PBX. This DISA station extension must be different from the extension used by the IP-PBX for the SIP endpoint.

qas.question: What parameters must be configured for a SIP trunk on the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To configure a SIP trunk on the Nyquist system, you must set the Name, Username, Password, DID, and define the corresponding DISA station extension. Additionally, ensure that the trunk is enabled and specify the Host as the IP address or fully qualified domain name of the IP-PBX.

qas.question: Why must the DISA Line station extension differ from the IP-PBX extension?

answers.text: The DISA Line station extension must differ from the IP-PBX extension to ensure that the Nyquist system can properly identify and process incoming calls without confusion. This separation allows the Nyquist system to apply the correct Class of Service (CoS) permissions and manage Caller-ID effectively, preventing conflicts between the two systems.

qas.question: What does the NYquist system do when receiving a call to the defined extension?

answers.text: When the Nyquist system receives a call to the defined extension (e.g., 511), it identifies the incoming call, converts it to the associated DISA station extension (e.g., 500), and initiates DISA. This allows the caller to hear a dial tone and enter DTMF/dial-pad commands to access Nyquist features such as paging.

qas.question: What options are available for Access settings in the SIP Trunk configuration?

answers.text:
In the SIP Trunk configuration, the available Access settings are:

1. PBX Connection – Incoming only, Allow DISA, No password
2. PBX Connection – Incoming only, Allow DISA, Password

qas.question: How can you view available SIP trunks for a facility?

answers.text: To view available SIP trunks for your facility, select "SIP Trunks" from the navigation bar. This will display the details of each SIP trunk, including its name, description, enabled status, and registration status.

qas.question: What details can be viewed for each SIP trunk in the management interface?

answers.text: In the management interface for each SIP trunk, you can view the name, description, enabled status, and registration status of the SIP trunk. The status indicates whether the SIP trunk is registered successfully with the provided credentials or if it has been rejected.

qas.question: What should be done if the copied single quotes in custom settings do not work?

answers.text: If the copied single quotes in custom settings do not work, delete them after pasting and replace them with new single quotes. Additionally, if the setting `realm=’ ’` does not work, try using `realm=’<server_ip_address>’` or `realm=’<server_hostname>’` instead.

qas.question: What steps are needed to view available SIP trunks for a facility?

answers.text: To view available SIP trunks for a facility, select "SIP Trunks" from the navigation bar. This will display a table with details for each SIP trunk, including parameters such as Name, Description, Status, and Access options.

qas.question: What parameters can be viewed for each SIP trunk on the SIP Trunks page?

answers.text: On the SIP Trunks page, the key parameters that can be viewed for each SIP trunk include the Name, Description, Enabled status, Registration Status, Access permissions, Extension, DID number, Username, Host, Dial Prefix, Local Area Code, Type, Day and Night Admin contacts, Admin Group, Allowed Codecs, Call Recording status, and Custom Settings. These parameters help in managing and configuring the SIP trunk effectively.

qas.question: How should custom settings be formatted when copied and pasted?

answers.text: When copying and pasting custom settings for SIP trunks, delete the single quotes that appear after pasting and replace them with actual single quotes, as the copy/paste operation does not preserve the correct character. Additionally, if `realm=' '` does not work, try using `realm='<server_ip_address>'` or `realm='<server_hostname>'`.

qas.question: What are the possible access permissions for a SIP trunk?

answers.text: The possible access permissions for a SIP trunk are: 911 Only, DISA (various configurations), Incoming Only, Outgoing Only, No Access, Unrestricted, and several PBX Connection options with different DISA settings. Each option defines the allowed access mode for the SIP trunk.

qas.question: What does the Status field indicate for a SIP trunk?

answers.text: The Status field for a SIP trunk indicates the registration status of the SIP trunk. It may show as "Register" if the credentials are used by the SIP endpoint or "Rejected" if the SIP endpoint does not use credentials, but the latter does not prevent a successful SIP connection.

qas.question: Can the name of a SIP trunk be edited after creation?

answers.text: No, the name of a SIP trunk cannot be edited after creation. However, other fields, such as the Dial Prefix and Local Area Code, can be modified.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Dial Prefix field in SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: The Dial Prefix field in SIP trunk configuration is used to specify the prefix required by the ITSP to complete an outbound call over the SIP trunk, such as 9 or 9+1. This ensures that calls are properly routed through the service provider.

qas.question: What information does the DID field contain in a SIP trunk setup?

answers.text: The DID (Direct Inward Dialing) field in a SIP trunk setup contains the DID telephone number associated with the outside line, which is assigned by the ITSP (Internet Telephony Service Provider). This number allows incoming calls to reach specific extensions directly without going through a receptionist or auto-attendant.

qas.question: How are allowed media codecs specified for a SIP trunk?

answers.text: Allowed media codecs for a SIP trunk are specified in the "Codecs Allowed" field, where a list of codecs is provided, separated by a semicolon. For example, codecs like g722 or ulaw can be included in this list to define the media capabilities of the trunk.

qas.question: What should be done if realm settings do not work as intended?

answers.text: If the realm settings do not work as intended, try replacing `realm=''` with either `realm='<server_ip_address>'` or `realm='<server_hostname>'`. This adjusts the realm to specify a particular server, which may resolve the issue.
