qas.question: What fields can be edited in a SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: In a SIP trunk configuration, you can edit the Dial Prefix, Local Area Code, Extension, Access permissions, Username, Change Password, Host, and Description fields. The SIP trunk's name cannot be edited.

qas.question: How do you access the Edit SIP Trunk page?

answers.text: To access the Edit SIP Trunk page, first select "SIP Trunks" from the navigation bar. Then, on the SIP Trunks page, click the Edit icon next to the SIP trunk you wish to modify.

qas.question: What is required to complete an outbound call over the SIP trunk?

answers.text: To complete an outbound call over the SIP trunk, a dial prefix specified by the ITSP must be entered. This allows the system to properly route the call. Additionally, it is essential that the SIP trunk is fully configured and enabled.

qas.question: When should a SIP trunk be enabled after configuration?

answers.text: A SIP trunk should be enabled after it has been fully configured to avoid erratic system behavior. This ensures that all necessary settings, such as Dial Prefix and Access permissions, are correctly set before activation.

qas.question: What are the available access permissions for a SIP trunk?

answers.text: The available access permissions for a SIP trunk include options such as 911 Only, DISA (various bi-directional and incoming only configurations with and without passwords), Incoming Only, Outgoing Only, No Access, Unrestricted, and several PBX Connection settings. Each option specifies different levels of access and capabilities for the SIP trunk.

qas.question: Where can you enter the host name or IP address for the ITSP?

answers.text: You can enter the host name or IP address for the ITSP in the "Host" field on the Edit SIP Trunk page. This is part of the configuration settings when editing a SIP trunk.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Username field in the SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: The Username field in the SIP trunk configuration is used to enter the user name required to access the SIP trunk. This credential is necessary for authentication purposes when establishing a connection with the SIP trunk provider or hosted VoIP service.

qas.question: How can you delete a SIP trunk from the configuration?

answers.text: To delete a SIP trunk, select "SIP Trunks" from the navigation bar, then click the delete icon next to the SIP trunk you wish to remove. Finally, confirm the deletion by selecting "Delete."

qas.question: What information is needed to re-enter when changing the SIP trunk password?

answers.text: When changing the SIP trunk password, you need to re-enter the new password in the "Change Password" field and confirm it in the "Confirm Password" field. Both fields must match for the password change to be successful.

qas.question: How can one view the status of outside lines in a facility?

answers.text: To view the status of outside lines in a facility, use the Outside Lines feature accessible from the navigation bar. This feature allows you to quickly determine the status of every outside line associated with the facility.

qas.question: What is a DID in the context of a SIP trunk?

answers.text: A DID, or Direct Inward Dialing number, is a telephone number associated with an outside line that allows callers to reach a specific extension or service directly without going through a reception or operator. In the context of a SIP trunk, it facilitates the routing of incoming calls to designated internal lines based on the incoming telephone number.

qas.question: What codecs are typically allowed for a SIP trunk connection?

answers.text: The typical codecs allowed for a SIP trunk connection are G.711 and ULAW, which are standard PSTN codecs. These codecs facilitate efficient voice communication over the trunk.

qas.question: How can you delete a previously added SIP trunk?

qas.question: What information is required to view the status of an outside line?

answers.text: To view the status of an outside line, you need to enter the DID (Direct Inward Dialing) telephone number associated with the outside line. Additionally, you can select the Admin Stations for daytime and nighttime calls, as well as the Admin Group for further escalation if needed.

qas.question: Which codecs are typically allowed for SIP trunk configurations?

answers.text: The typical codecs allowed for SIP trunk configurations are PSTN standard codecs, which include G.711 and ULAW.

qas.question: What should you do if both the Day and Night Admin Stations do not answer a call?

answers.text: If both the Day and Night Admin Stations do not answer a call, you should select the Admin Group to receive the call as a fallback option. This ensures that the call is directed to another designated group of administrators.

qas.question: Where can you find more information about custom setting configurations for SIP trunks?

answers.text: More information about custom setting configurations for SIP trunks can be found in the section titled "SIP Trunk Custom Configuration Settings," referenced on page 75 of the documentation.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Call Recording option in SIP trunk settings?

answers.text: The Call Recording option in SIP trunk settings allows users to select whether incoming and outgoing calls routed through the SIP trunk should be recorded. This feature is useful for quality assurance, legal compliance, and training purposes.

qas.question: How can you edit the user-provided description for a SIP trunk?

answers.text: To edit the user-provided description for a SIP trunk, navigate to the SIP Trunks page and locate the desired SIP trunk. There, you can edit the Description field to update the information as needed.

qas.question: What section of the SIP Trunks page allows for the configuration of additional custom settings?

answers.text: The section of the SIP Trunks page that allows for the configuration of additional custom settings is labeled "Custom Settings." This section enables users to edit custom setting configurations provided by Technical Support.

qas.question: What information is required to view the outside line status?

answers.text: To view the outside line status, you need to select the Outside Lines option from the navigation bar. This will provide information on the system port name, user-provided description, enabled status, line status, port type, access level, dial prefix, associated extension, DID number, day and night admin stations, and admin group.

qas.question: What options are available for accessing outside lines?

answers.text: The options available for accessing outside lines include 911 Only, DISA (with various configurations for bi-directional, incoming only, and password requirements), Incoming Only, Outgoing Only, and several types of PBX Connections that define access levels and DISA capabilities. There is also an option for Unrestricted access.

qas.question: How can you edit the parameters of an outside line?

answers.text: To edit the parameters of an outside line, select "Outside Lines" from the navigation bar, click the Edit icon next to the outside line name, make the desired edits, and then select "Save" to apply the changes.

qas.question: What does the "Description" field represent in the SIP trunk configuration?

answers.text: The "Description" field in the SIP trunk configuration allows the user to edit and provide a user-defined description of the SIP trunk's purpose. This helps in identifying and managing different SIP trunks more easily.

qas.question: Which media codecs are allowed for a SIP trunk?

answers.text: The allowed media codecs for a SIP trunk are PSTN standard codecs, specifically G.711 or ULAW. These codecs can be entered in the "Allow" field when configuring the SIP trunk.

qas.question: What identifies the status of an outside line?

answers.text: The status of an outside line is identified through the "Status" parameter on the Outside Lines page. This parameter provides information regarding whether the line is active or inactive.

qas.question: What does the Dial Prefix specify in the outside lines configuration?

answers.text: The Dial Prefix specifies the digit or digits that must be dialed to obtain an outside line. It serves as a key configuration parameter to facilitate outgoing calls through the designated outside line.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Admin Group selection for outside lines?

answers.text: The Admin Group selection for outside lines identifies the group of administrators to be called if neither the day nor night Admin Stations answer the call. This ensures that there is always an alternative point of contact for managing the outside line's activities during both daytime and nighttime hours.

qas.question: How can you enable or disable an outside line?

answers.text: To enable or disable an outside line, select "Outside Lines" from the navigation bar, then click the Edit icon next to the desired outside line name. Make the necessary changes to the "Enabled" status, then select "Save" to apply the changes.

ically set by Nyquist and cannot be changed.

qas.question: What steps are involved in editing an outside line?

answers.text: To edit an outside line, select "Outside Lines" from the navigation bar, click the Edit icon next to the desired line, make the necessary edits, and then select "Save." The system port name and port type cannot be edited, while other parameters such as access and dial prefix can be modified.

qas.question: What parameter identifies the level of access allowed on an outside line?

answers.text: The parameter that identifies the level of access allowed on an outside line is called "Access." It offers various options, including 911 Only, DISA (multiple configurations), Incoming Only, No Access, Outgoing Only, and several PBX Connection types, each specifying the permitted interactions with the line.

qas.question: Can the port name and port type for outside lines be edited by the user?

answers.text: No, the port name and port type for outside lines cannot be edited by the user; these parameters are automatically set by the system and remain fixed. Users can modify other settings such as enabling the line and adjusting access levels.

qas.question: What options are available for the Access parameter of an outside line?

answers.text: The Access parameter for an outside line offers various options, including: 911 Only, different types of DISA configurations (bi-directional or incoming only, with or without passwords), Incoming Only, No Access, Outgoing Only, and multiple PBX Connection types. Each option defines the level of access permitted for that outside line.

qas.question: What does the Dial Prefix parameter signify in the context of outside lines?

answers.text: The Dial Prefix parameter identifies the digit or digits that must be dialed to obtain an outside line. It serves as a necessary prefix for users to access external communication through the system.

qas.question: How does the Discover Ports feature function regarding DAHDI PCI cards?

answers.text: The Discover Ports feature allows Nyquist to automatically detect a newly installed DAHDI PCI card and create entries for each port supported by the card. The port name and type are automatically set by Nyquist and cannot be changed, allowing users to subsequently edit each port with their custom settings.

qas.question: What does the Night Admin parameter indicate?

answers.text: The Night Admin parameter identifies the Admin Station to call during nighttime hours. It serves as a contact point for administrative support outside of regular daytime hours.

qas.question: What is the significance of the DID parameter associated with an outside line?

answers.text: The DID (Direct Inward Dialing) parameter identifies the specific telephone number associated with the outside line, allowing callers to reach a particular extension directly without going through a main line or switchboard. This feature is essential for enhancing call routing and ensuring that incoming calls are directed to the intended recipient efficiently.

qas.question: What type of information is collected in the Description parameter for outside lines?

answers.text: The Description parameter for outside lines identifies the user-provided description of the outside line's purpose. This allows users to add context or specific information about the functionality or use of the line.

2.5
Configuring Firmware
Firmware, computer software stored on a hardware device, can be 
updated for Nyquist stations through the Nyquist Admin Web UI or 
through the appliance’s web UI. For information about the appli-
ance’s web UI, refer to the device’s configuration manual.
Through the Nyquist Admin Web UI, you can upload a firmware file 
to the Nyquist system server, download firmware to a station, view a 
list of stations that are linked to a firmware name, set default firm-
ware for any stations to be added, and delete firmware entries. For 
stations that are attached to a Networked Power Amplifier, such as an 
NQ-A2300, the firmware is updated to the amplifier and not to the 
individual station.
2.5.1
Viewing Firmware Stored on the Nyquist 
System Server
From the Firmware page, you can view a list of available firmware, 
bring up a list of devices that can be selected for updating firmware, 
set the file to the default firmware, check for updates, view release 
notes, select to edit information about or delete firmware files on the 
Nyquist system server, and configure automatic software downloads.
Note: Before configuring or using any Nyquist appliances, you must 
ensure that the appliance firmware is updated to the latest release. 
The latest firmware release can be obtained from the secured ES 
Dealers website: http://www.bogenedu.com/nyquist-secure-dealer-
resources/
Figure 2-21, Firmware Page

qas.question: What does the Discover Ports feature in Nyquist do?

answers.text: The Discover Ports feature in Nyquist automatically detects newly installed DAHDI PCI cards and creates entries for each supported port. The port name and type are automatically generated and cannot be changed, allowing users to edit each port with custom settings thereafter.

qas.question: How does one identify the Admin Group for calls in Nyquist?

answers.text: To identify the Admin Group for calls in Nyquist, you can specify the Admin Group that should be contacted if the day or night Admin Stations do not answer the call. This setting is configured within the Admin Group parameter in the system.

qas.question: What parameters can be customized for each port discovered by Nyquist?

answers.text: For each port discovered by Nyquist, the user can edit custom settings, including the Admin Group, Day Admin, Night Admin, DID, and a user-provided description of the outside line's purpose. However, the port name and port type are automatically set by Nyquist and cannot be changed.

qas.question: How can firmware be updated for Nyquist stations?

answers.text: Firmware for Nyquist stations can be updated through the Nyquist Admin Web UI by uploading a firmware file to the Nyquist system server and downloading it to the individual station. Alternatively, firmware can also be updated via the appliance’s web UI, specific to the device being used.

qas.question: What can you view on the Firmware page of the Nyquist Admin Web UI?

answers.text: On the Firmware page of the Nyquist Admin Web UI, you can view a list of available firmware, select devices for firmware updates, set default firmware, check for updates, view release notes, and manage firmware files (edit or delete). Additionally, you can configure automatic software downloads.

qas.question: Where can you obtain the latest firmware release for Nyquist appliances?

answers.text: The latest firmware release for Nyquist appliances can be obtained from the secured ES Dealers website at http://www.bogenedu.com/nyquist-secure-dealer-resources/. It is essential to ensure that the appliance firmware is updated to the latest release before configuring or using any Nyquist appliances.

qas.question: What happens to firmware updates for stations connected to a Networked Power Amplifier?

answers.text: For stations connected to a Networked Power Amplifier, such as the NQ-A2300, the firmware is updated to the amplifier itself rather than to the individual stations. This means that updates are managed at the amplifier level instead of at each station.

qas.question: How is the description for an outside line identified in Nyquist?

answers.text: The description for an outside line in Nyquist is identified by a user-provided description that specifies the purpose of the outside line. This information helps in managing and understanding the function of the line more effectively.

qas.question: What should be ensured before configuring any Nyquist appliances?

answers.text: Before configuring any Nyquist appliances, it is essential to ensure that the appliance firmware is updated to the latest release. The latest firmware release can be obtained from the secured ES Dealers website.

The Firmware page contains a Check for Updates button that allows

exist.

On the Firmware page, select Check For Updates.
A popup window appears with one of the following 
messages:
•No firmware dates available
•Can’t check for updates, check Internet connection, 
and try again

If the system attempts to download a firmware

again.

When prompted, select OK.

2.5.6
Setting Default Firmware
Through the Firmware page, you can set a firmware file as the default 
firmware for any new stations added to your Nyquist system.
To set a default firmware file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Firmware.
Step 2
On the Firmware page, select the Set as Default Firm-
ware icon next to a listed filename.
Warning
Completing this procedure will set the selected firm-
ware file as the default firmware for all new devices,
overriding the factory installed firmware. Ensure that
the selected firmware version is compatible with your
server’s software version. To use some appliances, you
may need to update your server software.
Step 3
Select Yes to continue.

Downloading Firmware to a Device
To download firmware from the Nyquist system server to a station:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Firmware.
Step 2
On the Firmware page, select the Device Selection 
icon next to a listed filename.
Step 3
Select the Update icon next to the device that you are 
updating firmware for.
2.5.8
Editing Firmware
You can edit Notes for firmware, but you cannot change the File-
name or Added Date information.
To edit notes for firmware:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Firmware.
Step 2
Select the Edit icon next to the desired firmware file.
Step 3
Make changes to the Notes parameter.
Step 4
Select Save.

qas.question: What is the first step to select devices for a firmware update?

answers.text: The first step to select devices for a firmware update is to select "Firmware" on the navigation bar. This will take you to the Firmware page, where you can then select the Device Selection icon next to the desired firmware version.

qas.question: How can you set a firmware file as the default for new stations?

answers.text: To set a firmware file as the default for new stations, navigate to the Firmware page and select the 'Set as Default Firmware' icon next to the desired firmware filename. Confirm the action by selecting "Yes" to override the factory-installed firmware, ensuring the selected version is compatible with your server's software.

qas.question: What should you verify before setting a firmware file as the default firmware?

answers.text: Before setting a firmware file as the default firmware, you should verify that the selected firmware version is compatible with your server’s software version. Additionally, ensure that you are aware that this action will override the factory-installed firmware for all new devices.

qas.question: How do you download firmware from the Nyquist system server to a station?

answers.text: To download firmware from the Nyquist system server to a station, select Firmware on the navigation bar, then click the Device Selection icon next to a listed filename. Finally, select the Update icon next to the device you are updating firmware for.

qas.question: What information can you edit for firmware in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: In the Nyquist system, you can edit the Notes parameter for firmware but cannot change the Filename or Added Date information. To edit, you need to select the Edit icon next to the desired firmware file and then make your changes before selecting Save.

qas.question: Is it possible to change the filename or added date for a firmware file?

answers.text: No, it is not possible to change the filename or added date for a firmware file. You can only edit the Notes parameter associated with the firmware.

qas.question: What happens when you select the Update option for a device during a firmware update?

answers.text: When you select the Update option for a device during a firmware update, the selected firmware is downloaded from the Nyquist system server to that device. This process updates the device with the chosen firmware version, ensuring it operates with the most recent updates available.

qas.question: What is the consequence of overriding the factory installed firmware by setting a new default firmware?

answers.text: The consequence of overriding the factory installed firmware by setting a new default firmware is that it will apply the selected firmware version to all new devices added to the Nyquist system, which may not be compatible with the existing server software. This could potentially lead to operational issues if the new firmware does not support the features or functions required by the server.

qas.question: What constitutes a facility in the context of the Nyquist system?

answers.text: In the context of the Nyquist system, a facility refers to a building or group of buildings that are managed by a Nyquist system server. Facilities enable multi-site paging and calling features across connected locations, allowing for functionalities like emergency paging and intercom calls between different sites.

qas.question: What multi-site features can be provided by connecting multiple Nyquist facilities?

answers.text: Connecting multiple Nyquist facilities enables features such as Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call paging, Multi-Site All-Call paging, targeted paging to a specific facility, and intercom calls between stations across different facilities. These functionalities enhance communication capabilities across multiple locations managed by the Nyquist system.

qas.question: How can you page all connected facilities in the Facilities list?

answers.text: To page all connected facilities in the Facilities list, use the Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call paging feature or the Multi-Site All-Call paging feature available within the Nyquist system. Ensure that the facilities are properly connected in the Facilities list to utilize these features effectively.

qas.question: Where can you find information about the Facilities list in the documentation?

qas.question: What are the features provided by connecting multiple Nyquist facilities?

answers.text: Connecting multiple Nyquist facilities enables multi-site paging and calling features, including Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call and All-Call paging to all connected facilities. It also allows for paging to specific facilities and intercom calls between stations in different facilities.

qas.question: Which DTMF code is used for Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call paging?

answers.text: The DTMF code used for Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call paging is ##0911. This code requires the necessary CoS permissions for Emergency All-Call and Multi-Site Paging.

qas.question: What is the maximum length for a facility name in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The maximum length for a facility name in the Nyquist system is 30 characters. Spaces in the name are replaced by dashes.

qas.question: How can a facility determine if it is enabled for registration with remote facilities?

answers.text: A facility can determine if it is enabled for registration with remote facilities by checking the "Enabled" field on the Facilities page. If this field indicates that the facility is enabled, it will register with the remote facility; otherwise, it will not.

qas.question: What does the status "Registration request sent; remote not registered" indicate?

answers.text: The status "Registration request sent; remote not registered" indicates that a connection attempt has been made from the local facility to the remote facility, but the remote facility has not completed the registration process. This status signifies that the two facilities are not yet interconnected and cannot communicate.

qas.question: What permissions are required for performing a Multi-Site All-Call page?

answers.text: To perform a Multi-Site All-Call page, the required CoS permissions are All-Call Paging and Multi-Site Paging. The DTMF syntax for this activity is ##0.

qas.question: What is the maximum password length for connecting to a remote facility?

answers.text: The maximum password length for connecting to a remote facility is 12 characters. This password is used for the remote connection between facilities.

qas.question: How do you perform an Intercom call to a remote facility using DTMF?

answers.text: To perform an Intercom call to a remote facility using DTMF, you need to enter the syntax ##*<Facility Number>*<Station Extension Number>, replacing <Facility Number> with the specific facility's ID and <Station Extension Number> with the desired station's extension number. Ensure you have the required inter-facility call/page permissions enabled.

qas.question: What parameters are displayed on the Facilities page?

answers.text: The Facilities page displays the following parameters: ID number for the facility, facility name (with spaces replaced by dashes), enabled status for registration, host name or IP address of the remote server, password for remote connection, and the registration status of the local and remote facility peers. The maximum facility name length is 30 characters, and the maximum password length is 12 characters.

qas.question: Can multiple Nyquist servers have the same password for remote connections?

answers.text: Yes, multiple Nyquist servers can have the same password for remote connections, or you can set different passwords for each server. This flexibility allows for easier management of server connections within the Nyquist network.

Page #
ID number for facility that is used when paging the facility.
Name
Displays the facility name of the remote server. Spaces in

Enabled
Specifies if the facility will register with the remote facility.

Displays the host name or host IP address of the remote

Displays the password that is used for the remote connec-

Displays the registration status of the local and remote

• Registration request sent; remote not registered –

101
• Registered; remote not registered – Indicates that the 
local facility is registered with the remote facility but the 
remote facility is not registered with the local facility. 
This could be a temporary status captured during server 
startup, or it might result from the remote server not 
having the local facility properly configured.
• Timeout; remote not registered – Indicates that a con-
nection is not established between facilities. This is prob-
ably due to a network connection issue or the remote 
facility may be down.
• Timeout; remote 10.10.5.100 registered (OK (8 ms)) – 
Indicates that the remote facility has registered with the 
local facility and the connection is good, or OK, with 8 
millisecond turnaround time (one-way connection).
• Registered; remote 10.10.5.100 registered (OK (3 
ms)) – Indicates that the local facility has registered with 
the remote facility, the remote facility has registered with 
the local facility, and the connection is OK with 3 milli-
second turnaround time. This is the desired state.
• Rejected; remote not registered – Probably indicates 
that the remote facility has disabled the local facility’s 
configuration entry.
• Registered; remote 10.10.5.100 registered 
(UNREACHABLE) – Indicates that both ends are (or 
were) registered but the local facility cannot reach the 
remote. This is probably due to a network issue or the 
remote Nyquist system server is down.

qas.question: What page provides a quick view of the building served by the Nyquist system server?

qas.question: How can you access the Facilities page in the Nyquist server?

answers.text: To access the Facilities page in the Nyquist server, select "Facilities" from the navigation bar. This will display a quick view of the building or buildings served by your Nyquist system server.

qas.question: What is the maximum length for a facility name in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The maximum length for a facility name in the Nyquist system is 30 characters. Spaces in the name are replaced by dashes.

qas.question: What does the "Enabled" parameter signify for a facility on the Facilities page?

answers.text: The "Enabled" parameter indicates whether the facility will register with the remote facility. If enabled, the facility is configured to establish a connection and participate in communication with the remote facility.

qas.question: How many characters can the password for a remote connection have?

answers.text: The password for a remote connection can have a maximum length of 12 characters.

qas.question: What status indicates that a connection is not established between facilities?

answers.text: The status that indicates a connection is not established between facilities is "Registration request sent; remote not registered." This status means that the local facility has attempted to register but has not successfully connected with the remote facility.

qas.question: What does the status "Registered; remote not registered" mean?

answers.text: The status "Registered; remote not registered" indicates that the local facility is successfully registered with the remote facility, but the remote facility has not registered back with the local facility. This situation may occur temporarily during server startup or may indicate a configuration issue on the remote server.

qas.question: What steps are involved in editing a facility's parameters?

qas.question: Is it possible to delete a facility linked to a Facility-Page routine action type?

qas.question: What information does the "Host" field display on the Facilities page?

answers.text: The "Host" field displays the host name or IP address of the remote server associated with the facility. This information is essential for establishing the connection between the local and remote facilities.

104
3 Managing Stations, 
Zones, and Queues
105
Managing Stations, Zones, and 
Queues
You can divide your facility into zones to control paging and audio 
activities or features. For example, suppose you want to allow the use 
of an audio source, such as a flash drive, in a cafeteria but prevent it 
from being played in a conference room. This feature, called audio 
distribution, can be turned on by zone, so the cafeteria could be 
placed in a zone that allows audio distribution while conference 
rooms would not be placed into that zone.
No limit exists for the number of zones or for the number of stations 
that can be in a multicast zone. Performance limits do exist for unicast 
connections. The station limit for your system is determined by your 
license (see "NQ-E7000SSL – Nyquist E7000 System Station License” 
on page 486).
With the Page Queuing feature, you can record an unlimited number 
of pages or messages for queuing (stacking) for a specified zone or 
zones. A zone can only be added to a single queue, but a queue may 
have multiple zones associated with it. Zones must be created before 
a queue can be created.
A station can be in multiple zones.
An E7000 station is: 
• A device used to access the web interface
• A speaker
• A phone 
• A Nyquist appliance
Note: For licensing purposes, an I/O Controller is not counted as a 
station.

qas.question: What is the first step to add a facility in the Nyquist system?

qas.question: How do you specify if a facility will register with a remote facility?

qas.question: What replaces spaces in the name of the remote facility when entered?

answers.text: Spaces in the name of the remote facility are replaced by dashes. This formatting change occurs when entering the facility name in the Add Facility parameters.

qas.question: Can multiple zones be created within a facility?

answers.text: Yes, multiple zones can be created within a facility. There is no limit to the number of zones, allowing for flexible control of paging and audio distribution across different areas.

qas.question: What feature allows recording an unlimited number of pages or messages for queuing?

answers.text: The feature that allows recording an unlimited number of pages or messages for queuing is called Page Queuing. This feature enables messages to be stacked for specified zones, with the requirement that zones must be created before a queue can be established.

qas.question: How many zones can be associated with a single queue?

answers.text: A single queue can have multiple zones associated with it. However, each zone can only be added to one queue.

qas.question: What distinguishes an E7000 station from an I/O Controller in terms of licensing?

answers.text: An E7000 station is classified as a device that can access the web interface, such as a speaker, phone, or Nyquist appliance, and is counted for licensing purposes. In contrast, an I/O Controller is not considered a station and therefore does not count towards the station licensing limit.

qas.question: What types of devices are classified as E7000 stations?

answers.text: E7000 stations include devices such as speakers, phones, Nyquist appliances, and any device used to access the web interface. An I/O Controller is not counted as a station for licensing purposes.

qas.question: What must be created before a queue can be established?

answers.text: Zones must be created before a queue can be established. Each zone can only be added to a single queue, but a queue may have multiple zones associated with it.

qas.question: How is the station limit of the Nyquist system determined?

answers.text: The station limit of the Nyquist system is determined by your license, as specified in the documentation. Each license type may impose different restrictions on the number of stations that can be used within the system.

context:
3 Managing Stations, 
Zones, and Queues
105
Managing Stations, Zones, and 
Queues
You can divide your facility into zones to control paging and audio 
activities or features. For example, suppose you want to allow the use 
of an audio source, such as a flash drive, in a cafeteria but prevent it 
from being played in a conference room. This feature, called audio 
distribution, can be turned on by zone, so the cafeteria could be 
placed in a zone that allows audio distribution while conference 
rooms would not be placed into that zone.
No limit exists for the number of zones or for the number of stations 
that can be in a multicast zone. Performance limits do exist for unicast 
connections. The station limit for your system is determined by your 
license (see "NQ-E7000SSL – Nyquist E7000 System Station License” 
on page 486).
With the Page Queuing feature, you can record an unlimited number 
of pages or messages for queuing (stacking) for a specified zone or 
zones. A zone can only be added to a single queue, but a queue may 
have multiple zones associated with it. Zones must be created before 
a queue can be created.
A station can be in multiple zones.
An E7000 station is: 
• A device used to access the web interface
• A speaker
• A phone 
• A Nyquist appliance
Note: For licensing purposes, an I/O Controller is not counted as a 
station.
106
To manage stations and zones, you first add stations and then create 
zones that contain more than one station. You can add stations by 
allowing the Nyquist server to automatically discover the device type, 
MAC address, IP address, and serial number, or manually add these 
and other parameters. For more information about adding a station, 
see "Adding a Station” on page 153.
3.1
Viewing Station Configuration Settings
On the Stations page, you can:
• View all configured stations. 
• Edit a station’s configuration. (See "Editing Station Configuration 
Settings” on page 118.)
• Exclude a station from paging. (See "Excluding Stations from Pag-
ing” on page 162.)
• View station status. (See "Viewing Station Status” on page 164.)
• Add new stations. (See "Adding a Station” on page 153.)
• View the status of Nyquist appliances, such as the I/O controller. 
(See "Viewing Appliance Status” on page 166.)
• Delete a station. (See "Deleting a Station” on page 152.)
Figure 3-1, Stations Page

qas.question: What is the purpose of dividing a facility into zones?

answers.text: Dividing a facility into zones allows for controlled paging and audio activities, enabling certain audio sources to be played in specific areas while restricting them in others. For example, audio can be distributed in a cafeteria zone while being blocked in a conference room zone. This zonal management enhances functionality and flexibility in audio distribution.

qas.question: How does audio distribution work in a zone?

answers.text: Audio distribution in a zone allows specific audio sources, like a flash drive, to be played in designated areas, such as a cafeteria, while preventing playback in others, like a conference room. This feature is enabled on a per-zone basis, meaning different zones can have different audio permissions. Each zone can only be associated with one queue, but a queue can comprise multiple zones.

qas.question: Are there any limits on the number of zones or stations in a multicast zone?

answers.text: There are no limits on the number of zones or the number of stations that can be in a multicast zone. However, performance limits do exist for unicast connections, and the station limit is determined by your system's license.

qas.question: What determines the station limit for a system?

answers.text: The station limit for a system is determined by the system's license. Each license specifies the maximum number of stations that can be connected, while there is no limit on the number of zones or multicast stations.

qas.question: Can a single zone be part of multiple queues?

answers.text: No, a zone can only be added to a single queue; however, a queue may have multiple zones associated with it. This means while a zone is limited to one queue, a queue can include several zones.

qas.question: What types of devices can be classified as an E7000 station?

answers.text: An E7000 station can be classified as a device used to access the web interface, a speaker, a phone, or a Nyquist appliance. Notably, an I/O Controller is not counted as a station for licensing purposes.

qas.question: Is an I/O Controller counted as a station for licensing purposes?

answers.text: No, an I/O Controller is not counted as a station for licensing purposes. Only devices such as speakers, phones, and Nyquist appliances are considered stations in this context.

qas.question: What actions can be performed on the Stations page?

answers.text: On the Stations page, you can view all configured stations, edit their configuration, exclude a station from paging, check station status, add new stations, view the status of Nyquist appliances, and delete a station.

qas.question: How can new stations be added to the system?

answers.text: New stations can be added to the system either automatically by allowing the Nyquist server to discover the device type, MAC address, IP address, and serial number, or manually by entering these parameters and other necessary information. For detailed steps, refer to the section "Adding a Station" on page 153.

qas.question: What is the significance of creating zones before queues?

answers.text: Creating zones before queues is significant because a zone can only be added to a single queue, while a queue can have multiple zones associated with it. This structure ensures that audio distribution and paging functionalities can be tailored and managed effectively within specific areas of the facility.

3.2
Editing Station Configuration Settings
The Edit Station page allows you to change a station’s configuration 
settings. For example, if you want to disable paging for a station or 
change a station’s access to an outside line, you edit the station’s 
configuration settings. 
You cannot edit the configuration settings for a station linked to a 
routine (see "Using Routines” on page 381).
If the station Type is Admin Web Interface, Admin Phone, IP Phone, 
Analog Phone, or Mobile Device, you can set a default Announce-
ment Zone and the Announcement Zone Configuration Type. If 
the Announcement Zone Configuration Type is set to Fixed, the 
zone used to play announcements will always be the zone number 
provided for Announcement Zone and cannot be changed. If set to 
Default, the Announcement Zone value is used as the default zone, 
but you can set an announcement to play to another zone.
If the station that you are editing is an I/O device, you can select to 
Configure Rules (see "Configuring I/O Controller Input Rules” on

qas.question: What steps are involved in managing stations and zones?

answers.text: To manage stations and zones, first, add stations—either through automatic discovery by the Nyquist server or by manually inputting parameters such as MAC address and device type. After stations are configured, create zones that group multiple stations together for more efficient management. For further configuration and management options, refer to specific sections on viewing, editing, and excluding stations.

qas.question: How can you view all configured stations on the Stations page?

answers.text: To view all configured stations on the Stations page, select "Stations" from the navigation bar. This will display a list of all the stations that have been added and configured in the system.

qas.question: What is the valid range for extension numbers assigned to stations?

answers.text: The valid range for extension numbers assigned to stations is from 030 to 899 for three-digit dialing. Extensions 900 to 999 are reserved by Nyquist features and should not be assigned to stations.

qas.question: Which special characters are allowed in the station name?

answers.text: The allowed special characters in the station name include: !@$*?-.,. The station name can have up to 16 characters in length, using uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), and spaces.

qas.question: What options are available for configuring the action when adding a new station?

answers.text: When adding a new station, the available action option is to select "Swap," which allows you to switch a discovered appliance for a previously added appliance that needs to be removed, such as in cases where the old device has malfunctioned and is being replaced. Other configuration parameters include specifying the station's extension, name, description, type, and device type, among others.

qas.question: What types of stations can be added to the configuration?

answers.text: The station types that can be added to the configuration include Admin Phone, Admin Web Interface, Web Interface, IP Phone, Mobile Device, VoIP Speaker Only, Analog Call Switch & Speaker, Digital Call Switch & Speaker, Analog Phone, DISA Line, 911 Line, I/O Controller, Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp, Paging-Audio Amp, Ambient Noise Sensor, and Push-To-Talk Microphone. Each type has specific restrictions and capabilities associated with it.

qas.question: How does the Nyquist system identify the physical device used by a station?

answers.text: The Nyquist system identifies the physical device used by a station through the "Device Type" parameter, which specifies the type of device, such as Analog-Port, IP Phone, or various Nyquist amplifiers. This information is important for determining the capabilities and configuration applicable to the station.

qas.question: When is the MAC address field displayed in the station configuration?

answers.text: The MAC address field is displayed in the station configuration when adding or editing stations, except for the Admin Web Interface and DISA Line types. It specifies the Media Access Control (MAC) address, which is a unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications on the physical network segment.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Day CoS and Night CoS fields in station settings?

answers.text: The Day CoS (Class of Service) and Night CoS fields in station settings define the permissions granted to the station during daytime and nighttime hours, respectively. These settings control the features and access levels available to the station based on the time of day, helping to manage call handling and station functionality effectively.

qas.question: What determines whether a station can place outside calls?

answers.text: A station's ability to place outside calls is determined by the Outside Access permissions assigned to it, which can range from No Access to Unrestricted. These parameters dictate the conditions under which the station can make external calls.

qas.question: Which parameter identifies the facility where a station is installed?

answers.text: The parameter that identifies the facility where a station is installed is labeled "Facility." This parameter allows users to specify the location or name of the facility associated with the station in the system.

qas.question: How do you configure the Announcement Zone for a station?

answers.text: To configure the Announcement Zone for a station, navigate to the Edit Station page for the desired station type (Admin Web Interface, Admin Phone, IP Phone, Analog Phone, or Mobile Device). Set the Announcement Zone value, and choose the Announcement Zone Configuration Type as either Fixed (cannot be changed later) or Default (can be altered for specific announcements).

qas.question: What is the role of the Registration Password in the station configuration?

answers.text: The Registration Password in the station configuration is used for SIP device registration, allowing the station to securely connect to the network. The default password is "bogen," and it must be confirmed upon entry to ensure accuracy.

qas.question: What options can be selected for VLAN configuration?

answers.text: For VLAN configuration, the options that can be selected are: **Server**, **Network/Device**, or **Disable**. Additionally, the VLAN ID can range from 2 to 4094, and VLAN Priority values range from 0 to 7.

qas.question: Which conditions prevent a station from being added to a zone?

answers.text: A station cannot be added to a zone if it is an analog phone, as these devices are specifically prohibited from being included in zones. Additionally, if the station is linked to a routine, its configuration settings cannot be edited, which may prevent zone inclusion.

qas.question: How can audio distribution to all speakers be controlled for a station?

answers.text: Audio distribution to all speakers for a station can be controlled by a specific setting in the station's configuration. If this setting is enabled, the station can receive audio distribution played to all stations, while audio distribution played to zones will still be received if the station is part of an audio zone.

qas.question: What does the Call Recording option do in station settings?

answers.text: The Call Recording option in station settings determines whether all calls made to and from the station are recorded. It is not available for I/O Controllers or Matrix Mixer Pre-Amps, and enables the capture of call audio for documentation or monitoring purposes.

qas.question: How can you enable or disable paging for a station?

answers.text: To enable or disable paging for a station, you need to edit the station's configuration settings on the Edit Station page. Find the Paging option and set it to either On or Off, depending on your preference.

qas.question: What happens if the firmware parameter is left empty for a connected appliance?

answers.text: If the firmware parameter is left empty for a connected appliance, the appliance will not undergo an automatic firmware update. This means it will continue to operate with the currently installed firmware, regardless of whether a newer version is available on the Nyquist server.

qas.question: Which parameters related to voicemail are available when adding a new station?

answers.text: When adding a new station, the parameters related to voicemail available include the Voicemail Password, which is used to access voicemail, and the Voicemail Password Confirmation, where the user must re-type the voicemail password. These fields can contain numeric characters only.

The Edit Station page allows you to change a station’s configuration 
settings. For example, if you want to disable paging for a station or 
change a station’s access to an outside line, you edit the station’s 
configuration settings.

Default, the Announcement Zone value is used as the default zone, 
but you can set an announcement to play to another zone.

3.2.1
Viewing I/O Controller Configuration Rules
The I/O Controller allows Nyquist to recognize third-party switch 
contact closures and to provide external circuits. Configuration rules 
can be set for each input and output port on an I/O Controller, so, for 
example, you can set a rule that if a contact is opened than an alarm 
sounds or set a rule that if a doorbell rings, an Admin user can trigger 
another rule that opens the door.
To view the configuration rules for an I/O Controller:
Step 1
From the navigation bar, select Stations.
Step 2
Select the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller.
Step 3
On the Edit Station page, select Configure Rules.
Figure 3-3, Configure Controller Rules Page

qas.question: What types of devices allow setting a default Announcement Zone and Configuration Type?

answers.text: Devices that allow setting a default Announcement Zone and Announcement Zone Configuration Type include Admin Web Interface, Admin Phone, IP Phone, Analog Phone, and Mobile Device. The configuration can be set to either Fixed or Default, affecting how announcements are played in relation to the specified zone.

qas.question: What happens if the Announcement Zone Configuration Type is set to Fixed?

answers.text: If the Announcement Zone Configuration Type is set to Fixed, the zone used to play announcements will always be the zone number provided for the Announcement Zone and cannot be changed. This means that all announcements will only be played through the designated zone without the option to redirect them to another zone.

qas.question: Can you edit the configuration settings for a station linked to a routine?

answers.text: No, you cannot edit the configuration settings for a station that is linked to a routine. The option to edit these settings is disabled for such stations.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the External Relay Trigger setting?

answers.text: The External Relay Trigger setting specifies whether the device should activate an external relay when audio is present. This feature is applicable only to specific VoIP Speaker Gen2 CallSwitch devices.

qas.question: What additional configuration options are available for an MMPA when editing its settings?

answers.text: When editing the settings for an MMPA, you can select to configure the mixer. This allows for adjustments specific to the mixing settings related to the Push To Talk functionality.

qas.question: How can a user view the I/O Controller configuration rules?

answers.text: To view the I/O Controller configuration rules, navigate to the Stations section and select the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller. Then, on the Edit Station page, select "Configure Rules."

qas.question: What steps are necessary to edit a station's configuration settings?

answers.text: To edit a station's configuration settings, select "Stations" from the navigation bar, then click the Edit icon for the desired station. Make the desired changes and select "Save" to apply the modifications.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Description parameter for a station?

answers.text: The Description parameter allows users to input a custom identifier or purpose for the station, facilitating easier management and differentiation among multiple stations within the system. This helps in quickly understanding the function or role of the station at a glance.

qas.question: How do you access the Configure Rules option for an I/O Controller?

answers.text: To access the Configure Rules option for an I/O Controller, first select Stations from the navigation bar, then click the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller. On the Edit Station page, select Configure Rules to view and set the configuration rules.

qas.question: What happens when you select Save after making changes to a station's settings?

answers.text: When you select Save after making changes to a station's settings, the updated configuration settings are applied to the station. This allows for modifications such as disabling paging or changing access to outside lines to take effect immediately.

ple, fire alarms) to disable all Nyquist audio, which

Note: This contact closure action will only initiate the dis-
abling of audio, it will not restore the audio. To restore

Phone.

available actions, but you do want to close a contact, 
create a dashboard message, or send an email when the 
contact is closed.

performing the same action as when the Enable Audio 
button is selected on the dashboard.

contact occurs.

Provides a list of stations that can manually control the out-
put contact.

to appear.

qas.question: What is the first step to edit a station’s configuration settings?

answers.text: The first step to edit a station’s configuration settings is to select "Stations" from the navigation bar. Then, you need to select the Edit icon for the station you want to edit.

qas.question: How can you view the configuration rules for an I/O Controller?

answers.text: To view the configuration rules for an I/O Controller, select "Stations" from the navigation bar, then click the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller. On the Edit Station page, select "Configure Rules" to access and review the configuration settings.

qas.question: What actions can be triggered when a contact is closed on the I/O Controller?

answers.text: When a contact is closed on the I/O Controller, the following actions can be triggered: audio distribution to all stations, playing an alarm or announcement, disabling or enabling audio in the Nyquist system, sending dashboard messages or emails, and starting or stopping calls or pages. Additional options include triggering a tone or other specified actions based on the user configuration.

qas.question: What does the "Close Interval" parameter signify in the Input Contact Rule?

answers.text: The "Close Interval" parameter in the Input Contact Rule indicates the duration, measured in milliseconds, that the contact remains open before triggering the associated input action. This allows for a delay in response to prevent false alarms from brief contact openings.

qas.question: Which parameter specifies how the action is stopped in the I/O Controller?

answers.text: The parameter that specifies how the action is stopped in the I/O Controller is called **Stop On**. It can be set to either **Manual Control**, requiring manual intervention to stop the action, or **Contact Open**, which automatically stops the action when the contact is opened.

qas.question: What happens when the "Disable-Audio" action is activated?

answers.text: When the "Disable-Audio" action is activated, it disables all audio in the Nyquist system, which includes audio distribution, tones, alarms, and paging. This action is executed by an external emergency system, such as a fire alarm, and will not restore audio; a different contact or method must be used to enable audio again.

qas.question: How can a user set a rule for an input contact related to doorbell events?

answers.text: To set a rule for an input contact related to doorbell events, a user should configure an I/O Controller input rule by selecting the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller, then selecting the Edit icon for the specific input contact associated with the doorbell. The user can define the action to be taken when the doorbell is pressed, such as triggering an alarm or sending an announcement.

qas.question: Which dashboard scope options are available for messages in the system?

answers.text: The available dashboard scope options for messages in the system are: "All," which sends the message to all web interface dashboards, and "Admin," which restricts the message to only Admin web interface dashboards.

qas.question: What does the "Duration" parameter indicate for output contacts?

answers.text: The "Duration" parameter for output contacts indicates the length of time (in milliseconds) that the contact remains closed. A value of 0 means the contact will remain closed indefinitely until it is manually opened or another action is taken.

qas.question: How can you configure an output rule for an I/O Controller?

answers.text: To configure an output rule for an I/O Controller, navigate to the Stations section and select the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller. On the Edit Station page, select Configure Rules, then choose the Edit icon for the output contact you want to configure and complete the necessary parameters before selecting Save.

qas.question: What options are available for specifying which devices receive dashboard messages?

answers.text: You can specify which devices receive dashboard messages by selecting the Dashboard Scope, with options including "All" (all web interface dashboards will receive the message) or "Admin" (only Admin web interface dashboards will receive the message).

qas.question: What distinguishes the "Action ID" parameter from other parameters in the context of alarms and tones?

answers.text: The "Action ID" parameter specifically identifies the alarm or tone file to be played when a corresponding action is triggered (e.g., Alarm, Announcement, or Tone actions). Unlike other parameters, it uniquely links the action to a specific audio file, enabling precise control over audio responses in the I/O Controller rules.

qas.question: In what way can you control audio behavior in the Nyquist system through contact closures?

answers.text: You can control audio behavior in the Nyquist system through contact closures by enabling or disabling audio using specific actions. For instance, you can use the "Disable-Audio" action to mute all audio in the system and the "Enable-Audio" action to restore it. Additionally, you can initiate audio distribution to all stations when a contact is closed, but the system cannot stop the audio; it requires a separate action to do so.

qas.question: What does the "Email" parameter accomplish in the context of I/O contact closures?

answers.text: The "Email" parameter specifies an email address for notification when an I/O contact is closed. This allows for timely alerts or updates to be sent to designated recipients whenever a specific contact closure event occurs.

qas.question: What are the options for how an action can be defined in the output section of the I/O Controller?

answers.text: In the output section of the I/O Controller, actions can be defined as: starting or stopping a call to 911; controlling audio distribution; initiating alarms, announcements, or tones; managing all-call pages; and enabling or disabling audio in the Nyquist system. Each action can be set to automatically close when the corresponding system activity begins and open when it ends.

qas.question: How can the "Close Button Label" and "Open Button Label" be utilized in the dashboard?

answers.text: The "Close Button Label" and "Open Button Label" are user-provided titles that appear on the dashboard for controlling output contacts. These buttons function as manual controls, allowing users to easily close or open the specified output contact if the duration for the contact closure is set to 0, thereby enabling quick access to these actions.

Displays if the contact is an input or output contact. This 
parameter is automatically set and cannot be edited.
Extension
Displays the station extension. This parameter is automati-
cally set and cannot be edited.

qas.question: How many input rules can be configured for each I/O Controller?

answers.text: You can configure eight input rules for each I/O Controller. This allows for customized actions based on the specific input contacts available.

qas.question: What is the procedure to access the Edit Station page for an I/O Controller?

answers.text: To access the Edit Station page for an I/O Controller, first select "Stations" from the navigation bar. Then, click the Edit icon next to the desired I/O Controller.

qas.question: What parameter must be set to 0 for the Close Button Label to appear?

answers.text: The duration for the contact must be set to 0 for the Close Button Label to appear. This means that the contact will remain closed indefinitely, allowing the label to be displayed on the Dashboard.

qas.question: In the context of output rules, what does the Email parameter specify?

answers.text: The Email parameter specifies the email address for notification when an I/O contact is closed. It allows users to receive alerts via email regarding the status of the output contact.

qas.question: What action does the Disable-Audio option perform when triggered?

answers.text: The Disable-Audio option disables all audio in the Nyquist system, similar to the action taken when the Disable Audio button on the dashboard is selected. This action can be triggered by an external emergency system, such as fire alarms, but it does not restore audio; a different action must be used to enable audio again.

qas.question: Which setting determines when an action is automatically stopped when using a contact?

answers.text: The setting that determines when an action is automatically stopped when using a contact is "Stop On." The options available for this setting are "Manual Control," which requires manual intervention to stop the action, and "Contact Open," which automatically stops the action when the contact is opened.

qas.question: Can the Name and Description parameters for a contact be edited after they are set?

answers.text: Yes, the Name and Description parameters for a contact can be edited after they are set. These parameters are user-provided and not automatically generated, allowing for updates as needed.

qas.question: What are the available options for the Dashboard Style parameter?

answers.text: The available options for the Dashboard Style parameter are Basic, Success, Info, Warning, and Danger. These options determine the icon and color coding that accompany the dashboard message.

qas.question: How does the duration of a contact closure affect the associated action?

answers.text: The duration of a contact closure determines how long the associated action remains active. A value of 0 leaves the contact closed, maintaining the action indefinitely, while a specified duration in milliseconds dictates the time the contact will stay open before triggering the action. For certain actions, like audio or alarms, this can impact how long those functions will persist before needing manual intervention or reset.

qas.question: What specifies which devices receive a dashboard message?

answers.text: The parameter that specifies which devices receive a dashboard message is called "Dashboard Scope." It offers options such as "All," which sends the message to all web interface dashboards, and "Admin," which restricts the message to only Admin web interface dashboards.

qas.question: What type of action is initiated when the contact closure action "Other" is selected?

answers.text: When the contact closure action "Other" is selected, it allows for a contact to be closed without taking one of the predefined actions. This option can be used to create a dashboard message, send an email, or execute specific logic as desired by the user.

qas.question: In the context of input rules, how is the Zones parameter defined?

answers.text: In the context of input rules, the Zones parameter provides a list of paging zones that trigger an output. If left blank, the rule affects all zones, but this field does not appear if the Action is set to Page.

Action
Select the Nyquist system activity that will close the output 
contact when the activity starts and open the output con-
tact when the activity stops. 
Note: If duration is greater than 0, the output contact 
opens after duration milliseconds even if the system activity 
is still ongoing. When a system activity is started, the output 
contact is closed; the contact is opened when the system 
activity ends.e
Options are:
• 911 – Starts or stops a call to 911.
• Audio – Starts or stops audio distribution to all stations 
(using previously selected playlist or matrix mixer input 
channel).
• Alarm – Starts or stops the alarm file selected as the 
Action ID.
• Announcement – Starts or stops the announcement file 
selected as the Action ID.
• All-Call – Starts or stops an All-Call page.

page.

site Emergency-A ll-Call page.
• Emergency-Call –Starts or stops an Emergency Call.
• Emergency-All-Call – Starts or stops an Emergency-All-
Call page.
• Hourly – Specifies the minutes and seconds when the 
Action occurs.
• Audio-Disabled – Disables or enables all audio in the 
Nyquist system. Contact is closed when audio is dis-
abled; open when audio is enabled. 
• No Action – Is the default action for outputs that have 
yet been configured.
• Page – Starts or stops a zone page.
• Tone – Starts or stops the tone file selected as the 
Action ID.
• Manual – Creates a dashboard button that can be used 
to manually close or open specified output contact.

nected to a doorbell that, when pressed, sends a dashboard message 
to Admin Stations that someone wants to gain access through a 
secured door. You or other Admin users can then select an Activate 
button that unlocks the door and allows entry to the secured area.
In this example, the dry contact connection of the doorbell would be 
wired to an I/O Controller input terminal and the secured door’s relay 
On Time

qas.question: How many output rules can be configured for each I/O Controller?

answers.text: You can configure eight output rules for each I/O Controller. This allows for a variety of actions and notifications to be assigned to each output contact.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the "Enabled" parameter in the output contact rule?

answers.text: The "Enabled" parameter in the output contact rule determines whether the rule is active for the specified output contact. Selecting this option ensures that the defined actions will be executed when the conditions of the rule are met.

qas.question: Which option specifies the icon and color coding for the message in the dashboard style?

answers.text: The option that specifies the icon and color coding for the message in the dashboard style includes five choices: Basic, Success, Info, Warning, and Danger. These options allow for visual differentiation of messages based on their context or urgency.

qas.question: What happens when a dry contact connection is activated in relation to a secured door?

answers.text: When a dry contact connection, such as a doorbell, is activated, it sends a dashboard message to Admin Stations indicating that someone wants to gain access through the secured door. Admin users can then select an Activate button to unlock the door, allowing entry to the secured area.

qas.question: What options are available for the action that closes and opens the output contact?

answers.text: The available options for the action that closes and opens the output contact include 911, Audio, Alarm, Announcement, All-Call, Multi-Site-All-Call, Emergency-Call, Emergency-All-Call, Hourly, Audio-Disabled, No Action, Page, Tone, and Manual. Each option corresponds to specific system activities that trigger the contact's closure or opening based on the defined parameters.

qas.question: How can you specify the days of the week for hourly closure in the output contact rule?

answers.text: To specify the days of the week for hourly closure in the output contact rule, set the Action to "Hourly." Then, you can specify the desired days of the week using the Days parameter, which appears only when the Action is set to Hourly.

qas.question: What parameter must be set to 0 for a dashboard button label to appear for closing or opening an output contact?

answers.text: The duration parameter must be set to 0 for a dashboard button label to appear for closing or opening an output contact. When set to 0, the contact remains closed, allowing the associated button label to be displayed on the dashboard.

qas.question: How does the duration parameter affect the closure of the output contact?

answers.text: The duration parameter specifies the length of time, in milliseconds, that the output contact remains closed after a system activity starts. If the duration is greater than 0, the output contact will automatically open after the specified duration, even if the system activity is still ongoing.

qas.question: Which parameter specifies the email address for notifications when an I/O contact is closed?

answers.text: The parameter that specifies the email address for notifications when an I/O contact is closed is labeled "Email."

qas.question: What is the effect of selecting "Audio-Disabled" as an action in the output contact rule?

answers.text: Selecting "Audio-Disabled" as an action in the output contact rule will close the output contact when audio is disabled and open it when audio is enabled. This action effectively manages the audio distribution within the Nyquist system, controlling when audio output occurs based on the audio state.

driver would be wired to an I/O Controller’s output terminal. (Refer to

Follow the steps for configuring an I/O Controller Input Configure 
Rule (see "Configuring I/O Controller Input Rules” on page 126) using 
the following parameters:
• For Close Interval, enter how long (in milliseconds) the input 
contact must remain closed before the input action is triggered. 
• For Action, select Other.
• For Close Extension, select that extension, or station number, 
for the I/O Controller connected to the output contact that, 
when closed, will open the door.
• For Close Contact, select the Output Contact # that is to be 
closed when Activate is pressed on the dashboard message.
• For Duration, enter the number of milliseconds required for the 
door open circuit to open the door.
• For Dashboard Type, select io-contact.
• For Dashboard Title, enter a title for the dashboard popup 
message (for example, Front Door).
• For Dashboard Text, enter the message that you want dis-
played on the dashboard popup message (for example, Front 
doorbell activated; press “Activate” to open the front door.
• For Dashboard Style, select basic.
When configured properly, the doorbell sounds and a message 
appears when the doorbell is pressed.

135
If you select Activate, the door opens. If you select Ignore, the door 
remains closed and the popup message disappears.
3.2.4
Viewing an I/O Controller Schedule
You can view all contact closures set for specific dates and times 
using the Configure Schedule button on the I/O Controller’s Edit Sta-
tion page. For information about scheduling a output contact event, 
see "Adding an I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule” on page 136.
To view contact closure schedules for an I/O Controller:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Stations.
Step 2
Select the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller.
Step 3
On the Edit Station page, select Configure Schedule.
The I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page appears.

qas.question: What is the purpose of connecting a doorbell to an I/O Controller in the context of secured access?

answers.text: Connecting a doorbell to an I/O Controller enables the notification of Admin Stations when someone requests access through a secured door. This system allows Admin users to remotely unlock the door by pressing an "Activate" button, facilitating controlled and secure entry to restricted areas.

qas.question: How is the duration for the contact closure set when configuring the I/O Controller?

answers.text: The duration for the contact closure is set by entering the number of milliseconds required for the action in the Duration parameter when configuring the I/O Controller. If a value of 0 is entered, it leaves the contact closed indefinitely.

qas.question: What parameters must be entered to configure an I/O Controller Input Configure Rule?

answers.text: To configure an I/O Controller Input Configure Rule, you must enter the Close Interval (in milliseconds), select an Action (set to Other), specify the Close Extension (station number), choose the Close Contact (Output Contact #), set the Duration (milliseconds for door opening), define the Dashboard Type (io-contact), and provide the Dashboard Title and Text.

qas.question: What happens when the "Activate" button is selected on the dashboard message after the doorbell is pressed?

answers.text: When the "Activate" button is selected on the dashboard message after the doorbell is pressed, the I/O Controller initiates the closure of the designated output contact, which opens the secured door. The door then remains open for the duration specified in the configured parameters.

qas.question: How can an Admin user control which paging zones trigger the output contact closure?

answers.text: An Admin user can control which paging zones trigger the output contact closure by specifying the desired zones in the "Zones" parameter when the Action is set to Page. If this parameter is left blank, any started paging zones will trigger the output contact closure.

qas.question: What is the significance of setting the Close Interval in the I/O Controller configuration?

answers.text: The Close Interval in the I/O Controller configuration defines the minimum duration (in milliseconds) that the input contact must remain closed before triggering the corresponding action. This parameter ensures that brief or accidental closures do not inadvertently activate the system, providing more reliable control over the output actions, such as unlocking a secured door.

qas.question: How can users view a schedule of contact closures for a specific I/O Controller?

answers.text: Users can view a schedule of contact closures for a specific I/O Controller by selecting "Stations" on the navigation bar, clicking the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller, and then selecting "Configure Schedule" on the Edit Station page. This will display the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule, showing contact details such as their state and activity time.

qas.question: What information is displayed in the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page?

answers.text: The I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page displays the assigned contact number, user-provided description, enabled status of contact activities, current state (open or closed), and the time for changing the contact event in HH:MM:SS format. This information allows users to manage and monitor scheduled contact activities effectively.

qas.question: What action does the I/O Controller take when the Close Contact is activated?

answers.text: When the Close Contact is activated on the I/O Controller, it triggers the output contact to close, allowing the door to open. This action is initiated when the corresponding dashboard "Activate" button is pressed after the doorbell is rung.

qas.question: Which options can be specified for the Dashboard Title and Dashboard Text when configuring an I/O Controller?

answers.text: When configuring an I/O Controller, the Dashboard Title can be any custom title for the dashboard popup message, such as "Front Door." The Dashboard Text can include a message displayed in the popup, like "Front doorbell activated; press 'Activate' to open the front door."

3.2.5
Adding an I/O Contacts Output Daily 
Schedule
Contact closures can be set for specific dates and times using the 
Configure Schedule button on the I/O Controller’s Edit Station page. 
For example, suppose you want to schedule an output that unlocks a 
door at 7:30 each weekday morning. You can set up an output con-
tact closure schedule for 7:30 am Monday through Friday. When the 
Activity Time occurs, the contact is closed, which in turn triggers a 
third-party contact switch that closes the door.
Days
Displays the day or days of the week that the event is to be 
executed.
Duration
Displays the duration of the contact closure in milliseconds. 
A value of 0 means that the contact remains closed until an 
open event occurs.
