qas.question: What options are available when prompted to activate a door in the Station Supervision context?

answers.text: When prompted to activate a door in the Station Supervision context, the available options are to select "Activate," which opens the door, or "Ignore," which keeps the door closed and dismisses the popup message.

qas.question: How can you view the contact closure schedules for an I/O Controller?

answers.text: To view the contact closure schedules for an I/O Controller, select "Stations" on the navigation bar, click the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller, and then select "Configure Schedule" on the Edit Station page. This will take you to the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page where you can review the contact closures.

qas.question: What does the "Enabled" indicator represent on the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page?

answers.text: The "Enabled" indicator on the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page signifies whether a contact activity event is active or disabled. If the indicator shows that the event is enabled, the scheduled action will occur as planned; if disabled, the event will not trigger.

qas.question: How is the "Activity Time" formatted on the schedule page?

answers.text: The "Activity Time" on the schedule page is formatted in HH:MM:SS format, representing the time to change the contact event.

qas.question: In what scenario would you need to set up an I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule?

answers.text: You would need to set up an I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule to automate actions, such as unlocking a door at a specific time each day (e.g., 7:30 am Monday through Friday). This scheduling enables the system to trigger a contact closure event, effectively operating a connected device, like a door lock, without manual intervention.

qas.question: What does a duration value of 0 signify for a contact closure?

answers.text: A duration value of 0 for a contact closure means that the contact will remain closed until an open event occurs. This indicates that there is no predefined time limit for how long the closure will be active.

qas.question: Where can you find the button to Configure Schedule for an I/O Controller?

answers.text: You can find the Configure Schedule button on the I/O Controller's Edit Station page. To access it, select Stations from the navigation bar and then click the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller.

qas.question: What is displayed in the "State" column of the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule?

answers.text: The "State" column of the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule displays whether the contact closure is currently open or closed. This indicates the current status of the contact activity event.

qas.question: Can the contact number be modified by the user on the schedule page?

answers.text: No, the contact number cannot be modified by the user on the schedule page. It is automatically set and remains fixed.

qas.question: What button is used to configure the schedule for I/O contacts on the Edit Station page?

answers.text: The button used to configure the schedule for I/O contacts on the Edit Station page is labeled "Configure Schedule." By selecting this button, you can access the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page to manage output contact closures.

qas.question: How can you schedule an output contact closure for unlocking a door at a specific time?

answers.text: To schedule an output contact closure for unlocking a door at a specific time, navigate to the I/O Controller’s Edit Station page, select Configure Schedule, and then use the Add icon to set the contact event for 7:30 am on the desired weekdays. Complete the necessary parameters, including enabling the contact and defining the duration, then select Save to finalize the schedule.

qas.question: What does a duration value of 0 signify in the contact closure schedule?

answers.text: A duration value of 0 in the contact closure schedule signifies that the contact remains closed indefinitely until an open event occurs. This means the contact will stay in the "on" state until explicitly reset or opened by another action.

qas.question: Which days can be selected for scheduling an output event?

answers.text: The days that can be selected for scheduling an output event are Monday through Friday, or any specific day(s) of the week as needed. The days are adjusted by entering the desired options in the configuration settings on the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page.

qas.question: What steps are involved in adding an output daily schedule for an I/O contact?

answers.text: To add an output daily schedule for an I/O contact, navigate to Stations and select the Edit icon for the desired I/O Controller. Then, on the Edit Station page, click Configure Schedule, select the Add icon on the I/O Contacts Output Daily Schedule page, complete the parameters in the Add I/O Contact Output Event page, and finally select Save.

qas.question: What parameters need to be completed on the Add I/O Contact Output Event page?

answers.text: The parameters to be completed on the Add I/O Contact Output Event page include selecting the contact number, enabling the contact activity event, choosing the state (On or Off), entering the activity time, specifying the duration in milliseconds, indicating the days of the week for execution, and providing a required description for the contact event.

qas.question: How can the daily schedule for an I/O contact be edited?

answers.text: To edit the daily schedule for an I/O contact, navigate to the "Stations" section and select the edit icon for the desired I/O Controller. Then, access "Configure Schedule," click the edit icon next to the specific contact, make the necessary changes on the Edit I/O Contact Output Event page, and select "Save."

qas.question: What options are available for the state of the output event?

answers.text: The options available for the state of the output event are "On," which means the contact is closed, and "Off," which means the contact is open.

qas.question: What are the two steps involved in configuring a device for Push To Talk?

answers.text: The two steps involved in configuring a device for Push To Talk are: first, enabling a Push To Talk Channel and selecting a Push To Talk Type through the Admin Web UI; second, enabling the Line Out for the selected channel via the appliance’s web UI.

qas.question: What should you do to enable a Push To Talk channel for a Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp in the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: To enable a Push To Talk channel for a Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp in the Admin Web UI, go to the Stations section, select the desired Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp using the Edit icon, and then choose "Configure PTT." From the Edit Push To Talk Configuration page, select the appropriate parameters and click "Save."

qas.question: Which options are available for the Push To Talk Type setting?

answers.text: The available options for the Push To Talk Type setting are: All-Call-Page, Emergency-All-Call-Page, DSP-Controlled, Zone-Page, and Record-Zone-Page.

qas.question: What happens to the PTT stream source for Mixer Output when the Push To Talk Type is set to Record-Zone-Page?

answers.text: When the Push To Talk Type is set to Record-Zone-Page, the PTT Stream Source for Mixer Output field does not appear, meaning that the option to select whether the PTT stream sent to the MMPA output is Analog or Network is unavailable. Additionally, the PTT Output parameter should be set to None unless live playback is desired.

qas.question: What are the possible selections for PTT Output when configuring Intercom Module?

answers.text: The possible selections for PTT Output when configuring the Intercom Module are: Both, Line-Out, None, and Speaker-Out. If the Push To Talk Type is set to Record-Zone-Page, the PTT Output should be set to None unless live playback is desired.

qas.question: What is required for the PTT Output setting to function correctly on a public address mixer/amplifier?

answers.text: For the PTT Output setting to function correctly on a public address mixer/amplifier, the Line-Out and Speaker-Out must be disabled on the appliance’s DSP Router. This is essential to ensure proper routing of the PTT signal.

qas.question: Which channel is the only available PTT channel for configuration?

answers.text: The only available Push To Talk (PTT) channel for configuration is Channel 4. This information is essential for setting up the PTT functionality in the system.

qas.question: What is the significance of the IP Address field in the Push To Talk configuration?

answers.text: The IP Address field in the Push To Talk configuration displays the known IP address of the mixer, allowing for easy identification and access to the mixer’s user interface through a Link button. If the Nyquist server is unable to discover the mixer’s IP address, the Link button will not be available.

qas.question: What are the steps to configure Push To Talk for a public address mixer amplifier?

answers.text: To configure Push To Talk for a public address mixer amplifier, go to the navigation bar, select Amplifier Devices, and then choose Configure PTT for the desired amplifier. Next, select the parameters from the Edit Push To Talk Configuration page and click Save. Ensure that the Line-Out and Speaker-Out are disabled on the appliance’s DSP Router for correct functionality.

Configuring Ambient Noise Sensor
The Ambient Noise Sensor ensures that page announcements and 
music are audible even during periods of high noise levels by contin-
uously monitoring the ambient noise level through a microphone 
module and adjusting the paging signal level for that area's amplifier 
channel. 
This feature requires that an ANS500M Ambient Sound Microphone 
be attached to an intercom module station type. For installation 
instructions, refer to the NQ-GA10P, NQ-GA10PV VoIP Intercom 
Module Installation and Use manual.
You must set the Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast IP Address and 
Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast Port system parameters (see "Set-
ting System Parameters” on page 53).
Then, create a station with Type as Ambient Noise Sensor and 
Device Type as NQ-GA10P-Intercom Module or NQ-GA10PV-
Intercom Module (see "Adding a Station” on page 153).

tion.

Select Configure.

Select the Add icon to add an ANS Listener.
An ANS Listener is a station that will receive Sound 
Pressure Level (SPL) reports from the ANS. For example, 
suppose you have speakers in a warehouse area that 
you want the volume to automatically adjust when

qas.question: What types of page outputs can be selected for the PTT Output configuration?

answers.text: For the PTT Output configuration, the selectable options are: Both, Line-Out, None, and Speaker-Out. If the Push To Talk Type is set to Record-Zone-Page, the parameter should be set to None unless live playback is desired.

qas.question: What should the PTT Output be set to when using Record-Zone-Page?

answers.text: When using Record-Zone-Page, the PTT Output should be set to "None" unless you want the page to also play live. This ensures that the paging is recorded without additional live output.

qas.question: How can you launch the mixer’s UI from the PTT configuration?

answers.text: You can launch the mixer’s UI from the PTT configuration by clicking the Link button next to the IP Address of the mixer. This button will only appear if the Nyquist server has discovered the mixer’s IP address.

qas.question: What steps are involved in editing an intercom module's configuration?

answers.text: To edit an intercom module's configuration, select "Stations" on the navigation bar, then click the Edit icon for the desired intercom module. Next, choose "Configure Intercom Module," make necessary edits on the configuration page, and select "Save" to apply the changes.

qas.question: What options are available for the Push To Talk Type setting?

answers.text: The options available for the Push To Talk Type setting are: All-Call-Page, Emergency-All-Call-Page, Zone-Page, and Record-Zone-Page.

qas.question: How many zones can be selected for the Push To Talk Zone configuration?

answers.text: Only one zone can be selected for the Push To Talk Zone configuration. This is specified in the editing options for the intercom module configuration.

qas.question: What does the Ambient Noise Sensor do in the context of paging and music?

answers.text: The Ambient Noise Sensor monitors ambient noise levels through a microphone module and automatically adjusts the paging signal level for the area's amplifier channel. This ensures that page announcements and music remain audible even during periods of high noise levels.

qas.question: What type of microphone module is required for the Ambient Noise Sensor feature?

answers.text: The Ambient Noise Sensor feature requires an ANS500M Ambient Sound Microphone. This microphone must be attached to an intercom module station type, such as the NQ-GA10P or NQ-GA10PV Intercom Module.

qas.question: What system parameters need to be set for the Ambient Noise Sensor to function?

answers.text: The Ambient Noise Sensor requires the setting of the Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast IP Address and Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast Port system parameters to function. Additionally, an ANS500M Ambient Sound Microphone must be attached to an intercom module station for proper operation.

qas.question: What is the purpose of an ANS Listener in the Ambient Noise Sensor configuration?

answers.text: An ANS Listener in the Ambient Noise Sensor configuration is a station that receives Sound Pressure Level (SPL) reports from the Ambient Noise Sensor (ANS). This allows the system to automatically adjust the volume of announcements and music based on the ambient noise levels monitored by the ANS, ensuring clear audibility in variable sound environments.

3.2.10
Configuring Ambient Noise Sensor
The Ambient Noise Sensor ensures that page announcements and 
music are audible even during periods of high noise levels by contin-
uously monitoring the ambient noise level through a microphone 
module and adjusting the paging signal level for that area's amplifier 
channel. 
This feature requires that an ANS500M Ambient Sound Microphone 
be attached to an intercom module station type. For installation 
instructions, refer to the NQ-GA10P, NQ-GA10PV VoIP Intercom 
Module Installation and Use manual.
You must set the Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast IP Address and 
Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast Port system parameters (see "Set-
ting System Parameters” on page 53).
Then, create a station with Type as Ambient Noise Sensor and 
Device Type as NQ-GA10P-Intercom Module or NQ-GA10PV-
Intercom Module (see "Adding a Station” on page 153). 
To configure ANS parameters:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Stations.
Step 2
Select the Edit icon for the Ambient Noise Sensor sta-
tion.
Step 3
Select Configure.
Step 4
Select the Add icon to add an ANS Listener.
An ANS Listener is a station that will receive Sound 
Pressure Level (SPL) reports from the ANS. For example, 
suppose you have speakers in a warehouse area that 
you want the volume to automatically adjust when 
Figure 3-9, Configure Ambient Noise Sensor
145
noisy machines are operating. You would add the 
speaker stations as ANS Listeners. When the SPL in the 
warehouse increases, the ANS reports the increase to 
the ANS Listeners and the speakers’ volumes are 
adjusted automatically.
Step 5
Set the ANS parameters for the ANS Listener.
Step 6
If you want to remove a station from the ANS Listener 
list, select the Remove icon on the station’s row.
Step 7
When all edits are made, select Save.
Table 3-9, Configure Ambient Noise Sensor Parameters
Station
Displays the extension number of the station 
that is an ANS Listener. A station can only lis-
ten to one ANS.
Max Boost (dB)
Displays the maximum dB gain adjustment 
allowed. Setting this parameter to 0 disables 
any volume adjustments from the ambient 
noise sensor. The default value is 20 dB.
Threshold (dBFS)
Displays the decibels relative to full scale 
(dBFS) value at which point the device will 
adjust the volume to compensate for the 
increased ambient noise volume. This value 
should be between -40 and 0 dBFS. A fairly 
noisy environment is around -20 dBFS; quiet 
environments are in the range of -40 dBFS. 
The default value is -20 dBFS.
Volume Adjust 
(dB)
Displays the amount of decibels to stay 
above the ambient noise level. Setting this to 
0 disables any volume adjustments from the 
ANS. The default value is 12 dB.
Sample Length(s) 
Displays the ambient noise sampling length, 
which can range from 1 to 20 seconds. Short 
lengths provide quicker response to changes 
in the ambient noise; longer lengths will 
ignore sudden, short fluctuations in the 
ambient noise.
146
3.2.11
Configuring Intercom HDMI Module Display 
Options
If you have a NQ-GA10PV Intercom HDMI Module Device Type, you 
can set display types for the connected monitor, including the type of 
clock and display colors that appear.
Options configured for the station affect the overall appearance of 
the display, such as the background color for the display and fonts 
used to display date and event. Options for specific messages are set 
through the Display Message option on the dashboard (see "Creat-
ing a Display Message” on page 438).

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Ambient Noise Sensor (ANS) in the system?

answers.text: The Ambient Noise Sensor (ANS) continuously monitors ambient noise levels to ensure that page announcements and music remain audible during high noise periods. It automatically adjusts the paging signal level for connected amplifiers based on the detected sound pressure level (SPL).

qas.question: Which microphone module is required to use the Ambient Noise Sensor feature?

answers.text: The Ambient Noise Sensor feature requires the ANS500M Ambient Sound Microphone to be attached to an intercom module station type. For installation instructions, refer to the NQ-GA10P and NQ-GA10PV VoIP Intercom Module Installation and Use manual.

qas.question: What parameters need to be set for the Ambient Noise Sensor during configuration?

answers.text: The parameters that need to be set for the Ambient Noise Sensor during configuration include the Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast IP Address, Ambient Noise Sensor Multicast Port, Max Boost (dB), Threshold (dBFS), Volume Adjust (dB), and Sample Length (s). The Max Boost limits the dB gain adjustment, while the Threshold and Volume Adjust define the volume adjustment levels in relation to ambient noise.

qas.question: How do you add an ANS Listener station in the configuration process?

answers.text: To add an ANS Listener station, navigate to Stations, select the Edit icon for the Ambient Noise Sensor station, and then select Configure. Click the Add icon to include an ANS Listener, which can receive Sound Pressure Level (SPL) reports from the ANS.

qas.question: What does the Max Boost parameter control in the ANS Listener settings?

answers.text: The Max Boost parameter in the ANS Listener settings controls the maximum decibel gain adjustment allowed for volume increasing due to ambient noise. Setting this parameter to 0 disables any volume adjustments from the ambient noise sensor, with a default value of 20 dB.

qas.question: What is the default value for the Threshold parameter, and what does it represent?

answers.text: The default value for the Threshold parameter is -20 dBFS. It represents the decibel level at which the Ambient Noise Sensor will adjust the volume to compensate for increased ambient noise, with values typically ranging from -40 to 0 dBFS, where -20 dBFS indicates a fairly noisy environment.

qas.question: How does the Volume Adjust parameter affect the sound output of the ANS Listener?

answers.text: The Volume Adjust parameter determines the number of decibels by which the sound output of the ANS Listener will be raised above the ambient noise level. A setting of 0 disables any volume adjustments, while the default value is 12 dB, indicating that the volume will automatically increase by this amount when ambient noise rises.

qas.question: What options can be configured for a NQ-GA10PV Intercom HDMI Module?

answers.text: For a NQ-GA10PV Intercom HDMI Module, you can configure display types, including the type of clock and display colors. The options affect the overall appearance of the display, such as background color and fonts used for date and event displays. Specific message settings are managed through the Display Message option on the dashboard.

qas.question: How does the sampling length affect the response time of the Ambient Noise Sensor?

answers.text: The sampling length of the Ambient Noise Sensor affects its response time by determining how quickly it reacts to changes in ambient noise. Shorter sampling lengths (1-5 seconds) allow for quicker adjustments to noise fluctuations, while longer lengths (10-20 seconds) may ignore sudden, brief changes in noise levels.

qas.question: What type of stations can be created as ANS Listeners?

answers.text: ANS Listeners can be any stations that will receive Sound Pressure Level (SPL) reports from the Ambient Noise Sensor (ANS). For example, speaker stations in a noisy environment, like a warehouse, can be configured as ANS Listeners to automatically adjust their volume based on ambient noise levels.

qas.question: What types of clocks can be displayed on the NQ-GA10PV Intercom HDMI Module?

answers.text: The NQ-GA10PV Intercom HDMI Module can display two types of clocks: an Analog Clock, which appears on the left side of the display screen, and a Digital Clock, which is shown at the top of the screen.

qas.question: How can the display date format be customized?

answers.text: The display date format can be customized by selecting from several available formats, including options like "MMM DD YY," "DD/MM/YYYY," or "MM/DD/YYYY." This selection is made in the Display Configuration section and allows for flexibility in how the date is presented on the screen.

qas.question: What options are available for selecting message layouts on the display?

answers.text: There are five message layout options available for the display: Analog Clock (displays an analog clock on the left), Digital Clock (displays a digital clock at the top), Messages 1 Column (single column for messages), Messages 2 Columns (two columns for messages), and Messages 3 Columns (three columns for messages).

qas.question: What methods can be used to choose a background color for the display?

answers.text: You can choose a background color for the display by using a color picker, entering a hex color (e.g., #000000 for black), entering an RGB color (e.g., rgb(0,0,0) for black), or entering a color alias name (e.g., red, blue, etc.).

qas.question: What font styles can be selected for the text on the display?

answers.text: The available font styles that can be selected for the text on the display are Comic-Relief, Courier-Prime, Gelasio, Liberation Sans, and Linux Libertine.

qas.question: How is the display size for text determined?

answers.text: The display size for text is determined by entering a text size value based on font points, with 72 points corresponding to one inch. Additionally, users can select the desired font from a drop-down list, which includes options like Comic-Relief and Liberation Sans.

qas.question: What are the options for showing or hiding seconds in the clock display?

answers.text: To show or hide seconds in the clock display, use the "Show Seconds" slider in the Display Configuration settings. This slider allows you to select whether seconds will be displayed on the clock.

qas.question: How can the time format be set to either 12 or 24 hours?

answers.text: To set the time format to either 12 or 24 hours, navigate to the Display Configuration settings of the intercom HDMI module. There, you can select your preferred time format from the available options.

qas.question: What happens when a station is deleted from the system?

answers.text: When a station is deleted from the system, all of its settings are permanently removed, and the station will no longer be able to register with the Nyquist system server. If the station is an admin station, it may require the deletion of all associated stations before it can be removed.

qas.question: Why might an admin station be restricted from being deleted?

answers.text: An admin station may be restricted from being deleted because it is likely integral to the system's operations and management. Deleting such a station could disrupt critical administrative functions and overall system stability, hence the requirement to remove all associated settings or dependencies first.

3.3
Deleting a Station
When you delete a station, all of its settings are deleted and the sta-
tion will not be able to register with the Nyquist system server. If it’s 
an admin station, you may not be able to delete it until you delete all 
Figure 3-14, Example of Two Column Display
Figure 3-15, Example of Three Column Display
Note: You cannot delete a station that is used in a routine Action 
(see "Understanding Action Parameters” on page 406).
153
associations that the Admin Station has (for example, member of Day 
Admin, Night Admin, Night Ring, or Admin Group). 
After you delete a second station from an SPA112, the Nyquist 
system server reboots the SPA112. If the Nyquist system server does 
not know the SPA112's IP Address, you must reboot the SPA112 
device for the changes to take effect on the SPA112. 
When a station is deleted from an SPA112, it can take several minutes 
for the changes to show up on the SPA112's web interface. When the 
second station is deleted from the SPA112, the remaining station is 
set up on the first port (Phone 1) even if that station was previously 
set up on the second port (Phone 2). If this situation occurs, move the 
attached phone cable from Phone 2 to Phone 1.
To delete a station’s configurations:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Stations.
Step 2
Select the Delete icon for the station that you want to 
delete configuration settings.
Step 3
When prompted, select Delete.
3.4
Adding a Station
Using the Nyquist system server’s automatic discovery feature is the 
preferred method of adding a station. If you manually add a station, 
you risk having the MAC address entered incorrectly, which would 
prevent the station from functioning properly.
If the station Type is Admin Web Interface, Admin Phone, IP Phone, 
Analog Phone, or Mobile Device, you can set a default Announce-
ment Zone and the Announcement Zone Configuration Type. If 
the Announcement Zone Configuration Type is set to Fixed, the 
zone used to play announcements will always be the zone number 
provided for Announcement Zone and cannot be changed. If set to 
Default, the Announcement Zone value is used as the default zone, 
but you can set an announcement to play to another zone.
To view and add discovered stations:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Stations.
Step 2
On the Stations page, select New Stations.

qas.question: What happens to a station's settings when it is deleted?

answers.text: When a station is deleted, all of its settings are removed, and it will no longer be able to register with the Nyquist system server. If the station is an admin station, it cannot be deleted until all associated groups or roles are removed. The deletion process may take several minutes to reflect on the SPA112's web interface.

qas.question: Why might you be unable to delete an admin station?

answers.text: You may be unable to delete an admin station because it is associated with routine actions, such as being a member of Day Admin, Night Admin, Night Ring, or an Admin Group. All associations must be removed before the admin station can be deleted.

qas.question: What occurs after deleting a second station from an SPA112?

answers.text: After deleting a second station from an SPA112, the Nyquist system server reboots the SPA112. If the server does not recognize the SPA112's IP Address, the device must be rebooted manually for the changes to take effect.

qas.question: How long does it typically take for changes to reflect on the SPA112's web interface after a station is deleted?

answers.text: It can take several minutes for changes to reflect on the SPA112's web interface after a station is deleted. Additionally, if a second station is deleted, the Nyquist system server reboots the SPA112, which may also affect how quickly changes are displayed.

qas.question: What action should you take if the remaining station is set up on a different port after a second station is deleted?

answers.text: If the remaining station is set up on a different port after a second station is deleted, move the attached phone cable from Phone 2 to Phone 1. This change is necessary to ensure the remaining station functions correctly on the first port (Phone 1).

qas.question: What is the preferred method for adding a station to the Nyquist system server?

answers.text: The preferred method for adding a station to the Nyquist system server is to use the automatic discovery feature. This method reduces the risk of incorrectly entering the MAC address, which could prevent the station from functioning properly.

qas.question: What risks are associated with manually adding a station?

answers.text: The main risk associated with manually adding a station is the possibility of incorrectly entering the MAC address, which would prevent the station from functioning properly. This could lead to additional troubleshooting steps and delays in setup.

qas.question: What configuration options are available for different station types regarding Announcement Zones?

answers.text: For station types such as Admin Web Interface, Admin Phone, IP Phone, Analog Phone, or Mobile Device, you can configure a default Announcement Zone and set the Announcement Zone Configuration Type to either Fixed or Default. If set to Fixed, the zone for announcements remains constant; if set to Default, it allows for flexibility in selecting different zones while using the specified default zone.

qas.question: How does the Announcement Zone Configuration Type affect zone announcements?

answers.text: The Announcement Zone Configuration Type determines how announcements are played through designated zones. If set to Fixed, the announcement will always play in the specified zone and cannot be changed, while if set to Default, the specified zone is the default but can be overridden for specific announcements.

qas.question: What steps are involved in viewing and adding discovered stations?

answers.text: To view and add discovered stations, go to the navigation bar and select "Stations." Then, on the Stations page, select "New Stations." This allows you to see the automatically discovered stations for addition.

3.4.1
Swapping a Nyquist Device
Through the New Stations option, you can replace an existing device 
with a new device. This option allows you to replace a device, such as 
VoIP speaker, with a new device of the same type and maintain the 
original device’s extension and configuration.
You can also use the New Stations option to replace an audio power 
amplifier with another amplifier, regardless of type. For example, you 
can replace an NQ-A2060 amplifier with an NQ-A2300 amplifier.
3.4.2
Using a Cisco SPA112 Adapter
The Cisco SPA112 is an Analog Telephone Adapter (ATA) that allows 
an analog phone to access IP phone services through two standard 
telephone RJ-11 phone ports.
The following limitations exist when the Cisco SPA112 is used as a 
Nyquist Admin Phone station:
• Call queuing is not supported.
• Call waiting is limited to one call. If the Admin Phone is associated 
with an Admin Group, a call made to the Admin Phone when the 
phone is already on a call will automatically ring the Admin Group. 
If the Admin Phone is not associated with an Admin Group and

qas.question: What happens to the SPA112 after deleting a second station?

answers.text: After deleting a second station from the SPA112, the Nyquist system server reboots the SPA112. If the server does not know the SPA112's IP address, a manual reboot of the SPA112 is required for the changes to take effect.

qas.question: How long may it take for changes to appear on the SPA112’s web interface after deleting a station?

answers.text: It can take several minutes for changes to appear on the SPA112’s web interface after deleting a station. If the changes do not appear, rebooting the SPA112 may be necessary for the changes to take effect.

qas.question: Where should the phone cable be moved after deleting the second station on the SPA112?

answers.text: After deleting the second station on the SPA112, the attached phone cable should be moved from Phone 2 to Phone 1, as the remaining station will be set up on the first port (Phone 1).

qas.question: What is the preferred method for adding a station in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The preferred method for adding a station in the Nyquist system is to use the system's automatic discovery feature. This approach minimizes the risk of incorrect MAC address entry, which could prevent the station from functioning properly.

qas.question: What are the potential consequences of manually adding a station?

answers.text: Manually adding a station increases the risk of incorrect MAC address entry, which can prevent the station from functioning properly. This can lead to connectivity issues and hinder communication, as the station may not register correctly within the Nyquist system.

qas.question: What configuration types can be set for the Announcement Zone in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: In the Nyquist system, the Announcement Zone Configuration Type can be set to either Fixed or Default. If Fixed, the zone used for announcements is always the specified zone number; if Default, the zone serves as the default but can be changed for specific announcements.

qas.question: How can a user view and add discovered stations in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To view and add discovered stations in the Nyquist system, go to the navigation bar and select "Stations." Then, on the Stations page, click on "New Stations," and select the Add icon next to the desired station to configure it.

qas.question: What steps are involved in manually adding a new station?

answers.text: To manually add a new station, select "Stations" from the navigation bar, then click the "Add" icon. Complete the required configuration parameters and finally select "Save" to finalize the addition.

qas.question: How can you replace an existing Nyquist device with a new device?

answers.text: To replace an existing Nyquist device with a new device, use the New Stations option to select the device you want to replace. This allows you to maintain the original device’s extension and configuration while substituting it with a new device of the same type.

qas.question: What limitations are there when using the Cisco SPA112 as a Nyquist Admin Phone station?

answers.text: When using the Cisco SPA112 as a Nyquist Admin Phone station, call queuing is not supported, and call waiting is limited to one call. If the Admin Phone is associated with an Admin Group, an incoming call while on another call will automatically ring the Admin Group; if not associated, the phone will only receive the incoming call.

qas.question: What happens to an Admin Phone when it receives a call while already on a call, if it is associated with an Admin Group?

answers.text: If an Admin Phone associated with an Admin Group receives a call while already on a call, the incoming call will automatically ring the Admin Group. This means the call is redirected to the group rather than the individual Admin Phone.

qas.question: What is the first step to add a new station from the New Stations page?

answers.text: The first step to add a new station from the New Stations page is to select the Add icon next to the station you want to configure. After that, you will need to complete the options that are not automatically filled and then select Save.

qas.question: How can you manually add a station using the navigation bar?

answers.text: To manually add a station, select "Stations" from the navigation bar, then click the "Add" icon. Complete the configuration parameters for the new station and select "Save" to finalize the addition.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the New Stations option in relation to swapping a Nyquist device?

answers.text: The New Stations option allows users to replace an existing Nyquist device with a new device of the same type while retaining the original device’s extension and configuration. This feature enables seamless upgrades, such as swapping out VoIP speakers or audio amplifiers without losing settings or functionalities.

qas.question: Can you replace an NQ-A2060 amplifier with an NQ-A2300 amplifier?

answers.text: Yes, you can replace an NQ-A2060 amplifier with an NQ-A2300 amplifier through the New Stations option. This allows you to maintain the original device’s extension and configuration during the swap.

qas.question: What limitations exist when using a Cisco SPA112 as a Nyquist Admin Phone station?

answers.text: The limitations when using a Cisco SPA112 as a Nyquist Admin Phone station include the lack of support for call queuing and limited call waiting to one active call. If the Admin Phone receives a call while already on a call and is part of an Admin Group, it will automatically redirect to the group, whereas this does not occur if it is not associated with an Admin Group.

qas.question: How does call waiting work for an Admin Phone not associated with an Admin Group?

answers.text: If an Admin Phone not associated with an Admin Group is on a call and receives another incoming call, it will not support call waiting. The second incoming call will not be queued or routed elsewhere; the initial call will continue without any notification of the new call.

qas.question: Where can details about configuration parameters for a new station be found?

3.4.2
Using a Cisco SPA112 Adapter
The Cisco SPA112 is an Analog Telephone Adapter (ATA) that allows 
an analog phone to access IP phone services through two standard 
telephone RJ-11 phone ports.
The following limitations exist when the Cisco SPA112 is used as a 
Nyquist Admin Phone station:
• Call queuing is not supported.
• Call waiting is limited to one call. If the Admin Phone is associated 
with an Admin Group, a call made to the Admin Phone when the 
phone is already on a call will automatically ring the Admin Group. 
If the Admin Phone is not associated with an Admin Group and 
155
receives a call when already on a call, a beep sounds on the Admin 
Phone to indicate a call is on call waiting.
• When you add two stations to an SPA112 device, you must enter 
the same MAC address for both ports.
• The station number with the lowest numerical value will be set up 
on the first port (Phone 1) of the SPA112.
• After you add or delete a second station to or from the SPA112, 
the Nyquist system server reboots the SPA112. If the Nyquist sys-
tem server does not know the SPA112’s IP address you must man-
ually reboot the SPA112 device for the changes to take effect on 
the SPA112.
• When a station is added to the SPA112, the web password is 
changed to bogen. You can change the web password when add-
ing or editing the station.
• If you configure two stations on the same SPA112, the web pass-
word is set to the station with the highest station number, even if 
the other station has a different web password defined. Ensure 
that the same web password is entered for both stations on the 
SPA112.
• When you delete the second station from the SPA112, the remain-
ing station is set up on the first port (Phone 1) even if that station 
was previously set up on the second port (Phone 2). If this situa-
tion occurs, move the attached phone cable from Phone 2 to 
Phone 1.
• When you configure two stations on the same SPA112, the second 
station (Phone 2) uses port # 5061.
• It can take several minutes for changes to show up on the 
SPA112’s web interface when adding, modifying, or deleting sta-
tions to or from an SPA112.
• When you add a station to an SPA 112 for the first time, you must 
reboot the SPA112 after adding the station with the Nyquist web 
UI before the SPA112 will retrieve its configuration information.
• If station VLAN settings are provided and two stations are defined 
on the SPA112, the VLAN settings from the station with the lowest 
station number are used. The best practice is to ensure that both 
stations on the SPA112 use the same VLAN settings.

qas.question: What steps are involved in manually adding a new station in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To manually add a new station in the Nyquist system, select "Stations" from the navigation bar, then click the "Add" icon. Complete the configuration parameters for the new station and select "Save."

qas.question: How can a Nyquist device be swapped using the New Stations option?

answers.text: To swap a Nyquist device using the New Stations option, select the Add icon next to the existing device you want to replace. This process allows you to enter the configuration for the new device while retaining the original device's extension and configuration settings.

qas.question: What are the limitations of using the Cisco SPA112 as a Nyquist Admin Phone station?

answers.text: The limitations of using the Cisco SPA112 as a Nyquist Admin Phone station include lack of support for call queuing, limited call waiting to one call, and the requirement to use the same MAC address for both ports when adding two stations. Additionally, the SPA112 may require manual rebooting for changes to take effect, and the web password defaults to ‘bogen’ upon adding a station.

qas.question: What configuration changes occur in the Cisco SPA112 when adding a station for the first time?

answers.text: When adding a station to the Cisco SPA112 for the first time, the device's web password is set to "bogen," and the Nyquist system server configures several parameters including proxy settings, user ID, password, and time server settings. Additionally, the SPA112 must be rebooted after the station addition for the configuration changes to take effect.

qas.question: What parameters must be completed when adding a Cisco SPA112 station?

answers.text: When adding a Cisco SPA112 station, you must complete the following configuration parameters: select the Type (Admin Phone or IP Phone), set the Device Type to Cisco SPA112, and enter the MAC Address of the Cisco SPA112. For all other parameters, refer to the "Station Configuration Page Parameters" on page 107.

qas.question: How does the Nyquist system handle VLAN settings when configuring multiple stations on the SPA112?

answers.text: When configuring multiple stations on the Cisco SPA112, the VLAN settings are derived from the station with the lowest station number. It is recommended that both stations use the same VLAN settings to avoid issues.

qas.question: What reboot procedure must be followed after adding or modifying a station on the SPA112?

answers.text: After adding or modifying a station on the Cisco SPA112, the device will automatically reboot if the Nyquist system server knows the SPA112's IP address. If the server does not recognize the IP address, you must manually reboot the SPA112 for the changes to take effect.

qas.question: What specific settings are changed on the Cisco SPA112 during the provisioning process?

answers.text: During the provisioning process for the Cisco SPA112, the following settings are changed: proxy, display name, user ID, password, dial plan, host name, time server configuration, and VLAN settings. Additionally, parameters related to quick setup and voicemail settings are configured to align with the Nyquist system server's specifications.

qas.question: What is the dial plan to be used for the Cisco SPA112 as outlined in the document?
What analog VoIP gateway is supported by the Nyquist E7000 Series for integrating analog phones?

answers.text: The Nyquist E7000 Series supports the Yeastar TA2400 FXS VoIP Gateway for integrating 24 standard analog phones into an IP communications system. It is important to note that Quantum/Multicom MCESS and MCWESS phones are not supported by this device.

qas.question: What is the purpose of enabling VLAN in the network setup?

answers.text: Enabling VLAN in the network setup allows for the segmentation of network traffic, improving performance and security by isolating different types of data (e.g., voice and data). This ensures that voice traffic is prioritized and managed separately, enhancing the quality of VoIP communications.

qas.question: How do you configure the mailbox ID for Line 1?

answers.text: To configure the mailbox ID for Line 1, navigate to the Voice settings, select Line 1, and enter the mailbox ID as "Nyquist-station-extension-number." Ensure that the correct extension number associated with the Nyquist server is used.

qas.question: What URL is used for provisioning the voice profile?

answers.text: The URL used for provisioning the voice profile is "tftp://NyquistServerIP:69/spa$MA.cfg". This URL is set in the Voice -> Provisioning -> Profile Rule configuration.

qas.question: Which authentication details are required for Line 1 subscriber information?

answers.text: For Line 1 subscriber information, the required authentication details are the Display Name, User ID, and Password. These credentials are necessary for the user to connect to the VoIP service.

qas.question: What is the dial plan format provided in the instructions?
How does one log out of the device after configuration?

answers.text: To log out of the device after configuration, simply navigate to the device's management interface and select the logout option. Ensure that any unsaved changes are correctly saved before logging out to avoid data loss.

qas.question: What is the function of the Yeastar TA2400 in the Nyquist E7000 Series setup?

answers.text: The Yeastar TA2400 functions as an FXS VoIP Gateway in the Nyquist E7000 Series setup, allowing integration of 24 standard analog phones into the IP communications system. It retrieves configuration settings from the Nyquist server to facilitate this integration.

qas.question: Which types of phones are not supported by the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: Quantum/Multicom MCESS and MCWESS phones are not supported by the Yeastar TA2400 FXS VoIP Gateway.

qas.question: How do you connect the Yeastar TA2400 to the Nyquist server?

answers.text: To connect the Yeastar TA2400 to the Nyquist server, access the Yeastar TA2400 web interface and navigate to System > Auto Provision Settings. Set the Provision Method to "Yes" for Server URL to enable retrieval of configuration from the Nyquist server.

qas.question: What is the first step in setting up the Yeastar TA2400 web interface?

answers.text: The first step in setting up the Yeastar TA2400 web interface is to obtain an IP address for the Yeastar TA2400. This can be done by following the instructions in the Yeastar TA Series Analog VoIP Gateway Installation Guide to log into the web interface.

3.4.3.2
Adding a Station that Uses a Yeastar TA2400 Port
To add a station that uses a Yeastar TA2400 port to your Nyquist sys-
tem, follow the procedures for adding a station (See "Adding a Sta-
tion” on page 153). 
When you select Yeastar-TA2400 Analog FXS Port as the Device 
Type, you must select the Port Number that the station is attached 
to from the drop-down list. Valid values are 1 through 24. 
If you have only one phone attached to the TA2400, it must be 
attached to port 1. If you have multiple phones attached to the 
TA2400, one must be attached to port 1 but the use of the other 
ports can be random. For example, you can have phones attached to 
port 1, 2, 5, and 10. However, you cannot attach phones to just ports 
2, 5, and 10 since that combination does not include phone 1.
The following rules apply when adding a station to a Yeastar TA2400 
port:
• Device Type is Yeastar-TA2400 Analog FXS Port.
• You can select Admin Phone or IP Phone for Type.
• MAC Address is a required field. If you are adding the first station 
for this MAC Address, the Port Number is automatically set to 1.
• Paging is set to No and cannot be changed.
• Multicast Audio Distribution is set to No but does not appear 
on the Add Station or Edit Station pages.
• Volume controls do not appear.
Note: Port number 1 must always be used.

qas.question: What is the first step to configure the Yeastar TA2400 to retrieve configuration from the E7000 Series server?

answers.text: The first step to configure the Yeastar TA2400 to retrieve configuration from the E7000 Series server is to access the Yeastar TA2400 web interface and select "System." Then, under "System Preferences," select "Auto Provision Settings."

qas.question: How do you input the Server URL in the Yeastar TA2400 web interface for auto provisioning?

answers.text: To input the Server URL in the Yeastar TA2400 web interface for auto provisioning, go to System Preferences, select Auto Provision Settings, and in the Server Address field, type `tftp://` followed by the Nyquist server's IP address and a trailing slash (e.g., `tftp://10.10.5.2/`). Ensure the Provision Method is set to Yes before saving the changes.

qas.question: What is the required field when adding a station using a Yeastar TA2400 port?

answers.text: The required field when adding a station using a Yeastar TA2400 port is the MAC Address. If you are adding the first station for this MAC Address, the Port Number is automatically set to 1.

qas.question: Can you attach phones to ports other than port 1 on the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: Yes, you can attach phones to ports other than port 1 on the Yeastar TA2400; however, at least one phone must always be attached to port 1. Additional phones can be connected to any other ports (2-24), but port 1 must be used in any configuration.

qas.question: Which settings are automatically applied when adding the first station for a specific MAC Address?

answers.text: When adding the first station for a specific MAC Address on a Yeastar TA2400, the Port Number is automatically set to 1. Additionally, the Device Type must be selected as Yeastar-TA2400 Analog FXS Port, and the MAC Address is a required field.

qas.question: What is the server address format required for setting up auto provisioning in the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: The server address format required for setting up auto provisioning in the Yeastar TA2400 is "tftp://<IP address of the Nyquist server>/". For example, it would be formatted as "tftp://10.10.5.2/".

qas.question: What happens if you try to attach phones only to ports 2, 5, and 10 on the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: If you try to attach phones only to ports 2, 5, and 10 on the Yeastar TA2400, it will not be allowed because port 1 must be used. The combination is invalid as it does not include a phone connected to port 1.

qas.question: Are volume controls available when adding a station to a Yeastar TA2400 port?

answers.text: No, volume controls do not appear when adding a station to a Yeastar TA2400 port. The configurations for volume are not available in the Add Station or Edit Station pages.

qas.question: What must you select as the Device Type when adding a station that uses the Yeastar TA2400 port?

answers.text: When adding a station that uses the Yeastar TA2400 port, you must select "Yeastar-TA2400 Analog FXS Port" as the Device Type. Additionally, if you are adding the first station for a given MAC Address, the Port Number will automatically be set to 1.

qas.question: What should be done after saving the auto provisioning settings on the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: After saving the auto provisioning settings on the Yeastar TA2400, you should select "Apply Changes," then go to "System Preferences" and choose "Reset and Reboot." If prompted, select "OK" to complete the reboot process.

qas.question: What must be entered in the Server URL field for the Nyquist server?

answers.text: In the Server URL field for the Nyquist server, you must enter "tftp://" followed by the IP address of the Nyquist server and a trailing slash. For example: tftp://10.10.5.2/.

qas.question: What should be left blank when adding a device?

answers.text: When adding a device, both the User Name and Password fields should be left blank. Additionally, the Paging setting is set to No and cannot be changed.

qas.question: What interval of time should be set after configuring the server address?

answers.text: The interval of time should be set to 60 after configuring the server address. This setting is found in the Interval of time field during the configuration process.

qas.question: What is the range of valid port numbers for attaching a station to a Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: The valid port numbers for attaching a station to a Yeastar TA2400 range from 1 to 24. Port 1 must always be used for at least one phone, while the other ports can be utilized randomly.

qas.question: What must be attached to port 1 of the Yeastar TA2400 when adding multiple phones?

answers.text: When adding multiple phones to the Yeastar TA2400, one phone must be attached to port 1. The other ports can have phones attached in a random manner, but port 1 is mandatory for the configuration to be valid.

qas.question: What are the device types that can be selected when adding a station for Yeastar TA2400 ports?

answers.text: When adding a station for Yeastar TA2400 ports, the device type that can be selected is "Yeastar-TA2400 Analog FXS Port." You can choose either "Admin Phone" or "IP Phone" as the Type for the station.

qas.question: Is the MAC Address required when adding a station, and what happens to the Port Number if it's the first entry?

answers.text: Yes, the MAC Address is a required field when adding a station. If it is the first entry for this MAC Address, the Port Number is automatically set to 1.

qas.question: What codec is allowed for devices connected to the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: The allowed codec for devices connected to the Yeastar TA2400 is g722, and this setting cannot be changed. Additionally, port number 1 must always be used when adding a station to the Yeastar TA2400.

qas.question: What must be done manually after adding a station to the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: After adding a station to the Yeastar TA2400, the device must be manually rebooted via the Yeastar TA2400’s web interface. Additionally, ensure that the Network Time Service is configured using the Nyquist Appliances Network Time Server Source.

qas.question: Where can the status of individual ports be viewed for the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: The status of individual ports for the Yeastar TA2400 can be viewed from the Yeastar TA2400 web interface. To do this, select "Status" and then choose "Port Status."

3.5
Excluding Stations from Paging
Stations can be excluded from paging except for Emergency All Call 
pages. Emergency All Call pages will be sent and heard at the station 
even if that station is set to exclude paging.
Stations excluded from paging are also excluded from receiving 
audio distribution, even if the station’s Multicast Audio Distribution 
parameter is enabled, the station is a member of a zone being used 
for Audio Distribution, or both.
Table 3-11,  Port Status Parameters
Port
Provides the port number for the associated station.
Up/Down
Displays Up if the FXS module is working. Otherwise, dis-
plays Down.
Name
Provides the name of the station.
Status
Shows the state of the port Possible statuses are:
• OK. Registration is successful, and the port is ready for 
use.
• Unreachable. The FXS module cannot determine the 
status of the port.
• Request Sent. A request for registering the port has 
been transmitted to the FXS module.
• Waiting for authentication. The FXS module is verify-
ing that the correct password and user name have been 
entered.
• Failed. The port registration has failed.
Voice Mail (New/Old)
This field is not used.
Off hook/On hook
On Hook appears if the FXS port is idle. Off Hook appears 
if the FXS port is busy.

qas.question: What codec is allowed on the Yeastar TA2400 and is it changeable?

answers.text: The only codec allowed on the Yeastar TA2400 is g722, and it cannot be changed.

qas.question: What must be done after adding a station to the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: After adding a station to the Yeastar TA2400, the device must be manually rebooted via the Yeastar TA2400’s web interface to apply the changes.

qas.question: How can a speaker be associated with a TA2400 port?

answers.text: A speaker can be associated with a TA2400 port by selecting a Speaker Extension in the device's settings. This enables the external (classroom) speaker to be utilized through the designated port.

qas.question: What happens to stations attached to the Yeastar TA2400 during Night Ring operations?

answers.text: Stations attached to the Yeastar TA2400 are not available for ringing during Night Ring operations. This means they will not receive incoming calls or alerts during this period.

qas.question: Which server is used to configure the Network Time Service on the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: The Nyquist Appliances Network Time Server Source is used to configure the Network Time Service on the Yeastar TA2400. The time zone of the Yeastar TA2400 will also be set to match the Nyquist server’s time zone.

qas.question: How is the time zone of the Yeastar TA2400 determined?

answers.text: The time zone of the Yeastar TA2400 is determined by matching it to the Nyquist server's time zone, which is configured using the Nyquist Appliances Network Time Server Source for the Network Time Service.

qas.question: Where can the overall status of the Yeastar TA2400 be viewed?

answers.text: The overall status of the Yeastar TA2400 can be viewed using the Station Status feature in the web interface. To access it, navigate to the Status section and select Port Status.

qas.question: What steps are needed to view port status on the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: To view port status on the Yeastar TA2400, log in to the web interface, then select "Status" followed by "Port Status." This will display various parameters related to the individual ports, including their registration status and operational state.

qas.question: What does the "Up/Down" status indicate for a port on the Yeastar TA2400?

answers.text: The "Up/Down" status for a port on the Yeastar TA2400 indicates whether the FXS module is operational; "Up" means the module is working correctly, while "Down" signifies that it is not functioning.

qas.question: What message is displayed if a port registration has failed?

answers.text: If a port registration has failed on the Yeastar TA2400, the status displayed will be "Failed." This indicates that the registration process for that port was unsuccessful.

qas.question: Can stations excluded from paging receive Emergency All Call pages?

answers.text: Yes, stations excluded from paging can still receive Emergency All Call pages. These emergency pages will be sent and heard at the station regardless of its paging exclusion status.

qas.question: What happens to audio distribution for stations excluded from paging?

answers.text: Stations excluded from paging are also excluded from receiving audio distribution. This applies even if the station's Multicast Audio Distribution parameter is enabled, or if the station is a member of a zone being used for Audio Distribution.

Provides the name of the station.
Status
Shows the state of the port Possible statuses are:
• OK. Registration is successful, and the port is ready for 
use.
• Unreachable. The FXS module cannot determine the 
status of the port.
• Request Sent. A request for registering the port has 
been transmitted to the FXS module.
• Waiting for authentication. The FXS module is verify-
ing that the correct password and user name have been 
entered.
• Failed. The port registration has failed.
Voice Mail (New/Old)
This field is not used.
Off hook/On hook
On Hook appears if the FXS port is idle. Off Hook appears 
if the FXS port is busy.

qas.question: What happens to Emergency All Call pages if a station is excluded from paging?

answers.text: Emergency All Call pages will still be sent and heard at a station even if that station is set to exclude paging. This means that stations excluded from regular paging will still receive Emergency All Call alerts.

qas.question: How can a station be excluded from paging in the system?

answers.text: To exclude a station from paging, navigate to the Stations menu and select Page Exclusions. Then, click the Add icon to include the desired station in the Page Exclusions list.

qas.question: What status indicates that a port registration is successful?

answers.text: The status that indicates a port registration is successful is "OK." This status means that registration has been successful and the port is ready for use.

qas.question: What does the "Unreachable" status imply about the FXS module?

answers.text: The "Unreachable" status indicates that the FXS module cannot determine the status of the port, suggesting a communication issue or failure to connect. This means the port is either not responding or is out of reach.

qas.question: If a station is excluded from paging, what other features are affected?

answers.text: If a station is excluded from paging, it is also excluded from receiving audio distribution, regardless of the station's Multicast Audio Distribution setting or its membership in a zone for audio distribution. Additionally, the excluded station will not receive tones if it is part of a Time or Paging+Time zone.

qas.question: How do you remove a station from the Page Exclusions list?

answers.text: To remove a station from the Page Exclusions list, select "Page Exclusions" on the navigation bar, then click the Delete icon next to the desired station. Confirm the deletion when prompted by selecting "Delete." Be aware that this action may force the station to reboot.

qas.question: What is the valid range for extension numbers in the system?

answers.text: The valid range for extension numbers in the system is from 001 to 899 for three-digit dialing. The system can be configured to use three, four, five, or six-digit dialing.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Station Status feature?

answers.text: The Station Status feature allows users to quickly assess the status of all stations by displaying crucial information such as extension numbers, station names, and device types. This helps in monitoring the operational status and readiness of each station within the system.

qas.question: What might occur when adding or deleting a station from the page exclusions list?

answers.text: Adding or deleting a station from the page exclusions list may force the station to reboot. This action could temporarily disrupt services for that station as it reinitializes.

qas.question: What types of information are displayed on the Station Status Page?

answers.text: The Station Status Page displays the unique multi-digit extension number for each station, the name of the station (up to 16 characters), and the device type (e.g., NQ-P0100 Matrix Mixer Pre Amp). This information allows for a quick assessment of all stations' statuses within the system.

Status
Shows the current state of the station. Possible statuses are:
• Not in use. This status indicates that the station is regis-
tered with the Nyquist system server and is not on a call.
• In use. This status indicates that the station is off hook 
and either placing a call or in a call, such as an intercom 
call, page, or using a Nyquist feature.
• Ring+Inuse. Indicates that the station is off hook, on a 
call, and ringing (at least one incoming call is ringing the 
station).
• Ringing. Indicates that the station is on hook and ring-
ing (at least one incoming call is ringing the station).
• Unavailable. Indicates that the station is not registered 
with the Nyquist system server and is unavailable. A sta-
tion in this status is unable to receive calls and most 
likely cannot place calls.
IP Address
Provides the IP address of the station.
Link
If the device can be configured or managed via an appli-
ance web UI, this provides a login window for the device. 
After you enter your Username and Password, the web UI 
for the device appears. 
Action
Provides a Reboot button for Nyquist devices that have an 
IP address. Selecting this button reboots the device.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Station Status feature in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Station Status feature in the Nyquist system allows users to quickly assess the current operational status of all stations, providing essential information such as extension numbers, names, device types, and current statuses (e.g., in use, ringing, unavailable). This enables efficient monitoring and management of communication resources within the system.

qas.question: How do you access the Appliance Status feature?

answers.text: To access the Appliance Status feature, navigate to the Stations section on the navigation bar and select Appliance Status. This will display the status of appliances recognized by the Nyquist system server.

qas.question: What possible statuses can a station have in the Station Status?

answers.text: A station can have the following possible statuses in the Station Status: Not in use, In use, Ring+Inuse, Ringing, and Unavailable. These statuses indicate whether the station is registered, on a call, ringing, or unavailable to make or receive calls.

qas.question: What is indicated by the "Unavailable" status for a station?

answers.text: The "Unavailable" status indicates that the station is not registered with the Nyquist system server, making it unable to receive calls and most likely unable to place calls. This status signifies that the station is unresponsive or disconnected from the network.

qas.question: How can you reboot a Nyquist device from the Station Status page?

answers.text: To reboot a Nyquist device from the Station Status page, you need to find the device's entry, and then select the Reboot button provided for devices that have an IP address. After clicking the button, the device will restart.

qas.question: What information is displayed regarding the IP address of a station?

answers.text: The IP address section provides the IP address assigned to the station. This information is crucial for identifying the network location of the device and is displayed in the Station Status page.

qas.question: What is the maximum character length for station names in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The maximum character length for station names in the Nyquist system is 16 characters.

qas.question: What does the "Ringing" status signify about a station's condition?

answers.text: The "Ringing" status signifies that the station is currently on hook and at least one incoming call is ringing the station. This indicates that the station is available to answer the call.

qas.question: What types of appliances can be viewed through the Appliance Status feature?

answers.text: The Appliance Status feature allows you to view the status of appliances such as I/O controllers, Analog Station Bridges, and Matrix Mixer Pre-Amps recognized by the Nyquist system server. It provides information such as extension numbers, names, and device types for each appliance.

qas.question: How does the system handle dialing extensions with different digit lengths?

answers.text: The system can be configured to use three, four, five, or six-digit dialing for extensions. Valid values for three-digit dialing range from 001 to 899. This flexibility allows for different dialing lengths based on user settings.

qas.question: What information is provided under the Appliance Status feature for each appliance recognized by the Nyquist system server?

answers.text: The Appliance Status feature provides the unique extension number, name, device type, current status, IP address, a link for web UI management, and an action option to reboot the device for each appliance recognized by the Nyquist system server. Possible statuses include Not in use, In use, Unavailable, or Unknown.

qas.question: What are the possible statuses that an appliance can display in the Appliance Status page?

answers.text: The possible statuses that an appliance can display in the Appliance Status page are: Not in use (registered but not on a call), In use (off hook and active on a call), Unavailable (not registered and unavailable), and Unknown (server cannot determine the state of the device).

qas.question: How can you access the Appliance Status page from the navigation bar?

answers.text: To access the Appliance Status page from the navigation bar, select "Stations," then choose "Appliance Status." This will display the status information for each appliance recognized by the Nyquist system server.

qas.question: What is the valid range for the unique multi-digit extension numbers for stations?

answers.text: The valid range for unique multi-digit extension numbers for stations is from 001 to 899 for three-digit dialing. The system can be configured to use three, four, five, or six-digit dialing, but the specified range applies specifically to three-digit extensions.

qas.question: What type of details can be viewed about zones on the Zones page?

answers.text: On the Zones page, you can view details about existing zones in either table format or card view. Key information includes a visual icon representing the zone type and a zone number associated with it, which can have up to five digits.

qas.question: How can you change the display format for viewing existing zones?

answers.text: To change the display format for viewing existing zones, select the Filter icon on the Zones page. This allows you to toggle between table format and card view by zone format.

qas.question: What action can you take for Nyquist devices with an IP address on the Appliance Status page?

answers.text: For Nyquist devices with an IP address on the Appliance Status page, you can reboot the device by selecting the Reboot button. This action is available for appliances that are registered with the Nyquist system server.

qas.question: What does the icon associated with a zone represent?

answers.text: The icon associated with a zone visually represents the type of zone it contains. For example, a Cutlery icon may indicate a zone that includes the cafeteria, while a Briefcase icon could represent a zone that contains executive offices.

qas.question: How many digits can the number associated with a zone have?

answers.text: The number associated with a zone can have up to five digits.

Icon
Displays a visual icon that represents the zone or zone type.

for a zone that contains executive offices. 
Number

3.9
Adding a Zone
You must have permission to add zones to perform this procedure. 
When you create a zone, you select whether the zone will allow 
manual paging, scheduled time paging, or audio distribution, or any 
combination of manual paging, scheduled time paging, or audio dis-
tribution.
Name
Identifies the zone by the user-created name. The name can 
be alphanumeric (such as Bldg 1) and contain up to 255 
characters.
Type
Identifies the zone as being able to receive paging, time, 
audio, or a combination of paging, time, or audio. 
Preannounce Tone
Identifies what, if any, tone should play before an 
announcement.
Cut Level (dB)
Sets the device volume cut level to be used when devices 
included in the zone receive pages, time scheduled tones, 
and manually activated tones. The cut level can range from 
0 to -42.
Audio Distribution Cut 
Level (dB)
Set the volume cut level for to be used when devices in the 
zone receive audio distribution and scheduled audio. (See 
"Using Audio Distribution” on page 315.)
Stations
Displays the extensions included in the zone when Show is 
selected. 
Description
Provides a description of the zone when Show is selected.
Multicast IP Address
Identifies the IP address for multicast calls to the zone.
Multicast Port Number
Identifies the port number for multicast calls to the zone.
Table 3-14,  Zone Page Parameters (Continued)
Note: The maximum number of zones that a Nyquist appliance can be 
enrolled in is 24. For ASBs, 2-channel amplifiers, and 4-channel amplifi-
ers, the maximum number of zones or all attached stations is 24. Admin 
Phones can be enrolled in a maximum of seven zones. An error displays 
if you attempt to add a Nyquist station to a zone and it is already 
enrolled in the maximum number of zones.

qas.question: What steps are required to view existing zones on the Zones page?

answers.text: To view existing zones on the Zones page, expand "Zones and Queues" in the navigation bar and select "Zones." You can switch between table format and card view by using the Filter icon.

qas.question: How can the view format for zones be changed on the page?

answers.text: To change the view format for zones on the page, select the Filter icon. This allows you to toggle between table format and card view by zone format.

qas.question: What permissions are needed to add a zone?

answers.text: You must have permission to add zones in order to perform the procedure of creating a zone. This permission is necessary to access options for manual paging, scheduled time paging, or audio distribution for the new zone.

qas.question: What are the allowed types of zones regarding paging and audio distribution?

answers.text: Zones can be designated to allow manual paging, scheduled time paging, audio distribution, or any combination thereof. When creating a zone, you must specify the type to determine its paging and audio capabilities.

qas.question: What character limit is imposed on the user-created name for a zone?

answers.text: The user-created name for a zone can contain up to 255 characters and can be alphanumeric.

qas.question: What does the "Preannounce Tone" parameter signify in zone settings?

answers.text: The "Preannounce Tone" parameter specifies the tone that should play before an announcement is made in a zone. This tone can alert users that a message is about to be communicated, enhancing clarity and attention.

qas.question: What is the range for the Cut Level (dB) setting in a zone?

answers.text: The range for the Cut Level (dB) setting in a zone is from 0 to -42 dB. This setting determines the device volume cut level for announcements within the zone.

qas.question: How many extensions can be displayed when "Show" is selected for stations?

answers.text: When "Show" is selected for stations, the extensions included in the zone are displayed. The maximum number of zones that a Nyquist appliance can be enrolled in is 24, and each Nyquist station can be enrolled in a maximum of 24 zones. However, the exact number of extensions displayed when "Show" is selected is not specified in the provided context.

qas.question: What information does the Multicast IP Address parameter provide?

answers.text: The Multicast IP Address parameter identifies the IP address used for multicast calls within a specific zone. This allows for the efficient distribution of audio or paging announcements to all devices within that zone.

qas.question: What is the maximum number of zones that a Nyquist appliance can enroll in?

answers.text: The maximum number of zones that a Nyquist appliance can enroll in is 24. This limit also applies to ASBs, 2-channel amplifiers, and 4-channel amplifiers, which can support a maximum of 24 zones or all attached stations combined. Admin Phones can be enrolled in a maximum of seven zones.

qas.question: What permissions are required to add zones?

answers.text: To add zones, you must have permission to perform this action. Additionally, you need to create separate page and time zones if you want tones to play during active pages, with time zones needing to be established first to set their priority.

qas.question: What are the different types of zones that can be created?

answers.text: The different types of zones that can be created are: Paging, Time, Audio, and combinations thereof, such as Paging+Time, Paging+Audio, Audio+Time, and Paging+Time+Audio. Each zone type serves specific functions related to paging, timed announcements, or audio distribution.

qas.question: What is the maximum number of zones a Nyquist appliance can enroll in?

answers.text: A Nyquist appliance can enroll in a maximum of 24 zones. For ASBs, 2-channel amplifiers, and 4-channel amplifiers, the total number of zones or all attached stations combined is also 24. Admin Phones can be enrolled in a maximum of seven zones.

qas.question: How do you set the cut level volume for devices in a zone?

answers.text: To set the cut level volume for devices in a zone, navigate to the zone’s configuration page and enter a value in the "Cut Level (dB)" parameter, which can range from 0 to -42 dB. This cut level will be used for pages, time scheduled tones, and manually activated tones for the devices included in the zone. Additionally, you can set a separate "Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB)" for audio distribution and scheduled audio.

qas.question: What parameters are necessary when adding a new zone?

answers.text: When adding a new zone, the necessary parameters include the zone number (up to five digits), name (up to 40 alphanumeric characters), cut level (ranging from 0 to -42 dB), audio distribution cut level, type (e.g., Paging, Time, Audio), stations to include, preannounce tone, multicast IP address, multicast port number (if applicable), and a description.

qas.question: Can an analog phone station be added to a zone?

answers.text: No, an analog phone station cannot be added to a zone. Only compatible extensions can be included in the zone.

qas.question: What should you do if you want tones to play during active pages?

answers.text: To have tones play during active pages, you must create separate page and time zones, ensuring that the time zones are created first. This prioritization allows time zones to take precedence over page zones.

qas.question: How can you edit an existing zone's configuration?

answers.text: To edit an existing zone's configuration, expand "Zones and Queues" in the navigation bar, select "Zones," and then click the Edit icon for the desired zone. Update the parameters as needed and select Save to apply the changes.

qas.question: What steps must be taken to delete a zone?
