3.12
Viewing Queues
Warning
Changes to queues – including adding a queue, modi-
fying an existing queue, or deleting a queue – will
result in the deletion of all recorded pages that have
not yet played. Changes should only be done after
business hours or during a small maintenance window
that does not exceed 5 minutes.
With the Page Queuing feature, you can record an unlimited number 
of pages or messages for queuing (stacking) for a specified zone or 
zones. A zone can only be added to a single queue, but a queue may 
have multiple zones associated with it. Zones must be created before 
a queue can be created.
Page Queuing is designed to eliminate feedback that can occur if a 
page is made in an area where a microphone and speaker are in close 
proximity. With page queuing, the page does not start until you (or 
the user recording the page) has indicated that the recording is com-
pleted.
Page Queuing also prevents page overlapping since pages sent to a 
queue play one at a time.
The Page Queuing feature differs from the Schedule Announcement 
(see "Using the Schedule Announcement Feature” on page 239) and 
Record Announcement (see "Monitoring/Recording” on page 479) 
features. The Schedule Announcement feature allows you to specify a 
date and time when the announcement is to be played, and the 
DTMF Code *990 allows a user to use the admin phone to record an 
announcement that is played immediately after it is recorded. 
Using the DTMF Codes *991 or *991*{Zone Number} or selecting 
Record Page from the Admin Phone or the Admin web UI allows you 
to initiate a queued page. 
When the DTMF Code #{Zone Number} is used to initiate a zone 
page, Nyquist will start a queued page if the zone belongs to a 
queue. If you want to start a real-time page to the zone instead, dial 
#{Zone Number}*.
With the Page Queuing feature, the recorded page is placed in a 
zone’s queue. The pages in the zone’s queue are played in the order 
that they are placed in the queue.
A live page started on a zone that is playing a recorded page will 
cause the recorded page to be terminated and sent back to the 
queue. The interrupted message will play again, from the beginning

qas.question: What permissions are required to edit a zone?

answers.text: To edit a zone, you must be logged in with a role that has permission to edit the zone. This permission is necessary to complete the editing process.

qas.question: How do you initiate the process to delete a zone?

answers.text: To initiate the process of deleting a zone, expand the "Zones and Queues" section on the navigation bar, select "Zones," and then click the Delete icon for the desired zone. Follow the confirmation page instructions by selecting "Delete."

qas.question: What happens to recorded pages when changes are made to queues?

answers.text: When changes are made to queues, including adding, modifying, or deleting a queue, all recorded pages that have not yet played will be deleted. It is advised to make these changes only after business hours or during a brief maintenance window not exceeding 5 minutes.

qas.question: Can a zone be linked to multiple queues?

answers.text: No, a zone can only be added to a single queue. However, a queue may have multiple zones associated with it.

qas.question: How does Page Queuing prevent audio feedback during announcements?

answers.text: Page Queuing prevents audio feedback by ensuring that a page does not start until the user confirms the recording is complete, eliminating the chance of feedback from nearby microphones and speakers. Additionally, it allows only one page to play at a time, reducing the risk of overlapping announcements.

qas.question: What distinguishes Page Queuing from the Schedule Announcement feature?

answers.text: Page Queuing allows users to record an unlimited number of pages for queuing in a specified zone, playing them one at a time to prevent overlapping and feedback. In contrast, the Schedule Announcement feature lets users specify a date and time for an announcement to be played.

qas.question: What DTMF code initiates a queued page?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to initiate a queued page is #{Zone Number}. If you want to start a real-time page to the zone instead, you should dial #{Zone Number}*.

qas.question: How is a real-time page initiated differently from a queued page?

answers.text: A real-time page is initiated by dialing #{Zone Number}*, while a queued page is started using the DTMF Code #{Zone Number} for zones that belong to a queue. This distinction ensures that real-time pages play immediately, whereas queued pages are played in the order they were recorded.

qas.question: What occurs if a live page starts while a recorded page is playing?

answers.text: If a live page starts while a recorded page is playing in a zone, the recorded page will be terminated and sent back to the queue. The interrupted message will then play again from the beginning.

qas.question: Is it possible to change the zone number for a zone linked to a routine?

answers.text: No, it is not possible to change the zone number for a zone that is linked to a routine. Additionally, you cannot delete a zone that is linked to a routine either.

qas.question: What are the consequences of making changes to queues during business hours?

answers.text: Making changes to queues during business hours, such as adding, modifying, or deleting a queue, will result in the deletion of all recorded pages that have not yet played. Therefore, it is advised to perform such changes only after business hours or during a short maintenance window not exceeding 5 minutes to avoid disruptions.

qas.question: How many queues can a user create for stacking pages?

answers.text: A user can create multiple queues for stacking pages. However, each zone can only be associated with a single queue.

qas.question: Can a zone be associated with multiple queues?

answers.text: No, a zone can only be associated with a single queue. However, a queue may have multiple zones associated with it.

qas.question: What is the maximum delay allowed between messages in a queue?

answers.text: The maximum delay allowed between messages in a queue is 10 seconds. The delay can be adjusted within a range of 1 to 10 seconds, with the default set to 2 seconds.

qas.question: How many times can each page in the queue be set to play?

answers.text: Each page in the queue can be set to play between 1 and 3 times. The default setting is for the message to play only once.

qas.question: Which types of zones can be selected when adding a queue?

answers.text: When adding a queue, only zones that are not already assigned to a queue and are of the types Paging, Paging+Time, Paging+Audio, and Paging+Time+Audio can be selected. A zone can only be associated with a single queue.

qas.question: How does the Page Queuing feature prevent page overlapping?

answers.text: The Page Queuing feature prevents page overlapping by ensuring that pages sent to a queue play one at a time. It requires users to indicate when a recording is completed, preventing another page from starting until the current one has finished.

qas.question: What happens to a recorded message when a live page is initiated to the same zone?

answers.text: When a live page is initiated to a zone that is currently playing a recorded message, the recorded message is terminated and sent back to the queue. The interrupted message will play again from the beginning once the zone becomes idle.

qas.question: What occurs if the Disable Audio option is selected during playback?

answers.text: Selecting the Disable Audio option during playback will stop all recorded messages. When audio is re-enabled, the messages will resume playback from the beginning.

qas.question: How can users view existing queues in the system?

answers.text: Users can view existing queues by expanding "Zones and Queues" on the navigation bar and then selecting "Queues." This will display the information about the queues, including their assigned numbers and names.

qas.question: What is the maximum number of zones that a queue can have?

qas.question: Can a zone be associated with multiple queues?

answers.text: No, a zone can only be associated with a single queue. While multiple queues can be created and may contain one or more zones, each zone must remain unique to one queue.

qas.question: What is the default delay time between messages in a queue?

answers.text: The default delay time between messages in a queue is 2 seconds. This delay can range between 1 and 10 seconds as specified in the parameters.

qas.question: How many times can each page in a queue play?

answers.text: Each page in a queue can play between 1 and 3 times, with the default being 1 play. The number of plays for each page can be adjusted as needed within this range.

qas.question: What types of zones appear in the drop-down menu when adding a queue?

answers.text: When adding a queue, the drop-down menu will only display zones that are not already assigned to a queue and are of the types: Paging, Paging+Time, Paging+Audio, and Paging+Time+Audio. A zone can only be associated with a single queue.

qas.question: What happens to recorded pages that have not yet played when changes are made to queues?

qas.question: What are the steps to create a new queue?

answers.text: To create a new queue, expand the Zones and Queues menu on the navigation bar, select Queues, click the Add icon, complete the Add Queue parameters, and then select Save. Remember that changes to queues will delete all recorded pages that have not yet played, so perform this during off-hours or a short maintenance window.

qas.question: How can you modify an existing queue?

answers.text: To modify an existing queue, expand the Zones and Queues section on the navigation bar, select Queues, and click the Edit icon next to the desired queue. Make the necessary changes to the queue parameters and then select Save. Be aware that modifying a queue will delete all recorded pages that have not yet played, so it should be done during a maintenance window.

qas.question: What should you do before deleting a queue?

answers.text: Before deleting a queue, ensure that all changes are made after business hours or during a small maintenance window not exceeding 5 minutes. This is important because deletion will result in the loss of all recorded pages that have not yet played.

qas.question: What is the importance of performing changes during non-business hours?

answers.text: Changes to queues, such as adding, modifying, or deleting a queue, result in the deletion of all recorded pages that have not yet played. Therefore, it is critical to perform these changes during non-business hours or within a small maintenance window, preferably not exceeding 5 minutes, to minimize disruption to operations.

4
Managing Bridge 
Devices
179
Managing Bridge Devices
Bridge Devices, such as the NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB), 
allow the E7000 solution to use the existing analog call switches, 25 
volt speakers, analog phones, and existing infrastructure when 
upgrading from Multicom 2000, Quantum Multicom IP, and sup-
ported third-party intercom systems. When used exclusively as a net-
worked component of the E7000 series paging and intercom 
solution, the ASB permits a hybrid IP/analog system configuration 
through use or connection of analog 25V speakers and associated 
analog call switches (for example, CA-15C type). 
The ASB has 24 station connections that attach to hardwired 25 volt 
speakers and their associated call switches. While each connection 
has its own SIP addressable Station ID, the ASB itself uses a single 
network IP address.
4.1
Viewing Bridge Devices
Through the Bridge Devices page, you can view information about all 
bridge devices configured for your E7000 system, select to add or 
edit devices, and select to manage stations for a bridge device.
Figure 4-1, Bridge Devices Page

qas.question: What warning should be considered before making changes to queues?

answers.text: Before making changes to queues, be aware that adding, modifying, or deleting a queue will result in the deletion of all recorded pages that have not yet played. It is advised to make these changes only after business hours or during a maintenance window that does not exceed 5 minutes.

qas.question: How are recorded pages affected by modifying or deleting a queue?

answers.text: Modifying or deleting a queue will result in the deletion of all recorded pages that have not yet played. This action should be performed only after business hours or during a short maintenance window not exceeding 5 minutes.

qas.question: What is the purpose of Bridge Devices in the E7000 solution?

answers.text: Bridge Devices, such as the NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB), enable the E7000 solution to integrate with existing analog infrastructure, including call switches and 25-volt speakers, during upgrades from older systems. They facilitate a hybrid IP/analog configuration, supporting 24 station connections with individual SIP addressable Station IDs, while using a single network IP address for the ASB.

qas.question: How many station connections does the ASB provide?

answers.text: The ASB provides 24 station connections that attach to hardwired 25 volt speakers and their associated call switches. Each connection has its own SIP addressable Station ID, while the ASB itself uses a single network IP address.

qas.question: What type of systems can be upgraded using Bridge Devices?

answers.text: Bridge Devices can be used to upgrade existing analog call switches, 25 volt speakers, analog phones, and infrastructure from Multicom 2000, Quantum Multicom IP, and supported third-party intercom systems to the E7000 series paging and intercom solution. They enable a hybrid IP/analog system configuration.

qas.question: How can you access the Bridge Devices page?

answers.text: To access the Bridge Devices page, expand the navigation bar by selecting Zones and then choose Bridge Devices. Here, you can view information about all configured bridge devices for your E7000 system.

qas.question: What configuration does the ASB allow for the E7000 series solution?

answers.text: The ASB (Analog Station Bridge) allows the E7000 series solution to integrate existing analog call switches and 25 volt speakers while enabling a hybrid IP/analog system configuration. It supports 24 station connections with individual SIP addressable Station IDs, all operating under a single network IP address.

qas.question: How does the ASB utilize SIP addressable Station IDs?

answers.text: The ASB utilizes SIP addressable Station IDs by assigning each of its 24 station connections, which are linked to hardwired 25 volt speakers and associated call switches, a unique Station ID. This allows for distinct identification and management of each connection within the network while the ASB itself operates using a single network IP address.

qas.question: What should you do to delete a queue?

answers.text: To delete a queue, expand "Zones and Queues" on the navigation bar, select "Queues," and then click the Delete icon next to the desired queue. When prompted, confirm the deletion by selecting "Delete." Ensure this action is performed after business hours or within a maintenance window not exceeding 5 minutes, as it will delete all recorded pages that have not yet played.

Managing Bridge 
Devices
179
Managing Bridge Devices
Bridge Devices, such as the NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB), 
allow the E7000 solution to use the existing analog call switches, 25 
volt speakers, analog phones, and existing infrastructure when 
upgrading from Multicom 2000, Quantum Multicom IP, and sup-
ported third-party intercom systems. When used exclusively as a net-
worked component of the E7000 series paging and intercom 
solution, the ASB permits a hybrid IP/analog system configuration 
through use or connection of analog 25V speakers and associated 
analog call switches (for example, CA-15C type). 
The ASB has 24 station connections that attach to hardwired 25 volt 
speakers and their associated call switches. While each connection 
has its own SIP addressable Station ID, the ASB itself uses a single 
network IP address.
4.1
Viewing Bridge Devices
Through the Bridge Devices page, you can view information about all 
bridge devices configured for your E7000 system, select to add or 
edit devices, and select to manage stations for a bridge device.
Figure 4-1, Bridge Devices Page

qas.question: What is the function of the NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB) in the E7000 solution?

answers.text: The NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB) allows the E7000 solution to integrate with existing analog infrastructure, enabling the use of analog call switches, 25 volt speakers, and analog phones when upgrading from older intercom systems. It supports a hybrid IP/analog configuration with 24 station connections, each having a unique SIP addressable Station ID, while the ASB itself operates using a single network IP address.

qas.question: How does the ASB facilitate a hybrid IP/analog system configuration?

answers.text: The ASB facilitates a hybrid IP/analog system configuration by allowing the connection of analog 25V speakers and associated call switches to the E7000 solution. It provides 24 station connections, each with its own SIP addressable Station ID, while the ASB operates using a single network IP address.

qas.question: How many station connections does the ASB have for 25 volt speakers and call switches?

answers.text: The ASB has 24 station connections that attach to hardwired 25 volt speakers and their associated call switches. Each connection has its own SIP addressable Station ID, while the ASB uses a single network IP address.

qas.question: What type of existing infrastructure can be utilized when upgrading to the E7000 solution?

answers.text: When upgrading to the E7000 solution, existing infrastructure such as analog call switches, 25 volt speakers, and analog phones can be utilized. This allows for a hybrid IP/analog system configuration, integrating with devices like the NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge.

qas.question: How is the ASB identified on the network compared to its station connections?

answers.text: The ASB (Analog Station Bridge) uses a single network IP address for identification, while each of its 24 station connections has its own unique SIP addressable Station ID. This setup allows the ASB to function as a collective component within the networked E7000 series system.

qas.question: What can be managed through the Bridge Devices page in the E7000 system?

answers.text: Through the Bridge Devices page in the E7000 system, you can view information about all configured bridge devices, add or edit devices, and manage stations for a bridge device. This allows for effective management of analog and hybrid IP/analog system configurations.

Through the Bridge Devices page, you can view information about all

The Bridge Devices page provides a list of all bridges that have been

Table 4-1,  Bridge Devices Page Parameters
Name
Provides a name for the bridge.
Manage
Provides a link to the Station Management tools.
Action
Provides a Reboot button to select if the bridge device 
needs to be rebooted.
MAC Address
Provides the MAC address for the bridge device.
Serial Number
Provides serial number of the bridge device.
IP Address
Provides the IP address for the bridge device.
Link
Provides a link to the bridge device’s user interface.
Status
Provides the status of the bridge device. Possible statuses 
include:
• Unknown. The server is unable to determine the state of 
the device.
• Unreachable. The server is unable to ping the device.
• Registering. More than one IP address has been found. 
Stations may still be registering with new IP addresses.
• Up: X of 24 stations. At least some of the stations are 
registered with the E7000 Series server and are operat-
ing.
Description
Provides a description for the bridge device.
Intercom Cut Level 
(dB)
Indicates the intercom volume cut level, which applies to all 
attached stations for intercom calls. The intercom volume 
cut level can range from 0 to -42. 
Output Power (dB)
Provides the channel output setting. The available settings 
increment by 1 and range from -6 to 6 with the default 
being 0.
VLAN Configuration
Specifies how the VLAN configuration is set. 
181
VLAN ID
Identifies the VLAN for this bridge device. The VLAN ID 
parameters range from 2 through 4094 and pertain to the 
bridge’s network interface (not to the ports or stations).
VLAN Priority
Identifies the priority for the port. Values range from 0 
through 7.
Web Username
Provides a username for logging into the bridge device.
Firmware
Provides information about firmware that is loaded onto 
the bridge device.

qas.question: What is the purpose of Bridge Devices like the NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB)?

answers.text: Bridge Devices like the NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB) enable the E7000 solution to integrate existing analog infrastructure, such as call switches and speakers, during upgrades from systems like Multicom 2000 and Quantum Multicom IP. The ASB supports a hybrid IP/analog configuration, connecting hardwired 25 volt speakers and their associated call switches while utilizing a single network IP address for the device.

qas.question: How many station connections does the ASB provide for hardwired 25 volt speakers?

answers.text: The NQ-E7030 Analog Station Bridge (ASB) provides 24 station connections for hardwired 25 volt speakers. Each connection is associated with its own SIP addressable Station ID, while the ASB itself uses a single network IP address.

qas.question: What type of configuration does the ASB allow within the E7000 series paging and intercom solution?

answers.text: The ASB allows a hybrid IP/analog system configuration within the E7000 series paging and intercom solution, enabling the use of existing analog call switches, 25-volt speakers, and analog phones. It supports up to 24 station connections, each with its own SIP addressable Station ID, while the ASB itself utilizes a single network IP address.

qas.question: Where can you view bridge devices attached to your network?

answers.text: You can view bridge devices attached to your network on the Bridge Devices page, which can be accessed by selecting "Bridge Devices" from the navigation bar. This page displays a list of all discovered or manually configured bridge devices for your E7000 system, along with their relevant details.

qas.question: What information is displayed for each bridge device on the Bridge Devices page?

answers.text: The Bridge Devices page displays key information for each bridge device, including its name, MAC address, serial number, IP address, status, intercom cut level, output power, VLAN configuration, web username, and firmware details. Additionally, it provides links to manage the device and reboot options if necessary.

qas.question: What are the possible statuses for a bridge device listed on the Bridge Devices page?

answers.text: The possible statuses for a bridge device listed on the Bridge Devices page are: Unknown (server cannot determine the state), Unreachable (server cannot ping the device), Registering (multiple IP addresses found, stations still registering), and Up (at least some stations are registered and operating).

qas.question: How can you add a new bridge device to your E7000 system?

answers.text: To add a new bridge device to your E7000 system, select "Bridge Devices" from the navigation bar, then click on the Add icon on the Bridge Devices page. Following this, you can proceed with the configuration for the new bridge device.

qas.question: What is the default output power setting (dB) for a bridge device?

answers.text: The default output power setting for a bridge device is 0 dB. This setting is part of a range that increments by 1, from -6 to 6 dB.

qas.question: What range of VLAN IDs can be set for a bridge device?

answers.text: The range of VLAN IDs that can be set for a bridge device is from 2 to 4094. These VLAN ID parameters pertain specifically to the bridge’s network interface.

qas.question: What does the intercom cut level (dB) indicate in relation to the bridge devices?

answers.text: The intercom cut level (dB) indicates the volume reduction applied to all attached stations during intercom calls for the bridge devices. It can range from 0 to -42 dB, allowing for adjustments to ensure appropriate audio levels during communication.

qas.question: What steps are involved in adding a bridge device to the E7000 system?

answers.text: To add a bridge device to the E7000 system, select "Bridge Devices" from the navigation bar, click the Add icon, complete the required parameters on the Add Bridge Device page, and then select Save. This will redirect you to the Station Management page for adding stations and configuring their settings.

qas.question: What parameters are required when completing the Add Bridge Device page?

answers.text: The required parameters when completing the Add Bridge Device page include providing a Name, MAC Address, Serial Number, and configuring the VLAN related settings (VLAN Configuration, VLAN ID, and VLAN Priority). Additionally, a Web Username and Web Password must be specified, along with a description for the bridge device.

qas.question: What is the valid range for the Intercom Cut Level setting?

answers.text: The valid range for the Intercom Cut Level setting is from 0 to -42 dB. This setting applies to all attached stations for intercom calls.

qas.question: How can the Output Power setting be adjusted on the Add Bridge Device page?

answers.text: The Output Power setting on the Add Bridge Device page can be adjusted by selecting a value that increments by 1, ranging from -6 to 6, with the default setting being 0. This allows users to customize the channel output level for the bridge device.

qas.question: What options are available for the VLAN Configuration parameter?

answers.text: The VLAN Configuration parameter has three options: Server, Network/Device, or Disabled. These settings determine how the VLAN is configured for the bridge device.

qas.question: What is the range of valid values for the VLAN ID field?

answers.text: The valid range of values for the VLAN ID field is from 2 to 4094. This field cannot be edited after it is set.

qas.question: How do you specify a Web Username and Web Password for logging into the bridge?

answers.text: To specify a Web Username and Web Password for logging into the bridge, you need to fill in the corresponding fields on the Add Bridge Device page: enter the desired username in the Web Username field and the password in the Web Password field. Additionally, retype the password in the Web Password Confirmation field to confirm it before saving the settings.

qas.question: What parameters can be set for auto-generating new stations when adding a bridge?

answers.text: When adding a bridge, the parameters for auto-generating new stations include the "Number of Stations to Create," which allows you to select how many stations will be created automatically. Additionally, you can specify the "Station Name(s)" format and the "First Extension" to be used for naming the stations.

qas.question: What steps must be taken to edit an existing bridge device?

answers.text: To edit an existing bridge device, select "Bridge Devices" from the navigation bar, then click the Edit icon for the desired bridge. Complete the parameters on the Edit Bridge Device page as needed.

qas.question: What options are provided for the Station Type when creating stations for a bridge?

answers.text: The options provided for the Station Type when creating stations for a bridge are "VoIP Speaker Only" and "Call Switch & Speaker." These selections determine the functionality of the stations associated with the bridge device.

qas.question: How is the Day Admin and Night Admin extension selected for the bridge stations?

answers.text: The Day Admin and Night Admin extensions for the bridge stations are selected on the Edit Bridge Device page. Users can choose the appropriate extension for the Admin Station that will cover the attached stations during daytime and nighttime hours, respectively.

qas.question: What does the 911 Route parameter specify for the stations attached to a bridge?

answers.text: The 911 Route parameter specifies how 911 calls made by the stations attached to a bridge are to be routed. This setting ensures that emergency calls are directed to the appropriate service or destination based on the configuration of the bridge device.

qas.question: What are the steps to edit a bridge device in the system?

answers.text: To edit a bridge device, select "Bridge Devices" on the navigation bar, click the Edit icon for the desired bridge, and complete the parameters on the Edit Bridge Device page, including fields like Station Name(s), First Extension, and Admin Group. Finally, select "Save" to apply the changes.

qas.question: How can you specify the name format for creating stations associated with a bridge?

answers.text: To specify the name format for creating stations associated with a bridge, select the desired format from the Station Name(s) option on the Edit Bridge Device page. You can use the format [extension] to append the extension to the name, which is added by default.

qas.question: What must be entered as the first extension when editing a bridge device?

answers.text: The first extension to be used when creating stations for the bridge must be entered in the "First Extension" field on the Edit Bridge Device page. This extension will be the starting point for assigning extensions to the stations associated with the bridge.

qas.question: Which station types can be selected for the stations created under a bridge?

answers.text: The station types that can be selected for the stations created under a bridge are "VoIP Speaker Only" and "Call Switch & Speaker." These options allow for flexibility in configuring the functionality of the stations assigned to the bridge device.

qas.question: What are Day CoS and Night CoS in the context of a bridge device?

answers.text: Day CoS (Class of Service) and Night CoS are default settings applied to the stations attached to a bridge device, determining the service priorities and functionalities during daytime and nighttime hours, respectively. These settings help manage the behavior of the stations based on the time of day, ensuring appropriate call handling and resource allocation.

qas.question: How is the Admin Group associated with the station identified?

answers.text: The Admin Group associated with the station is identified by its designation in the settings. It is called if the Day/Night admin does not answer within 30 seconds.

qas.question: What role does the Day Admin extension play in a bridge device configuration?

answers.text: The Day Admin extension in a bridge device configuration is the designated extension that manages and oversees the stations during daytime hours. It is contacted when there are issues that require administrative attention, particularly if the Day/Night admin does not respond within 30 seconds.

qas.question: How do you specify how 911 calls are routed for stations under a bridge device?

answers.text: To specify how 911 calls are routed for stations under a bridge device, select the desired routing option in the "911 Route" parameter on the Edit Bridge Device page. Ensure that this setting is configured before saving the changes.

qas.question: What information is required regarding the bridge device's MAC Address and Serial Number?

answers.text: The MAC Address for the bridge device must be provided and is essential for network identification. Additionally, the Serial Number is required to uniquely identify the device, facilitating support and warranty services.

qas.question: What is the range for the intercom cut level in dB for attached stations?

answers.text: The range for the intercom cut level in dB for attached stations is from 0 to -42 dB. This setting specifies the volume cut level that applies to all intercom calls made by the stations.

qas.question: What default range does the output power (dB) setting have for a bridge device?

answers.text: The default range for the output power (dB) setting on a bridge device is from -6 to 6 dB, with the default value set to 0 dB.

qas.question: What parameters can be configured for VLAN settings in a bridge device?

answers.text: The parameters that can be configured for VLAN settings in a bridge device include VLAN Configuration (options: Server, Network/Device, or Disabled), VLAN ID (with valid values ranging from 2 to 4094, which cannot be edited), and VLAN Priority (valid values range from 0 to 7, which also cannot be edited).

qas.question: What roles do the Web Username and Web Password play in bridge device management?

answers.text: The Web Username and Web Password are used for authenticating access to the bridge device's management interface. They ensure that only authorized users can log in and make configurations or changes to the device settings.

qas.question: How can you specify a description for the bridge device during editing?

answers.text: To specify a description for the bridge device during editing, navigate to the Edit Bridge Device page and enter the desired description in the "Description" field. Make sure to select the Save option afterward to apply the changes.

Managing Amplifiers

address/mixer amplifier provided the amplifier has an available port. 
The station must be assigned manually but the audio power amplifier 
itself can be automatically discovered by your Nyquist system.

all audio power amplifiers and public address/mixer amplifiers con-

devices; select to manage stations for an amplifier, and select to con-
figure Push To Talk parameters for an amplifier.

qas.question: What parameters can be edited when configuring a bridge device in the E7000 system?

answers.text: When configuring a bridge device in the E7000 system, the editable parameters include the device name, MAC address, serial number, intercom cut level, output power, VLAN configuration settings, web username and password, firmware version, and a description for the bridge device. Additionally, you can reorder extensions for ports and edit individual station settings.

qas.question: How can you reorder extensions for a bridge device port in Station Management?

answers.text: To reorder extensions for a bridge device port in Station Management, select the icon next to the Name (Extension) of the port and drag the extension to the desired location. This allows you to easily move extensions to different ports as needed.

qas.question: What settings are available to apply to newly created stations in Station Management?

answers.text: In Station Management, the settings available to apply to newly created stations include the Station Type (VoIP Speaker Only, Analog Call Switch & Speaker, Digital Call Switch & Speaker, Analog Phone), Day and Night CoS (Class of Service) options, and routing for 911 calls. Additionally, you can specify the station name format, the first extension and port numbers for the generated stations, and the Admin Stations for both daytime and nighttime hours.

qas.question: What is the range of valid values for the Intercom Cut Level in decibels?

answers.text: The range of valid values for the Intercom Cut Level is from 0 to -42 decibels. This setting applies to all attached stations for intercom calls.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the VLAN Configuration parameter when setting up a bridge device?

answers.text: The VLAN Configuration parameter determines how the VLAN settings are applied to the bridge device. It can be set to Server, Network/Device, or Disabled, which influences the network's segmentation and communication policies for the attached stations.

qas.question: How can you generate new stations automatically when adding a new bridge device?

answers.text: To generate new stations automatically when adding a new bridge device, use the drop-down menu to select the number of stations to create and choose the settings to apply to the newly created stations. Finally, select "Generate Stations" to complete the process.

qas.question: Which types of stations can be selected when configuring stations attached to a bridge device?

answers.text: When configuring stations attached to a bridge device, you can select from the following station types: VoIP Speaker Only, Analog Call Switch & Speaker, Digital Call Switch & Speaker, and Analog Phone. Multiple analog and digital call switches can be assigned the same port by assigning the Digital Call Switch & Speaker type to each.

qas.question: How are 911 calls routed according to the Station Settings?

answers.text: In the Station Settings, the 911 Route specifies how 911 calls made by the stations are routed. Users can select from available routing options during the configuration process to ensure proper emergency call handling based on the assigned stations.

qas.question: What information is provided on the Amplifier Devices page in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Amplifier Devices page in the Nyquist system provides information about all configured audio power amplifiers and public address/mixer amplifiers, including options to view, add, edit, or delete these devices. It also allows users to manage stations assigned to an amplifier and configure Push To Talk parameters.

qas.question: How must stations be assigned to an audio power amplifier or public address/mixer amplifier?

answers.text: Stations must be assigned manually to an audio power amplifier or public address/mixer amplifier, provided the amplifier has an available port. The audio power amplifier itself can be automatically discovered by the Nyquist system.

qas.question: How can a station be assigned to an audio power amplifier?

answers.text: A station can be assigned to an audio power amplifier manually through the Amplifier Devices page in the Nyquist system, provided the amplifier has an available port. The amplifier can be automatically discovered by the system to facilitate this assignment.

qas.question: What types of amplifiers can be managed within the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Nyquist system can manage audio power amplifiers and public address/mixer amplifiers. These amplifiers can be automatically discovered and configured within the system, allowing for manual station assignments and adjustments to settings like Push To Talk parameters.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Amplifier Devices page?

answers.text: The Amplifier Devices page allows users to view, add, edit, or delete audio power amplifiers and public address/mixer amplifiers within the Nyquist system. It also enables the management of station assignments for each amplifier and the configuration of Push To Talk parameters.

qas.question: Can audio power amplifiers be discovered automatically in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: Yes, audio power amplifiers can be automatically discovered by the Nyquist system. However, stations must be assigned manually to the amplifier.

qas.question: What actions can you perform on amplifier devices within the Nyquist system?

answers.text: Within the Nyquist system, you can view information about amplifier devices, add, edit, or delete them, manage stations assigned to an amplifier, and configure Push To Talk parameters. Additionally, audio power amplifiers can be automatically discovered by the system.

qas.question: Is it possible to configure Push To Talk parameters for an amplifier?

answers.text: Yes, it is possible to configure Push To Talk parameters for an amplifier within the Nyquist system. This can be done through the Amplifier Devices page, where you can manage settings for audio power amplifiers and public address/mixer amplifiers.

qas.question: Are manual assignments required for stations on all amplifiers?

answers.text: Yes, manual assignments are required for stations on all amplifiers in the Nyquist system. However, the audio power amplifier itself can be automatically discovered.

qas.question: What type of amplifiers can be assigned stations in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: In the Nyquist system, stations can be assigned to both audio power amplifiers and public address/mixer amplifiers, as long as the amplifier has an available port. The assignment of stations must be done manually.

qas.question: How can you view information about amplifiers in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To view information about amplifiers in the Nyquist system, navigate to the Amplifier Devices page from the navigation bar. This page displays details such as the amplifier's name, device type, MAC address, IP address, status, and allows management of associated stations.

qas.question: What does the status "Registering" indicate about the amplifier's state?

answers.text: The status "Registering" indicates that more than one IP address has been found for the amplifier and that stations may still be in the process of registering with new IP addresses. This status suggests that the amplifier is actively attempting to establish its connections but has not yet completed the registration process.

qas.question: What is the VLAN ID range for the amplifier's network interface?

answers.text: The VLAN ID range for the amplifier's network interface is from 2 to 4094. This configuration is applicable when the VLAN Configuration is set to the "Server" option.

qas.question: How can you access the web UI of an amplifier?

answers.text: To access the web UI of an amplifier, you need to go to the Amplifier Devices page and locate the amplifier you want to access. From there, click on the link provided under the "Link" column associated with that amplifier.

qas.question: What parameters can be edited when adding a new amplifier?

answers.text: When adding a new amplifier, you can edit parameters such as the amplifier's name, device type, MAC address, IP address, VLAN configuration, VLAN ID, VLAN priority, web username, web password, and firmware version. Other parameters include the number of stations and channels configured on the amplifier.

qas.question: What does the "Manage" link allow you to do for an amplifier?

answers.text: The "Manage" link allows you to access the Station Management tools for the amplifier, enabling you to assign stations manually and manage their configurations.

qas.question: What happens if the number of registered stations does not match the number expected by the amplifier?

answers.text: If the number of registered stations does not match the expected number for the amplifier, it indicates that one or more stations may not be available for service. This discrepancy could be due to stations still registering or a potential configuration error if the issue persists.

qas.question: What are the possible statuses specified for the amplifiers on the Amplifier Devices page?

answers.text: The possible statuses for amplifiers on the Amplifier Devices page are: Unknown (the server cannot determine the device's state), Unreachable (the server cannot ping the device), Registering (more than one IP address has been found), and Up (indicating the number of registered available stations attached to the amplifier). If the number of registered stations does not match, it may indicate that one or more stations are unavailable or there is a configuration error.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the "Reboot" button located on the Amplifier Devices page?

answers.text: The "Reboot" button on the Amplifier Devices page allows users to restart the selected amplifier if needed. This function is helpful for resolving issues or refreshing the device's connection within the network.

Mixer Amplifier
Like with the Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp, configuring a Public Address/ 
Mixer Amplifier for Push To Talk is a two-step process. The first part is 
done through the Admin Web UI and pertains to enabling a Push To 
Talk Channel and selecting a Push To Talk Type.
The second step is done through the appliance’s web UI and involves 
enabling the Line Out for the selected channel.

qas.question: What steps are required to add a new amplifier to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To add a new amplifier to the Nyquist system, select Amplifier Devices from the navigation bar, click the Add icon, and fill in the required parameters on the Add Amplifier Device page. Finally, click Save to complete the process and proceed to the Station Management page.

qas.question: What information is required to enter in the "Add Amplifier Device" page?

answers.text: To add an amplifier, you need to provide the name, device type, MAC address, serial number, VLAN configuration, VLAN ID, VLAN priority, web username, and password on the "Add Amplifier Device" page. The VLAN ID and priority can only be modified when the Server option is selected for VLAN Configuration.

qas.question: How can the VLAN configuration for the amplifier be set, and what options are available?

answers.text: The VLAN configuration for the amplifier can be set by selecting one of the available options: Server, Network/Device, or Disabled. This selection determines how the VLAN is configured for the amplifier’s network interface.

qas.question: What parameters can be edited in the Edit Amplifier Device page?

answers.text: The parameters that can be edited on the Edit Amplifier Device page include the amplifier's name, device type, MAC address, serial number, VLAN configuration and ID, VLAN priority, web username, and password. These are the same parameters available on the Add Amplifier page.

qas.question: What is the process to configure Push to Talk for a Public Address/Mixer Amplifier?

answers.text: To configure Push to Talk for a Public Address/Mixer Amplifier, first enable a Push To Talk Channel and select a Push To Talk Type through the Admin Web UI. Then, access the appliance’s web UI to enable the Line Out for the selected channel.

qas.question: What information does the firmware section provide about the amplifier?

answers.text: The firmware section provides information about the firmware that is loaded onto the amplifier, including details such as the version and status of the firmware currently in use. This information is essential for ensuring that the amplifier operates with the latest features and fixes.

qas.question: How is the number of stations associated with the amplifier determined?

answers.text: The number of stations associated with the amplifier is determined by the number of ports available on the amplifier. Each port can be linked to a different station, indicating how many stations can be connected to the device.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the "Description" field when adding an amplifier?

answers.text: The "Description" field when adding an amplifier is designed to provide additional details about the device. This can help users identify the amplifier's specific purpose or features, enhancing clarity and organization within the system.

qas.question: What is the first step to edit an amplifier in the system?

answers.text: The first step to edit an amplifier in the system is to select "Amplifier Devices" from the navigation bar. After that, you can proceed to select the Edit icon on the Amplifier Devices page.

qas.question: Where can you find the parameters for editing an amplifier?

answers.text: The parameters for editing an amplifier can be found on the Edit Amplifier Device page, which contains the same parameters as the Add Amplifier page. You can refer to "Add Amplifier Parameters" on page 194 for more details.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Station Management button when editing an amplifier?

answers.text: The Station Management button allows users to associate stations with the amplifier while editing it. This functionality helps manage the connections and configurations related to the amplifier effectively.

qas.question: How is Push To Talk configured for a Public Address/Mixer Amplifier?

answers.text: Configuring Push To Talk for a Public Address/Mixer Amplifier involves a two-step process: first, enable a Push To Talk Channel and select a Push To Talk Type through the Admin Web UI; second, enable the Line Out for the selected channel via the appliance’s web UI.

qas.question: What information does the firmware section provide about the amplifier?

answers.text: The firmware section provides information about the firmware that is loaded onto the amplifier. This includes details on the version and status of the firmware, which can be important for ensuring compatibility and optimal performance of the amplifier.

qas.question: How can you determine the number of stations associated with the amplifier?

answers.text: The number of stations associated with the amplifier can be determined by checking the "Number of Stations" parameter on the Amplifier Devices page, which reflects the count of stations based on the number of ports linked to the device.

qas.question: What role do channels play in the configuration of the amplifier?

answers.text: Channels in the configuration of the amplifier represent the specific paths through which audio signals are processed and outputted. They are configured via switch positions on the amplifier, allowing for customized audio routing and management based on the amplifier’s capabilities and the associated stations.

qas.question: What type of description is provided for the amplifier device?

answers.text: The description provided for the amplifier device includes information about the device's functionality and configuration, such as its firmware details, the number of associated stations based on ports, and the configured channels via switch position. This information helps in understanding the amplifier's capabilities and management.

qas.question: What is the significance of enabling the Line Out in the configuration process?

answers.text: Enabling the Line Out in the configuration process is essential for routing audio signals from the Public Address/Mixer Amplifier to external devices, allowing effective communication and sound amplification. This step ensures that the selected Push To Talk channel can output audio properly for performance in public address systems.

qas.question: What is the first step to edit an amplifier in the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: The first step to edit an amplifier in the Admin Web UI is to select "Amplifier Devices" from the navigation bar. Then, on the Amplifier Devices page, click the Edit icon for the amplifier you wish to modify.

qas.question: How can you associate stations to an amplifier?

answers.text: To associate stations to an amplifier, navigate to the Amplifier Devices page and select the Station Management button. From there, you can manage and associate the desired stations to the amplifier.

qas.question: What parameters on the Edit Amplifier Device page are similar to those on the Add Amplifier page?

answers.text: The parameters on the Edit Amplifier Device page that are similar to those on the Add Amplifier page include firmware information, the number of associated stations, configured channels, and device description. These parameters allow for consistent configuration and management of amplifiers.

qas.question: What is the purpose of enabling the Push To Talk Channel in the configuration process?

answers.text: Enabling the Push To Talk Channel in the configuration process allows for the selection of a Push To Talk Type, which facilitates communication through the Public Address/Mixer Amplifier. This is essential for ensuring that audio is transmitted correctly when the Push To Talk feature is activated.

qas.question: What must be done on the appliance's web UI to complete the Push To Talk configuration?

answers.text: On the appliance's web UI, you must enable the Line Out for the selected channel to complete the Push To Talk configuration. Additionally, if you have selected Analog for PTT Stream Source for Mixer Output on the server side, disable Line-Out and Speaker-Out for channel 4 (A4-LO and A4-SO).

qas.question: What should be disabled to prevent PTT from being heard on both the speaker and line-out?

answers.text: To prevent PTT from being heard on both the speaker and line-out, you must disable Line-Out and Speaker-Out for channel 4 (A4-LO and A4-SO) on the appliance’s DSP Router. This ensures that the PTT Output set on the Edit Push To Talk Configuration page functions correctly.

qas.question: How does the number of ports affect the stations displayed on the Station Management page?

answers.text: The number of ports on an amplifier determines how many stations can be associated with that device. Consequently, the Station Management page displays the number of ports available based on the type of amplifier, such as the A2120 Audio Power Amplifier.

qas.question: What information does the Firmware section provide on the amplifier?

answers.text: The Firmware section provides information about the firmware that is loaded onto the amplifier. This includes details on the version and status of the firmware currently in use.

qas.question: What is included in the description section for the amplifier?

answers.text: The description section for the amplifier includes a brief overview of the device, detailing its associated firmware, the number of stations linked to the device based on the number of ports, and the channels configured on the amplifier via switch position.

qas.question: Where can you find more information about configuring a device for Push To Talk?

answers.text: More information about configuring a device for Push To Talk can be found in the section titled "Configuring Device for Push To Talk" on page 139 of the manual. It outlines the necessary steps for enabling a Push To Talk Channel and selecting a Push To Talk Type through the Admin Web UI.

qas.question: What must be disabled on the appliance’s DSP Router when selecting Analog for PTT Stream Source for Mixer Output?

answers.text: When selecting Analog for PTT Stream Source for Mixer Output on the server side, you must disable Line-Out and Speaker-Out for channel 4 (A4-LO and A4-SO) on the appliance’s DSP Router to prevent hearing PTT on both the speaker and line-out.

qas.question: How does the number of ports in Station Management for amplifiers relate to the device type?

answers.text: The number of ports displayed in the Station Management page for amplifiers is directly related to the device type; for example, the A2120 Audio Power Amplifier has two ports, while the four-channel A4120 Audio Power Amplifier displays four ports. Public Address/Mixer Amplifiers like the NQ-PA120, NQ-PA240, or NQ-PA600 will show both Speaker Out and Line Out options.

qas.question: Which amplifiers will show Speaker Out and Line Out options in Station Management?

answers.text: The amplifiers that will show Speaker Out and Line Out options in Station Management are the Public Address/Mixer Amplifiers, specifically the NQ-PA120, NQ-PA240, and NQ-PA600 models.

qas.question: What is the first step to use Station Management for amplifiers?

answers.text: The first step to use Station Management for amplifiers is to select "Amplifier Devices" from the navigation bar. Then, choose "Station Management" for the desired amplifier.

qas.question: What action should be taken to delete a port in Station Management?

answers.text: To delete a port in Station Management, select the Delete icon next to the desired port, and when prompted, confirm the deletion by selecting Delete.

6 Managing Roles and 
Users
199
Managing Roles and Users
Nyquist uses roles to control system configuration, access, and use. 
When you create a user, you assign a role that determines what the 
user sees from the dashboard and what tasks the user can perform.
Nyquist provides four default roles. These roles can be edited or 
deleted by anyone assigned permissions to do so. Of the default roles, 
only the Admin role has the ability to add users and to add, edit, and 
delete roles.
Table 6-1,  Default Roles
Admin
Has access to the entire system and can perform all tasks.
OpTech
Can operate the system and view, but not change, system 
configurations.
Operator
Can operate the system, but cannot view or change system 
configurations.
User
Can only operate specific parts of the system.

qas.question: What steps are involved in using Station Management for amplifiers?

answers.text: To use Station Management for amplifiers, navigate to the Amplifier Devices section and select Station Management for the desired amplifier. You can then delete a port by selecting the Delete icon and confirming the action, or edit a station by selecting the Edit icon next to the port.

qas.question: How can you delete a port in Station Management?

answers.text: To delete a port in Station Management, select the Delete icon next to the port you wish to remove. When prompted, confirm the deletion by selecting Delete.

qas.question: What occurs on the Station Management page when a new amplifier is created?

answers.text: When a new amplifier is created, the Station Management page for that amplifier automatically appears. This page displays the available ports and allows for management actions, such as editing or deleting ports associated with the amplifier.

qas.question: How can you delete an amplifier device through the Amplifier Devices page?

answers.text: To delete an amplifier device through the Amplifier Devices page, select the Delete icon next to the amplifier you want to remove. When prompted, confirm the deletion by selecting Delete.

qas.question: What are the four default roles provided by Nyquist?

answers.text: The four default roles provided by Nyquist are Admin, OpTech, Operator, and User. The Admin role has full access to the system, while OpTech can view system configurations without making changes, the Operator can operate the system without viewing configurations, and the User can only operate specific parts of the system.

qas.question: Which role has the highest level of access in Nyquist?

answers.text: The Admin role has the highest level of access in Nyquist. It allows users to access the entire system and perform all tasks, including adding users and managing roles.

qas.question: What capabilities does the OpTech role have within the system?

answers.text: The OpTech role can operate the system and view system configurations but cannot make any changes to them. This role allows for oversight of the system without the authority to modify configurations.

qas.question: Can a User role modify system configurations in Nyquist?

answers.text: No, a User role cannot modify system configurations in Nyquist. Users can only operate specific parts of the system without access to view or change any configurations.

199
Managing Roles and Users
Nyquist uses roles to control system configuration, access, and use. 
When you create a user, you assign a role that determines what the 
user sees from the dashboard and what tasks the user can perform.
Nyquist provides four default roles. These roles can be edited or 
deleted by anyone assigned permissions to do so. Of the default roles, 
only the Admin role has the ability to add users and to add, edit, and 
delete roles.
Table 6-1,  Default Roles
Admin
Has access to the entire system and can perform all tasks.
OpTech
Can operate the system and view, but not change, system 
configurations.
Operator
Can operate the system, but cannot view or change system 
configurations.
User
Can only operate specific parts of the system.
200
6.1
Viewing Roles
The default roles of Admin and OpTech can view existing roles. If you 
are assigned one of these roles or a user created role that allows it, 
you can assign View Roles permissions to other roles. 
To view roles:
On the navigation bar, select Roles.
The Roles page appears. The following table describes the parameters 
that appear on this page.
Figure 6-1, Roles Page
Table 6-2,  Roles Page Parameters
Permissions
When the icon is selected, displays the Edit Admin Permis-
sions page where the permissions assigned to this role can 
be viewed or changed.
Name
Displays the nomenclature created for the role.
Note: Valid characters include uppercase letters (A-Z), low-
ercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and the following 
special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: What are the four default roles provided by Nyquist?

answers.text: The four default roles provided by Nyquist are Admin, OpTech, Operator, and User. The Admin role has full access and management capabilities, while OpTech can view system configurations without changing them, Operator can operate the system without viewing configurations, and User can only operate specific parts of the system.

qas.question: Which role has the ability to add, edit, and delete users?

answers.text: The Admin role has the ability to add, edit, and delete users. This role also has access to the entire system and can perform all tasks.

qas.question: Can a User role change system configurations?

answers.text: No, a User role cannot change system configurations. The User role is limited to operating specific parts of the system without access to system configuration settings.

qas.question: What permissions can be assigned to roles by someone with Admin or OpTech roles?

answers.text: Someone with Admin or OpTech roles can assign View Roles permissions to other roles and can also access the Edit Admin Permissions page to view or change the permissions assigned to these roles. Admins have full control over adding, editing, and deleting roles, while OpTech can view existing roles.

qas.question: How can a user view existing roles in Nyquist?

answers.text: To view existing roles in Nyquist, a user with the Admin or OpTech role, or a user-created role that allows it, should select "Roles" from the navigation bar. This will open the Roles page, where they can see the parameters associated with each role.

qas.question: What characters are valid for naming roles in the system?

answers.text: Valid characters for naming roles in the system include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and the following special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: What is the primary function of the OpTech role?

answers.text: The primary function of the OpTech role is to operate the system and view its configurations without the ability to change them. This role allows users to monitor system status while restricting access to configuration changes.

qas.question: Which roles can view the permissions of the Admin role?

answers.text: The roles that can view the permissions of the Admin role are the Admin and OpTech roles. These roles have the capability to access the Edit Admin Permissions page to view or change the permissions assigned to the Admin role.

If none of the default roles have the exact permissions that you want

new role. For example, only the Admin default role has the ability to

special characters: !@$*?-.,.
Description
When the Show button is selected, displays a brief descrip-
tion of the role.
Note: Valid characters include uppercase letters (A-Z), low-
ercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and the following 
special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: What roles can view existing roles in the system?

answers.text: The roles that can view existing roles in the system are Admin and OpTech. Additionally, any user-created role that has been assigned the necessary permissions can also view roles.

qas.question: How can a user with the Admin role modify permissions for other roles?

answers.text: A user with the Admin role can modify permissions for other roles by selecting the appropriate icon on the Roles page, which directs them to the Edit Admin Permissions page. From there, they can view or change the permissions assigned to the specific role.

qas.question: What parameters are displayed on the Roles page?

answers.text: The Roles page displays parameters such as Permissions, Name, Label, and Description for each role. The Permissions section allows for viewing or editing assigned permissions, while the Name and Label show the nomenclature used for the role, and the Description provides a brief overview of the role's purpose. Valid characters for these fields include uppercase and lowercase letters, numerals, spaces, and specific special characters.

qas.question: Which role has the exclusive ability to create a new station?

answers.text: The Admin role has the exclusive ability to create a new station. No other default roles possess this permission.

qas.question: What special characters are allowed in role names and labels?

answers.text: The allowed special characters in role names and labels are: !, @, $, *, ?, -, ., and ,.

qas.question: How can a user access the Edit Admin Permissions page?

answers.text: A user can access the Edit Admin Permissions page by selecting the permissions icon on the Roles page. This action will display the page where the permissions assigned to the selected role can be viewed or changed.

qas.question: What does the Show button do in relation to role descriptions?

answers.text: The Show button, when selected, displays a brief description of the role. This feature helps users quickly understand the purpose and function of the specific role.

qas.question: Can a new role be created with permissions similar to an existing default role?

answers.text: Yes, a new role can be created with permissions similar to an existing default role. You can either edit the permissions of a default role or create a new role that specifically meets your requirements.

qas.question: What format should valid characters follow when naming roles?

answers.text: Valid characters for naming roles include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: Is it possible to edit the permissions of an existing role?

answers.text: Yes, it is possible to edit the permissions of an existing role. You can either modify the permissions of a default role or create a new role if none of the default roles meet your specific needs.

You may want to change the names, labels, and descriptions

want to change the permissions assigned to an existing role. In both 
of these scenarios, you would edit a role.

On the navigation bar, select Roles.

On the Roles page, select the Edit icon next to the role 
that you want to edit.

On the Edit Role page, make any desired changes to the 
Name, Label, and Description fields. (See "Roles Page 
Parameters” on page 200.)
Step 4
Select Save.
Step 5
On the Roles page, select the Permissions icon.
Step 6
On the Edit Permissions page, make desired changes. 
Step 7
Select Save.

qas.question: What is the first step required to add a new role?

answers.text: The first step required to add a new role is to select "Roles" on the navigation bar. This action takes you to the Roles page, where you can then select the Add icon to proceed with creating a new role.

qas.question: Which default role possesses the ability to create new stations?

answers.text: The Admin default role possesses the ability to create new stations. This role can also add new users, which is a unique permission not available to other default roles.

qas.question: What characters are allowed in the role name when creating a user?

answers.text: When creating a user role, valid characters for the role name include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: How do you access the Add Role page?

answers.text: To access the Add Role page, first select "Roles" from the navigation bar. Then, click on the Add icon on the Roles page.

qas.question: What should you do after adding the name, label, and description for a new role?

answers.text: After adding the name, label, and description for a new role, select "Save." Then, on the Roles page, select the Permissions icon for the newly added role to set its permissions.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Permissions icon in the Roles page?

answers.text: The Permissions icon on the Roles page allows users to set and modify permissions for a specific role. Selecting this icon takes users to the Edit Permissions page, where they can determine the capabilities associated with that role. This feature is only accessible to users logged in with a role that has permission to edit other roles.

qas.question: What changes can be made when editing a role?

answers.text: When editing a role, you can change the Name, Label, and Description fields for clarity. Additionally, you can modify the permissions assigned to the role to adjust its capabilities.

qas.question: How do you access the Edit Role page for an existing role?

answers.text: To access the Edit Role page for an existing role, first select "Roles" from the navigation bar. Then, click the Edit icon next to the role you want to modify on the Roles page.

qas.question: What must you have permission to do in order to edit roles?

answers.text: To edit roles, you must be logged in with a role that has permission to edit other roles. This includes the ability to change names, labels, descriptions, and permissions assigned to existing roles.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Show button on the Add Role page?

answers.text: The Show button on the Add Role page allows users to view a brief description of the role when selected. This descriptive text can provide clarity about the role's purpose and functionalities, helping users to ensure they are creating the appropriate role.

qas.question: What steps are involved in adding a new role in the system?

answers.text: To add a new role in the system, select Roles on the navigation bar, then click the Add Role button to enter the name, label, and description for the role. After saving, set the permissions for the new role by selecting the Permissions icon and saving the changes again.

qas.question: How can you edit the name, label, and description of an existing role?

answers.text: To edit the name, label, and description of an existing role, select the Roles option on the navigation bar, click the Edit icon next to the desired role, make changes on the Edit Role page, and then select Save. Finally, if needed, you can adjust permissions by selecting the Permissions icon and saving changes on the Edit Permissions page.

qas.question: What is required to assign or edit permissions for a role?

answers.text: To assign or edit permissions for a role, you must be logged in with a role that has permission to edit other roles. Additionally, you can use the Permissions icon on the Roles page to access the Edit Permissions page and make the desired changes.

qas.question: What permissions can be assigned for various features like Schedule Announcements or the Dashboard?

answers.text: For Schedule Announcements, permissions can include Create, Delete, Edit, and View. In contrast, the Dashboard and most of its features are limited to View permissions only.

qas.question: How do you delete a role in the system?

answers.text: To delete a role in the system, go to the Roles page and select the Delete icon next to the role you wish to remove. Confirm the deletion when prompted. Note that you must have the appropriate permissions to delete a role, and a warning will appear if the role is associated with a user.

qas.question: What happens if you attempt to delete a role that is associated with a user?

answers.text: If you attempt to delete a role that is associated with a user, a warning will appear, preventing the deletion. This ensures that you do not inadvertently remove a role that is currently in use within the organization or the Nyquist system.

qas.question: What buttons are used to assign specific permissions on the Edit Permissions page?

answers.text: On the Edit Permissions page, specific permissions are assigned using color-coded buttons. These buttons represent actions such as Create, Delete, Edit, View, Manage (for playlists), Import/Export, Set parameters for backup jobs, Restart the Nyquist server, Restore a backup, Change navigation order, and Import a system update.

qas.question: Why might an organization want to edit roles within their system?

answers.text: An organization may want to edit roles within their system to improve clarity and specificity, such as renaming roles for better alignment with job functions. Additionally, updating permissions can enhance security and ensure users have access only to the features and data necessary for their responsibilities.

qas.question: How can a role be deleted in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To delete a role in the Nyquist system, navigate to the Roles page and click the Delete icon next to the desired role. You must confirm the deletion when prompted, and the role can only be deleted if it is not associated with any user.

qas.question: What warning appears if you attempt to delete a role associated with a user?

answers.text: If you attempt to delete a role that is associated with a user, a warning will appear indicating that the role cannot be deleted because it is linked to a user. To delete a role, it must not be associated with any users within the organization or the Nyquist system.

qas.question: What permissions are required to create a user in the Nyquist system?

qas.question: What icon is used to access permissions for a role on the Roles page?

qas.question: What happens if a role is being used by a user when you attempt to delete it?

answers.text: If a role is being used by a user when you attempt to delete it, a warning will appear, preventing the deletion of that role. You cannot delete a role that is associated with any user in the Nyquist system.

qas.question: Can you edit permissions for a role if you do not have the necessary permissions?

7 Using Admin Groups
211
Using Admin Groups
You can place Admin Stations into Admin Groups, which are used if 
incoming calls are not answered by the assigned Admin Station or 
the Day or Night Admin associated with the Admin Station. Admin 
Groups act as an always answer feature by providing an alternate list 
of Admin Stations. If an incoming call is not answered by the assigned 
Admin Station within 30 seconds for normal calls or 15 seconds for 
emergency calls, all Admin Stations in the Admin Group will ring.
If Call Forwarding is enabled at the Admin Station, Nyquist tries the 
forwarded extension. If that station does not answer or is busy, the 
call timeout is reduced to 15 seconds. After 15 seconds, the call rolls 
over to the Admin Group.
In addition, if an emergency level call receives no answer, the Admin 
Group will ring if the Day Admin or Night Admin does not answer. 
You can assign Admin Stations to multiple Admin Groups. A Day or 
Night Admin can also be assigned to one or more Admin Groups.

qas.question: What permissions are required to edit a user’s information?

answers.text: Admin permissions are required to edit a user's information, which includes changing their email address, password, and role. Only users with these permissions can access the editing functionalities for user information.

qas.question: What steps do you need to follow to edit a user’s information?

answers.text: To edit a user’s information, navigate to the Users page and select the Edit icon next to the desired user. Make the necessary changes on the Edit User page and then select Save.

qas.question: How long does an Admin Station have before a call rolls over to an Admin Group under normal conditions?

answers.text: An Admin Station has 30 seconds before a call rolls over to an Admin Group under normal conditions. If Call Forwarding is enabled and the forwarded extension does not answer or is busy, the call timeout is reduced to 15 seconds.

qas.question: What is the role of Admin Groups in incoming call management?

answers.text: Admin Groups serve as a backup for incoming call management, ensuring that if a call is not answered by the assigned Admin Station within specified time frames (30 seconds for normal calls and 15 seconds for emergency calls), all Admin Stations in the group will ring. This mechanism enhances call handling efficiency by providing an alternative response option and can be supplemented by Call Forwarding features.

qas.question: How does Call Forwarding affect the call handling process in Admin Groups?

answers.text: If Call Forwarding is enabled at an Admin Station, calls will first attempt to reach the forwarded extension. If that station does not answer or is busy, the call timeout is reduced to 15 seconds before rolling over to the Admin Group for ringing.

qas.question: What happens if an emergency call is not answered by the assigned Admin Station?

answers.text: If an emergency call is not answered by the assigned Admin Station, the call will roll over to the Admin Group after 15 seconds. If the Day Admin or Night Admin associated with the Admin Station also does not answer, the Admin Group will ring to provide an alternate response.

qas.question: Can Admin Stations be assigned to multiple Admin Groups?

answers.text: Yes, Admin Stations can be assigned to multiple Admin Groups. This allows for flexibility in handling incoming calls across different groups.

qas.question: What is the primary purpose of Admin Groups in relation to incoming calls?

answers.text: The primary purpose of Admin Groups is to ensure that incoming calls are answered even if the assigned Admin Station does not respond within a specified time. If a call goes unanswered, it will ring all Admin Stations in the group after designated timeouts (30 seconds for normal calls and 15 seconds for emergency calls), acting as an always-answer feature for call management.

qas.question: How long does it take for calls to roll over to the Admin Group if an Admin Station does not answer?

answers.text: Calls will roll over to the Admin Group if an Admin Station does not answer within 30 seconds for normal calls or 15 seconds for emergency calls. If Call Forwarding is enabled and the forwarded extension does not answer or is busy, the call timeout is reduced to 15 seconds before rolling over to the Admin Group.

qas.question: Can Admin Stations be assigned to multiple Admin Groups?

answers.text: Yes, Admin Stations can be assigned to multiple Admin Groups. Additionally, a Day or Night Admin can also be assigned to one or more Admin Groups.

qas.question: What happens to emergency calls if they are not answered by the Day or Night Admin?

answers.text: If an emergency call is not answered by the assigned Admin Station, the Day or Night Admin, it will roll over to the Admin Group. All Admin Stations in the Admin Group will then ring to ensure the call is answered.

qas.question: What types of characters are allowed in the names and descriptions of Admin Groups?

answers.text: The names and descriptions of Admin Groups can include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: How can you view the details of Admin Groups on the system?
