qas.question: How can songs be added to a playlist for audio distribution?

answers.text: Songs can be added to a playlist for audio distribution by selecting them from the Songs page and using the playlist feature. Additionally, songs can be imported from a USB memory stick by creating a root file called MusicLibrary.txt, where users can specify a playlist name and whether to create a new playlist or use an existing one.

qas.question: What default songs are provided for tuning volume in an audio distribution zone?

answers.text: The default songs provided for tuning volume in an audio distribution zone are white noise and pink noise. These tunes help optimize the audio levels within the distribution area.

qas.question: What happens if a song is deleted from a playlist?

answers.text: If a song is deleted from a playlist, it is automatically removed from the playlist. This action ensures that the playlist remains updated and does not include any deleted songs.

qas.question: How do you access the song list in the audio management system?

answers.text: To access the song list in the audio management system, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar and select Songs. This will allow you to add, edit, or delete songs from the list.

qas.question: What must be created on a USB memory stick to store songs for playback?

answers.text: To store songs for playback on a USB memory stick, you must create a root file called MusicLibrary.txt. This file can include entries such as playlistname=<text entered by customer>, createplaylist=no, and useexistingplaylist=yes.

qas.question: Which music file formats are valid for use with the USB memory stick?

answers.text: The valid music file formats for use with the USB memory stick are mp3, wav, and aac. Music files must be placed in the root directory of the USB memory stick.

qas.question: What options can be included in the MusicLibrary.txt file for playlists?

answers.text: The MusicLibrary.txt file can include the following options for playlists: `playlistname=<text entered by customer>` to define the playlist name, `createplaylist=no` to prevent creating a new playlist for imported files, and `useexistingplaylist=yes` to add new songs to an existing playlist specified by the playlistname option.

qas.question: What parameters are displayed for each song in the songs page?

answers.text: The parameters displayed for each song on the Songs page include Title, Artist, Album, Track Number, Length, Genre, Year, and Playback options. Each parameter provides specific information about the song, such as its title, the performing artist, album details, duration, genre classification, and the year it was recorded.

9.1.6
Adding Songs
You can add songs from your local computer or from removable 
media, such as a Flash drive. You can add a song to playlists as part of 
the Add Song process or you can add a song to a playlist later 
through the Playlists menu.
You can select to add one song or multiple songs.
Nyquist can use any ID3 tag data and save that automatically. An ID3 
tag acts as a container file within an MP3 audio file and commonly 
contains the title, artist name, album, track data, year, and genre.
Note: If you use a USB memory stick as storage for songs on a 
playlist and the USB memory stick is removed from the USB drive, 
the meta data for the songs and the playlist still resides in the 
Nyquist song list and playlist, but Audio Distribution cannot play. 
For this reason, we recommend never removing the memory stick 
from the computer.

qas.question: What file must be created on the USB memory stick to add songs and create a playlist?

answers.text: A file named "MusicLibrary.txt" must be created in the root directory of the USB memory stick to add songs and create a playlist. This file can include entries such as `playlistname=<text>`, `createplaylist=no`, and `useexistingplaylist=yes` to manage the playlist settings.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the "createplaylist" entry in MusicLibrary.txt?

answers.text: The "createplaylist" entry in MusicLibrary.txt determines whether a new playlist will be created for the imported songs. If set to "no," a playlist is not created, and the songs are simply added to the existing songs list.

qas.question: How does the "useexistingplaylist" option affect song importing?

answers.text: The "useexistingplaylist=yes" option allows new songs imported from the USB memory stick to be added to an existing playlist defined by the "playlistname" entry in the MusicLibrary.txt file. If this option is not used, or if "createplaylist=no" is specified, no new playlist will be created, and the imported songs will not be added to any existing playlist.

qas.question: Where must music files be located on the USB memory stick for them to be recognized?

answers.text: Music files must be located in the root directory of the USB memory stick to be recognized. Valid formats for these files include mp3, wav, and aac.

qas.question: What music file formats are supported for playback from the USB memory stick?

answers.text: The supported music file formats for playback from the USB memory stick are mp3, wav, and aac. The music files must be located in the root directory of the USB memory stick.

qas.question: What is the default name for the playlist created from songs on the USB memory stick?

answers.text: The default name for the playlist created from songs on the USB memory stick is "USB Music Library." This playlist is automatically generated by the Nyquist server when songs are added from the USB stick.

qas.question: How can you upload songs from a USB memory stick to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To upload songs from a USB memory stick to the Nyquist system, expand the Audio section in the navigation bar, select Songs, and click the Add icon. Ensure Multiple Songs is set to Yes, insert the memory stick, choose the files from it, and then save your selections.

qas.question: What settings must be enabled to upload multiple songs to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To upload multiple songs to the Nyquist system, ensure that Multiple Songs is set to Yes on the Add Song page. Additionally, insert the USB memory stick and select the desired files for upload before saving.

qas.question: What data does an ID3 tag commonly contain?

answers.text: An ID3 tag commonly contains metadata such as the title, artist name, album, track number, year, and genre of the audio file. It acts as a container within MP3 audio files to store this information.

qas.question: What happens to song metadata if a USB memory stick is removed from the device?

answers.text: If a USB memory stick is removed from the device, the metadata for the songs and the playlist remains in the Nyquist song list and playlist. However, Audio Distribution will not be able to play the songs without the USB memory stick connected.

qas.question: What is the default name for the playlist created from a USB Music Library?

answers.text: The default name for the playlist created from a USB Music Library is "USB Music Library." This name is assigned when uploading songs from a USB memory stick to the Nyquist system.

qas.question: How can you upload songs from a USB memory stick to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To upload songs from a USB memory stick to the Nyquist system, insert the memory stick and navigate to the Audio section, selecting Songs and then the Add icon. Ensure Multiple Songs is set to Yes, choose the desired file from the memory stick, and select Save twice to complete the upload.

qas.question: Which setting must be enabled to upload multiple songs during the Add Song process?

answers.text: To upload multiple songs during the Add Song process, the "Multiple Songs" setting must be set to Yes on the Add Song page. This allows users to select multiple files for upload.

qas.question: What happens to the meta data and playlist if the USB memory stick is removed after adding songs?

answers.text: If the USB memory stick is removed after adding songs, the meta data for the songs and the playlist remains in the Nyquist song list, but Audio Distribution cannot play the songs. Therefore, it is recommended to never remove the memory stick from the computer.

qas.question: What additional options are available when adding songs to playlists?

answers.text: When adding songs to playlists, you can select multiple playlists at once, choose to add all playlists using the Add All option, or use the Clear button to deselect playlists. Additionally, you can include songs as part of the Add Song process or add them later through the Playlists menu.

qas.question: What information does Nyquist automatically populate if the imported song file contains meta data?

answers.text: If the imported song file contains meta data, Nyquist automatically populates the Title, Artist, Album, Track Number, Year, and Genre after the Save button is pressed. If no meta data exists, the Title is set to Untitled, and the other parameters are left blank.

qas.question: How can you edit the information associated with a specific song in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To edit the information associated with a specific song in the Nyquist system, expand Audio on the navigation bar, select Songs, and then click the Edit icon next to the desired song. On the Edit Song page, make the necessary changes to the parameters and save the updates.

qas.question: What parameters can be edited on the Edit Song page?

answers.text: On the Edit Song page, the parameters that can be edited include Title, Artist, Album, Track Number, Year, Genre, and the File Upload option. Users can make changes to any of these fields as needed.

qas.question: How do you select multiple songs at once when adding them to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To select multiple songs at once when adding them to the Nyquist system, ensure that "Multiple Songs" is set to Yes on the Add Song page. Then, use the Shift or Control keys while clicking on the desired files to select them.

qas.question: What file types can be uploaded from the computer or USB drive to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Nyquist system allows uploading of MP3 audio files, which commonly contain ID3 tag data with metadata such as title, artist, album, and genre. While the text does not explicitly mention other file types, the focus is primarily on MP3 files for song uploads.

qas.question: How do you select multiple songs for copying onto the Nyquist system?

qas.question: What steps are required to edit the information of a particular song?

answers.text: To edit the information of a particular song, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar, select Songs, and then click the Edit icon next to the desired song. On the Edit Song page, make the necessary changes to the parameters and select Save to apply the updates.

qas.question: What parameters can be modified on the Edit Song page?

answers.text: On the Edit Song page, you can modify the following parameters: Title, Artist, Album, Track Number, Year, Genre, and manage Playlists. Additionally, you can upload a new song file to replace the existing one.

qas.question: How do you upload a new song file through the system?

answers.text: To upload a new song file through the system, expand the Audio section in the navigation bar and select Songs. qas.question: What happens to a song in a Playlist if it is deleted from the Songs page?

answers.text: If a song is deleted from the Songs page, it is automatically removed from any Playlist it was part of. This ensures that the Playlist does not contain any missing tracks.

qas.question: How can users create and manage playlists in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: Users can create and manage playlists in the Nyquist system by navigating to the Playlists page, where they can view all available playlists, as well as create new ones or delete existing ones. Additionally, they can add or remove songs from these playlists to organize audio for scheduled events and audio distribution purposes.

qas.question: What is audio distribution in the context of managing playlists?

answers.text: Audio distribution refers to the process of specifying the audio program for stations or zones, allowing users to schedule and manage the playback of multiple songs through playlists. This ensures that the correct audio content is delivered during scheduled events within the Nyquist system.

9.1.9.2
Creating a Playlist
When you add a playlist, you first create the playlist container and 
then you use the Manage tool to add songs to the playlist. To add 
songs to a playlist, you must have access to songs that have been 
downloaded to your Nyquist network or to removable media, such as 
a Flash drive.
Scheduled Audio 
Repeat
When enabled, the playlist audio will be repeated after all 
songs have been played. When disabled, Scheduled Audio 
will automatically stop after the last song has been played 
from the playlist. When disabled, a corresponding stop 
event is not needed when Scheduled Audio is started via 
the schedule.
Note: When playlists are being used by the Audio Distribu-
tion feature, the Scheduled Audio options are ignored.
Scheduled Audio Shuf-
fle
When enabled, the order in which the songs are played is 
shuffled. When disabled, the playlist songs will be played in 
the order that they appear in the playlist.
Note: When playlists are being used by the Audio Distribu-
tion feature, the Scheduled Audio options are ignored.

qas.question: What steps are required to delete a song from the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To delete a song from the Nyquist system, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar and select Songs. Then, click the Delete icon next to the desired song and confirm the deletion when prompted.

qas.question: How does deleting a song from the Songs page affect a Playlist?

answers.text: When you delete a song from the Songs page, it is automatically removed from any Playlist that contains it. This ensures that no deleted songs remain in the Playlist, maintaining its integrity.

qas.question: Where can you view and manage playlists within the Nyquist system?

answers.text: You can view and manage playlists within the Nyquist system on the Playlists page, accessed by expanding the Audio section on the navigation bar. This page allows you to create, delete, and manage playlists, as well as drag and drop songs into and out of playlists.

qas.question: What information is displayed on the Playlists page?

answers.text: The Playlists page displays the user-provided name and description of each playlist, along with options to manage songs within the playlist, such as adding or removing songs. Additionally, it includes parameters for scheduled audio settings, such as repeat and shuffle options.

qas.question: How can you create a new Playlist in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To create a new Playlist in the Nyquist system, first expand the Audio section on the navigation bar and select Playlists. Then, create the playlist container and use the Manage tool to add songs from your Nyquist network or removable media.

qas.question: What is the function of the Scheduled Audio Repeat feature in a Playlist?

answers.text: The Scheduled Audio Repeat feature in a Playlist enables the audio to be repeated after all songs have been played. When disabled, the audio will automatically stop after the last song has been played, eliminating the need for a corresponding stop event.

qas.question: What happens when the Scheduled Audio Shuffle option is enabled in a Playlist?

answers.text: When the Scheduled Audio Shuffle option is enabled in a Playlist, the order in which the songs are played is randomized. If disabled, the songs will be played in the sequence they appear in the playlist. Note that when playlists are used with the Audio Distribution feature, the Scheduled Audio options are ignored.

qas.question: What characters are allowed in the name and description fields for a Playlist?

answers.text: The allowed characters in the name and description fields for a Playlist include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,. The name field has a maximum of 40 characters, while the description field allows up to 256 characters.

qas.question: How does the Manage Playlist feature work in terms of song organization?

answers.text: The Manage Playlist feature allows users to organize songs within a playlist by adding, deleting, or rearranging the order of songs through a drag-and-drop interface. This enables efficient customization of the playlist's content and sequence for scheduled events.

qas.question: What actions can you perform on songs within the Playlists page?

answers.text: Within the Playlists page, you can view all available playlists and manage their content by adding or removing songs. Additionally, you can change the order of songs in a playlist using the Manage tool.

qas.question: What are the first steps to create a playlist in the Nyquist network?

answers.text: To create a playlist in the Nyquist network, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar, select Playlists, and then click the Add icon. Complete the necessary parameters for the playlist on the Add Playlist page and select Save.

qas.question: How many characters can the name of a playlist contain?

answers.text: The name of a playlist can contain a maximum of 40 characters. Valid characters include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and certain special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: What happens to the Scheduled Audio when the Repeat option is disabled?

answers.text: When the Scheduled Audio Repeat option is disabled, the audio will automatically stop after the last song has been played from the playlist. A corresponding stop event is not needed when Scheduled Audio is started via the schedule.

qas.question: Which feature ignores the Scheduled Audio options for playlists?

answers.text: The Audio Distribution feature ignores the Scheduled Audio options for playlists. This means that both the Scheduled Audio Repeat and Scheduled Audio Shuffle settings are not applicable when playlists are being used with this feature.

qas.question: What is the maximum number of characters allowed for the playlist description?

answers.text: The maximum number of characters allowed for the playlist description is 256 characters. Valid characters include uppercase and lowercase letters, numerals, spaces, and certain special characters.

qas.question: How do you add songs to an existing playlist?

answers.text: To add songs to an existing playlist, expand Audio in the navigation bar and select Playlists. Then, click the Manage icon next to the desired playlist, drag and drop the songs from the Songs field to the Playlist field, and select Save.

qas.question: What is the function of the Shuffle option in a playlist?

answers.text: The Shuffle option in a playlist, when enabled, randomizes the order in which the songs are played. When disabled, the songs will play in the order they appear in the playlist.

qas.question: Can you add songs directly from an online source to the playlist?

answers.text: No, you cannot add songs directly from an online source to the playlist. You must have access to songs that have been downloaded to your Nyquist network or to removable media, such as a Flash drive.

qas.question: What types of characters are permissible in playlist names and descriptions?

qas.question: What information is displayed for each source in the Internet Radio Services?

answers.text: For each source in the Internet Radio Services, the following information is displayed: the station's icon, name, and description; the codec used for streaming media compression; the sample rate in samples per second; whether the signal is mono or stereo; and the bit rate for media transmission.

qas.question: What options are available when adding an Internet radio source?

answers.text: When adding an Internet radio source, you can select from a list of available sources and manage credentials or sign up for services like SOUNDMACHINE. The process involves navigating to the Internet Radio Services window and selecting "Add Sources."

qas.question: What details does the codec parameter provide regarding streaming media?

answers.text: The codec parameter provides information on how the streaming media is compressed and decompressed. This affects the efficiency and quality of the audio transmission.

qas.question: How is the sample rate defined in the context of Internet radio services?

answers.text: In the context of Internet radio services, the sample rate is defined as the number of samples of audio carried per second. It indicates how frequently audio is measured during the streaming process, which can impact sound quality and fidelity.

qas.question: What distinguishes mono from stereo in audio transmission?

answers.text: Mono audio transmission uses a single channel to deliver sound, resulting in a singular audio output regardless of the number of speakers. In contrast, stereo audio uses two channels, creating a sense of depth and directionality in the sound, allowing for a more immersive listening experience.

qas.question: What does the bit rate represent in streaming media?

answers.text: The bit rate in streaming media represents the amount of data transmitted per second, typically measured in kilobits per second (kbps). It indicates the quality of the audio or video stream, with higher bit rates generally resulting in better quality but requiring more bandwidth.

qas.question: What steps are involved in adding an Internet radio source to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To add an Internet radio source to the Nyquist system, expand Audio on the navigation bar, select Internet Radio Services, and choose Add Sources. From there, select a source from the list, choose a specific radio station or a service like SOUNDMACHINE, and select Add Source for the desired streams, such as aac or mp3.

qas.question: What information is displayed in the Internet Radio Services window for each source?

answers.text: In the Internet Radio Services window, each source displays details such as the station icon, name, description, codec (compression method), sample rate (audio samples per second), mono/stereo indication, and bit rate (transmission rate of the streaming media).

qas.question: How can you filter the list of stations when selecting a source in SOUNDMACHINE?

answers.text: To filter the list of stations when selecting a source in SOUNDMACHINE, you can use the Filter option to narrow down the list by Location, Language, or Genre. Additionally, you can use the Search function to enter specific search terms.

qas.question: What options are available for selecting a specific album or song within SOUNDMACHINE?

answers.text: Within SOUNDMACHINE, you can select a specific album or song by drilling down from various categories, such as Genres, Stations, My Stations, and Mixes. Additionally, you can access Local stations, Popular stations, Trending, High quality, New stations, and use the Filter or Search options to refine your selection.

qas.question: What must be considered when creating a Music Selection Schedule?

answers.text: When creating a Music Selection Schedule, it is essential to ensure that there are no empty time periods; otherwise, audio distribution will stop when an empty time slot is encountered. Additionally, scheduled stations or mixes must be designated for specific times of the day to function properly.

answers.text: To manage logon credentials for the SOUNDMACHINE service, you must be assigned the necessary permissions. For specific information about roles and permissions required, refer to the section titled "Assigning and Editing Permissions."

9.1.10.10 Using SOUNDMACHINE Music Selection Schedules
Schedules that you create using the SOUNDMACHINE web-based 
user interface appear as Music Selection Schedules in the Nyquist 
Admin Web UI. You can select a Music Selection Schedule to play as 
audio distribution. (See "Using Audio Distribution” on page 353.)
When you create a Music Selection Schedule, you cannot have any 
empty time periods or audio distribution will stop when the empty 
time period is encountered. 
You cannot name a Music Selection Schedule using all special charac-
ters; the name must contain at least one alpha or numeric character 
or the Music Selection Schedule will not appear.
Scheduled Audio takes priority over a Music Selection Schedule. For 
information about Scheduled Audio, refer to "Understanding Event 
Settings” on page 228.

configuration on your station. See "Editing CoS Parameters for a Sta-
tion” on page 66 if you need to change your station’s CoS.

qas.question: What steps are needed to sign up for SOUNDMACHINE?

answers.text: To sign up for SOUNDMACHINE, expand Audio on the navigation bar, select Internet Radio Services, and then either select Add Source or go to Credentials and click the Add icon. Next, choose Sign Up and follow the on-screen instructions on the SOUNDMACHINE and BOGEN page.

qas.question: What should you do if a Music Selection Schedule contains empty time periods?

answers.text: If a Music Selection Schedule contains empty time periods, audio distribution will stop when the empty time period is encountered. Therefore, ensure that there are no empty time periods within the schedule to maintain continuous audio playback.

qas.question: What is required for the name of a Music Selection Schedule to be valid?

answers.text: The name of a Music Selection Schedule must contain at least one alpha or numeric character; using only special characters will result in the schedule not appearing. Additionally, there cannot be any empty time periods in the schedule, as this would cause audio distribution to stop.

qas.question: How does Scheduled Audio interact with a Music Selection Schedule?

answers.text: Scheduled Audio takes priority over a Music Selection Schedule; when both are present, the Scheduled Audio will play instead of the Music Selection Schedule. Additionally, if there are any empty time periods in a Music Selection Schedule, audio distribution will stop when encountered.

qas.question: What is necessary for using the Audio Distribution feature in relation to CoS configuration?

answers.text: To use the Audio Distribution feature, it is necessary to have the proper Class of Service (CoS) configuration on your station. If changes are needed, refer to the section on "Editing CoS Parameters for a Station."

answers.text: To edit credentials for SOUNDMACHINE, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar, then select Internet Radio Services followed by Credentials. You can then select the Edit option for the desired account.

qas.question: What happens if you select Show Saved Password for an account?

answers.text: Selecting "Show Saved Password" allows you to view the existing password for the account being edited. This feature is useful for confirming the password without having to re-enter it.

9.1.10.10 Using SOUNDMACHINE Music Selection Schedules
Schedules that you create using the SOUNDMACHINE web-based 
user interface appear as Music Selection Schedules in the Nyquist 
Admin Web UI. You can select a Music Selection Schedule to play as 
audio distribution. (See "Using Audio Distribution” on page 353.)
When you create a Music Selection Schedule, you cannot have any 
empty time periods or audio distribution will stop when the empty 
time period is encountered. 
You cannot name a Music Selection Schedule using all special charac-
ters; the name must contain at least one alpha or numeric character 
or the Music Selection Schedule will not appear.
Scheduled Audio takes priority over a Music Selection Schedule. For 
information about Scheduled Audio, refer to "Understanding Event 
Settings” on page 228.
9.1.11
Creating an Audio Distribution
To use the Audio Distribution feature, you must have the proper CoS 
configuration on your station. See "Editing CoS Parameters for a Sta-
tion” on page 66 if you need to change your station’s CoS.
Figure 9-15, Audio Distribution Portion of Dashboard
Figure 9-16, Audio Distribution Set in CoS

qas.question: What is the consequence of having empty time periods in a Music Selection Schedule?

answers.text: Having empty time periods in a Music Selection Schedule will cause the audio distribution to stop when an empty period is encountered. To avoid this issue, all time periods must be filled with audio selections.

qas.question: How must a Music Selection Schedule be named to avoid it not appearing?

answers.text: A Music Selection Schedule must contain at least one alpha or numeric character; if it is named using all special characters, it will not appear. Additionally, ensure that there are no empty time periods in the schedule to prevent audio distribution from stopping.

qas.question: What takes precedence over a Music Selection Schedule when it comes to audio playback?

answers.text: Scheduled Audio takes precedence over a Music Selection Schedule in terms of audio playback. If Scheduled Audio is set, it will override any Music Selection Schedule that has been created.

qas.question: What must be configured correctly to use the Audio Distribution feature?

answers.text: To use the Audio Distribution feature, the correct Class of Service (CoS) configuration must be set up on your station. If adjustments are needed, refer to the section on editing CoS parameters.

qas.question: Where can you find information on editing the CoS parameters for a station?

answers.text: Information on editing the CoS parameters for a station can be found in the section titled "Editing CoS Parameters for a Station" on page 66 of the manual. This section provides guidance on configuring the necessary settings for the Audio Distribution feature.

9.1.12
Starting and Stopping Audio Distribution
Starting and stopping Audio Distribution can be done either manu-
ally via your dashboard or automatically either through scheduled 
events or routines.
A list of existing Audio Distributions appears on the dashboard. An 
existing Audio Distribution can be edited or deleted, provided it is 
not currently playing, by selecting the Edit or Delete icon next to the 
Audio Distribution.
To manually start and stop Audio Distribution:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Select the Play icon next to the Audio Distribution that 
you want to launch.
Shuffle
If you select a playlist and want to shuffle the 
song order, set Shuffle to Yes.
Description
Add a description for the Audio Distribution. 
For example, you may want to note that the 
audio is for lunchtime. 
Figure 9-19, Audio Distribution Play Icon

qas.question: What must be included in a Music Selection Schedule to prevent audio distribution from stopping?

answers.text: To prevent audio distribution from stopping, a Music Selection Schedule must not contain any empty time periods. Additionally, the schedule must be named using at least one alpha or numeric character; otherwise, it will not appear.

qas.question: Which characters are not allowed in the name of a Music Selection Schedule?

answers.text: The name of a Music Selection Schedule cannot consist entirely of special characters; it must contain at least one alpha or numeric character. If the name is made up solely of special characters, the Music Selection Schedule will not appear.

qas.question: What takes priority over a Music Selection Schedule?

answers.text: Scheduled Audio takes priority over a Music Selection Schedule. If both are set to play, Scheduled Audio will override any Music Selection Schedule in effect.

qas.question: What is required to use the Audio Distribution feature at a station?

answers.text: To use the Audio Distribution feature at a station, you must have the proper Class of Service (CoS) configuration and be assigned a Role with permissions to create Audio Distribution. Additionally, a Music Selection Schedule must be properly configured without any empty time periods to ensure uninterrupted audio playback.

qas.question: What are the steps to create an Audio Distribution?

answers.text: To create an Audio Distribution, go to your dashboard and select the Add icon next to Audio Distribution. Complete the parameters, select the zones and stations, choose the audio source, set Shuffle if desired, and then select Save.

qas.question: What must you select if you choose Line-Input as the Input Source/Playlist?

answers.text: If you select Line-Input as the Input Source/Playlist, you must select the Amplifiers/Matrix Mixers and the Input Channel. This step is necessary to properly configure the audio source for distribution.

qas.question: How can you enable shuffling for a playlist in Audio Distribution?

answers.text: To enable shuffling for a playlist in Audio Distribution, you need to select a playlist as the audio source and set the Shuffle option to "Yes" during the creation of the Audio Distribution. This must be done in the parameters section before saving the distribution.

qas.question: What actions can be performed on existing Audio Distributions via the dashboard?

answers.text: On the dashboard, existing Audio Distributions can be manually started or stopped by selecting the Play or Stop icons next to them. Additionally, they can be edited or deleted, provided they are not currently playing, by using the Edit or Delete icons.

qas.question: How can you manually start Audio Distribution?

answers.text: To manually start Audio Distribution, navigate to your dashboard and select the Play icon next to the desired Audio Distribution. Ensure that the Audio Distribution is not currently playing, as it can only be edited or deleted when not active.

qas.question: What is the purpose of adding a description to an Audio Distribution?

answers.text: The purpose of adding a description to an Audio Distribution is to provide context or clarity regarding the audio content, such as noting that the audio is intended for a specific time or event, like lunchtime. This helps users quickly identify the purpose of the distribution when managing multiple audio sources.

Audio list includes selections to start or stop the audio stream. This 
list only includes Airable/SOUNDMACHINE selections that apply to 
the specific zone. If the Audio Distribution zone selected includes a 
time zone and another zone type, such as Paging, that is not for time,

The Routines feature lets you automatically launch one or more 
actions using Audio Distribution (Audio-Dist) as a trigger. For exam-
ple, maybe you want a bell or tone to sound in the kitchen when the 
lunchtime music begins to alert kitchen staff that orders will soon be 
coming. To do this, you can create a routine, add an Audio-Dist trig-

you can remotely launch a routine using the Routines API.

9.1.13
Other Features and Audio Distribution
Audio Distribution will be paused automatically by higher priority 
feature activation (for example, All-Call Page, Paging, Tones) and will 
automatically resume when the higher priority feature is finished.
Audio Distribution volume to all speakers can be changed by setting 
Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB), available in System Parameters. 
The Audio Distribution volume to zones can be changed by setting 
Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB) in Edit Zone. For information 
about editing a zone, see "Editing Zone Configuration” on page 165.

qas.question: How can Audio Distribution be started manually?

answers.text: Audio Distribution can be started manually by going to the dashboard and selecting the Play icon next to the desired Audio Distribution. If you wish to shuffle the playlist, set Shuffle to Yes before starting it.

qas.question: What should you do to shuffle the song order in a playlist?

answers.text: To shuffle the song order in a playlist, select the desired playlist and set the Shuffle option to Yes. Ensure you are on the dashboard while performing this action.

qas.question: Can an Audio Distribution be edited or deleted while it is playing?

answers.text: No, an Audio Distribution cannot be edited or deleted while it is playing. It can only be modified if it is not currently active.

qas.question: What is required to automatically schedule audio as part of an event?

answers.text: To automatically schedule audio as part of an event, you need to follow the steps for creating an event and ensure that you set the Scheduled Audio for the playlist, Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp channel, or amplifier to be used for that event.

qas.question: How does one stop the Scheduled Audio during an event?

answers.text: To stop the Scheduled Audio during an event, select the Stop Playlist or Stop Line-Input option. This can be done while the event is ongoing.

qas.question: What triggers can be set using Routines for Audio Distribution?

answers.text: Routines for Audio Distribution can be triggered by actions such as Audio-Dist-Start to begin audio distribution or Audio-Dist-Stop to end it. Additionally, these routines can be activated through third-party systems via I/O Controller Input Contact closure or remotely using the Routines API.

qas.question: How can third-party systems launch a routine for Audio Distribution?

answers.text: Third-party systems can launch a routine for Audio Distribution via I/O Controller Input Contact closure or by using the Routines API to remotely initiate the routine. This allows integration with other systems, such as access control systems, to trigger audio actions.

qas.question: What happens to Audio Distribution when a higher priority feature is activated?

answers.text: When a higher priority feature, such as All-Call Page, Paging, or Tones, is activated, Audio Distribution will be paused automatically. It will resume once the higher priority feature is finished.

qas.question: Where can the Audio Distribution volume be adjusted for all speakers?

answers.text: The Audio Distribution volume for all speakers can be adjusted by setting the Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB) in the System Parameters. Additionally, the volume for specific zones can be changed by setting the same Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB) in the Edit Zone configuration.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB) setting?

answers.text: The Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB) setting allows users to adjust the volume of audio distribution to all speakers or specific zones. This setting ensures that audio levels can be managed effectively, accommodating different environments and needs.

qas.question: What actions can be used to control audio distribution?

answers.text: To control audio distribution, you can use the actions Audio-Dist-Start to initiate and Audio-Dist-Stop to halt distribution. Additionally, routines can be launched remotely via the Routines API or through third-party systems using I/O Controller Input Contact closure.

qas.question: How can third-party systems launch a routine for audio distribution?

answers.text: Third-party systems can launch a routine for audio distribution via I/O Controller Input Contact closure. Additionally, routines can be remotely initiated using the Routines API.

qas.question: What happens to audio distribution during a higher priority feature activation?

answers.text: Audio Distribution will be automatically paused when a higher priority feature, such as All-Call Page, Paging, or Tones, is activated. It will resume automatically once the higher priority feature has finished.

qas.question: How can the audio distribution volume be adjusted for all speakers?

answers.text: The audio distribution volume for all speakers can be adjusted by setting the Audio Distribution Cut Level (dB) in the System Parameters. This allows for a uniform volume adjustment across all connected speakers.

qas.question: What is the default setting for Nyquist stations regarding audio distribution?

answers.text: The default setting for Nyquist stations is to be pre-programmed to receive Audio Distribution to All Stations. To disable this distribution for a specific station, the Multicast Audio Distribution must be changed to "No" on the Edit Station page.

qas.question: Who has the authority to stop audio distribution?

answers.text: Any Admin web UI user can stop the Audio Distribution if their station has the Audio Distribution CoS Configuration parameter enabled. Additionally, audio distribution can be paused automatically by higher priority feature activation.

qas.question: What takes priority over audio distribution when an event occurs?

answers.text: Scheduled Audio has a higher priority than Audio Distribution. If Scheduled Audio interrupts while Audio Distribution is playing, the Audio Distribution will briefly play between the tone and the Scheduled Audio.

qas.question: How does a playlist behave once initiated in audio distribution?

answers.text: Once initiated, a playlist in audio distribution will continue playing until it is manually stopped by an administrator or user. It is unaffected by interruptions from other audio features, and it will play in the background during audio distribution events.

qas.question: What notifications are displayed when starting or stopping audio distribution?

answers.text: When starting Audio Distribution, a popup notification appears indicating that Audio Distribution has been enabled. Similarly, another popup notification is displayed when Audio Distribution is stopped.

Using the Admin Phone
If you are using a Nyquist NQ-T1100 appliance as an admin phone, 
you can start and stop a specified Audio Distribution or stop all Audio 
Distribution using the phone’s Audio Distribution menu.
For more information, refer to the Nyquist NQ-T1000’s Admin Phone

9.2
Using Announcements
Announcements are pre-recorded audio files that can be scheduled 
to play during specific times and in specific zones, played manually 
via the dashboard or played via routine actions. Announcements can 
be either normal announcements, such as pre-recorded announce-
ments about upcoming site events, or emergency announcements, 
such as pre-recorded shelter in place announcements that can be 
played during events such as tornado warnings or active shooter sce-
narios.
Announcements can also precede a page.
Through the Nyquist web-based UI, you can add, edit, delete, and 
play announcements.
Figure 9-26, Admin Phone Display

qas.question: How can Audio Distribution be disabled for a specific Nyquist station?

answers.text: To disable Audio Distribution for a specific Nyquist station, navigate to the Edit Station page and change the Multicast Audio Distribution setting to "No." This setting prevents audio from being distributed to that particular station.

qas.question: What happens when Scheduled Audio interrupts Audio Distribution?

answers.text: When Scheduled Audio interrupts Audio Distribution, the Audio Distribution briefly plays between the tone and the Scheduled Audio. Scheduled Audio has a higher priority than Audio Distribution, ensuring it takes precedence during the interruption.

qas.question: What notifications appear when Audio Distribution is started or stopped?

answers.text: When Audio Distribution is started, a popup window notifies the user that Audio Distribution was enabled. Similarly, another popup window appears when Audio Distribution is stopped, providing a clear indication of the action taken. Additionally, an informational message displays in the Admin Web UI dashboard indicating the currently playing song and the speakers or zones to which the audio is distributed.

qas.question: What information is displayed in the Admin Web UI dashboard regarding Audio Distribution?

answers.text: When Audio Distribution is enabled, an informational message appears in the Messages window of the Admin Web UI dashboard, indicating the currently playing song and specifying which speakers (all or selected) and zones the audio is directed to. Additionally, popup windows notify users when Audio Distribution is started or stopped.

qas.question: How does the Nyquist NQ-T1100 appliance function in relation to Audio Distribution?

answers.text: The Nyquist NQ-T1100 appliance functions as an admin phone that allows users to start and stop specified Audio Distribution or halt all Audio Distribution using its Audio Distribution menu. It provides a user-friendly interface for managing audio settings directly from the phone.

qas.question: What types of announcements can be created and scheduled via the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Nyquist system allows for the creation and scheduling of two types of announcements: normal announcements, which inform about upcoming site events, and emergency announcements, which are critical messages for situations like tornado warnings or active shooter scenarios. Announcements can be played manually or automatically during specified times and in designated zones.

qas.question: Can announcements be played manually or only on a schedule?

answers.text: Announcements can be played both manually via the dashboard and on a schedule. They can include normal announcements for events or emergency announcements for critical situations.

qas.question: What role do announcements play in emergency scenarios according to the context?

answers.text: Announcements serve a critical role in emergency scenarios by delivering pre-recorded messages, such as shelter in place directives during events like tornado warnings or active shooter situations. These announcements can be scheduled or played manually to ensure timely communication with individuals in specific zones.

qas.question: What actions can be performed on announcements through the Nyquist web-based UI?

answers.text: Through the Nyquist web-based UI, users can add, edit, delete, and play announcements. Announcements can be scheduled for specific times and zones, played manually, or used in routine actions.

9.2.1
Announcements, Zones, and Priorities
You can select a zone for an announcement to play or select to play 
an announcement to all speakers. The Nyquist system also supports 
the simultaneous playing of multiple announcements to different 
zones. 
However, there are some set rules and priorities that govern how and 
when announcements play. For example, announcements played via 
an I/O controller can be played to a selected zone but not to All 
Speakers.
When you attempt to play a non-emergency, or Normal, announce-
ment to a zone, you will receive a busy signal if any of the following 
are true:
• An announcement, page, or recorded page is being played on the 
zone.
• An announcement is being played to All Speakers.
• An Alarm, Tone, All-Call, or Emergency All-Call is being played.
A Normal announcement plays to All Speakers only if all zones are 
idle and no higher level audio is playing. You will receive a busy signal 
if any of the following are true:
• A Normal or Emergency announcement is already playing to All 
Speakers.
• An announcement is already playing to a zone.
• A page or queued page is already playing to a zone.
• An Emergency-All-Call, All-Call, Alarm, or Tone is already playing.
If you attempt to play an emergency announcement to a zone or to 
All Speakers, you will receive a busy signal if any of the following are 
true:
• An emergency announcement is already playing to the zone or to 
All Speakers.
• An Emergency All-Call is already playing.
If you attempt to play an emergency announcement to a zone or to 
All Speakers that is already playing a non-emergency announce-
ment, an alarm or tone, a page or queued page, or an All-Call, the 
emergency announcement takes priority. A currently playing non-
emergency announcement, alarm or tone, page or queued page, or 
All-Call will stop playing.

qas.question: How can an admin phone user start or stop Audio Distribution using the Nyquist NQ-T1100 appliance?

answers.text: An admin phone user can start or stop a specified Audio Distribution or halt all Audio Distribution using the Audio Distribution menu on the Nyquist NQ-T1100 appliance. For detailed instructions, users should refer to the Nyquist NQ-T1000’s Admin Phone User Manual.

qas.question: What types of announcements can be made using the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Nyquist system can make two types of announcements: normal announcements, which include general information about events, and emergency announcements, used for critical situations like tornado warnings or active shooter scenarios. Announcements can be played at scheduled times, manually via the dashboard, or through routine actions, and can be directed to specific zones or all speakers.

qas.question: How can announcements be scheduled or played through the Nyquist web-based UI?

answers.text: Announcements can be scheduled to play at specific times and in specific zones through the Nyquist web-based UI. Users can also add, edit, delete, and manually play announcements via the UI.

qas.question: What happens when you attempt to play a Normal announcement to a busy zone?

answers.text: When you attempt to play a Normal announcement to a busy zone, you will receive a busy signal if any of the following are true: an announcement, page, or recorded page is already playing in that zone, or if an announcement is being played to All Speakers. Normal announcements can only play to All Speakers if all zones are idle and no higher-level audio is in progress.

qas.question: Under what conditions can a Normal announcement be played to All Speakers?

answers.text: A Normal announcement can be played to All Speakers only if all zones are idle and no higher-level audio (such as an Emergency announcement, Alarm, Tone, or All-Call) is currently playing. If any of these conditions are not met, a busy signal will be received.

qas.question: What priorities govern the playing of emergency announcements compared to Normal announcements?

answers.text: Emergency announcements take priority over Normal announcements. If an emergency announcement is attempted while a non-emergency announcement, alarm, tone, page, or All-Call is playing, it will stop the current audio and play the emergency announcement. Conversely, Normal announcements can only play if all zones are idle and no higher-level audio is active.

qas.question: What occurs if you try to play an emergency announcement while another emergency announcement is already in progress?

answers.text: If you try to play an emergency announcement while another emergency announcement is already in progress, you will receive a busy signal. The system does not allow multiple emergency announcements to play simultaneously in the same zone or to All Speakers.

qas.question: Can multiple announcements be played simultaneously to different zones in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: Yes, the Nyquist system supports the simultaneous playing of multiple announcements to different zones. However, specific rules and priorities determine how and when these announcements can be played without conflict.

qas.question: What is indicated by a busy signal when trying to play a Normal announcement?

answers.text: A busy signal when trying to play a Normal announcement indicates that either an announcement, page, or recorded page is currently being played on the selected zone, or a higher priority audio such as an Emergency announcement, All-Call, or Alarm is active. Additionally, if an announcement is playing to All Speakers, you will also receive a busy signal.

qas.question: What happens to a currently playing Normal announcement if an emergency announcement is initiated?

answers.text: If an emergency announcement is initiated while a Normal announcement is currently playing, the Normal announcement will stop playing, as the emergency announcement takes priority.

context:

9.2.1
Announcements, Zones, and Priorities
You can select a zone for an announcement to play or select to play 
an announcement to all speakers. The Nyquist system also supports 
the simultaneous playing of multiple announcements to different 
zones. 
However, there are some set rules and priorities that govern how and 
when announcements play. For example, announcements played via 
an I/O controller can be played to a selected zone but not to All 
Speakers.
When you attempt to play a non-emergency, or Normal, announce-
ment to a zone, you will receive a busy signal if any of the following 
are true:
• An announcement, page, or recorded page is being played on the 
zone.
• An announcement is being played to All Speakers.
• An Alarm, Tone, All-Call, or Emergency All-Call is being played.
A Normal announcement plays to All Speakers only if all zones are 
idle and no higher level audio is playing. You will receive a busy signal 
if any of the following are true:
• A Normal or Emergency announcement is already playing to All 
Speakers.
• An announcement is already playing to a zone.
• A page or queued page is already playing to a zone.
• An Emergency-All-Call, All-Call, Alarm, or Tone is already playing.
If you attempt to play an emergency announcement to a zone or to 
All Speakers, you will receive a busy signal if any of the following are 
true:
• An emergency announcement is already playing to the zone or to 
All Speakers.
• An Emergency All-Call is already playing.
If you attempt to play an emergency announcement to a zone or to 
All Speakers that is already playing a non-emergency announce-
ment, an alarm or tone, a page or queued page, or an All-Call, the 
emergency announcement takes priority. A currently playing non-
emergency announcement, alarm or tone, page or queued page, or 
All-Call will stop playing.

such as a message or tone. The announcement can be scheduled to 
play at certain times and in certain zones.
Through the Add Announcement page, you can also enter text to be 
converted into speech provided your Nyquist license allows this 
option. 
To upload an announcement file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, expand Audio.
Step 2
Select Announcements.
Figure 9-27, Add Announcement Page

qas.question: What are the rules regarding playing announcements to zones in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: In the Nyquist system, announcements cannot play to a zone if an announcement, page, or emergency signal is currently active on that zone, or if an announcement is being made to All Speakers. Normal announcements to All Speakers can only occur if all zones are idle and no higher-level audio is in progress; otherwise, a busy signal will be issued. Emergency announcements take priority over non-emergency announcements and can interrupt them if needed.

qas.question: Under what conditions will a busy signal be received when attempting to play a Normal announcement to a zone?

answers.text: A busy signal will be received when attempting to play a Normal announcement to a zone if any of the following conditions are true: an announcement, page, or recorded page is currently playing on that zone; an announcement is playing to All Speakers; or if an Alarm, Tone, All-Call, or Emergency All-Call is in progress.

qas.question: Can a Normal announcement be played simultaneously with an Emergency announcement in the same zone?

answers.text: No, a Normal announcement cannot be played simultaneously with an Emergency announcement in the same zone. If an Emergency announcement is initiated, any currently playing Normal announcement will stop.

qas.question: What happens if an emergency announcement is attempted to be played while a non-emergency announcement is still active?

answers.text: If an emergency announcement is attempted while a non-emergency announcement is still active, the emergency announcement takes priority, causing the currently playing non-emergency announcement to stop. This applies even if the non-emergency announcement is being played in a different zone.

qas.question: How can an announcement be uploaded in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To upload an announcement in the Nyquist system, expand the Audio section in the navigation bar and select Announcements on the Add Announcement page. You can upload an audio recording or enter text for speech conversion, depending on your Nyquist license.

qas.question: Is it possible to schedule an announcement to play at specific times?

answers.text: Yes, it is possible to schedule an announcement to play at specific times and in certain zones using the Add Announcement page in the Nyquist system. This feature allows you to upload audio recordings or enter text to be converted into speech for scheduled announcements.

qas.question: What additional option is available for announcements if the Nyquist license allows it?

answers.text: If the Nyquist license allows it, an additional option for announcements is the ability to enter text that can be converted into speech. This feature enables users to create announcements without needing pre-recorded audio files.

qas.question: What components are involved in managing priority and scheduling of announcements in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Nyquist system manages priority and scheduling of announcements through a set of rules that govern the playing of Normal and Emergency announcements based on the status of zones and ongoing audio. Components involved include zones, I/O controllers, and the ability to upload audio files or convert text to speech, with priorities established for overlapping announcements and specific situations that trigger busy signals.

qas.question: Which types of announcements can be played to All Speakers?

answers.text: Normal announcements can be played to All Speakers only if all zones are idle and no higher level audio is playing. Emergency announcements take priority and can interrupt existing non-emergency announcements to play if needed.

qas.question: Can multiple Emergency announcements be played simultaneously in different zones?

answers.text: Yes, multiple Emergency announcements can be played simultaneously in different zones. However, they cannot be played to All Speakers at the same time.

Note: When you record an announcement by dialing *990

The saved announcement has Play to Zone set to blank (no

announcement via an IP phone Announcement menu

0 = All Speakers). You can define a permanent zone number 
for the saved announcement by updating Play to Zone 
after the recorded announcement has been saved.

9.2.3
Using SSML for Text-to-Speech Entries
You can use Speech Synthesis Markup Language (SSML), an XML-
based markup language for speech synthesis applications, when 
typing text that you want converted to speech for announcements. 
You can use SSML formatting to insert pauses, adjust speech rate, 
adjust voice pitch, adjust output volume, add emphasis to speech, or 
spell words phonetically. The following table provides examples of 
SSML formats that can be used when adding announcements.
Times to Play
Select the number of times the announcement will play. 
Parameters are between 0 and 10.
Note: A setting of 0 results in the playing continuously until 
it is manually stopped via the dashboard.
Time Between Repeats 
(seconds)
Select the time in seconds between replaying of the 
announcement. You can select between 0.5 to 5 in 0.5 
increments.
Text-To-Speech
Type the text that you want converted to speech for this 
announcement. Ensure that the File Upload parameter is 
blank. The system will generate a .wav file. 
Note: This field only appears if your Nyquist license allows 
this option.
Play to Zone
Select either All Speakers or a specific zone for this 
announcement to play.
Note: If the Type for the station is set to Admin Web 
Interface, Admin Phone, IP Phone, Analog Phone, or 
Mobile Device and an Announcement Zone was set for 
the station, the Announcement Zone overrides the Play to 
Zone. 
Description
Provide a description of the announcement.
Note: Valid characters include uppercase letters (A-Z), low-
ercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and the following 
special characters: !@$*?-.,.
Table 9-11,  Add Announcement Page Parameters (Continued)

qas.question: What types of announcements can be played simultaneously in different zones?

answers.text: Emergency announcements can be played in one zone while Normal announcements play in a different zone. Multiple Emergency and Normal announcements can be simultaneously played to different zones, but not to All Speakers at the same time.

qas.question: How can you upload an audio announcement for immediate use?

answers.text: To upload an audio announcement for immediate use, navigate to the Audio section on the navigation bar, select Announcements, and then click the Add icon. Complete the Add Announcement page by providing the necessary parameters and choose an audio file in WAV or MP3 format before selecting Save.

qas.question: What parameters must be completed on the Add Announcement page?

answers.text: On the Add Announcement page, the required parameters to complete include the Name, Type (Normal or Emergency), DTMF Code, and either File Upload or Text-to-Speech (if the license allows). Additionally, you should specify Times to Play, Time Between Repeats, Play to Zone, and provide a Description.

qas.question: What character restrictions apply when naming an announcement?

answers.text: When naming an announcement, valid characters include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: How do you provide a DTMF code for an announcement?

answers.text: To provide a DTMF code for an announcement, enter a code consisting of 1 to 10 digits in the DTMF Code field on the Add Announcement page. Ensure that the DTMF code is unique and not assigned to multiple announcements.

qas.question: What happens if you do not select a zone when saving an announcement?

answers.text: If you do not select a zone when saving an announcement, the saved announcement will have the Play to Zone parameter set to blank, meaning it is not assigned to any specific zone. As a result, when the announcement is played via an IP phone Announcement menu selection, you will be prompted to enter a zone number, with 0 indicating All Speakers.

qas.question: Which audio file formats are supported for announcements?

answers.text: Nyquist supports both WAV and MP3 file formats for announcements. You can upload an announcement by selecting a file in either of these formats through the Add Announcement page.

qas.question: How can SSML be used when adding text-to-speech entries?

answers.text: SSML (Speech Synthesis Markup Language) can be used to format text for conversion to speech when adding announcements. It allows you to insert pauses, adjust speech rate, pitch, and volume, add emphasis, or spell words phonetically, enhancing the clarity and effectiveness of the spoken message.

qas.question: What is the range of times you can set for an announcement to play?

answers.text: You can set an announcement to play between 0 and 10 times. A setting of 0 will result in the announcement playing continuously until it is manually stopped.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Time Between Repeats parameter?

answers.text: The Time Between Repeats parameter determines the interval in seconds between consecutive plays of an announcement. You can select values ranging from 0.5 to 5 seconds in 0.5-second increments, allowing for flexibility in how often the announcement is repeated.

qas.question: What happens if the Play to Zone is overridden by the Announcement Zone setting?

answers.text: If the Play to Zone is overridden by the Announcement Zone setting, the announcement will play in the zone specified by the Announcement Zone, regardless of the selection made in the Play to Zone parameter. This means that the intended zone for the announcement may not be the zone where it actually plays.

qas.question: What valid characters can be used in the description of an announcement?

answers.text: The valid characters that can be used in the description of an announcement include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and the following special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: What is SSML and how is it used in text-to-speech applications?

answers.text: Speech Synthesis Markup Language (SSML) is an XML-based markup language designed for speech synthesis applications, allowing users to control various aspects of speech output such as pauses, speech rate, pitch, volume, and emphasis. It enables customization of text-to-speech conversion to create more natural and human-like announcements in applications.

qas.question: What range of times can an announcement be set to play?

answers.text: An announcement can be set to play between 0 and 10 times. A setting of 0 results in the announcement playing continuously until manually stopped.

qas.question: How can the time between repeats for an announcement be adjusted?

answers.text: The time between repeats for an announcement can be adjusted by selecting the time in seconds from a range of 0.5 to 5 seconds in 0.5-second increments. This setting determines the interval before the announcement plays again after the initial playback.

qas.question: What should be done if the File Upload parameter is not used in the Text-To-Speech field?

answers.text: If the File Upload parameter is not used in the Text-To-Speech field, the system will automatically generate a .wav file from the text entered for the announcement. This option is available only if the user's Nyquist license permits it.

qas.question: What character set is valid for the Description field of an announcement?

answers.text: The valid character set for the Description field of an announcement includes uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: What are the different types of breaks that can be inserted using SSML?

answers.text: The different types of breaks that can be inserted using SSML include: no pause, phrase breaks (x-weak, weak, medium, strong, x-strong), sentence breaks, and specific timed pauses (e.g., a three-second pause or a 4.5-second pause). Each type is used to adjust the pacing and clarity of spoken announcements.

qas.question: How can speech rate be adjusted in SSML?

answers.text: Speech rate in SSML can be adjusted using the `<prosody>` tag with different attributes for rate. Options include `x-slow`, `slow`, `medium`, `fast`, and `x-fast`, which correspond to varying speeds from half to double the normal speech rate. For precise adjustments, you can also use decimal values, such as `<prosody rate='0.42'>` for 42% of normal speed.

qas.question: What options are available for adjusting voice pitch in SSML?

answers.text: In SSML, voice pitch can be adjusted using various options, including `<prosody pitch='x-low'>` for half-pitch, `<prosody pitch='low'>` for 3/4 pitch, `<prosody pitch='medium'>` for normal pitch, `<prosody pitch='high'>` for twice as high, and `<prosody pitch='x-high'>` for three times as high. Additionally, pitch can be altered with percentage or semitone values, such as `<prosody pitch='-50%'>` for 50% lower or `<prosody pitch='+6st'>` for six semitones higher.

qas.question: How can output volume be controlled using SSML?

answers.text: Output volume in SSML can be controlled using the `<prosody volume='...'>` tag, allowing for adjustments ranging from silent to x-loud. Options include settings like `x-soft` for 25% as loud, `medium` for default volume, and `+33%` for 33% louder, among others.

qas.question: How can emphasis be applied to specific parts of speech in SSML?

answers.text: Emphasis can be applied to specific parts of speech in SSML using the `<emphasis>` tag, which allows for three levels of emphasis: strong, moderate, and none. For example, the syntax `<emphasis level='strong'>stronger</emphasis>` indicates that the word "stronger" should be emphasized more than the surrounding text.

qas.question: What does the phoneme tag do in SSML?

answers.text: The phoneme tag in SSML is used to specify the phonetic pronunciation of a word, allowing for accurate speech synthesis. It enhances clarity by providing a phonemic spelling that guides the text-to-speech engine on how to pronounce the word correctly.

qas.question: How can users view and manage announcements through the Announcements page?

answers.text: Users can view and manage announcements through the Announcements page by expanding the Audio section in the navigation bar and selecting Announcements. This page displays a list of announcements with details such as the name, type, DTMF code, creation date/time, and the extension that created the announcement, allowing users to edit, delete, or add new announcements as needed.

qas.question: What parameters are displayed for each announcement in the scheduling list?

answers.text: The parameters displayed for each announcement in the scheduling list include the announcement's name, type (Normal or Emergency), DTMF code for activation, creation date/time, and the extension of the user who created the announcement. Valid characters for the announcement name include uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numerals, spaces, and specific special characters.

qas.question: How is the DTMF code related to announcements?

answers.text: The DTMF (Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency) code is used to manually dial or activate announcements via a tone on a dial pad. It allows users to trigger specific announcements, enabling quick access to pre-recorded messages during various situations.

qas.question: What information does the 'Created By' field provide in the Announcements page?

answers.text: The 'Created By' field on the Announcements page displays the extension that is considered the source of the announcement for Class of Service (CoS) considerations. It identifies who created the announcement, which can be relevant for permissions and management within the system.

qas.question: What steps are needed to view available announcements on the Announcements page?

answers.text: To view available announcements on the Announcements page, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar and select Announcements. This will display a list of all announcements that are available for scheduling, along with their associated parameters.

qas.question: What information is displayed under the "Name" parameter for each announcement?

answers.text: The "Name" parameter displays the user-provided name of the announcement file. Valid characters for the name include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and special characters such as !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: How can a user edit an existing announcement?

answers.text: To edit an existing announcement, a user should navigate to the Audio section and select Announcements. Then, they can click the Edit icon next to the desired announcement, make the necessary changes, and select Save.

qas.question: What does a "Times to Play" setting of 0 indicate for an announcement?

answers.text: A "Times to Play" setting of 0 indicates that the announcement will play continuously until it is manually stopped via the dashboard. This setting allows for uninterrupted playback.

qas.question: What options are available for the "Play to Zone" parameter?

answers.text: The "Play to Zone" parameter offers the choice of either "All Speakers" or a specific zone for the announcement to play. Additionally, if the announcement zone for a specific station is set, it overrides the "Play to Zone" selection.

qas.question: How can users manually play an announcement from the Announcements page?

answers.text: Users can manually play an announcement from the Announcements page by selecting the Playback option. Additionally, they can download and save the announcement by clicking the Menu icon and then the down arrow in this field.

qas.question: What types of announcements can be identified on the Announcements page?

answers.text: The Announcements page identifies two types of announcements: Normal and Emergency. Each announcement is listed with parameters such as Name, DTMF Code, Creation Date/Time, Created By, and additional edit options.

qas.question: What is the significance of the "Created By" parameter in the announcement details?

answers.text: The "Created By" parameter indicates the extension considered the source of the announcement, which is important for determining Class of Service (CoS) considerations. This helps in identifying the origin of the announcement, affecting permissions and access based on the originating source's settings.

qas.question: What special characters are allowed in the announcement name and description?

answers.text: The allowed special characters in the announcement name and description include: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: How does the Announcement Zone setting interact with the Play to Zone option?

answers.text: The Announcement Zone setting overrides the Play to Zone option if the Type for the station is set to Admin Web Interface, Admin Phone, IP Phone, Analog Phone, or Mobile Device. This means that if an Announcement Zone is designated for a station, it will take precedence over any specified Play to Zone for the announcement.

9.2.6
Deleting an Announcement
To delete an announcement that is associated with a schedule, you 
must delete the schedule announcement first and then delete the 
announcement. To delete the schedule announcement, see "Using 
the Schedule Announcement Feature” on page 239.
To delete an announcement:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, expand Audio.
Step 2
Select Announcements.
Step 3
On the Announcements page, select the Delete icon 
next to the announcement that you want to delete.
Step 4
When prompted, select Delete.

qas.question: What steps are involved in editing an announcement?

answers.text: To edit an announcement, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar, select Announcements, and then click the Edit icon next to the desired announcement. Make your changes and select Save to apply them. Note that you can adjust parameters such as times to play, play to zone, and DTMF code.

qas.question: How many times can an announcement be configured to play?

answers.text: An announcement can be configured to play a maximum of 10 times. A setting of 0 results in the announcement playing continuously until it is manually stopped via the dashboard.

qas.question: What does a setting of 0 for "Times to Play" imply?

answers.text: A setting of 0 for "Times to Play" means that the announcement will play continuously until it is manually stopped via the dashboard. This setting allows for ongoing playback without a predefined limit.

qas.question: What character limits or restrictions apply to the description field of an announcement?

answers.text: The description field of an announcement allows valid characters including uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,. There are no specified character limits mentioned for this field.

qas.question: How can you manually play an announcement or download it?

answers.text: To manually play an announcement, you can select the Playback option on the Edit Announcement page. Additionally, by clicking the Menu icon and then the down arrow in the Playback field, you can download and save the announcement.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF code in relation to announcements?

answers.text: The DTMF code is used to manually start an announcement from an Admin Phone. It can consist of 1 to 10 digits and must be unique for each announcement; the initial DTMF code is set to the announcement's row ID upon recording, but can be changed later in the web interface.

qas.question: Can you directly edit the "Created By" field of an announcement?

answers.text: No, you cannot directly edit the "Created By" field of an announcement. This field displays the number for the station used to create or download the announcement and is non-editable.

qas.question: What range of options is available for setting "Times Between Repeats"?

answers.text: The "Times Between Repeats" can be set between 0.5 to 5 seconds, with increments of 0.5 seconds. This parameter determines the duration in seconds before the announcement is replayed.

qas.question: What must be done before deleting an announcement that is associated with a schedule?

answers.text: Before deleting an announcement associated with a schedule, you must first delete the schedule announcement. This involves accessing the scheduling feature as outlined in the relevant documentation.

qas.question: Which types of tones does Nyquist provide, and how can they be used?

answers.text: Nyquist provides default tones such as white noise and pink noise, which can be used with events like schedules or as audio indicators for alarms. Additionally, users can download and generate customized tones or use a line input channel as the tone source.

qas.question: What are the methods available for uploading tones in the Nyquist system?

qas.question: Can default tones be deleted from the system?

qas.question: How can a tone be hidden from the dashboard view?

qas.question: What valid characters can be used in the name of an announcement file?

qas.question: What is the significance of the DTMF code in the tone parameters?

answers.text: The DTMF code in the tone parameters is used for manual dialing to activate an announcement or tone. It allows users to trigger the tone playback using a standard dial pad, enhancing control over the audio announcements in the system.

qas.question: What is the maximum length of time a tone can play before it must be manually stopped?

answers.text: The maximum length of time a tone can play is continuous, as indicated by a setting of 0 in the "Times to Play" parameter, which results in the tone playing indefinitely until it is manually stopped via the dashboard.

qas.question: How can the time between repeats for a tone be adjusted?

answers.text: The time between repeats for a tone can be adjusted by selecting a value between 0.5 to 5 seconds in 0.5-second increments. This parameter allows users to control how long to wait before the tone is replayed.

qas.question: Is it possible to download and save an announcement from the Tones page?

qas.question: What does a setting of 0 in the "Times to Play" parameter indicate?

qas.question: What tone types are specified in the Tones page?

answers.text: The tone types specified in the Tones page are classified as "Normal" or "Alarm." These categories help in identifying the purpose of each tone within the Nyquist system.
