answers.text: The 'Time Between Repeats' parameter can be set between 0.5 to 5 seconds, with increments of 0.5 seconds.

qas.question: How can you manually play a tone after it has been uploaded?

answers.text: To manually play an uploaded tone, go to the Tones page and select the Playback option next to the desired tone. Additionally, you can select the Menu icon in that field to download and save the announcement.

qas.question: What steps are involved in uploading a tone to the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To upload a tone to the Nyquist system, navigate to the Audio section, select Tones, and click the Add icon. Then, choose "Upload File," complete the required parameters, and select Save. Ensure you provide a valid name and specify other settings like tone type and playback options.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF code in tone management?

answers.text: The DTMF code in tone management provides a way to manually activate an announcement or tone using a dial pad. It facilitates the triggering of specific tones remotely, enabling flexibility in tone activation during use.

qas.question: What should you do to generate a one frequency tone in Nyquist?

answers.text: To generate a one frequency tone in Nyquist, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar and select Tones. Then follow the prompts on the screen to set the parameters for the generated tone.

qas.question: What options does the 'Type' parameter provide when adding a tone?

answers.text: The 'Type' parameter provides two options when adding a tone: Normal or Alarm. Users can select the desired tone type from a drop-down menu.

qas.question: What are the steps to generate a tone in the system?

answers.text: To generate a tone, expand Audio on the navigation bar and select Tones, then click the Add icon and choose Generate Tone. Complete the required parameters on the Add Tone page and select Save.

qas.question: Which frequencies are allowed when generating a tone?

answers.text: When generating a tone, the allowed frequencies range from 300 Hz to 2000 Hz.

qas.question: What parameters must be completed on the Add Tone page for generating a tone?

answers.text: On the Add Tone page for generating a tone, you must complete the following parameters: Name, Type, Hide, Frequency (Hz), Duration (seconds), Times to Play, Time Between Repeats (seconds), and DTMF Code.

qas.question: How can the visibility of a tone be controlled in the dashboard view?

answers.text: The visibility of a tone in the dashboard view can be controlled using the "Hide" parameter on the Add Tone page. Users can specify whether the tone should be hidden or displayed by selecting the appropriate option.

qas.question: What does a setting of 0 indicate for the "Times to Play" parameter?

answers.text: A setting of 0 for the "Times to Play" parameter indicates that the tone will play continuously until it is manually stopped via the dashboard. This allows for indefinite playback of the tone.

qas.question: What is the range for the "Time Between Repeats" parameter when generating a tone?

answers.text: The "Time Between Repeats" parameter for generating a tone can be set between 0.5 to 5 seconds, with increments of 0.5 seconds. This setting determines the interval before the tone plays again after each repetition.

qas.question: What does DTMF stand for and when is it used in tone generation?

answers.text: DTMF stands for Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency. It is used in tone generation to provide a DTMF code for manual dial pad announcements or tone activation, allowing users to trigger specific tones or commands through their phone's keypad.

qas.question: How can a line input tone be added to the system?

answers.text: To add a line input tone to the system, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar and select Tones. Click the Add icon, choose Line Input on the Add Tone page, complete the required parameters, and then select Save.

qas.question: What option is available to select a source for a tone when using line input?

answers.text: When using line input to add a tone, you can select a Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp or amplifier channel as the source for the tone. This option allows you to utilize external audio sources for tone generation.

qas.question: What types of announcements can be selected when generating a tone?

answers.text: When generating a tone, you can select the type of announcement as either a normal announcement or an emergency announcement. This option is available in the parameters of the Add Tone page.

Editing Tones
You can edit parameters of existing tones, but which parameters can 
be changed depends on whether the tone is a default tone or a user 
added tone. For example, you cannot change the Name for a default 
tone, but you can change that parameter for a tone that you added. 
Some parameters only appear for Line Input tones. You also cannot 
change the Type of a tone if it is used in a routine (see "Understand-
ing Trigger Parameters” on page 395 and "Understanding Action 
Parameters” on page 406).

answers.text: To add a line input tone from the Add Tone page, expand the Audio section from the navigation bar, select Tones, and click the Add icon. Then, choose Line Input and complete the required parameters before selecting Save.

qas.question: Which parameters can be changed when editing a user-added tone?

answers.text: When editing a user-added tone, you can change the Name, Hide, Length, DTMF Code, Amplifiers/Matrix Mixers, and Input Channel parameters. In contrast, you cannot change the Type of a tone if it is used in a routine.

qas.question: What is the maximum length allowed for a tone, and what does a length setting of 0 signify?

answers.text: The maximum length allowed for a tone is 999999 seconds. A length setting of 0 signifies that the tone will play continuously until it is manually stopped via the dashboard.

qas.question: What types of announcements can be specified when adding a line input tone?

answers.text: When adding a line input tone, you can specify the type of announcement as either a normal announcement or an emergency announcement. This selection is made in the "Type" parameter on the Add Tone page.

qas.question: How can the visibility of a tone be configured in the dashboard view?

answers.text: The visibility of a tone in the dashboard view can be configured by using the "Hide" parameter on the Add Tone page. This allows you to specify whether the tone is to be hidden or displayed.

qas.question: What characters are valid for naming a tone?

answers.text: Valid characters for naming a tone include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), space, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,.

qas.question: Which type of tones can only be edited in terms of parameters that appear specifically for Line Input tones?

answers.text: Parameters that appear specifically for Line Input tones can only be edited for user-added tones. Default tones do not allow changes to their parameters, including those specific to Line Input tones.

qas.question: What role does the DTMF code play in tone activation?

answers.text: The DTMF (Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency) code is used for manual dial pad announcement or tone activation, allowing users to trigger the associated tone remotely. It provides a way to initiate specific tones or announcements through an input device, enhancing control over audio cues.

qas.question: How do you select the source for a tone from the Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp or amplifier channel?

answers.text: To select the source for a tone from the Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp or amplifier channel, navigate to the Audio section and select Tones. On the Tones page, click the Add icon, choose Line Input on the Add Tone page, and use the drop-down menu to select the desired Matrix Mixer Pre-Amp or amplifier along with its associated station number.

qas.question: Can the type of a tone be changed if it is used in a routine?

answers.text: No, the type of a tone cannot be changed if it is used in a routine. This restriction applies regardless of whether the tone is a default tone or a user-added tone.

qas.question: What parameters can be changed for user-added tones?

answers.text: For user-added tones, the parameters that can be changed include the Name, Type, Hide status, Times to Play, Time Between Repeats, DTMF Code, Length (for Line Input tones), and the ability to upload a new File. All changes must be made on the Edit Tone page before selecting Save.

qas.question: Is it possible to change the name of a default tone?

answers.text: No, it is not possible to change the name of a default tone. The name parameter can only be edited for user-added tones.

qas.question: What happens if the Length parameter is set to 0?

answers.text: If the Length parameter is set to 0, the tone will play continuously until it is manually stopped via the dashboard. This setting allows for an uninterrupted audio playback until user intervention occurs.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF Code parameter?

answers.text: The DTMF Code parameter is used to provide the Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency (DTMF) code that activates manual dial pad announcements or tones. This parameter is relevant for both editing and adding tones, allowing users to specify the code needed for tone activation.

qas.question: Can you hide a tone from the dashboard view?

answers.text: Yes, you can hide a tone from the dashboard view by specifying the Hide parameter. This option is available when editing tones, allowing users to control the visibility of individual tones on the dashboard.

qas.question: What is the maximum number of times a tone can play when using the Times to Play parameter?

answers.text: The maximum number of times a tone can play using the Times to Play parameter is 10. A setting of 0 results in the tone playing continuously until it is manually stopped via the dashboard.

qas.question: What is the range of the Time Between Repeats parameter?

answers.text: The Time Between Repeats parameter has a range of 0.5 to 5 seconds, with increments of 0.5 seconds. This parameter does not appear for Line Input tones.

qas.question: Which parameter allows for the selection of a new audio file?

answers.text: The parameter that allows for the selection of a new audio file is "File Upload." This parameter is only available for user-provided tones and not for Line Input tones.

qas.question: Who is allowed to delete tones in the system?

answers.text: Only user-added tones can be deleted in the system. Default system tones cannot be deleted, especially if they are used in a routine or alarm action.

qas.question: Under what conditions can you not delete a tone?

answers.text: You cannot delete a tone if it is used in a routine with a tone action Type or if it is used as an alarm in an Alarm action Type. Additionally, only user-added tones can be deleted; default system tones cannot be deleted.

qas.question: Are Line Input tones affected by the Length parameter?

answers.text: Yes, Line Input tones are affected by the Length parameter. For Line Input tones, the Length can be set to a specific number of seconds, with a setting of 0 resulting in continuous playback until manually stopped.

qas.question: Which parameters are exclusive to Line Input tones?

answers.text: The parameters exclusive to Line Input tones include Amplifiers/Matrix Mixers, Input Channel, and Length (although Length can only be changed for Line Input tones). These parameters do not appear for other types of tones.

qas.question: Can a tone's Type be changed if it is included in a routine?

answers.text: No, a tone's Type cannot be changed if it is included in a routine. This restriction applies to tones used in a routine with a tone action Type or as an alarm in an Alarm action Type.

qas.question: What is the effect of setting the "Hide" option to true?

answers.text: Setting the "Hide" option to true will cause the tone to be hidden from the dashboard view, making it not visible to users who access the dashboard. This parameter allows for better management of tones without cluttering the user interface.

qas.question: How can you navigate to the tone editing section in the system?

answers.text: To navigate to the tone editing section, expand the Audio menu on the navigation bar and select Tones. On the Tones page, click the Edit icon next to the tone you wish to modify.

qas.question: Are there any restrictions regarding valid characters for naming tones?

answers.text: Yes, valid characters for naming tones include uppercase letters (A-Z), lowercase letters (a-z), numerals (0-9), spaces, and the special characters: !@$*?-.,. Additionally, the name parameter cannot be changed for default system tones.

Maintenance and Troubleshooting
This section provides detail instructions on several of the Nyquist 
features that are designed to help maintain and troubleshoot your 
system.
10.1
Backing Up Your E7000 System and Files
You can create a full system backup of all configuration settings, 
back up only voice mail files, or back up only recordings. You can also 
schedule an automatic full system backup. Information backed up 
during a full system backup includes any custom alarm, tones, 
announcements, and music files. Phone calls and location recordings 
are not backed up.
You should do a system backup after a change is made to system 
programming, including station and zone configuration.
You can set retention periods for each type of backup. (See "Setting 
System Parameters” on page 53.)

qas.question: What types of tones can be deleted in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: In the Nyquist system, only user-added tones can be deleted. Tones that are used in a routine with a tone action type or as an alarm in an alarm action type cannot be deleted.

qas.question: What steps are required to delete a tone in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To delete a tone in the Nyquist system, expand the Audio section on the navigation bar, select Tones, then click the Delete icon next to the tone you want to delete. Confirm the deletion by selecting Delete when prompted. Note that you can only delete user-added tones, not those used in routines or alarms.

qas.question: How can you manage call recordings in Nyquist?

answers.text: You can manage call recordings in Nyquist by navigating to the Audio section, selecting Recordings, and using the Play button to listen to individual calls. Additionally, you can delete selected calls by checking the boxes next to them and selecting Delete Selected, or delete all calls by choosing Select All and then clicking Delete Selected.

qas.question: What options are available for playback of recorded calls?

answers.text: To playback recorded calls in the Nyquist system, navigate to the Recordings page and select the Play button in the Playback column for the desired call. This allows you to listen to individual call recordings as needed.

qas.question: How do you delete selected or all recorded calls in Nyquist?

answers.text: To delete selected recorded calls in Nyquist, check the box in the Select column for each call you want to delete, then select "Delete Selected." To delete all recorded calls, select "Select All" and then click on "Delete Selected."

qas.question: What information is provided on the Recordings page for recorded calls?

answers.text: The Recordings page provides information for recorded calls, including the source (the extension or number that placed the call), destination (the extension that received the call), and the date/time when the call was received. It also indicates the type of call (such as Normal) and provides a playback option to listen to the recording.

qas.question: What features are available in Nyquist for maintaining and troubleshooting the system?

answers.text: Nyquist offers features for maintaining and troubleshooting the system, including the ability to create full system backups of configuration settings, voice mail files, or recordings, as well as scheduling automatic backups. Additionally, it includes audio file management for call recordings, allowing users to play back, delete selected calls, or delete all recordings.

qas.question: What types of backups can be created for the E7000 system?

answers.text: You can create a full system backup of all configuration settings, back up only voice mail files, or back up only recordings for the E7000 system. Additionally, you can schedule an automatic full system backup, which includes custom alarms, tones, announcements, and music files, while phone calls and location recordings are not backed up.

qas.question: When should a system backup be performed in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: A system backup should be performed after any changes are made to system programming, including updates to station and zone configurations. Additionally, it is advisable to schedule automatic full system backups to ensure regular preservation of configuration settings.

qas.question: What does a full system backup include in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: A full system backup in the Nyquist system includes all configuration settings, custom alarms, tones, announcements, and music files. However, it does not back up phone calls and location recordings.

Maintenance and Troubleshooting
This section provides detail instructions on several of the Nyquist 
features that are designed to help maintain and troubleshoot your 
system.
10.1
Backing Up Your E7000 System and Files
You can create a full system backup of all configuration settings, 
back up only voice mail files, or back up only recordings. You can also 
schedule an automatic full system backup. Information backed up 
during a full system backup includes any custom alarm, tones, 
announcements, and music files. Phone calls and location recordings 
are not backed up.
You should do a system backup after a change is made to system 
programming, including station and zone configuration.
You can set retention periods for each type of backup. (See "Setting 
System Parameters” on page 53.)

Viewing System Backup Files

available for restore.

On the navigation bar, select System Backup/Restore.
The following table describes the information that appears for each 
file:
Figure 10-1, System Backup/Restore Page

Select
Indicates if the file has been selected for restore, export, 
edit, or delete.
Keep

the retention period. See "Using the Edit System Parame-
ters Page” on page 54 for information about setting reten-
tion periods of for system, recordings, or voicemail 
backups.
Description
Indicates if the backup was created by Nyquist or the user.
Date/Time
Provides the month, day, year, and time that the job was 
created.
Type
Indicates what data was backed up. Options are System, 
Recordings, and Voicemail.

qas.question: What types of backups can be created for the E7000 system?

answers.text: For the E7000 system, you can create a full system backup of all configuration settings, a backup of only voice mail files, or a backup of only recordings. Additionally, you have the option to schedule an automatic full system backup.

qas.question: When should a system backup be performed?

answers.text: A system backup should be performed after any change is made to system programming, including modifications to station and zone configurations. Additionally, it is advisable to regularly back up the system to ensure all settings and files are securely saved.

qas.question: What information is included in a full system backup?

answers.text: A full system backup includes all configuration settings, custom alarms, tones, announcements, and music files. However, it does not back up phone calls or location recordings.

qas.question: How can users view available system backup files?

answers.text: Users can view available system backup files by selecting the "System Backup/Restore" option on the navigation bar. This page displays information about each backup file, including whether it has been selected for actions like restore or delete, its description, creation date/time, and the type of data backed up.

qas.question: What does the "Select" indicator signify in the backup file data?

answers.text: The "Select" indicator signifies whether the backup file has been chosen for restore, export, edit, or delete actions. It helps users manage their backup files effectively within the System Backup/Restore page.

qas.question: What does the "Keep" option do regarding backup files?

answers.text: The "Keep" option indicates whether a backup file will be retained even if it exceeds the set retention period. This allows users to preserve important backups beyond the default timeframe specified in the system parameters.

qas.question: What types of data are indicated in the "Type" field of the backup file information?

answers.text: The "Type" field of the backup file information indicates the category of data backed up, which includes three options: System, Recordings, and Voicemail.

qas.question: Where can users find information about setting retention periods for backups?

answers.text: Users can find information about setting retention periods for backups in the section titled "Setting System Parameters," which is referenced on page 53 of the document. This section provides guidance on how to adjust the retention settings for system, recordings, and voicemail backups.

10.1.2
Creating a Backup File
You can manually create a backup of all system files, voicemail files, 
or recordings.
To create a backup file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select System Backup/Restore.
Step 2
On the System Backup/Restore page, select Create 
Backup.
Step 3
On the Create Backup popup window, select one of the 
following options:
•System
•Voicemail
•Recordings
The new backup file appears in the System Backup/Restore list.
10.1.3
Deleting a Backup File
You can delete a single backup file or select to delete multiple 
backup files. By default, Nyquist does not automatically purge a 
backup file, even if the file has passed its retention period (see "Using 
the Edit System Parameters Page” on page 54). However, you can 
select to delete any files; the system will warn you if you select to 
delete a file marked to keep.
Figure 10-2, Create Backup Page

qas.question: What page do you select to view system backup files?

answers.text: To view system backup files, select the "System Backup/Restore" page from the navigation bar. This page will display all available backup files along with their details.

qas.question: What information does the "Select" column provide in the backup file data?

answers.text: The "Select" column indicates whether a backup file has been chosen for actions such as restore, export, edit, or delete. This allows users to easily manage their backup files based on their current needs.

qas.question: How can a user indicate that a backup file should be kept beyond the retention period?

answers.text: A user can indicate that a backup file should be kept beyond the retention period by selecting the "Keep" option for that file on the System Backup/Restore page. This setting prevents the backup file from being automatically purged by the system, even if it surpasses the designated retention period.

qas.question: What types of data can be backed up according to the options provided?

answers.text: The types of data that can be backed up include System files, Voicemail files, and Recordings. Users can select any of these options when creating a backup file.

qas.question: What steps are required to manually create a backup file?

answers.text: To manually create a backup file, select System Backup/Restore from the navigation bar, then click on Create Backup. In the popup window, choose one of the options: System, Voicemail, or Recordings, and the new backup file will appear in the System Backup/Restore list.

qas.question: What will happen if you try to delete a file marked to keep?

answers.text: If you attempt to delete a file marked to keep, the system will issue a warning. This indicates that the file will not be automatically purged even if it has surpassed its retention period.

qas.question: How does Nyquist handle backup files that exceed their retention period?

answers.text: Nyquist does not automatically purge backup files that exceed their retention period. Users have the option to manually delete any backup files, and the system will issue a warning if a user attempts to delete a file marked to be kept.

qas.question: What options are available when creating a backup file in the popup window?

answers.text: When creating a backup file in the popup window, you can select one of the following options: System, Voicemail, or Recordings. The newly created backup file will then appear in the System Backup/Restore list.

Type

eter cannot be edited.

Displays the date and time that the file was created. This param-
eter cannot be edited.

qas.question: What is the first step to delete a backup file in the system?

answers.text: The first step to delete a backup file in the system is to select "System Backup/Restore" from the navigation bar. This will take you to the System Backup/Restore page where you can choose the backup file(s) you want to delete.

qas.question: How can a user edit the description of a backup or restore file?

answers.text: To edit the description of a backup or restore file, the user should navigate to System Backup/Restore, select the Edit icon next to the desired file, edit the description, and then select Save. The edit option is available for user-created, system-created, or installation-created backup files.

qas.question: What are the types of backup file descriptions that are automatically generated?

answers.text: The types of backup file descriptions that are automatically generated are "User Created" for user-created backups, "System Created" for backups created automatically based on specified settings, and "Installation Created" for backups created during the installation process.

qas.question: What does the "Keep" option allow a user to do regarding backup files?

answers.text: The "Keep" option allows a user to select "Yes" if they want Nyquist to retain a backup file even after its retention period has expired. This ensures that at least one backup file is preserved despite the expiration of its regular retention policy.

qas.question: What parameters can be set when editing backup settings?

answers.text: When editing backup settings, you can schedule automatic backups and specify parameters such as the backup directory where the files will be stored. Additionally, you can set other specific settings related to system backups.

qas.question: What types of backup file might a user encounter in the system?

answers.text: A user might encounter three types of backup files in the system: User Created, System Created, and Installation Created. User Created files are manually generated by users, System Created files are automatically generated based on specified settings, and Installation Created files are generated during the installation process.

qas.question: How does one confirm the deletion of a backup file?

answers.text: To confirm the deletion of a backup file, select Delete when prompted after choosing the backup file or files you want to delete. Then, confirm the action by selecting Delete again when asked to confirm the deletion.

qas.question: Where can a user find the option to edit backup settings?

answers.text: A user can find the option to edit backup settings on the navigation bar by selecting "System Backup/Restore." This section allows the user to schedule automatic backups and configure specific parameters for system backups.

313

Step 3

Select Save.
10.1.6
Exporting a Backup File
You can export a backup file as a .gz file, which can be stored on the 
Admin Station or downloaded to removable media, such as a thumb 
drive, to be stored off site. 
To export a backup file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select System Backup/Restore.
Step 2
On the System Backup/Restore page, select the backup 
file that you want to export.

Table 10-3,  Backup Settings Page Parameters
Backup Directory
Displays current path for backup file.
New Backup 
Directory
Enter new path for backup file, if applicable.
Auto Backup
Indicates if the backup is to be automatically generated.
Minute
Specifies the minute the backup job runs. If you do not select a 
minute, the system defaults to 0.
Hour
Specifies the hour that the backup job runs. Selections are for-
matted with the hour and either am or pm. The default setting is 
1 am.
Day
Specifies the day of the month that the backup job runs. The 
system defaults to every day.
Month
Specifies the month the job is to run. The system defaults to 
every month.
Day of the Week
Specifies the day of the week that the job is to run. The system 
defaults to every day.

qas.question: What settings can be edited on the System Backup/Restore page?

answers.text: On the System Backup/Restore page, you can edit the backup directory, enable or disable automatic backups, and set specific parameters such as minute, hour, day, month, and day of the week for the backup job schedule. After making desired changes, you can save the updates.

qas.question: How can you export a backup file, and what format is used?

answers.text: To export a backup file, select System Backup/Restore from the navigation bar, choose the backup file you want to export, and then click on Export. The backup file is exported in .gz format.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the 'Backup Directory' parameter?

answers.text: The 'Backup Directory' parameter displays the current path where backup files are stored. It allows users to identify the location of their backups and change it if necessary by entering a new path in the 'New Backup Directory' field.

qas.question: What does the 'Auto Backup' option indicate?

answers.text: The 'Auto Backup' option indicates whether the backup will be automatically generated by the system. If enabled, the system will perform backups according to the specified schedule without user intervention.

qas.question: How is the minute for the backup job specified?

answers.text: The minute for the backup job is specified by selecting a value from the "Minute" parameter. If no minute is selected, the system defaults to 0.

qas.question: What is the default hour for the backup job to run?

answers.text: The default hour for the backup job to run is 1 am. If no specific minute is selected, it defaults to 0 minutes past the hour.

qas.question: How can you change the day of the month for the backup job?

answers.text: To change the day of the month for the backup job, navigate to the System Backup/Restore page and select Settings. Then, specify your desired day in the "Day" parameter field, which defaults to every day. Finally, select Save to apply the changes.

qas.question: What is the default setting for the month the backup job runs?

answers.text: The default setting for the month that the backup job runs is every month. This means the system is configured to conduct backups monthly unless changed by the user.

qas.question: How do you specify the day of the week for the backup job execution?

answers.text: To specify the day of the week for the backup job execution, go to the System Backup/Restore page and find the Day of the Week parameter. Here, you can select the desired day; the system defaults to every day if no selection is made.

qas.question: What steps are involved in saving changes to backup settings?

answers.text: To save changes to backup settings, select System Backup/Restore from the navigation bar, go to Settings on the System Backup/Restore page, make your desired changes, and then select Save.

10.2
Restoring a Backup File
You can restore the facility configuration to that saved during a 
system backup. You can also restore voicemail or recordings back-
ups.
To restore a file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select System Backup/Restore.

On the System Backup/Restore page, select the backup 
file that you want to restore.

Select Restore.

When prompted, select Restore.

Importing a Backup File
You can import a backup file that was previously exported. You can 
then select to restore this file.
To import a backup file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select System Backup/Restore.
Step 2
On the System Backup/Restore page, select Import.
Step 3
Select Choose file, and then navigate to the backup file 
that you want to import.
Step 4
Select Open.
Step 5
Select Import.
Note: System backups created by older versions of the System 
Controller software are not compatible with the newer releases and 
should not be used to restore configuration data.

qas.question: How can you export a backup file and what file format is used?

qas.question: What parameters are displayed on the Backup Settings Page?

answers.text: The Backup Settings Page displays the following parameters: Backup Directory (current path for the backup file), New Backup Directory (option to enter a new path), Auto Backup (indicates automatic generation), along with scheduling options for Minute, Hour, Day, Month, and Day of the Week, each with default settings.

qas.question: How do you specify the hour for an automatic backup job?

qas.question: What is the default day setting for the backup job configuration?

answers.text: The default day setting for the backup job configuration is set to every day. This means that the backup job is scheduled to run daily unless specified otherwise.

qas.question: How can you import a backup file that was previously exported?

answers.text: To import a previously exported backup file, select System Backup/Restore from the navigation bar, then click on Import. Choose the backup file by selecting "Choose file," navigating to its location, and clicking "Open," followed by selecting "Import."

qas.question: What should be noted about system backups created by older software versions?

answers.text: System backups created by older versions of the System Controller software are not compatible with newer releases and should not be used to restore configuration data. Attempting to restore from an incompatible backup may lead to errors or data loss.

Select Restore.
Step 4
When prompted, select Restore.
10.2.1
Importing a Backup File
You can import a backup file that was previously exported. You can 
then select to restore this file.
To import a backup file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select System Backup/Restore.
Step 2
On the System Backup/Restore page, select Import.
Step 3
Select Choose file, and then navigate to the backup file 
that you want to import.
Step 4
Select Open.
Step 5
Select Import.
Note: System backups created by older versions of the System 
Controller software are not compatible with the newer releases and 
should not be used to restore configuration data.

qas.question: What is the first step to take when restoring a facility configuration?

answers.text: The first step to restore a facility configuration is to select "System Backup/Restore" from the navigation bar. This will take you to the System Backup/Restore page where you can proceed with selecting the backup file to restore.

qas.question: How do you select a backup file for restoration?

answers.text: To select a backup file for restoration, go to the navigation bar and select System Backup/Restore. On the System Backup/Restore page, choose the backup file you wish to restore, and then click on Restore.

qas.question: What must you do after selecting a backup file to restore it?

qas.question: How can you import a previously exported backup file?

qas.question: What is the initial action required to import a backup file?

10.3
Using System Log Files
A log file records either events or messages that occur when software 
runs and is used when troubleshooting the system. The following 
parts of the Nyquist system generate log files:
• Server (This provides access to the Debian Linux OS server log 
files.)
• Nyquist E7000 (This provides access to the Nyquist application log 
files.)
• Web Server (This provides access to the web server log files.)
From the web-based UI, system logs can be viewed directly or 
exported via download to your PC, Mac, or Android device and then 
copied to removable media or attached to an email to technical sup-
port.
Table 10-4,  System Logs  
File
Description
Server
mysql.log
Contains a general record of what mysql is 
doing (connect, disconnect, queries).
btmp
Contains information about failed login 
attempts.
auth.log
Contains system authorization information, 
including user logins and authentication 
methods that were used.
messages
Contains global system messages, including 
the messages that are logged during system 
startup. Items logged in the messages file 
include cron, daemon, kern, auth, and so on.
debug
Contains errors and debug information.
daemon.log
Contains information logged by the various 
background daemons that run on the sys-
tem. 
alternatives.log
Contains information by the update-alterna-
tives, which maintain symbolic s determining 
default commands.

qas.question: What icon appears after downloading a report in a web browser on Windows or Mac OS X?

answers.text: After downloading a report in a web browser on Windows or Mac OS X, an Excel icon with the downloaded report name appears in the lower left section of the browser window, providing the option to open the report.

qas.question: Where are files automatically downloaded on Android devices?

answers.text: Files are automatically downloaded and saved to the device’s Download folder on Android devices.

qas.question: What are the first two steps to restore a backup file in the system?

answers.text: To restore a backup file in the system, first select "System Backup/Restore" from the navigation bar. Then, on the System Backup/Restore page, choose the backup file that you want to restore.

qas.question: What should be done if a backup file was generated from an older version of the System Controller software?

answers.text: If a backup file was generated from an older version of the System Controller software, it should not be used to restore configuration data, as it is not compatible with the newer releases. It is advisable to create a new backup using the current software version.

qas.question: Which parts of the Nyquist system generate log files?

answers.text: The Nyquist system generates log files from three parts: the Server, which provides access to Debian Linux OS server log files; the Nyquist E7000, which gives access to the application log files; and the Web Server, which offers access to web server log files. These logs are useful for troubleshooting system issues.

qas.question: How can system logs be accessed from the web-based UI?

answers.text: System logs can be accessed from the web-based UI by navigating to the appropriate section for the Server, Nyquist E7000, or Web Server. Users can view the logs directly or export them by downloading to their PC, Mac, or Android device for further use or to send to technical support.

qas.question: What type of information is contained in the mysql.log file?

answers.text: The mysql.log file contains a general record of MySQL activities, including details about connections, disconnections, and executed queries. It is used to monitor and troubleshoot MySQL operations within the system.

qas.question: What does the btmp log file record?

answers.text: The btmp log file records information about failed login attempts on the system. It helps in tracking unauthorized access attempts and potential security breaches.

qas.question: What kinds of messages are logged in the messages file?

answers.text: The messages file contains global system messages, including logs from system startup and activities related to cron jobs, daemons, the kernel (kern), and user authentication (auth). It serves as a comprehensive log of system-level events and notifications.

qas.question: What type of information does the debug log file contain?

answers.text: The debug log file contains errors and debug information related to the system's operation. It is used primarily for troubleshooting purposes to identify issues within the Nyquist system.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the daemon.log file within the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The daemon.log file in the Nyquist system contains information logged by various background daemons running on the system. It helps monitor the activities and status of these daemons, aiding in system troubleshooting and performance assessment.

qas.question: Which log file contains information maintained by update-alternatives?

answers.text: The log file that contains information maintained by update-alternatives is the `alternatives.log`. This log provides details relevant to managing symbolic links that determine default commands on the system.

qas.question: What types of log files are generated by the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Nyquist system generates log files for the Nyquist E7000, which includes the "checkin" log that records actions during the Check-In process, as well as other logs like "messages" that contain messages generated by the E7000. It also includes access logs from the web server, such as "error.log," "access.log," and "checkin.log."

qas.question: What information does the mysql.log file contain?

answers.text: The mysql.log file contains a general record of the actions performed by MySQL, including events related to connections, disconnections, and queries executed on the database.

qas.question: How can system logs be exported to a personal device?

answers.text: System logs can be exported to a personal device by using the web-based UI to download them directly to your PC, Mac, or Android device. Once downloaded, the logs can be copied to removable media or attached to an email for technical support.

qas.question: What does the btmp log file record?

answers.text: The btmp log file records information about failed login attempts on the system. It helps in monitoring unauthorized access attempts and enhancing security measures.

qas.question: What kind of messages are found in the messages log file?

answers.text: The messages log file contains global system messages, including information logged during system startup and events from various system components such as cron jobs, daemons, and kernel activities. It helps in monitoring general system operations and troubleshooting issues.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the debug log file?

answers.text: The debug log file contains errors and debug information generated by the system. It is used for troubleshooting and identifying issues within the software's operations.

qas.question: What type of information is logged in the daemon.log file?

answers.text: The daemon.log file contains information logged by various background daemons that run on the system. This includes runtime events, status updates, and error messages related to these background processes.

qas.question: What does the alternatives.log file track?

answers.text: The alternatives.log file tracks information related to the update-alternatives system, which manages symbolic links that determine the default commands associated with various programs on the server. It logs changes made to these alternatives to help maintain consistent command usage.

qas.question: What does the mysql.err file record?

answers.text: The mysql.err file records errors that occur when the MySQL server is running. It provides essential information for troubleshooting issues related to MySQL operations.

qas.question: What kind of records are stored in the dpkg.log file?

answers.text: The dpkg.log file contains information that is logged when a package is installed or removed using the dpkg command on the Debian Linux system. This includes records of actions related to package management, such as installations, upgrades, and removals.

qas.question: What information does the dmesg log provide during system startup?

answers.text: The dmesg log provides kernel ring buffer information during system startup, displaying messages about the hardware devices detected by the kernel. It includes details that pertain to the boot process, but older messages are overwritten as new messages are logged.

qas.question: What is included in the user.log file?

answers.text: The user.log file contains information about all user-level logs, documenting activities and events related to user actions on the system. This can include user logins, actions performed, and any relevant user-specific events.

qas.question: What does the fontconfig.log log about?

answers.text: The fontconfig.log contains records of the use of the fontconfig program, which is responsible for configuring or substituting fonts for other programs. It logs actions related to font management tasks.

qas.question: What type of information is found in kern.log?

answers.text: The kern.log file contains information logged by the kernel, including system errors and recent login information for all users. It helps track kernel-related events and user activity on the system.

qas.question: What records are contained within the syslog file?

answers.text: The syslog file contains a list of errors that occur when the server is running, as well as records of server start and stop events. It helps in monitoring system activity and troubleshooting issues.

qas.question: What does lastlog provide regarding user logins?

answers.text: The lastlog file contains information about the last login of each user on the system, including the timestamp and the terminal used for the login. This helps administrators track user access and identify any unusual login activity.

qas.question: What information does the aptitude log file record?

answers.text: The aptitude log file records information about packages that are installed or upgraded on the server. It provides a history of these package management activities, which can be useful for troubleshooting or tracking changes in the system.

qas.question: What is tracked in the faillog file?

answers.text: The faillog file tracks user failed login attempts on the system. It records information related to unsuccessful login attempts for users, helping to monitor and troubleshoot authentication issues.

qas.question: What type of information does wtmp maintain?

answers.text: The wtmp log maintains a historical record of user logins, logouts, system events, terminal usage, and the current status of the system, including system boot times. It is used to track user activity and system utilization over time.

qas.question: What historical records are found in the Nyquist E7000 checkin log?

answers.text: The Nyquist E7000 checkin log contains a historical record of actions that occurred during the Check-In process, including details about Check-In Start, Stop, Reset, Done, Vacancy Add, and Vacancy Delete events for individual stations.

qas.question: What types of errors are logged in the web server's error.log file?

answers.text: The web server's error.log file contains information about errors encountered when processing requests, such as missing files and other issues that prevent successful request handling. This log helps in troubleshooting and identifying problems related to web server operations.

qas.question: What does the other_vhosts_access.log file contain?

answers.text: The other_vhosts_access.log file contains access records for virtual hosts (vhosts) that do not have their own defined log files. It captures details of access requests processed by the web server for these vhosts.

qas.question: What kind of events are recorded in the checkin.log for the web server?

answers.text: The checkin.log for the web server records events associated with the Station Check-In process, including timestamps and data for actions such as Check-In Start, Stop, Reset, Done, Vacancy Add, and Vacancy Delete for individual stations.

10.3.2
Exporting a Log File
To export a log file:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select System Logs.
Step 2
Use the drop-down menu of the desired server to 
select the log file that you want to export.
Step 3
Select Export.
When the Save As dialog box appears, you can select where to down-
load or save the log file.
Once saved, an Excel icon with the downloaded report name appears 
in the lower left section of the Windows or MAC OS X web browser 
window, giving you the option to open the report. (See "Exporting a 
Report” on page 32.) For Android devices, files are automatically 
downloaded and saved to the device’s Download folder.
10.4
Using the Call Details Feature
The Call Details feature allows you to view or print detail records of 
every call in a facility in a call log format. Calls include scheduled 
announcements, paging, and internally and externally made or 
received telephone calls.

qas.question: What types of messages are contained in the messages log file on the E7000 server?

answers.text: The messages log file on the E7000 server contains messages generated by the server, which typically include system alerts, warnings, and other notifications related to server operations.

qas.question: What information can be found in the web server's error.log?

answers.text: The web server's error.log contains information about errors encountered by the web server while processing requests, specifically detailing instances when files are missing or other issues arise. This log helps in diagnosing and troubleshooting problems related to web server operations.

qas.question: What does the other_vhosts_access.log file contain?

answers.text: The other_vhosts_access.log file contains access records for virtual hosts (vhosts) that do not define their own log files. It records requests made to those vhosts, helping to track access and usage.

qas.question: What kind of events are recorded in the checkin.log file?

answers.text: The checkin.log file records events related to the Station Check-In process, including times and data for Check-In Start, Stop, Reset, Done, Vacancy Add, Vacancy Delete, and Check-in for individual stations.

qas.question: What are the steps to view a specific log file?

qas.question: How can a user export a log file?

answers.text: To export a log file, the user should select System Logs from the navigation bar, choose the desired log file from the drop-down menu, and then click Export. This will prompt a Save As dialog box, allowing the user to choose where to download or save the log file.

For Android devices, the files are automatically downloaded and saved to the device’s Download folder.

answers.text: Files are automatically downloaded and saved to the device’s Download folder on Android devices.

The following table describes the Call Details parameters:
Figure 10-6, Call Details Page
Table 10-5,  Call Details Page Parameters
Source
Provides the extension where the call originated or the 
station that recorded a page for page queuing.
Destination
Provides the extension where the call is directed, the 
zone selected for page queuing, or the zone selected for 
a zone announcement. A Destination of None entered 
means that an invalid zone was entered.
Type
Provides the type of call, such as Emergency Call, Admin 
Call, Announcement, and so on.
Start
Provides the date and time that the call began.

answers.text: The Call Details Page includes the following parameters: Source (the extension where the call originated), Destination (the extension or zone for call direction), Type (the nature of the call, such as Emergency or Announcement), and Start (the date and time the call began).

qas.question: What does the Start parameter indicate in the Call Details Page?

answers.text: The Start parameter in the Call Details Page indicates the date and time when a call began. This provides a timestamp for each call record, facilitating tracking and reference.

To view the call detail records for the facility:
On the navigation bar, select Call Details.
The following table describes the Call Details parameters:

Table 10-5,  Call Details Page Parameters
Source
Provides the extension where the call originated or the 
station that recorded a page for page queuing.
Destination
Provides the extension where the call is directed, the 
zone selected for page queuing, or the zone selected for 
a zone announcement. A Destination of None entered 
means that an invalid zone was entered.
Type
Provides the type of call, such as Emergency Call, Admin

10.4.2
Exporting and Printing a Call Log
To export and print a call details report:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Call Details.
Step 2
Select Export.
When the Save As dialog box appears, you can name 
the report and select where the report is to be down-
loaded or saved. The default name is call_details_(date 
in the yyyymmddhhhmmss format).csv.
Step 3
On the lower left of the page, select the Excel spread-
sheet.
Step 4
On the Excel spreadsheet, select Page Layout and set 
the desired parameters.
Step 5
Select File, and then select Print.
End
Provides the date and time that the call ended.
Status
Provides information about whether the call was 
answered or not answered. For queued pages, the status 
could be:
• Played – Page was successfully recorded and was 
played to the specified zone.
• Queued – Page was successfully recorded and is 
queued for playing to the specified zone.
• Not Recorded – Either zone was not defined or the 
user hung up without pressing # after the recording.
• Timed Out – Page timed out and was not saved 
either because there was more than 60 seconds of 
silence or because the recording exceeded 60 minutes 
in length.
• Requeued – Page message was interrupted while 
being played and was returned to the queue.
Duration
Provides the number of hours, minutes, and seconds that 
the call lasted.

qas.question: What information does the Source parameter provide in the Call Details page?

answers.text: The Source parameter provides the extension where the call originated or the station that recorded a page for page queuing. This helps identify the initial point of contact for the call.

qas.question: How can you determine the destination of a call from the Call Details page?

answers.text: You can determine the destination of a call from the Call Details page by looking at the "Destination" parameter, which provides the extension where the call is directed, the zone selected for page queuing, or the zone selected for a zone announcement. If "None" is displayed, it indicates that an invalid zone was entered.

qas.question: What types of calls are identified under the Type parameter?

answers.text: The types of calls identified under the Type parameter include Emergency Call, Admin Call, Announcement, and other similar classifications. These categories help distinguish the nature of the calls recorded in the call detail records.

qas.question: What format is used for the date and time displayed in the Start and End parameters?

answers.text: The date and time displayed in the Start and End parameters are in the format of "yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss." This format consists of the year, month, day, hour, minute, and second.

qas.question: What steps are involved in exporting a call details report?

answers.text: To export a call details report, select Call Details on the navigation bar, then click Export to open the Save As dialog box where you can name and choose the save location for the report. Finally, open the Excel spreadsheet, adjust the Page Layout parameters as desired, and print the report.

qas.question: What is the default name format for the exported call details report?

answers.text: The default name format for the exported call details report is call_details_(date in the yyyymmddhhmmss format).csv. This includes the date and time structured in year, month, day, hour, minute, and second format.

qas.question: How can you set parameters in an Excel spreadsheet after exporting the call details?

answers.text: After exporting the call details to an Excel spreadsheet, select "Page Layout" to set the desired parameters for the report. Then, you can adjust settings such as margins, orientation, and size before printing.

qas.question: What status options indicate whether a page was successfully recorded or not?

answers.text: The status options that indicate whether a page was successfully recorded are: "Played" (indicating the page was successfully recorded and played), "Queued" (the page was recorded and is queued for playback), and "Not Recorded" (the page wasn't recorded due to zone issues or user interruption). Additional statuses like "Timed Out" and "Requeued" indicate failures or interruptions in the recording process.

qas.question: What does a Status of "Timed Out" imply about a page recording?

answers.text: A Status of "Timed Out" implies that the page recording was not saved due to exceeding allowable silence (more than 60 seconds) or exceeding the maximum recording length of 60 minutes. As a result, the page recording was discarded.

qas.question: What metric is provided by the Duration parameter on the Call Details page?

answers.text: The Duration parameter on the Call Details page provides the total length of the call, measured in hours, minutes, and seconds. This metric indicates how long the call lasted from start to end.

10.5
Tuning Volume with White or Pink Noise
Nyquist provides white noise and pink noise files to help tune, or 
adjust, the volume of speakers in a zone.
White noise has equal energy for each frequency that the human ear 
can hear. Pink noise sounds less harsh than white noise because 
humans hear in octaves (the doubling of a frequency band). The 
energy in pink noise decreases by half as the frequency doubles, 
making the noise sound more balanced.
Both white and pink noise files are provided by default in Nyquist as 
both tones and songs. You can use the tone files as a tone generator 
to help adjust volume and frequency for pages in time-based zones. 
You can use the song files to help adjust volume and frequency in 
audio zones that play audio distribution.
Remember that when creating, editing, or viewing a zone, the Type 
identifies the zone as being able to receive paging, time, audio, or a 
combination of paging, time, or audio. (See "Viewing Zone Informa-
tion” on page 168.)
To launch a white noise or pink noise file as a tone, follow the steps 
listed in "Managing Tones Via the Dashboard” on page 346, selecting 
either the White Noise or Pink Noise file.
To play a white noise or pink noise file to a zone that plays audio dis-
tribution, first create a playlist that contains the white or pink noise 
song (see "Creating a Playlist” on page 259) and then follow the steps 
listed in "Using Audio Distribution” on page 353 to launch the audio 
distribution. 
If the zone can receive a combination of paging, time, and audio, you 
should use both the tone files and the song files to tune the speaker 
volume.

qas.question: What steps are required to export and print a call details report?

answers.text: To export and print a call details report, select Call Details on the navigation bar, then choose Export to name and save the report as a .csv file. Open the saved file in Excel, adjust the Page Layout settings, and proceed to print by selecting File, then Print.

qas.question: How is the status of a call categorized in the call details?

answers.text: The status of a call is categorized into several types: "Played" indicates the call was successfully recorded and played, "Queued" means it is waiting to be played, "Not Recorded" occurs if the zone wasn't defined or the user hung up too early, "Timed Out" indicates silence or excessive recording length, and "Requeued" signifies the message was interrupted and returned to the queue.

qas.question: What details can be found regarding the duration of a call in the call details?

answers.text: The duration of a call in the call details provides the total length of the call expressed in hours, minutes, and seconds. This parameter helps to quantify how long the call lasted.

qas.question: What is the difference between white noise and pink noise in terms of their frequency energy?

answers.text: White noise has equal energy across all frequencies that the human ear can hear, resulting in a harsher sound. In contrast, pink noise decreases in energy by half with each doubling of frequency, creating a more balanced sound that corresponds better to human auditory perception.

qas.question: How can white or pink noise files be used to adjust speaker volume in Nyquist?

answers.text: White and pink noise files in Nyquist can be used to adjust speaker volume by serving as tone generators for tuning volume and frequency in time-based zones or by creating playlists for audio zones that distribute sound. White noise has a consistent energy across frequencies, while pink noise decreases energy with increasing frequency, making it sound more balanced for audio adjustments.

qas.question: What steps must be taken to delete all call detail records?

answers.text: To delete all call detail records, select Call Details on the navigation bar, then choose Delete All. When prompted, confirm by selecting Delete.

qas.question: How does the energy level in pink noise vary with frequency compared to white noise?

answers.text: In pink noise, the energy decreases by half as the frequency doubles, resulting in a more balanced sound that is less harsh than white noise. In contrast, white noise has equal energy across all frequencies that the human ear can hear.

qas.question: What must be created to play a white noise or pink noise file in an audio distribution zone?

answers.text: To play a white noise or pink noise file in an audio distribution zone, you must first create a playlist that includes the white or pink noise song. After creating the playlist, follow the steps for launching the audio distribution to play it.

qas.question: How does white noise differ from pink noise in terms of frequency energy?

answers.text: White noise has equal energy across all frequencies that the human ear can hear, resulting in a harsh sound. In contrast, pink noise's energy decreases by half with each doubling of frequency, which makes it sound more balanced and less harsh due to its emphasis on lower frequencies.

qas.question: In what scenarios should you use tone files versus song files in Nyquist?

answers.text: Use tone files (white or pink noise) to adjust volume and frequency in time-based zones that require paging. In contrast, use song files for audio zones that play audio distribution, where you need to create a playlist containing the noise before launching the audio.

qas.question: How can you tune speaker volume using white or pink noise files?

answers.text: To tune speaker volume using white or pink noise files, you can use the tone files as a tone generator to adjust volume and frequency for paging in time-based zones. For audio zones, create a playlist containing the white or pink noise song files and use the audio distribution feature to play them, ensuring a balanced sound.

qas.question: What should you check regarding the type of zone before using paging, time, or audio features?

answers.text: Before using paging, time, or audio features, check the Type of the zone to ensure it is capable of receiving the intended features. The Type determines whether the zone can handle paging, time audio, or a combination of these functionalities.

qas.question: What is the process for launching a white noise or pink noise file as a tone?

answers.text: To launch a white noise or pink noise file as a tone, follow the steps listed in "Managing Tones Via the Dashboard" and select either the White Noise or Pink Noise file. This allows you to adjust the volume and frequency as needed.

qas.question: How can you create a playlist containing white or pink noise songs?

answers.text: To create a playlist containing white or pink noise songs, follow the instructions in "Creating a Playlist" on page 259 of the documentation. Once the playlist is created, you can use it to play the noise through zones that support audio distribution.

qas.question: What is the significance of the energy decrease in pink noise as frequency doubles?

answers.text: The significance of the energy decrease in pink noise as frequency doubles is that it creates a more balanced sound experience, as human hearing is more sensitive to lower frequencies. This decrease in energy helps ensure that pink noise is perceived as less harsh than white noise, making it more suitable for audio tuning and speaker adjustments.

qas.question: How does pink noise differ from white noise in terms of frequency energy balance?

answers.text: Pink noise differs from white noise in that its energy decreases by half as the frequency doubles, resulting in a more balanced sound that is less harsh to the human ear. In contrast, white noise has equal energy across all audible frequencies, leading to a sharper sound.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Type field when creating or editing a zone in Nyquist?

answers.text: The Type field in Nyquist identifies the capabilities of a zone, specifying whether it can receive paging, time, audio, or a combination of these functions. qas.question: How can a user launch a white or pink noise tone file from the dashboard?

Then, add the desired white or pink noise song to the playlist before using it to adjust volume in audio zones that play audio distribution.

qas.question: What are some common causes and solutions for day calls not being routed correctly to an Admin Station?

answers.text: Common causes for day calls not being routed correctly to an Admin Station include incorrectly set system parameters, particularly the Day Start time. To resolve this issue, navigate to System Parameters, review the Day Start time, and edit it to ensure it accurately reflects when the Admin Station should receive day calls.

qas.question: How can one adjust the Day Start time for routing calls in the system?

answers.text: To adjust the Day Start time for routing calls in the system, go to the navigation bar and select System Parameters. Then, review the Day Start time and, if necessary, click the Edit icon to enter the correct time for when the Admin Station should receive day calls.

qas.question: What should be checked if night calls are not being routed to the correct Admin Station?

answers.text: If night calls are not being routed to the correct Admin Station, check the system parameters, specifically the Night Start time. Ensure that the Night Start time is correctly set to the time when the Admin Station should receive night calls by selecting the Edit icon to make any necessary adjustments.

qas.question: What should you check if day calls are not routed to the proper Admin Station?

answers.text: If day calls are not routed to the proper Admin Station, check the system parameters to ensure the Day Start time is correctly set. On the navigation bar, select System Parameters, review the Day Start time, and edit it as necessary to match when the Admin Station should receive calls.

qas.question: How can you correct the Night Start time if night calls are misrouted?

answers.text: To correct the Night Start time for misrouted night calls, navigate to System Parameters on the navigation bar and review the Night Start time setting. If it's incorrect, select the Edit icon and enter the correct time for Night Start.

qas.question: What steps should be taken if the Nyquist server is not displaying the correct date and time?

answers.text: If the Nyquist server is not displaying the correct date and time, check the parameters set for the Network Time Server (NTP server) and the server's date/time. Access the System Parameters on the navigation bar, select the Edit icon, and make any necessary changes to ensure accurate settings.

qas.question: How do you determine if an extension can initiate non-emergency calls during the day?

answers.text: To determine if an extension can initiate non-emergency calls during the day, navigate to the CoS Configuration on the navigation bar and identify which configurations allow a Call in Level of Normal+Emergency. Then, check the station’s Day CoS settings to ensure it is assigned a configuration that permits this Call in Level.

qas.question: What are the potential reasons for a station not receiving Audio Distribution?

answers.text: A station may not receive Audio Distribution due to being on the Paging Exclusion list, not being a member of an audio distribution zone, having the Multicast Audio Distribution parameter disabled, or if multicast IP packets are being blocked or not routed. To resolve these issues, the station should be removed from the Paging Exclusion list, added to an audio distribution zone, the parameter enabled, and multicast packet flow verified.

qas.question: How can you resolve the issue if a DCS's LED changes to solid green but no call is made?

answers.text: If the DCS's LED changes to solid green but no call is made, ensure that the DCS is connected to a device configured to support the Digital Call Switch & Speaker station type. Check the Device Type assigned in the Stations list and adjust it accordingly if necessary.

enabled. (See "Editing Outside Lines” on page 87.)

qas.question: What messages are displayed on the Admin web UI dashboard during Nyquist operations?

answers.text: During Nyquist operations, the Admin web UI dashboard displays error, warning, and informational messages. Error and warning messages indicate operation failures and possible causes, while informational messages provide status updates on alarms, pages, announcements, and audio distributions. Users can delete error messages but may want to notify system administrators about them.

qas.question: How can an admin remove a station from the Paging Exclusion list?

answers.text: To remove a station from the Paging Exclusion list, refer to the relevant section titled "Excluding Stations from Paging" on page 162 of the documentation. Follow the instructions provided to modify the station's settings accordingly.

qas.question: What should you check if the DCS’s LED changes to solid green but no call is made?

answers.text: If the DCS’s LED changes to solid green but no call is made, check the device type the DCS is attached to and ensure it is configured to support the Digital Call Switch & Speaker station type. Refer to the Stations list to verify the correct configuration.

qas.question: What does the message "Alarm active (<extension>): <alarm-name>" indicate?

answers.text: The message "Alarm active (<extension>): <alarm-name>" indicates that the specified extension is currently initiating an alarm. This is part of the informational messages displayed during Nyquist operations to provide real-time status updates.

qas.question: What are the possible causes for a failed 911 call from an extension?

answers.text: A failed 911 call from an extension may occur due to a lack of available outbound lines, indicated by the message "Call to 911 from <extension> failed due to no outbound lines available." Alternatively, it may fail if the station does not have the 911 Route and Outside Access parameters correctly configured, leading to the message "Call to 911 from <extension> failed due to no 911 access."

qas.question: How can audio distribution be enabled or disabled?

answers.text: Audio distribution can be enabled or disabled through the system settings in the Admin web UI. Refer to the section "Enabling and Disabling Audio" on page 356 for specific instructions on how to toggle this feature.

qas.question: What information does the message "Audio Distribution: Playing <song-name> to Zone (<zone-number(s)>)" convey?

answers.text: The message "Audio Distribution: Playing <song-name> to Zone (<zone-number(s)>)" indicates that a specific song is currently being played through the audio distribution system to the designated zone(s). This message may also mention if the song is being played to "All Speakers" or "selected stations" within that zone.

qas.question: How does the system behave when it is running in demonstration mode?

answers.text: When the system is running in demonstration mode, all Nyquist functions are enabled, but the maximum station count is limited to 6 and the maximum number of simultaneous calls is capped at 2. This allows users to test the system's features with these constraints in place.

qas.question: What action should be taken if multicast IP packets are not flowing between the Nyquist server and stations?

answers.text: If multicast IP packets are not flowing between the Nyquist server and stations, you should ensure that the network configuration allows multicast routing and that any firewalls are not blocking multicast packets. Additionally, verify that the correct network settings and parameters are configured on both the server and the stations.

qas.question: What do user-created messages set up for I/O Controller rules signify on the dashboard?

answers.text: User-created messages set up for I/O Controller rules appear on the dashboard to provide specific status or notifications related to I/O operations. These messages can help users monitor and manage the functionality of the I/O Controller within the system. For additional information on setting up these messages, refer to the sections on configuring I/O Controller Input and Output rules.

10.7.2
Maximum Concurrent Call Error
If you reach your maximum concurrent call limit, the following error 
message appears:
Maximum concurrent calls reached. Contact Customer Service to 
increase maximum concurrent calls limit.
In this case, calls include telephone calls, pages, tones, alarms, and 
announcements.
To view the concurrent call limit set for your system:
From the navigation bar, select System Parameters.
The limit is based on your licensing set up and can only be changed 
by contacting Customer Service.
If you are using the Record Page feature, you must be below your 
concurrent calls limit by two calls for the page to play. Otherwise, the 
page remains in the queue.

qas.question: What does the error message "Call to 911 from <extension> failed due to no outbound lines available" indicate?

answers.text: The error message "Call to 911 from <extension> failed due to no outbound lines available" indicates that all outbound lines from the facility are currently busy, preventing the extension from successfully placing the emergency call. To mitigate this issue, the Bump on 911 system parameter can be set to Yes to allow for greater accessibility during emergencies.

qas.question: How can the "Bump on 911" system parameter help prevent 911 call errors?

answers.text: The "Bump on 911" system parameter can help prevent 911 call errors by allowing calls to 911 to be prioritized over other outbound calls, ensuring they go through even when all outbound lines are busy. Setting this parameter to "Yes" increases the likelihood that emergency calls will connect successfully during high traffic periods.

qas.question: What actions should be taken if a station cannot make a 911 call due to "no 911 access"?

answers.text: If a station cannot make a 911 call due to "no 911 access," ensure that the extension has the 911 Route parameter and Outside Access parameters correctly configured. Refer to the section on "Editing Station Configuration Settings" to adjust these settings appropriately.

qas.question: What does the Audio Distribution feature message indicate about the song being played?

answers.text: The Audio Distribution feature message indicates that a specific song is currently being played to a designated zone or zones. The message may also specify whether the audio is being distributed to all speakers or selected stations.

qas.question: How can one verify if Audio is enabled or disabled in the system?

answers.text: To verify if Audio is enabled or disabled in the system, check the status messages displayed on the dashboard. The message will indicate either "Audio Enabled" or "Audio Disabled," and you can refer to "Enabling and Disabling Audio" on page 356 for more information.

qas.question: What limitations exist when the system is running in demonstration mode?

answers.text: When the system is running in demonstration mode, the maximum station count is limited to 6, and only 2 simultaneous calls are permitted. All Nyquist functions remain enabled, but the reduced capacity restricts full operational capabilities.

qas.question: What should be done if the system displays the message "Maximum concurrent calls reached"?

answers.text: If the system displays the message "Maximum concurrent calls reached," you should contact Customer Service to increase the maximum concurrent calls limit, as the current limit is based on your licensing setup. Additionally, if using the Record Page feature, ensure you have two fewer calls than the limit for the page to play.

qas.question: How can a user find out their system's concurrent call limit?

answers.text: A user can find out their system's concurrent call limit by selecting "System Parameters" from the navigation bar. The limit is determined by the system's licensing setup and can only be changed by contacting Customer Service.

qas.question: What does the error "NOTICE: Server was restarted due to error" imply about the server's status?

answers.text: The error "NOTICE: Server was restarted due to error" implies that the server has likely experienced a crash or an error that necessitated a restart. It is recommended to contact Technical Support to ensure that the crash did not lead to any further issues. Additionally, the server may restart during installations or upgrades.

qas.question: What troubleshooting step can be taken if an extension is reported as "not available"?

answers.text: If an extension is reported as "not available," it is recommended to check for connectivity issues that may be preventing the station from registering with the Nyquist server. Rebooting the device may resolve the problem.
