12.2
Configuring Parameters for the Maps Feature
To use the Maps feature:
• You must have the correct Maps Panel permissions set. 
• You must be associated to a station that has the necessary CoS 
configuration. 
• The station Type for the associated station must be either an 
Admin Web Interface or a Web Interface.
• You must select a map on the associated station.
12.2.1
Assigning Maps Panel Permissions
Importing graphics and creating defined action objects are restricted 
to users associated with roles with Create and Edit Maps Panel per-
missions. A user only requires View Maps Panel permissions to use 
the Maps feature for initiating pages and calls and viewing Check-In 
status.
Select this Delete icon if you want to delete a map. This 
icon does not appear if you are in Live mode.
Select the Maps button to select which map you want to 
have appear on the Dashboard.
Select the Stations button to view which stations are 
allowed to add defined action objects or make other 
changes to the map. This icon does not appear if you are 
in Live mode.

qas.question: What modes can the Maps Panel be in, and how can you identify the current mode?

answers.text: The Maps Panel can be in either Edit or Live mode. The current mode is indicated by a Mode button that appears above the graphic, but it will not be visible if you are not authorized to edit Maps parameters.

qas.question: What permissions are necessary to create or edit Maps Panel features?

answers.text: To create or edit Maps Panel features, a user must be associated with roles that have Create and Edit Maps Panel permissions. Additionally, View Maps Panel permissions are required for users to initiate pages, make calls, and view Check-In status.

qas.question: Which station types are required for the Maps feature to function?

answers.text: The station types required for the Maps feature to function are either an Admin Web Interface or a Web Interface. Additionally, the associated station must have the necessary CoS configuration.

qas.question: How can a user initiate pages and calls using the Maps feature?

answers.text: A user can initiate pages and calls using the Maps feature by having View Maps Panel permissions, which allow access to the Maps functionality without requiring Create and Edit permissions. This enables the user to view the map and interact with it to initiate actions such as pages and calls.

qas.question: What actions can be performed using the Edit icon in the Maps Panel?

answers.text: The Edit icon in the Maps Panel allows users to edit the top-level map when the system is in Edit mode. This icon is not available in Live mode. Users must have the appropriate permissions to access this feature.

qas.question: Under what conditions does the Delete icon appear in the Maps Panel?

answers.text: The Delete icon in the Maps Panel appears only when the system is in Edit mode. It does not appear when the system is in Live mode. Additionally, users must have the correct Maps Panel permissions to utilize the Delete function.

qas.question: How can users select which map to display on the Dashboard?

answers.text: Users can select which map to display on the Dashboard by clicking the Maps button in the Maps Panel. This option allows them to choose from the available maps, but it does not appear if the system is in Live mode.

qas.question: What does the Stations button do within the Maps Panel?

answers.text: The Stations button within the Maps Panel allows users to view which stations are permitted to add defined action objects or make other changes to the map. This icon does not appear if the system is in Live mode.

qas.question: What must a user do to select a map on the associated station?

qas.question: What happens to the Delete icon when in Live mode?

qas.question: What are the two primary actions a user can perform with the Maps feature?

answers.text: The two primary actions a user can perform with the Maps feature are initiating pages and calls, and viewing Check-In status. To execute these actions, the user only requires View Maps Panel permissions.

qas.question: Which role permissions are essential for users to edit and create within the Maps Panel?

answers.text: Users must have Create and Edit Maps Panel permissions to import graphics and create defined action objects within the Maps Panel. Without these permissions, users cannot make edits or create new content in the Maps feature.

To set Maps Panel Permissions:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Roles.

On the Roles page, select the Permissions icon next to

sions.
Step 3

Note: To perform this task, you must be logged in with a role that

12.2.2
Setting CoS Configurations for the Station
The All Call and Emergency All Call buttons do not appear in the 
Maps panel section of the Dashboard if the correct CoS parameters 
are not set for the station. The ability to call any station or to initiate 
zone paging are also set for the station through CoS Configuration.
To set CoS Parameters for the Map Feature:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select CoS Configuration.
Step 2
Select the Add icon.
Step 3
Complete Parameters for the station. 
For information about the settings, see "CoS Configura-
tion Page Parameters” on page 64. 
Step 4
After all changes are made, select Save.
12.2.3
Assigning the Default Map
Your Dashboard will not show the Maps Panel until you have selected 
at least one map for your station. You must assign the default map 
(Site) to the station first. You can then create a new map for your sta-
tion. 
To assign the default map:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Stations.
Step 2
If you are adding your station, select the Add icon and 
ensure that the Type is Admin Web Interface or Web 
Interface. Then, complete all of the options for your 
station.
Step 3
If you are editing your station, select the Edit icon next 
to your station.
Step 4
Scroll to the Maps parameter and select the default 
map.
Step 5
Select Save.

qas.question: What permissions are required to import graphics and create defined action objects in the Maps feature?

answers.text: To import graphics and create defined action objects in the Maps feature, users must be associated with roles that have Create and Edit Maps Panel permissions. Only View Maps Panel permissions are needed to initiate pages and calls or view Check-In status.

qas.question: Which station types are compatible with the Maps feature?

answers.text: The station types compatible with the Maps feature are either an Admin Web Interface or a Web Interface. Users must be associated with a station of one of these types to utilize the Maps functionality.

qas.question: How can a user view which stations are allowed to make changes to the map?

answers.text: A user can view which stations are allowed to make changes to the map by selecting the "Stations" button in the Maps feature section. This button allows the user to see the list of stations with permission to add defined action objects or make other changes to the map, though it does not appear if in Live mode.

qas.question: What is the significance of assigning the default map for the Dashboard?

answers.text: Assigning the default map is critical for enabling the Maps Panel on the Dashboard, as it must have at least one map selected for visibility. This step ensures that users can view and interact with the map features effectively.

qas.question: What steps should be followed to set Maps Panel permissions for a role?

answers.text: To set Maps Panel permissions for a role, select "Roles" on the navigation bar, click the Permissions icon next to the desired role, choose the appropriate buttons to assign the Map Panel permissions, and then select "Save." Ensure you are logged in with a role that has permission to assign or edit permissions.

qas.question: What happens if the correct CoS parameters are not set for the station regarding the Maps panel?

answers.text: If the correct CoS parameters are not set for the station, the All Call and Emergency All Call buttons will not appear in the Maps panel section of the Dashboard. Additionally, the ability to call any station or initiate zone paging will also be restricted.

qas.question: How can a user assign the default map to their station?

answers.text: To assign the default map to a station, the user must navigate to the Stations page, either add a new station (ensuring the Type is Admin Web Interface or Web Interface) or edit an existing station. Then, scroll to the Maps parameter, select the default map, and click Save.

qas.question: What must a user do if they want to delete a map in the Maps feature?

answers.text: To delete a map in the Maps feature, a user must select the Delete icon associated with the map. This icon will not be visible if the user is in Live mode.

qas.question: What user role is necessary to perform edits on the permissions for the Maps Panel?

answers.text: To perform edits on the permissions for the Maps Panel, you must be logged in with a role that has permission to assign or edit permissions. Specifically, roles must have the Create and Edit Maps Panel permissions to import graphics and create defined action objects.

qas.question: What happens if the correct CoS parameters are not set for the station?

answers.text: If the correct CoS parameters are not set for the station, the All Call and Emergency All Call buttons will not appear in the Maps panel section of the Dashboard. Additionally, the ability to call any station or initiate zone paging will also be restricted.

qas.question: How can you initiate zone paging for a station?

answers.text: To initiate zone paging for a station, you must ensure that the correct CoS parameters are set for the station. This involves selecting CoS Configuration in the dashboard, adding the necessary parameters, and saving the changes before the ability to call any station or initiate zone paging is enabled.

qas.question: What is the first step to assign the default map to a station?

answers.text: The first step to assign the default map to a station is to select "Stations" on the navigation bar. If you are adding a new station, click the Add icon and ensure the Type is set to Admin Web Interface or Web Interface.

qas.question: What types of interface are acceptable when adding a new station?

answers.text: When adding a new station, the acceptable types of interface are Admin Web Interface and Web Interface. It is essential to select one of these types to complete the station setup process.

qas.question: How do you scroll to the Maps parameter to select the default map?

answers.text: To scroll to the Maps parameter to select the default map, first, navigate to the Stations section and either add a new station or edit an existing one by selecting the appropriate icon. Once in the station settings, use the scroll function (e.g., mouse scroll or touchpad) to find the Maps parameter and select the default map.

qas.question: What file formats are allowable for uploading a site graphic?

answers.text: You can upload a site graphic in either PNG or JPEG file formats.

qas.question: What should you ensure before attempting to add a graphic to the Nyquist system UI?

answers.text: Before attempting to add a graphic to the Nyquist system UI, ensure that the Mode is set to Edit. Additionally, verify that you have the necessary create or edit permissions, as the Mode button will not appear if you do not.

qas.question: What action needs to be taken if you want to edit a station's details?

answers.text: To edit a station's details, select the Edit icon next to the station on the Stations panel. Make the necessary changes and then select Save to apply the updates.

12.4
Adding a Defined Action Object
After the top level graphic has been added, you can create defined 
action objects on the graphic map and then select files to appear 
when the object is selected. For example, if your top level graphic is a 
site graphic that shows multiple buildings you might want to make 
each building a defined action object. Each building could then have 
multiple defined action objects, such as multiple zones or stations.
Table 12-1,  Edit Image Parameters
Name
Enter a name for the image, such as the name of the site. 
The maximum character length for this parameter is 20.
Width
Enter the width for the image canvas. This width will be the 
canvas size for all views that appear when drilling down 
into the map. 
Height
Enter the height for the image canvas. This height will be 
the canvas size for all views that appear when drilling 
down into the map. 
Image
Displays the file name for the image. Select Choose file to 
navigate to the desired file.
Note: If you move a defined action object or button outside of the 
map’s dimensions or too far to the edge of the map image, you 
may not be able to use or even see the button. In this situation, 
you must edit the map’s dimensions to view the object or button 
and then move it to within the map image.
Note: Stations and zones must first be added to your Nyquist sys-
tem before they can be added to a graphic as a defined action 
object.

qas.question: What file formats are supported for uploading a site graphic in the Nyquist system UI?

qas.question: What is the maximum character length for naming an image in the Edit Image Parameters?

answers.text: The maximum character length for naming an image in the Edit Image Parameters is 20 characters.

qas.question: What should be ensured about the Mode before adding a site graphic?

answers.text: Before adding a site graphic, ensure that the Mode is set to Edit. If you do not have create or edit permissions, the Mode button will not appear.

qas.question: How can you navigate to the desired file when adding a graphic?

answers.text: To navigate to the desired file when adding a graphic, select the "Choose file" button in the Edit Image Parameters section and browse to the location where the image file (PNG or JPEG) is stored. After locating the file, select it to upload.

qas.question: What happens if a defined action object is moved outside of the map’s dimensions?

answers.text: If a defined action object is moved outside of the map's dimensions or too close to the edge of the map image, it may become unusable or invisible. To resolve this, you must edit the map's dimensions to view the object and then reposition it within the map image.

qas.question: What must be done before adding stations and zones as defined action objects to a graphic?

answers.text: Before adding stations and zones as defined action objects to a graphic, you must first ensure that they are added to your Nyquist system. Only after this can they be incorporated into the graphic map.

qas.question: What defines the canvas size for views in the Nyquist graphic system?

answers.text: The canvas size for views in the Nyquist graphic system is defined by the width and height parameters entered during the image editing process. These dimensions will be the size for all views that appear when drilling down into the map.

qas.question: How can you create defined action objects after adding the top-level graphic?

answers.text: After adding the top-level graphic, you can create defined action objects on the graphic map by selecting areas such as buildings to represent them as defined action objects. You can then assign additional defined action objects, like zones or stations, to each building as needed.

qas.question: What steps are involved in adding a defined action object to a graphic?

qas.question: What options are available for resizing and rotating the rectangle when adding defined action objects?

qas.question: In what mode must you be in to add defined action objects from the dashboard?

answers.text: To add defined action objects from the dashboard, you must be in Edit mode. This allows you to manipulate the graphic map and create the defined action objects as needed.

Table 12-2,  Edit Parameters
Name
Enter a name for the selectable object.
Show Name
Select No if you do not want the name to appear on the 
map. The default is Yes.
Type
Select Rectangle if you want the object to cover a building 
or site. Select Button if you want the object to become a 
button that is associated with an action. For more informa-
tion about buttons, see "Creating a Defined Action Object 
“Button”” on page 371.
370
Action
Select what action is to be assigned to this object. Options 
are:
• None. By default, no action is associated with the 
object.
• Call. If you select this option, a drop-down menu 
appears so that you can select an Extension for the 
object. Extensions must have previously been associ-
ated to a Nyquist system station when stations were 
created.
• Page. If you select this option, a drop-down menu 
appears so that you can select a Paging Zone for this 
option. Zones must have previously been created and 
stations added to the zones before a zone can be asso-
ciated to a defined action object.
• All Call. Creates a button to use for making an All Call 
page.
• Emergency All Call. Creates a button to use for making 
an Emergency All Call page.
• Multi-Site All Call. Creates a button to use for making 
a Multi-Site All Call page.
• Multi-Site Emergency All Call. Creates a button to use 
for making a Multi-Site Emergency All Call page.
• Facility All-Call Page. Creates a button to use for mak-
ing a Facility All-Call Page. If this option is selected, you 
must also select a Facility.
• Facility Zone Page. Creates a button to use for making 
a Facility Zone Page. If this option is selected, you must 
also select a Facility.
• Facility Station Call. Creates a button to use for calling 
a specific station in a facility. If this option is selected, 
you must also select a Facility and an Extension. 
• Open URL. Creates a button to use to open a URL. If 
this option is selected, you must also enter the web 
address or other web resource that you want the button 
to open in the URL field. 
• Execute Routine. Creates a button that launches a 
specified routine. If this option is selected, you must 
also select the specific Routine.

qas.question: What must be enabled on the dashboard to assign an image to a defined action object?

answers.text: The dashboard must be in Edit mode to assign an image to a defined action object. This allows the user to access the Edit screen and upload an image file for the object.

qas.question: Which icon should be selected to edit a selectable object in the Edit mode?

answers.text: In Edit mode, the Edit icon (usually represented as a pencil or similar graphic) should be selected on the selectable object that you wish to edit. This will open the Edit screen where you can modify parameters for the object.

qas.question: What is the first step to edit a defined action object's appearance on the map?

answers.text: The first step to edit a defined action object's appearance on the map is to ensure the Mode is set to Edit from the dashboard. Then, click the Edit icon on the selectable object you wish to modify.

qas.question: What options are available for the "Action" parameter in a defined action object?

answers.text: The available options for the "Action" parameter in a defined action object include: None, Call (with a drop-down for selecting an Extension), Page (with a drop-down for selecting a Paging Zone), All Call, Emergency All Call, Multi-Site All Call, Multi-Site Emergency All Call, Facility All-Call Page (requiring a Facility selection), Facility Zone Page (with Facility), Facility Station Call (with Facility and Extension), Open URL (requiring a web address), and Execute Routine (requiring a specific Routine selection).

qas.question: How can you make the name of a selectable object not appear on the map?

answers.text: To make the name of a selectable object not appear on the map, ensure you are in Edit mode, click the Edit icon on the object, and set the "Show Name" parameter to "No." Then, select Save to apply the changes.

qas.question: What values are acceptable for the width and height parameters in pixels?

answers.text: The acceptable values for the width parameter must be 70 pixels or above, while the height parameter must be 30 pixels or above. These minimums ensure that the defined action objects are appropriately sized on the map.

qas.question: When creating a button to execute a routine, what additional selection is required?

answers.text: When creating a button to execute a routine, you must also select the specific Routine that you want to execute. This selection is required in addition to setting the action to "Execute Routine."

qas.question: What does selecting "Open URL" as an action require from the user?

answers.text: Selecting "Open URL" as an action requires the user to enter the full web address or other web resource that they want the button to open in the URL field. This option only appears if the Action is set to "Open URL."

qas.question: What color options are available for a defined action object?

answers.text: The available color options for a defined action object are Green, Blue, Brown, Gray, Orange, Pink, Purple, Red, White, and Yellow. The default color is Green.

qas.question: Which action option should be selected to make an Emergency All Call page?

answers.text: To make an Emergency All Call page, you should select the "Emergency All Call" action option from the available actions when editing the defined action object. This creates a button specifically for making an Emergency All Call page.

372
serves as a button. For example, suppose you have layers of maps 
that include the buildings and each floor in a building, but you most 
frequently call one or two extensions. Rather than drilling down mul-
tiple maps or objects each time you call an extension, you can create 
a defined action object that is associated with that extension. The 
selectable object can be named for the extension and placed on the 
first level graphic. 
Another reason for creating a defined action object that serves as a 
button would be if your Nyquist system server is managing multiple 
sites on a single campus. All Call and Emergency All Call pages would 
go to all stations on the Nyquist system. If you want to make a page 
to all stations of a single site in a multiple site campus, you can create 
a defined action object that launches a page to all stations in that site 
only.
12.4.2.2 Opening a URL
If you select Open URL as the Action for a defined action option but-
ton, you can use the button to open a specific web page or to refer-
ence a specific application, such as a video feed from a classroom. 
The full name, or path of the URL, must be entered in the URL field 
(see Table 12-2, “Edit Parameters,” on page 369). For example, to 
access the main Bogen web site, you would enter http://
www.bogen.com/.
When the Open URL button is selected in Live mode, the web page 
opens a new tab in the browser.
12.4.2.3 Execute Routine
If you select Execute Routine as the Action for a defined action 
option button, you can use the button to manually launch a routine. 
Only routines that have been previously created, are Enabled, and 
have Allow DTMF set to Yes appear in the Routine list on the Edit 
Map Object popup (see Table 12-2, “Edit Parameters,” on page 369). 
For more information about enabling routines and the Allow DTMF 
option, see Table 13-1, “Routines Parameters,” on page 385.

qas.question: What is the minimum width requirement for a defined action object “button”?

answers.text: The minimum width requirement for a defined action object "button" is 70 pixels.

qas.question: Which action options are available for the Facility drop-down menu?

answers.text: The action options available for the Facility drop-down menu include Facility All-Call Page, Facility Zone Page, and Facility Station Call. This menu is only accessible when the Action is set to one of these specific options.

qas.question: How can you use a defined action object to streamline calling extensions on a map?

answers.text: You can use a defined action object to streamline calling extensions on a map by creating a button associated with specific extensions, allowing quick access without navigating through multiple layers of maps. This button can be placed on the first-level graphic and named after the extension, facilitating faster connections to frequently called numbers.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the URL field in relation to the Open URL action?

answers.text: The URL field is used to enter the full path of a web page or application that the button will open when the Open URL action is selected. This allows users to access specific resources, such as a video feed or a website, directly through the defined action object button.

qas.question: What happens when the Open URL button is clicked in Live mode?

answers.text: When the Open URL button is clicked in Live mode, the specified web page opens in a new tab in the browser. The full URL must be entered in the URL field to access the desired content.

qas.question: What criteria must be met for a routine to appear in the Routine list when executing a routine?

answers.text: For a routine to appear in the Routine list when executing a defined action object, it must have been previously created, be enabled, and have the Allow DTMF option set to Yes.

qas.question: What color options are available for defining action objects?

answers.text: The available color options for defining action objects are Blue, Brown, Gray, Orange, Pink, Purple, Red, White, Yellow, and the default color is Green.

qas.question: Why might you create a defined action object to page all stations in a single site?

answers.text: You would create a defined action object to page all stations in a single site to facilitate targeted communication within a multi-site campus, ensuring that the message reaches only the relevant stations instead of all stations on the Nyquist system. This approach simplifies operations and enhances the effectiveness of emergency notifications or announcements.

qas.question: What is the available range for the rotation angle of a defined action object?

answers.text: The available range for the rotation angle of a defined action object is from 0 to 359 degrees.

qas.question: In which scenarios would the Video URL field be applicable?

answers.text: The Video URL field is applicable when the defined action object is intended to display a video feed from a specific room camera. This option appears when the Action is set to utilize a video source, allowing the button to link directly to a camera feed’s URL.

www.bogen.com/.
When the Open URL button is selected in Live mode, the web page 
opens a new tab in the browser.
12.4.2.3 Execute Routine
If you select Execute Routine as the Action for a defined action 
option button, you can use the button to manually launch a routine. 
Only routines that have been previously created, are Enabled, and 
have Allow DTMF set to Yes appear in the Routine list on the Edit 
Map Object popup (see Table 12-2, “Edit Parameters,” on page 369). 
For more information about enabling routines and the Allow DTMF 
option, see Table 13-1, “Routines Parameters,” on page 385.

qas.question: What is the purpose of creating a defined action object that serves as a button in a mapping system?

answers.text: The purpose of creating a defined action object that serves as a button in a mapping system is to streamline access to frequently used extensions or functions, allowing users to execute actions without navigating through multiple layers of maps. Additionally, it facilitates targeted communications, such as paging to specific sites on a multi-site campus, enhancing user efficiency and control.

qas.question: How can a defined action object help manage multi-site communications in a Nyquist system?

answers.text: A defined action object in a Nyquist system allows users to create a button that can quickly initiate communications, like paging, to a specific site within a multi-site campus, rather than broadcasting to all stations. This functionality enhances efficiency by enabling targeted messages and reducing confusion across different locations.

qas.question: What action does the 'Open URL' option perform when configured on a defined action button?

answers.text: The 'Open URL' option configured on a defined action button allows the button to open a specific web page or reference a specific application, such as a video feed, when selected in Live mode. The complete URL must be provided in the designated field, and selecting the button will open the web page in a new browser tab.

qas.question: What format must be used when entering a URL for the Open URL action?

answers.text: When entering a URL for the Open URL action, you must provide the full name or path of the URL in the URL field. For example, to access the Bogen website, you would enter "http://www.bogen.com/".

qas.question: What happens when the Open URL button is selected during Live mode?

answers.text: When the Open URL button is selected in Live mode, it opens the specified web page in a new tab in the browser. The full URL must be entered in the designated URL field for this action to work.

qas.question: What is required for a routine to appear in the Routine list for the Execute Routine action?

answers.text: For a routine to appear in the Routine list for the Execute Routine action, it must have been previously created, be Enabled, and have the Allow DTMF option set to Yes.

qas.question: What are the conditions that enable a routine to be executed via the defined action button?

answers.text: A routine can be executed via a defined action button if it has been previously created, is enabled, and has the Allow DTMF option set to Yes. Only those routines that meet these conditions will appear in the Routine list on the Edit Map Object popup.

qas.question: Where can one find more information about enabling routines and the Allow DTMF option?

answers.text: More information about enabling routines and the Allow DTMF option can be found in Table 13-1, “Routines Parameters,” on page 385 of the document.

12.5
Launching Pages Via the Map Feature
Depending on the parameters set, you can launch pages to an indi-
vidual zone, launch All Call pages, or launch Emergency All Call 
pages.
Zones must be created and stations added to the zones before the 
zones can be associated to a defined action object or paged via the 
Maps feature. For information about creating zones, see "Managing 
Stations, Zones, and Queues” on page 105.
12.5.1
Page an Individual Zone
If the Action for a defined action object is set to Page, then a Page 
icon appears in the left side of a defined action object. 
To page an individual zone using the Maps feature:
Step 1
From the dashboard, ensure the Mode is Live.
Step 2
Click the Page icon on the defined action object.
12.5.2
Launch All Call or Emergency All Call Pages
CoS parameters must be set before you can create All Call and 
Emergency All Call buttons that will appear in the Maps panel sec-
tion of the Dashboard. (See "Setting CoS Configurations for the Sta-
tion” on page 363.)
An All Call page is made to all zones associated with your Nyquist 
system server unless a zone is excluded from paging. An Emergency 
All Call page is made to all zones associated with the Nyquist system 
server; page exclusion does not affect Emergency All Call pages.
Figure 12-7, Page Icon

qas.question: What is the purpose of creating a defined action object that serves as a button in the Yeastar TA2400 system?

answers.text: Creating a defined action object that serves as a button in the Yeastar TA2400 system allows users to quickly access frequently called extensions or launch specific actions, such as paging all stations in a designated zone or opening a URL. This streamlines operations by minimizing navigation through multiple layers of maps and improving efficiency in managing communications across multiple sites.

qas.question: How does the Open URL action function in a defined action option button?

answers.text: The Open URL action in a defined action option button allows users to open a specific web page or application, such as a video feed, by entering the full URL in the designated field. When selected in Live mode, it opens the specified web page in a new tab within the browser.

qas.question: What prerequisites must be met for executing a routine using a defined action option button?

answers.text: To execute a routine using a defined action option button, the routine must be previously created, enabled, and the "Allow DTMF" option must be set to Yes. Only routines that meet these criteria will appear in the Routine list on the Edit Map Object popup.

qas.question: What is required to page an individual zone using the Maps feature?

answers.text: To page an individual zone using the Maps feature, ensure the Mode is set to Live and then click the Page icon on the defined action object associated with that zone. Additionally, zones must be created and stations added before they can be paged.

qas.question: How do All Call and Emergency All Call pages differ in terms of zone association?

answers.text: All Call pages are made to all zones associated with the Nyquist system server, but can exclude specific zones from paging. In contrast, Emergency All Call pages are sent to all zones regardless of any exclusions, ensuring that all stations receive the emergency alert.

qas.question: What must be configured before creating All Call and Emergency All Call buttons in the Maps panel?

answers.text: CoS parameters must be set before you can create All Call and Emergency All Call buttons that will appear in the Maps panel of the Dashboard. This ensures that the buttons function correctly for paging all associated zones in the Nyquist system server.

qas.question: In Live mode, what happens when the Open URL button is selected?

answers.text: In Live mode, when the Open URL button is selected, it opens a specific web page or application in a new tab in the browser. The full path of the URL must be entered in the designated URL field to function correctly.

qas.question: How can a defined action object be named for easy identification?

answers.text: A defined action object can be named after the specific extension it represents, allowing for easy identification. By placing this clearly labeled button on the first level graphic, users can quickly access frequently called extensions without navigating through multiple maps or objects.

qas.question: What steps are necessary to launch a page to an individual zone in the system?

answers.text: To launch a page to an individual zone using the Maps feature, ensure the Mode is set to Live from the dashboard, and then click the Page icon on the defined action object associated with the desired zone.

qas.question: What do you need to do before associating zones with a defined action object?

answers.text: Before associating zones with a defined action object, you must create the zones and add stations to them. This foundational setup is necessary to ensure that the zones can be used effectively in the Maps feature for paging.

qas.question: What are the different types of pages that can be launched via the Map feature?

answers.text: The different types of pages that can be launched via the Map feature are individual zone pages, All Call pages, and Emergency All Call pages. Individual zone pages target specific zones, while All Call pages reach all associated zones unless specified exclusions are set. Emergency All Call pages are broadcast to all zones without the possibility of exclusion.

qas.question: What needs to be configured to create All Call and Emergency All Call buttons?

answers.text: CoS parameters must be set before creating All Call and Emergency All Call buttons in the Maps panel section of the Dashboard. Refer to the section on "Setting CoS Configurations for the Station" for detailed instructions.

qas.question: How does an All Call page differ from an Emergency All Call page in terms of zone exclusion?

answers.text: An All Call page can exclude specific zones from paging, meaning that only the included zones will receive the page. In contrast, an Emergency All Call page is sent to all zones associated with the Nyquist system server, and zone exclusion does not apply, ensuring that every zone receives the emergency notification.

qas.question: What is the first step needed to page an individual zone from the dashboard?

12.7
Using Maps for Check-In
From the Maps view, you can monitor Check-In or launch a routine 
that starts or stops Check-In.
To use Maps for Check-In, the following conditions must be met:
•  You have permissions configured to view maps (see "Assigning 
and Editing Permissions” on page 203).
• Your station Type is Admin Web Interface or Web Interface (see 
"Editing Station Configuration Settings” on page 118).
• Check-In has been configured for your system (see "Configuring 
Check-In” on page 453).
• You have an available map that shows the rooms or areas that you 
want to monitor (see "Adding a Site Graphic” on page 364).
• You have created a map object for each station that you want to 
monitor (see "Creating a Map Object for Check-In” on page 376).
To use a routine to start or stop Check-In, the routine must have been 
previously created with either a trigger or an action Type of Check-In. 
(see"Adding a Routine” on page 387). 
Figure 12-9, Maps Check-In View
Note: You can only listen in areas or rooms that allow two-way 
communications; in other words, the station in that room must be 
associated with a speaker with a microphone.

qas.question: Which station types are compatible with the Admin Web Interface or Web Interface for Check-In?

qas.question: What must be configured for Check-In to function within a system?

Additionally, a routine for Check-In must be created with a trigger or action type of Check-In.

12.7.2
Monitoring Check-In
When Check-In is active, the Map panel changes to Live Mode and 
the Map objects for all stations being monitored will no longer show 
the Edit icon. Instead, you will see icons for Call, Listen, Video, and 
Information. 
The Listen icon only works if the station is associated with a speaker 
that allows two-way communication. The Video icon only works with 
Map objects that have been configured with a Video URL (see 
Table 12-2, “Edit Parameters,” on page 369). If the Map object isn’t 
large enough to display the icons, a hamburger menu (also known as 
a three-line menu or menu button) appears in the top right corner.
Note: You must create a defined action object for each room or 
area that you want to monitor.
Figure 12-10, Map Object in Live Mode

qas.question: What icons are displayed on the Map panel when Check-In is active?

qas.question: What does the Listen icon represent in the context of the map objects?

qas.question: What does a green color indicate for a station on the map?

qas.question: How can you identify if a station is not expected to check in?

13Using Routines
381
Using Routines
A routine automatically launches a procedure, or sequence of 
actions, that the Nyquist system executes as a result of an input trig-
ger. Routines can support your crisis plans for situations such as 
school lockdown, weather events, or emergency evacuation.
A routine can be started manually via the Admin Phone or the Admin 
Web UI. 
A routine can also be automatically launched:
• By an event, such as playing a specific announcement
• Via third-party switch contact closures recognized by the Nyquist 
I/O Controller
• Via a Routines API that can be used by third-party systems, 
including fire systems, access control systems, and video security 
systems 
A routine that has Allow DTMF enabled does not need a trigger. 
However, most routines will have at least one associated trigger and 
one or more actions. For example, if an administrator manually trig-
gers a lockdown routine, several actions could result, such as:
• Play a lockdown announcement.
• Display lockdown instructions on monitors connected to NQ-
GA10PV devices.
• Close I/O controller output contacts to trigger third-party systems 
that lock doors.
• Initiate the check-in process.
Note: You should always run a test of a routine after creating or 
editing it.

qas.question: What steps are required to delete a defined action object?

answers.text: To delete a defined action object, ensure the Mode is Edit from the dashboard, double-click the Menu icon of the object you wish to delete, select Delete, and confirm by selecting Delete again when prompted.

qas.question: What happens to associated objects and images when a map is deleted?

answers.text: When a map is deleted, all associated objects and images are also deleted. This action is comprehensive and affects everything linked to the map.

qas.question: How can a routine be manually triggered within the Nyquist system?

answers.text: A routine can be manually triggered within the Nyquist system via the Admin Phone or the Admin Web UI. This allows administrators to execute a sequence of actions in response to a specific situation, such as a school lockdown or emergency evacuation.

qas.question: What types of triggers can automatically launch a routine?

answers.text: A routine can be automatically launched by events such as playing a specific announcement, through third-party switch contact closures recognized by the Nyquist I/O Controller, or via a Routines API used by third-party systems like fire or access control systems.

qas.question: What does enabling Allow DTMF mean for a routine?

answers.text: Enabling Allow DTMF for a routine means that the routine can be initiated without needing a specific trigger. This allows for manual activation via Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency (DTMF) signals, providing greater flexibility for executing the routine.

qas.question: Can a routine be executed without any triggers?

answers.text: Yes, a routine can be executed without any triggers if it has the "Allow DTMF" feature enabled. However, most routines typically require at least one associated trigger and one or more actions to execute.

qas.question: What actions might occur when a lockdown routine is manually triggered?

answers.text: When a lockdown routine is manually triggered, it may result in several actions including playing a lockdown announcement, displaying lockdown instructions on connected monitors, closing I/O controller output contacts to lock doors, and initiating the check-in process.

qas.question: Why is it important to test a routine after creating or editing it?

answers.text: Testing a routine after creating or editing it is crucial to ensure that all actions are executed correctly and that the system responds as intended during an actual event. A test helps identify any potential issues or errors, ensuring reliability and effectiveness in crisis situations.

Using Routines
A routine automatically launches a procedure, or sequence of 
actions, that the Nyquist system executes as a result of an input trig-
ger. Routines can support your crisis plans for situations such as 
school lockdown, weather events, or emergency evacuation.
A routine can be started manually via the Admin Phone or the Admin 
Web UI. 
A routine can also be automatically launched:
• By an event, such as playing a specific announcement
• Via third-party switch contact closures recognized by the Nyquist 
I/O Controller
• Via a Routines API that can be used by third-party systems, 
including fire systems, access control systems, and video security 
systems 
A routine that has Allow DTMF enabled does not need a trigger. 
However, most routines will have at least one associated trigger and 
one or more actions. For example, if an administrator manually trig-
gers a lockdown routine, several actions could result, such as:
• Play a lockdown announcement.
• Display lockdown instructions on monitors connected to NQ-
GA10PV devices.
• Close I/O controller output contacts to trigger third-party systems 
that lock doors.
• Initiate the check-in process.
Note: You should always run a test of a routine after creating or

382
• Launch an emergency all call announcement.
To use the Routines feature, you must have the appropriate permis-
sions (see "Assigning and Editing Permissions” on page 176) and the 
station being used to launch the routine must have the CoS parame-
ter Execute Routines enabled. (see "Using CoS Configuration” on 
page 61).
To allow a third-party system to launch a routine via the Routines API, 
you must enable Allow API for the routine.
You can import or export routines by selecting the appropriate 
button from the Routines view. When importing a routine, the rou-
tine file must have a .sql extension. See "Exporting a Routine” on 
page 433 or "Importing a Routine” on page 435 for more information. 
13.1
Launching and Stopping a Routine from the 
Admin Web UI
You can manually launch a routine that has Allow DTMF enabled 
and stop a running routine from the Admin Web UI.
In addition to the routine needing Allow DTMF enabled, the Admin 
Web UI must have Execute Routines CoS enabled (see "Using CoS 
Configuration” on page 61).
To launch a routine from the Admin Web UI:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Under Calling/Paging, select Routines.
Step 3
Select one of the listed routines.
To stop a routine from the Admin Web UI:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Under Calling/Paging, select Routines.
Step 3
Select Routines Manager.

qas.question: What is a routine in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: A routine in the Nyquist system is a procedure that automatically executes a sequence of actions in response to a triggering input, such as an event or a manual command. It supports crisis plans like school lockdowns or evacuations by performing actions such as playing announcements or triggering third-party systems. Routines can be launched manually or automatically and may include triggers, actions, and permissions to ensure proper execution.

qas.question: What are some situations that can trigger a routine?

answers.text: A routine can be triggered by events such as playing a specific announcement, third-party switch contact closures recognized by the Nyquist I/O Controller, or through a Routines API used by third-party systems like fire or access control systems. Additionally, routines can be manually started via the Admin Phone or Admin Web UI.

qas.question: How can a routine be started manually?

answers.text: A routine can be started manually via the Admin Phone or the Admin Web UI, provided that the routine has Allow DTMF enabled and the user has the required permissions. In the Admin Web UI, users can navigate to the Routines section under Calling/Paging to select and launch a routine.

qas.question: What events can automatically launch a routine?

answers.text: A routine can be automatically launched by events such as playing a specific announcement, third-party switch contact closures recognized by the Nyquist I/O Controller, or through a Routines API used by third-party systems like fire, access control, and video security systems.

qas.question: What must be enabled for a routine to allow third-party API triggers?

answers.text: To allow a third-party system to launch a routine via the Routines API, the "Allow API" option must be enabled for that routine. Additionally, the routine must also have the appropriate permissions and the station must support executing routines.

qas.question: What are some actions that can result from manually triggering a lockdown routine?

answers.text: Manually triggering a lockdown routine can result in several actions, including playing a lockdown announcement, displaying lockdown instructions on connected monitors, closing I/O controller output contacts to lock doors via third-party systems, and initiating the check-in process.

qas.question: What permissions are required to use the Routines feature?

answers.text: To use the Routines feature, you must have the appropriate permissions enabled, as outlined in the "Assigning and Editing Permissions" section. Additionally, the station used to launch the routine must have the CoS parameter Execute Routines enabled.

qas.question: What file extension is needed for importing a routine?

answers.text: The file extension needed for importing a routine is .sql. This ensures that the routine file is recognized and can be successfully imported into the system.

qas.question: How can a routine be stopped from the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: To stop a routine from the Admin Web UI, navigate to your dashboard, select "Routines" under the Calling/Paging section, and then click on "Routines Manager." This allows you to manage and stop any running routines as needed.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Allow DTMF setting for routines?

answers.text: The Allow DTMF setting for routines enables them to be launched manually without needing a specific trigger. It is essential for executing routines directly from the Admin Web UI, as both the routine and the user interface must have the Execute Routines capability enabled to function properly.

13.2
Launching a Routine from the Admin Phone
You can manually launch a routine that has Allow DTMF enabled 
from an Admin Phone by doing one of the following:
• Dial *94<Routine-DTMF-Code>.
• Select the Routines menu from the Admin Phone and then select 
the routine that you want to launch. 
In addition to the routine needing Allow DTMF enabled, the Admin 
Phone must have Execute Routines CoS enabled (see "Using CoS 
Configuration” on page 61).
If you disconnect the call during a routine, the routine continues until 
finished. If the routine includes Pause actions, the call will not discon-
nect until all Pause actions have been executed. 
A routine launched from the Admin Phone may end with any of the 
following page commands, provided the Admin Phone has the 
appropriate CoS enabled:
• All-Call
• Emergency-All-Call
• Facility-Page
• Multi-Site-All-Call
• Multi-Site-Emergency-All-Call
• Zone-Page
Note: Stopping a routine does not reverse any actions that the 
routine has already started. You may need to clear the actions 
manually.
Note: Only routines with Allow DTMF enabled appear in the 
menu.

qas.question: What permissions are required to use the Routines feature?

answers.text: To use the Routines feature, you must have the appropriate permissions assigned and the station used to launch the routine must have the Execute Routines CoS parameter enabled. Additionally, the routine itself must have Allow DTMF enabled for manual launching.

qas.question: Which parameter must be enabled to launch routines from a station?

answers.text: To launch routines from a station, the CoS parameter "Execute Routines" must be enabled. Additionally, the routine itself must have the "Allow DTMF" option enabled.

qas.question: How can a third-party system launch a routine via the Routines API?

answers.text: To allow a third-party system to launch a routine via the Routines API, you must enable the "Allow API" option for the specific routine. Additionally, the routine must have the appropriate permissions set for execution.

qas.question: What file extension is required for importing a routine?

answers.text: The file extension required for importing a routine is .sql. This is specified in the context regarding the import functionality for routines.

qas.question: What steps are needed to manually launch a routine from the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: To manually launch a routine from the Admin Web UI, select Dashboard from the navigation bar, then under Calling/Paging, select Routines and choose one of the listed routines. Ensure that the routine has Allow DTMF enabled and that the Admin Web UI has Execute Routines CoS enabled.

qas.question: Which feature must be enabled on the Admin Web UI to stop a running routine?

answers.text: To stop a running routine from the Admin Web UI, the Execute Routines CoS must be enabled. Additionally, the routine must have Allow DTMF enabled.

qas.question: How can a routine be launched from an Admin Phone?

answers.text: A routine can be launched from an Admin Phone by either dialing *94 followed by the Routine DTMF Code or by selecting the routine from the Routines menu on the phone. The routine must have Allow DTMF enabled, and the Admin Phone must have Execute Routines CoS enabled to perform this action.

qas.question: What happens if you disconnect the call during a routine?

answers.text: If you disconnect the call during a routine, the routine continues until it is finished. If the routine includes Pause actions, the call will not disconnect until all Pause actions have been executed.

qas.question: Which page commands can end a routine launched from an Admin Phone?

answers.text: A routine launched from an Admin Phone may end with the following page commands: All-Call, Emergency-All-Call, Facility-Page, Multi-Site-All-Call, Multi-Site-Emergency-All-Call, and Zone-Page. Ensure that the Admin Phone has the appropriate CoS enabled to execute these commands.

qas.question: Do routines with Allow DTMF enabled appear in the Admin Phone menu?

answers.text: Yes, only routines with Allow DTMF enabled appear in the Admin Phone menu. This allows users to manually launch these routines from the Admin Phone.

qas.question: What is the outcome of stopping a routine that has already started executing actions?

answers.text: Stopping a routine that has already started executing actions does not reverse any of the actions that have been initiated. You may need to manually clear or address those actions afterward.

Select the routine that you want to stop.

13.2
Launching a Routine from the Admin Phone
You can manually launch a routine that has Allow DTMF enabled 
from an Admin Phone by doing one of the following:
• Dial *94<Routine-DTMF-Code>.
• Select the Routines menu from the Admin Phone and then select 
the routine that you want to launch. 
In addition to the routine needing Allow DTMF enabled, the Admin 
Phone must have Execute Routines CoS enabled (see "Using CoS 
Configuration” on page 61).
If you disconnect the call during a routine, the routine continues until 
finished. If the routine includes Pause actions, the call will not discon-
nect until all Pause actions have been executed. 
A routine launched from the Admin Phone may end with any of the 
following page commands, provided the Admin Phone has the 
appropriate CoS enabled:
• All-Call
• Emergency-All-Call
• Facility-Page
• Multi-Site-All-Call
• Multi-Site-Emergency-All-Call
• Zone-Page
Note: Stopping a routine does not reverse any actions that the 
routine has already started. You may need to clear the actions 
manually.
Note: Only routines with Allow DTMF enabled appear in the 
menu.

13.3
Using the Routines API
You can allow third-party systems, such as access control systems, to 
launch a routine, or you can remotely launch a routine using the Rou-
tines API. 
The routine must be created from an Admin Station that has the CoS 
parameter Execute Routines enabled (see "Using CoS Configuration” 
on page 61).
The routine must have the Allow API parameter enabled (see "Edit-
ing a Routine” on page 387).
To remotely launch a routine using the Routines API:
Step 1
On the browser’s address line, type:
http://<server_ip_address>/routine/api/<routine_dtm-
f_code>/<password>/<delay_flag>
where:
 <server_ip_address> is replaced by the Nyquist 
server’s IP address
<routine_dtmf_code> is replaced by the routine’s DTMF 
code
<password> is replaced by the password associated 
with the extension defined in the routine. 
<delay_flag> is replaced by either 1 or 0. A setting of 1 
returns the status to the remote station after the rou-
tine finishes while a setting of 0 returns the status 
immediately after the routine launches.
Note: The routine cannot end with a paging action or any call type 
action that requires a user to speak.

qas.question: What steps are involved in stopping a routine from the Admin Phone?

answers.text: To stop a routine from the Admin Phone, select the routine you want to stop and then select "Yes" to confirm. Note that stopping a routine does not reverse any actions that have already started, and you may need to clear those actions manually.

qas.question: How can you manually launch a routine using the Admin Phone?

answers.text: You can manually launch a routine from the Admin Phone by either dialing *94 followed by the Routine-DTMF-Code or by selecting the Routines menu and choosing the desired routine. Ensure that the routine has Allow DTMF enabled, and the Admin Phone has Execute Routines CoS enabled for this action.

qas.question: What must be enabled on the Admin Phone to execute routines?

answers.text: To execute routines from the Admin Phone, the Execute Routines Class of Service (CoS) must be enabled. Additionally, the routine itself must have the Allow DTMF feature enabled.

qas.question: What happens if the call is disconnected while a routine is executing?

answers.text: If the call is disconnected during a routine, the routine will continue executing until it is finished. If the routine includes Pause actions, the call will not disconnect until all Pause actions have been executed.

qas.question: Which page commands can end a routine launched from the Admin Phone?

answers.text: A routine launched from the Admin Phone may end with the following page commands: All-Call, Emergency-All-Call, Facility-Page, Multi-Site-All-Call, Multi-Site-Emergency-All-Call, and Zone-Page. The Admin Phone must have the appropriate CoS enabled to use these commands.

qas.question: Does stopping a routine reverse any actions already taken?

answers.text: No, stopping a routine does not reverse any actions that have already started. You may need to manually clear the actions that the routine has executed.

qas.question: What conditions allow a routine to be listed in the Admin Phone menu?

answers.text: For a routine to be listed in the Admin Phone menu, it must have the Allow DTMF enabled. Additionally, the Admin Phone must have the Execute Routines Class of Service (CoS) enabled.

qas.question: How can third-party systems launch a routine using the Routines API?

answers.text: Third-party systems can launch a routine using the Routines API by sending an HTTP request to the Nyquist server. The request should be formatted as follows: `http://<server_ip_address>/routine/api/<routine_dtmf_code>/<password>/<delay_flag>`, where `<server_ip_address>` is the server's IP, `<routine_dtmf_code>` is the routine's DTMF code, `<password>` is the associated extension password, and `<delay_flag>` indicates whether to return the status after the routine finishes (1) or immediately after launch (0).

qas.question: What parameters must be enabled for a routine to be launched via the Routines API?

answers.text: For a routine to be launched via the Routines API, it must have the Allow API parameter enabled, and it must be created from an Admin Station that has the CoS parameter Execute Routines enabled.

qas.question: What is the correct URL format for launching a routine using the Routines API?

answers.text:
The correct URL format for launching a routine using the Routines API is:  
http://<server_ip_address>/routine/api/<routine_dtmf_code>/<password>/<delay_flag>  
where `<server_ip_address>` is the Nyquist server’s IP address, `<routine_dtmf_code>` is the DTMF code of the routine, `<password>` is the routine's associated password, and `<delay_flag>` is either 1 (status returns after routine finishes) or 0 (status returns immediately).

qas.question: What do the delay_flag values signify when launching a routine through the API?

answers.text: The delay_flag values signify the timing of the status return after launching a routine through the API. A setting of 1 returns the status to the remote station after the routine finishes, while a setting of 0 returns the status immediately after the routine launches.

qas.question: What types of actions cannot be the final action in a routine launched via the API?

answers.text: The final action in a routine launched via the API cannot be a paging action or any call type action that requires a user to speak.

qas.question: What must be enabled in the CoS parameter to allow routine execution from an Admin Station?

answers.text: The CoS parameter "Execute Routines" must be enabled to allow routine execution from an Admin Station. This setting is necessary for launching routines through the Routines API.

qas.question: What does the Allow API parameter control for a routine?

answers.text: The Allow API parameter controls whether a routine can be launched remotely using the Routines API. If this parameter is not enabled, the routine cannot be triggered via external systems or browsers.

qas.question: How can a routine be remotely launched using the Routines API?

answers.text: To remotely launch a routine using the Routines API, input the following URL in a browser: `http://<server_ip_address>/routine/api/<routine_dtmf_code>/<password>/<delay_flag>`, replacing the placeholders with the Nyquist server's IP address, the routine's DTMF code, the associated password, and a delay flag (1 for status after completion, 0 for immediate status). Ensure the routine is created with the Allow API parameter enabled and is on an Admin Station with Execute Routines in the CoS configuration.

qas.question: What format should the URL follow to remotely launch a routine?

answers.text:
The URL format to remotely launch a routine should follow this structure:  
http://<server_ip_address>/routine/api/<routine_dtmf_code>/<password>/<delay_flag>  
Replace `<server_ip_address>` with the Nyquist server’s IP address, `<routine_dtmf_code>` with the routine’s DTMF code, `<password>` with the associated extension password, and `<delay_flag>` with either 1 (for status after routine completion) or 0 (for immediate status).

qas.question: What is indicated by the delay_flag in the API call?

answers.text: The delay_flag in the API call indicates whether to return the status to the remote station after the routine finishes (set to 1) or to return the status immediately after the routine launches (set to 0). This allows users to choose between waiting for the routine to complete or receiving immediate feedback.

qas.question: What restrictions are there for the final action in a routine?

answers.text: The final action in a routine cannot end with a paging action or any call type action that requires a user to speak. This restriction ensures that the routine completes without requiring further user interaction.

qas.question: Where can users view and edit existing routines?

answers.text: Users can view and edit existing routines by selecting "Routines" from the navigation bar. This action takes them to the Routines page, where they can see parameters for each routine and make necessary edits.

qas.question: What information is displayed in the Routines parameters table?

answers.text: The Routines parameters table displays the routine’s name, the extension used for granting CoS permissions and as Caller ID, and whether the routine is enabled or disabled. The extension field must be set unless the Caller’s Extension option is used, or the routine is considered invalid.

qas.question: What purpose does the Extension field serve in routine actions that require CoS permission?

answers.text: The Extension field specifies the station extension used to grant the required CoS permissions for routine actions. It also serves as the Caller ID wherever Caller ID is displayed. If the caller's extension is used, this field must remain blank to ensure the routine is valid.

qas.question: What happens if neither the Extension field nor the Use Callers Extension field is set in a routine?

answers.text: If neither the Extension field nor the Use Callers Extension field is set in a routine, the routine is considered invalid and cannot be executed. This requirement ensures that the routine has a valid caller identification.

13.5
Adding a Routine
Adding a routine creates a New Routine on the Routines page. By 
default, this new routine is not enabled. It also has no Triggers or 
Actions.
To add a routine:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Routines.
Step 2
On the Routines page, select the Add icon.
The Edit Routine page appears (see "Editing a Routine” on page 387).
13.6
Editing a Routine
Editing a routine allows you to change the Name from New Routine 
to a more descriptive name. The Edit Routine page allows you to set 
other parameters for the routine (see Table 13-1, “Routines Parame-
ters,” on page 385).
Note: When a Routine is added, edited, or deleted, all Admin 
phones will automatically be rebooted to update their Routines 
menu.

qas.question: What parameters are displayed for each routine on the Routines page?

answers.text: The parameters displayed for each routine on the Routines page include the routine’s Name, Extension, Enabled status, Use Caller’s Extension option, Allow DTMF option, DTMF Code, Allow API option, Allow Multiple option, and a Description. Each parameter helps define how the routine operates and interacts with caller permissions and triggers.

qas.question: What does the "Enabled" parameter indicate for a routine?

answers.text: The "Enabled" parameter indicates whether a routine is active or inactive; by default, a newly created routine is disabled. If the routine is enabled, it can be executed based on its defined triggers and actions.

qas.question: What must be set for a routine to be considered valid—Extension or Use Caller’s Extension?

answers.text: For a routine to be considered valid, either the Extension or the Use Caller’s Extension must be set. If one of these fields is not set, the routine will be deemed invalid.

qas.question: How can a routine be started manually from an Admin Phone?

answers.text: A routine can be started manually from an Admin Phone by dialing the routine’s DTMF code, provided that the "Allow DTMF" option is enabled. The DTMF code must be a unique number between 1 to 10 digits assigned to that routine.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF Code parameter?

answers.text: The DTMF Code parameter specifies the number used to manually start a routine from an Admin Phone or via the Routine API. It can consist of 1 to 10 digits, and each routine must have a unique DTMF code assigned to it.

qas.question: What does the "Allow API" option do for a routine?

answers.text: The "Allow API" option permits the routine to be executed via the Routines API, enabling third-party applications, such as fire alarm systems, to launch a Nyquist routine programmatically. This allows for automated integration with external systems.

qas.question: How does the "Allow Multiple" parameter affect routine execution?

answers.text: The "Allow Multiple" parameter determines whether multiple instances of a routine can run simultaneously. If enabled, the system permits multiple executions of the routine at the same time, regardless of how many times it is triggered. If disabled, only one instance of the routine can execute at any given time.

qas.question: What happens when a routine is added, edited, or deleted regarding Admin phones?

answers.text: When a routine is added, edited, or deleted, all Admin phones will automatically reboot to update their Routines menu. This ensures that any changes made to the routines are reflected on all Admin devices.

qas.question: What steps are involved in adding a new routine?

answers.text: To add a new routine, first select "Routines" from the navigation bar. Then, on the Routines page, click the Add icon to access the Edit Routine page, where you can configure the routine's parameters. By default, the new routine will not be enabled and will have no Triggers or Actions.

qas.question: What is the default status of a newly created routine?

answers.text: The default status of a newly created routine is disabled. Additionally, it does not have any Triggers or Actions assigned to it upon creation.

13.7
Deleting a Routine
Use caution when deleting routines. If you delete a routine and then 
recreate it, you may need to assign a new DTMF Code if the previous 
code was assigned to another routine.

On the navigation bar, select Routines.

When prompted, select Delete.
13.8
Creating and Executing Multi-Site Routines
You can create a routine to be launched on one or more remote sites, 
such as a lockdown routine to be launched at all sites in a district.
To create such a routine, you would select the Routine action Type 
(see "Actions” on page 402 and "Understanding Action Parameters” on 
page 406). You can select to execute the action on the local facility, a 
specific facility, or all facility. If you want to execute the routine or 
multiple, but not all, facilities, you must create a separate action for 
each facility (using Routine action Type).
When you select a specific facility, you can enter the DTMF code of 
the routine. A routine with that DTMF code must exist on that facility.
Routines that are triggered by another site will not execute calling or 
paging type actions. Also, the receiving facility must have Use Caller 
Extension disabled.
Note: There will be a one-second delay between execution of one 
Routine action and another Routine action. So, if you execute a 
multi-site routine for 10 sites, there will be 10-second delay 
between when the routine starts on the first facility and when it 
starts on the tenth facility. To eliminate this delay, you can select 
All Facilities and then ensure that a routine with the specified 
DTMF does not exist on the sites that you do not want to run the 
routine. If All Facilities is selected, the remote routines start at the 
same time.

qas.question: How do you add a new routine on the Routines page?

answers.text: To add a new routine on the Routines page, select Routines from the navigation bar and then click the Add icon. This will open the Edit Routine page, where you can configure your new routine.

qas.question: What happens to Admin phones when a routine is added, edited, or deleted?

answers.text: When a routine is added, edited, or deleted, all Admin phones automatically reboot to update their Routines menu. This ensures that any changes made to the routines are reflected across all devices.

qas.question: What steps are involved in editing a routine's parameters?

answers.text: To edit a routine's parameters, select Routines on the navigation bar, click the Edit icon next to the desired routine, complete the necessary changes on the Edit Routines page, and then select Save. Ensure all changes align with the parameters outlined on the relevant documentation page.

qas.question: What precautions should be taken when deleting a routine?

answers.text: When deleting a routine, exercise caution as recreating the routine may require assigning a new DTMF code if the previous code has been reassigned to another routine. It's important to ensure that no critical actions are lost due to the deletion of the routine.

qas.question: How can a routine be created for execution across multiple sites?

answers.text: To create a routine for execution across multiple sites, select the Routine action Type and choose to execute the action on either a specific facility or all facilities. If using specific facilities, ensure that a routine with the specified DTMF code exists at each site, and be aware that a one-second delay will occur between executing each routine unless "All Facilities" is selected, which allows for simultaneous execution.

qas.question: What is the significance of the DTMF code when creating routines for specific facilities?

answers.text: The DTMF code is significant because it must match an existing routine on the specific facility for the routine to be executed there. If the routine is recreated after deletion, a new DTMF code may need to be assigned if the previous one is already associated with another routine.

qas.question: What type of actions will not execute when triggered by another site?

answers.text: Routines that are triggered by another site will not execute calling or paging type actions. Additionally, the receiving facility must have Use Caller Extension disabled for the routine to function properly.

qas.question: How can you eliminate the delay when executing multi-site routines?

answers.text: To eliminate the delay when executing multi-site routines, select "All Facilities" for the action, and ensure that a routine with the specified DTMF code does not exist on the sites where you do not want the routine to run. This allows all remote routines to start simultaneously without delays.

qas.question: What is required for a routine with a DTMF code to execute on a specific facility?

qas.question: What types of actions will not execute for routines triggered by another site?

qas.question: What must be disabled at the receiving facility for remote routines to execute?

qas.question: How does the execution delay work when triggering routine actions across multiple sites?

answers.text: When executing routine actions across multiple sites, there is a one-second delay between the execution of each Routine action. For example, if a routine is triggered for 10 sites, there will be a total of a 10-second delay from the start of the routine on the first facility to the start on the tenth facility. qas.question: How can you eliminate the execution delay for a multi-site routine?

answers.text: To eliminate the execution delay for a multi-site routine, select "All Facilities" when creating the routine. Ensure that a routine with the specified DTMF code does not exist on the sites where you do not want the routine to run, allowing all remote routines to start simultaneously.

qas.question: What happens if the selected routine DTMF code already exists on a facility?

answers.text: If the selected routine DTMF code already exists on a facility, you may need to assign a new DTMF code to the routine you are trying to create, as the existing code is already in use. Additionally, if you attempt to execute the routine using the existing DTMF code, it may not function as intended.

13.7
Deleting a Routine
Use caution when deleting routines. If you delete a routine and then 
recreate it, you may need to assign a new DTMF Code if the previous 
code was assigned to another routine.
To delete a routine:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Routines.
Step 2
On the Routines page, select the Delete icon next to 
the routine that you want to delete.
Step 3
When prompted, select Delete.
13.8
Creating and Executing Multi-Site Routines
You can create a routine to be launched on one or more remote sites, 
such as a lockdown routine to be launched at all sites in a district.
To create such a routine, you would select the Routine action Type 
(see "Actions” on page 402 and "Understanding Action Parameters” on 
page 406). You can select to execute the action on the local facility, a 
specific facility, or all facility. If you want to execute the routine or 
multiple, but not all, facilities, you must create a separate action for 
each facility (using Routine action Type).
When you select a specific facility, you can enter the DTMF code of 
the routine. A routine with that DTMF code must exist on that facility.
Routines that are triggered by another site will not execute calling or 
paging type actions. Also, the receiving facility must have Use Caller 
Extension disabled.
Note: There will be a one-second delay between execution of one 
Routine action and another Routine action. So, if you execute a 
multi-site routine for 10 sites, there will be 10-second delay 
between when the routine starts on the first facility and when it 
starts on the tenth facility. To eliminate this delay, you can select 
All Facilities and then ensure that a routine with the specified 
DTMF does not exist on the sites that you do not want to run the 
routine. If All Facilities is selected, the remote routines start at the 
same time.
