13.8.1
Call Detail Records
Call Detail Records (CDRs) are created when a routine is started. 
When started on a local facility, the Destination field will show Local 
Facility and the Type field will show Start Routine (<routine-
DTMF-code>).
When a routine is started on a selected remote facility, the CDR will 
show the remote facility name in the Destination field and Start 
Remote Routine (<routine-DTMF-code>) in the Type field.
When a routine is started on all facilities, the CDR will show All Facil-
ities in the Destination field and Start Remote Routine (<routine-
DTMF-code>) in the Type field.
For more information about view CDRs, see "Viewing Call Detail 
Records” on page 319.
13.9
Allowing Input Contact Closure to Initiate 
Ring-Tone to Speakers
Through the Routines feature, you can let an input contact closure 
initiate the playing of a ringtone to designated stations. 
To do this, create a routine (see "Adding a Routine” on page 387) that 
uses Play-Ringtone as the action Type (see "Understanding Action 
Parameters” on page 406). For the Action, select Start. Select the 
Zones that contain the speakers you want to play the ringtone.
To stop the ringtone, create a second routine that is triggered when 
the contact opens and uses the Stop for the Action.
13.10
Using Triggers
A trigger is an event that starts a routine. By default, when you create 
a routine, it has no trigger or actions.
A trigger can have up to two parameters. For example, you can create 
a trigger that uses a specific Announcement. The first parameter 
would be the Announcement Type (Number) and the second 
parameter would be the Announcement.

qas.question: What caution should be exercised when deleting a routine?

answers.text: When deleting a routine, be cautious because if you recreate it, you may need to assign a new DTMF Code if the previous code is already assigned to another routine.

qas.question: How do you delete a routine from the system?

answers.text: To delete a routine from the system, navigate to the Routines page and select the Delete icon next to the routine you wish to remove. When prompted, confirm by selecting Delete.

qas.question: What is the process to create and execute multi-site routines?

answers.text: To create and execute multi-site routines, select the Routine action Type and choose whether to execute the action on the local facility, a specific facility, or all facilities. If executing on multiple but not all facilities, create separate actions for each; ensure that a routine with the specified DTMF code exists on those selected facilities. Note that selecting All Facilities allows routines to start simultaneously, avoiding any execution delay.

qas.question: What happens if a routine is triggered by another site?

answers.text: If a routine is triggered by another site, it will not execute calling or paging type actions. Additionally, the receiving facility must have the "Use Caller Extension" option disabled.

qas.question: How can you ensure that a multi-site routine starts at the same time?

answers.text: To ensure that a multi-site routine starts at the same time, select "All Facilities" when creating the routine and ensure that a routine with the specified DTMF code does not exist on the sites where you do not want the routine to run. This configuration eliminates the one-second delay that occurs when executing routines sequentially on multiple sites.

qas.question: What information is recorded in Call Detail Records when a routine is initiated?

answers.text: When a routine is initiated, Call Detail Records (CDRs) capture the Destination field and the Type field. If started on a local facility, the Destination shows "Local Facility" and the Type indicates "Start Routine (<routine-DTMF-code>)." For a selected remote facility, the Destination reflects the facility name, and the Type shows "Start Remote Routine (<routine-DTMF-code>)." If initiated on all facilities, the Destination is "All Facilities" with the Type as "Start Remote Routine (<routine-DTMF-code>)."

qas.question: How can input contact closures be used to initiate ringtones on speakers?

answers.text: Input contact closures can be used to initiate ringtones on speakers by creating a routine that utilizes the Play-Ringtone action type. The routine is triggered by the closure event, playing the selected ringtone on designated zones, and a second routine can be created to stop the ringtone when the contact opens again.

qas.question: What actions need to be taken to stop a ringtone once it has started?

answers.text: To stop a ringtone once it has started, create a second routine that is triggered when the input contact opens. This routine should use the Stop action type.

qas.question: What defines a trigger in the context of routines?

answers.text: A trigger in the context of routines is an event that initiates the execution of a routine. It can have up to two parameters, allowing for specific criteria to be defined, such as a particular Announcement Type and its corresponding Announcement.

qas.question: How many parameters can a trigger have, and what is an example of their use?

answers.text: A trigger can have up to two parameters. For example, in a trigger using a specific Announcement, the first parameter would be the Announcement Type (Number) and the second parameter would be the Announcement itself.

qas.question: What are Call Detail Records (CDRs) and when are they created?

answers.text: Call Detail Records (CDRs) are generated when a routine is initiated. They indicate the location of the routine's start in the Destination field and specify the type of action taken in the Type field, such as "Start Routine" for local facilities or "Start Remote Routine" for remote facilities.

qas.question: How is the Destination field populated in a CDR for a local facility?

answers.text: In a Call Detail Record (CDR) for a local facility, the Destination field is populated with the value "Local Facility" when a routine is started. The Type field will indicate "Start Routine (<routine-DTMF-code>)".

qas.question: What does the Type field indicate when a routine is started on a remote facility?

answers.text: When a routine is started on a selected remote facility, the Type field in the Call Detail Record (CDR) will indicate "Start Remote Routine (<routine-DTMF-code>)". This signifies that the routine initiated is specifically targeting a remote location.

qas.question: How does the CDR represent a routine started on all facilities?

answers.text: When a routine is started on all facilities, the Call Detail Record (CDR) will display "All Facilities" in the Destination field and "Start Remote Routine (<routine-DTMF-code>)" in the Type field.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Routines feature in relation to input contact closures?

answers.text: The Routines feature allows an input contact closure to initiate the playing of a ringtone to designated stations. By creating a routine that uses Play-Ringtone as the action, the ringtone can be triggered when the contact closes, and a second routine can be set to stop the ringtone when the contact opens.

qas.question: What action type should be selected to initiate a ringtone through a routine?

answers.text: To initiate a ringtone through a routine, you should select "Play-Ringtone" as the action Type and choose "Start" for the Action. Additionally, specify the Zones that contain the speakers where the ringtone will be played.

qas.question: How can a ringtone be stopped once it has started playing via a routine?

answers.text: To stop a ringtone that has started playing via a routine, create a second routine triggered by the opening of the contact closure. This routine should use the action type "Stop" to halt the ringtone playback.

qas.question: What defines a trigger in the context of routines?

answers.text: A trigger in the context of routines is an event that initiates the execution of a routine. It can have up to two parameters, such as a specific Announcement Type and the corresponding Announcement itself.

qas.question: How many parameters can a trigger have, and what might those parameters represent?

answers.text: A trigger can have up to two parameters. These parameters might represent the Announcement Type (Number) as the first parameter and the specific Announcement as the second parameter.

qas.question: How can you stop a ringtone that is playing as a result of an input contact closure?

qas.question: How do you view triggers associated with a specific routine?

answers.text: To view triggers associated with a specific routine, select "Routines" on the navigation bar and then choose "Triggers" for the routine you wish to view. If any triggers have been added, their information will appear on the Triggers page, where you can also add new triggers or actions.

qas.question: What information can be found in the Triggers table regarding the user-provided name for a trigger?

answers.text: The Triggers table displays the user-provided name for each trigger. This name allows users to identify and differentiate between various triggers associated with routines. Additionally, the table indicates whether the trigger is enabled, which determines if the routine will start when the trigger event occurs.

qas.question: What does the 'Enabled' status indicate about a trigger's functionality?

answers.text: The 'Enabled' status indicates whether a trigger is active and will cause the routine to start when the specified event occurs. If a trigger is enabled, it can initiate the associated actions of the routine; if disabled, it will not activate the routine.

13.10.2
Adding a Trigger
One or more triggers, which are events that launch a routine, can be 
added to a routine. When adding a trigger, you can set up to two 
parameters for the trigger (see "Understanding Trigger Parameters” 
on page 395).
To add a trigger:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Routines.
Step 2
Select Triggers for the routine that you want to add a 
trigger for.
Step 3
Select the Add icon.
The Edit Trigger page appears.
Step 4
Complete the parameters for the new trigger (see "Edit-
ing a Trigger” on page 394).
Step 5
Select Save.
Parameter 1
Displays the first parameter for the specified 
trigger if required. For example, if a trigger 
involves the closing of a contact on an I/O 
Controller, Parameter 1 is the name of the I/
O Controller. For more information about 
Parameter 1 options, see "Understanding 
Trigger Parameters” on page 395.
Parameter 2
Displays the second parameter for the speci-
fied trigger if required. For example, if a trig-
ger involves the closing of a contact on an I/
O Controller, Parameter 2 is the specific con-
tact or contacts of the device. For more infor-
mation about Parameter 2 options, see 
"Understanding Trigger Parameters” on 
page 395.
Description
Displays the description entered by the user 
for the selected trigger.

qas.question: What steps are required to view triggers for a routine?

answers.text: To view triggers for a routine, select "Routines" on the navigation bar, then choose "Triggers" for the specific routine you want to view. If triggers have been added, information about them will be displayed, and you can also add new triggers or actions if needed.

qas.question: How can a user determine if a trigger is enabled?

answers.text: A user can determine if a trigger is enabled by checking the "Enabled" field on the Triggers page for the selected routine. If the trigger is enabled, it will indicate that the trigger will cause the routine to begin when the trigger event occurs.

qas.question: What types of system events can trigger a routine?

answers.text: A routine can be triggered by various system events, including 911 calls, alarms, announcements, incoming calls, emergency situations, and several others such as audio status changes and scheduled events. The specific types of triggers include, but are not limited to, Urgent-Call, Facility Status Down, and Night-Ring.

qas.question: What is the purpose of adding triggers to a routine?

answers.text: The purpose of adding triggers to a routine is to define specific events that will automatically initiate the execution of that routine. Triggers can be associated with various system events, allowing for automated responses based on predefined conditions.

qas.question: What are the steps needed to add a trigger to a routine?

answers.text: To add a trigger to a routine, select Routines from the navigation bar, then choose Triggers for the desired routine and click the Add icon. Complete the required parameters for the new trigger on the Edit Trigger page and select Save.

qas.question: What kind of information does Parameter 1 display when adding a trigger?

answers.text: Parameter 1 displays the first parameter for the specified trigger, which is required for certain triggers. For example, if the trigger involves the closing of a contact on an I/O Controller, Parameter 1 would show the name of the I/O Controller.

qas.question: What does Parameter 2 represent in the context of triggers?

answers.text: Parameter 2 represents the specific contact or contacts of a device, particularly if the trigger involves the closing of a contact on an I/O Controller. It is a required field when applicable and helps to define the specific event that will activate the trigger within the routine.

qas.question: What information is provided in the description field when adding a trigger?

answers.text: The description field when adding a trigger displays the information entered by the user for the selected trigger. This field allows the user to provide context or details about the specific trigger being set up.

answers.text: The Edit Trigger page allows you to change the trigger's name to a more descriptive title and adjust its parameters, such as Parameter 1 and Parameter 2, as needed. This enables the user to customize triggers for specific events effectively.

qas.question: Where can you find information about Parameter options for triggers?

On the navigation bar, select Routines.
Step 2
Select the Delete icon next to the trigger that you want 
to delete.
Step 3
When prompted, select Delete.
13.10.5
Understanding Trigger Parameters
A trigger can have up to two parameters, depending on the Type 
selected. 
When viewing triggers, the parameters appear as Parameter 1 and 
Parameter 2. On the Edit Trigger page, though, the parameter 
names and available selections change based on the Type. For exam-
ple, if Alarm is selected as Type, a field called Alarm appears with a 
drop-down menu that shows all of the tones with Type set to Alarm 
on the Tones page (see "Viewing Available Tones” on page 256). 
If you select the trigger Type to Announcement, the Announce-
ment Type field appears. The selection for Announcement Type will 
appear as Parameter 1 on the Triggers page. For some Announce-
ment Types, additional information is needed. For instance, if you 
select Normal-Zone as the Announcement Type on the Edit Trigger 
page, the Zone field appears. From the Zone field, you can select All 
Speakers, Any Zone, or a specific zone. 
Some triggers have no parameters. For example, if you select Emerg-
All-Call for Type, no parameters are applicable.

qas.question: What do the parameters appear as when viewing triggers?

qas.question: What happens when you select the trigger Type as Alarm?

qas.question: What type of information is required when selecting Normal-Zone as the Announcement Type?

qas.question: Are there any parameters for the trigger Type 911?

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Edit icon when managing triggers?

An action is an activity or task that the system performs as the result 
of a trigger launching a routine. For example, a routine that uses a 
selected tone for the trigger could have audio distribution start as the 
action.
13.11.1

To view actions for a routine:

information about the action appears (see Table 13-4,

qas.question: What are the steps to delete a trigger in the system?

answers.text: To delete a trigger in the system, select "Routines" on the navigation bar, then click the Delete icon next to the desired trigger. Confirm the deletion by selecting "Delete" when prompted.

qas.question: How many parameters can a trigger have, and how do they differ based on the trigger Type?

answers.text: A trigger can have up to two parameters, depending on the selected Type. The parameter names and available selections change based on the Type; for example, an Alarm trigger has a parameter for Alarm selection, while an Announcement trigger may have parameters for Announcement Type and Zone.

qas.question: What specific information does the parameter field display when "Alarm" is selected as the trigger Type?

answers.text: When "Alarm" is selected as the trigger Type, the parameter field displays a field called "Alarm" with a drop-down menu that shows all of the tones with Type set to Alarm on the Tones page. There are no additional parameters applicable for this trigger Type.

qas.question: What additional field appears when "Normal-Zone" is chosen as the Announcement Type?

answers.text: When "Normal-Zone" is chosen as the Announcement Type, an additional field called "Zone" appears. From this field, you can select options such as All Speakers, Any Zone, or a specific zone.

qas.question: Which trigger Type has no applicable parameters?

answers.text: The trigger Types that have no applicable parameters are 911, All-Call, Emerg-All-Call, Audio Disabled, Audio Enabled, Multi-Site-All-Call, and Multi-Site-E-All-Call. In these cases, no additional information or selections are required when setting up the trigger.

qas.question: What triggers an action when the "Incoming-Call" Type is activated?

answers.text: An action is triggered when the "Incoming-Call" Type is activated if there is an incoming call from the PSTN (from SIP or DAHDI trunks) that is received by an Admin station, requiring the call to be answered. This trigger does not activate for incoming DISA or Security DISA calls.

qas.question: What must be set to No for the Audio-Dist trigger Type?

answers.text: For the Audio-Dist trigger type, the "Use Caller’s Extension" option must be set to No. Additionally, an extension must be defined for the routine.

qas.question: How can an audio distribution trigger using a playlist be scheduled?

answers.text: To schedule an audio distribution trigger using a playlist, you must first define the playlist as an Audio Distribution selection. Then, schedule the Audio Distribution instead of the playlist itself to trigger the desired audio routine.

qas.question: What is indicated by a "Done" status in the Check-In trigger Type?

answers.text: A "Done" status in the Check-In trigger Type indicates that all expected stations have successfully checked in. It reflects the completion of the check-in process for the specified stations.

qas.question: In the context of Emergency-Call triggers, how does the selection of Callers and Called enhance functionality?

answers.text: The selection of Callers and Called in Emergency-Call triggers enhances functionality by allowing the trigger to activate when either a specified caller or a specified called party is involved in an intercom call. This flexibility ensures that the system responds promptly to emergency situations, regardless of which party initiates the call.

qas.question: What occurs during a reboot trigger and what must be disabled for it to function?

answers.text: During a reboot trigger, routines automatically execute whenever the Nyquist server reboots, intended for tasks typically started via DTMF or API calls. To function, it is required that an extension is defined and the "Use Caller’s Extension" option must be disabled.

qas.question: How can one view actions associated with a routine?

answers.text: To view actions associated with a routine, select Routines from the navigation bar, then choose Actions for the desired routine. If actions have been added, their details will be displayed, and you can also add new actions or triggers.

qas.question: What is the function of the Enabled slider for actions within a routine?

answers.text: The Enabled slider for actions within a routine allows users to activate or deactivate a specific action. Moving the slider to Yes enables the action, meaning it will be performed when the routine is triggered.

qas.question: What is the difference between Station-Status-Up and Station-Status-Down triggers?

answers.text: The Station-Status-Up trigger activates when a selected station's status indicates that it is operational again, while the Station-Status-Down trigger activates when a selected station's status indicates that it is currently non-operational. Both triggers require an extension to be defined and the Use Caller’s Extension option to be disabled.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the "Urgent-Call" trigger type in an intercom system?

answers.text: The "Urgent-Call" trigger type in an intercom system activates when an intercom call involves a specified caller or called party, allowing for immediate attention to urgent communications. This trigger enhances response times during critical situations by notifying designated stations instantly.

qas.question: What is the purpose of an action in the context of a routine?

qas.question: How can you view actions for a specific routine?

answers.text: To view actions for a specific routine, select "Routines" from the navigation bar, then choose "Actions" for the desired routine. Information about the actions will be displayed if any have been added.

qas.question: What information is displayed in the Actions table?

answers.text: The Actions table displays the name of the action and its enabled status, which can be toggled to "Yes" to enable the action. This information helps users manage the actions associated with a selected routine.

qas.question: What step allows you to enable or disable an action?

answers.text: To enable or disable an action, move the slider to "Yes" in the Actions page for the selected routine. This step allows you to toggle the action's enabled status.

qas.question: What option is available on the Actions page besides viewing actions?

answers.text: Besides viewing actions, the Actions page allows you to add a new action or select the Triggers button to add triggers for the selected routine. You can also enable or disable actions using a slider.

qas.question: What would you select to add triggers to a routine?

answers.text: To add triggers to a routine, select the Triggers button on the Actions page of the routine you are viewing. This will allow you to configure triggers for the selected routine.

qas.question: What is an action in the context of a routine?

answers.text: An action in the context of a routine is an activity or task performed by the system in response to a trigger launching the routine. Actions can include various types such as alarms, announcements, or audio distribution, and may involve configurable parameters to customize their execution.

qas.question: How can you view actions for a specific routine?

answers.text: To view actions for a specific routine, select "Routines" on the navigation bar, then choose "Actions" for the desired routine. If any actions have been added, their information will be displayed on the Actions page.

qas.question: What types of actions can be associated with a routine?

answers.text: A routine can have various types of actions, including Alarm, Announcement, Audio Distribution Start/Stop, Emergency Call, and Intercom Call, among others. Each action type can have specific parameters that may need to be set depending on the functionality required.

qas.question: How do you enable an action for a routine?

answers.text: To enable an action for a routine, navigate to Routines and select Actions for the desired routine. Move the slider next to the action's "Enabled" status to "Yes" to activate it.

qas.question: What are the parameters that can be set when adding an action?

answers.text: When adding an action, you can set up to four parameters specific to the action type required. Additionally, you can specify an execute order and whether the routine should wait for the action to complete before starting the next action.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Execute Order in the action settings?

answers.text: The Execute Order in the action settings specifies the sequence in which actions within a routine should be performed. This ensures that actions are executed in a predetermined order, which can be critical for maintaining the desired functionality and flow of the routine.

qas.question: How do you add a new action to a routine?

answers.text: To add a new action to a routine, select "Routines" on the navigation bar, then choose "Actions" for the desired routine. Click the "Add" icon, complete the required parameters for the action, and select "Save."

qas.question: What information is displayed for each action in the Actions page?

answers.text: The Actions page displays the Name of the action, whether it is Enabled (with a slider to toggle), and the Type of action (such as Alarm, Announcement, Email, etc.). Additionally, the page may show parameters specific to the action type, such as Execution Order and Finish Delay, along with a user-provided Description for the action.

qas.question: Can multiple actions be added to a single routine?

answers.text: Yes, multiple actions can be added to a single routine. When adding an action, you can set up to four parameters for each action, allowing for a variety of configurations within the routine.

qas.question: What does the Finish Delay parameter indicate in the context of actions?

answers.text: The Finish Delay parameter indicates whether the routine should wait until the specified action is completed before proceeding to the next action. This ensures that actions are executed in a specific order, allowing for proper sequencing in complex routines.

404
13.11.2
Adding an Action
One or more actions can be added to a routine. When adding an 
action, you can set up to four parameters for the action (see "Under-
standing Action Parameters” on page 406).
To add a trigger:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Routines.
Step 2
Select Actions for the routine that you want to add an 
action for.
Step 3
Select the Add icon.
The Edit Action page appears.
Step 4
Complete the parameters for the new action (see 
"Actions” on page 402).
Step 5
Select Save.
Parameter 1
Displays the first parameter for the specified 
action type if required. For example, if Rou-
tine is selected as action Type, then the 
DTMF Code for the routine appears as 
Parameter 1.
Parameter 2
Displays the second parameter for the speci-
fied action type if required. For example, if 
Routine is selected as the action Type, then 
either Local or a specific facility appears as 
Parameter 2.
Parameter 3
Displays the third parameter for the speci-
fied action type if required.
Parameter 4
Displays the fourth parameter for the speci-
fied action type if required.
Execute Order
Displays the order that the action should be 
executed.
Finish Delay
Specifies if the routine should wait until this 
action is completed before starting the next 
action.
Description
Displays the user provided description for 
the action.
Table 13-4, Actions (Continued)
405
13.11.3
Editing an Action
Editing an action allows you to change the Name from New Action 
to a more descriptive name, such as Announcement. The Edit Action 
page allows you to set other parameters for the action.
To edit an action:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Routines.
Step 2
Select Actions for the routine that you want to edit an 
action for.
Step 3
Select the Add icon.
The Edit Action page appears.
Step 4
Complete the parameters for the action (see "Actions” 
on page 402).
Step 5
Select Save.
Figure 13-6, Edit Action

qas.question: What is the maximum number of parameters that can be set for an action when adding it to a routine?

answers.text: The maximum number of parameters that can be set for an action when adding it to a routine is four. Each action can have up to four specific parameters, depending on the action type selected.

qas.question: Which action type parameter is represented by Parameter 1 if Routine is selected?

answers.text: If Routine is selected as the action type, Parameter 1 represents the DTMF Code for the routine. This parameter is required for the specified action type.

qas.question: What step must be taken first to add an action to a routine?

answers.text: To add an action to a routine, first select "Routines" from the navigation bar. Then, proceed to select "Actions" for the specific routine you want to add an action for.

qas.question: How can you edit the name of an action from the default "New Action"?

answers.text: To edit the name of an action from the default "New Action," navigate to the Routines section, select Actions for the specific routine, then click the Add icon to access the Edit Action page. From there, you can change the name to a more descriptive title and save the changes.

qas.question: What does the Finish Delay parameter specify in the context of routine actions?

answers.text: The Finish Delay parameter specifies whether the routine should wait until the current action is completed before starting the next action. This allows for controlled execution of actions within a routine.

qas.question: How is the order of action execution determined in a routine?

answers.text: The order of action execution in a routine is determined by the "Execute Order" parameter, which specifies the sequence in which the actions should be executed. Additionally, the "Finish Delay" option can indicate whether the routine should wait for the completion of the current action before starting the next one.

qas.question: What page appears when you select the Add icon to add or edit an action?

answers.text: When you select the Add icon to add or edit an action, the Edit Action page appears. This page allows you to complete the parameters for the action before saving it.

qas.question: Where can you find more information about actions related to routines?

answers.text: More information about actions related to routines can be found on page 402 of the referenced document, which outlines the details of actions and their parameters. Additionally, specific instructions for adding and editing actions are detailed in sections 13.11.2 and 13.11.3, respectively.

qas.question: What indicates a user-provided description for an action during setup?

answers.text: The user-provided description for an action during setup is displayed in the "Description" field on the Edit Action page. This allows users to provide a more meaningful name for the action instead of the default "New Action."

qas.question: What type of information is displayed in Parameter 2 if Routine is selected as the action Type?

answers.text: If Routine is selected as the action Type, Parameter 2 displays either "Local" or a specific facility. This allows the user to specify the location associated with the action.

406
13.11.4
Cloning an Action
If an action is used more than once in a routine, you might want to 
clone the action rather than create a new action. Cloning an action 
creates a duplicate of the selected action and places the duplicate at 
the end of the action list.
You can edit a cloned action if you want to change any of the param-
eters, such as duration.
To clone an action:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Routines.
Step 2
Select Actions for the routine that has the action you 
want to clone.
Step 3
Select the Clone button (
) for the action that you 
want to duplicate.
13.11.5
Understanding Action Parameters
An action can have up to four parameters, depending on the Type 
selected. 
When viewing actions, the parameters appear as Parameter 1, 
Parameter 2, Parameter 3, and Parameter 4. On the Edit Action 
page, though, the parameter names and available selections change 
based on the Type. For example, if Alarm is selected as Type, a field 
called Alarm appears with a drop-down menu that shows all of the 
tones with Type set to Alarm on the Tones page (see "Viewing Avail-
able Tones” on page 256). With this type of action, you can also set 
the Duration, which appears on the Actions page as Parameter 3. 
Parameters 2 and 4 are not used for this type of action, but you can 
set a Finish Delay, which establishes if the routine should wait until 
this action is completed before starting the next action.
Some actions have no parameters. For example, if you select All-Call 
for Type, no parameters are applicable.
The following table describes the action Type and any applicable 
parameters.

qas.question: What steps are involved in editing an action within the Station Management system?

answers.text: To edit an action within the Station Management system, select Routines from the navigation bar, then choose Actions for the desired routine. Click the Add icon to access the Edit Action page, complete the necessary parameters, and finally select Save to save your changes.

qas.question: How can you clone an action, and what happens to the duplicate?

answers.text: To clone an action, select Routines on the navigation bar, choose Actions for the desired routine, and then click the Clone button for the action you want to duplicate. The duplicate action is created and placed at the end of the action list, allowing for further editing if needed.

qas.question: What determines the number and names of action parameters when editing an action?

answers.text: The number and names of action parameters when editing an action are determined by the selected Type of action. Each Type specifies different applicable parameters, which can vary in both quantity and naming, such as Duration and Finish Delay for types like Alarm, or none for types like All-Call.

qas.question: Which action type does not have any applicable parameters?

answers.text: The action type "All-Call" does not have any applicable parameters. In this case, no additional settings are required, unlike other action types that may have specific parameters to configure.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Finish Delay parameter in an action?

answers.text: The Finish Delay parameter in an action determines whether the routine should wait for the completion of the current action before starting the next one. This allows for better control of the sequence and timing of actions within a routine.

qas.question: How can you edit a cloned action after duplicating it?

answers.text: To edit a cloned action after duplicating it, simply select the cloned action in the list and access the Edit Action page. From there, you can modify any parameters, such as duration, before saving your changes.

qas.question: What specific parameter is available when the Alarm type is selected for an action?

answers.text: When the Alarm type is selected for an action, the specific parameter available is the "Alarm" field, which features a drop-down menu displaying all tones categorized as Alarm on the Tones page. Additionally, you can set the "Duration," which is displayed as Parameter 3 on the Actions page.

qas.question: What is the purpose of cloning an action in a routine?

answers.text: Cloning an action in a routine allows you to create a duplicate of an action that is used multiple times, which saves time compared to creating a new action from scratch. The cloned action is placed at the end of the action list and can be edited to change parameters, such as duration, if necessary.

qas.question: How does one access the option to clone an action?

answers.text: To access the option to clone an action, first select "Routines" on the navigation bar. Then, select "Actions" for the routine containing the action you wish to clone and click the Clone button next to the desired action.

qas.question: What changes can be made to a cloned action after duplication?

answers.text: After cloning an action, you can edit the cloned action to change parameters such as duration. The cloned action is a duplicate and allows for adjustments without affecting the original action.

qas.question: How many parameters can an action have, and what determines this?

answers.text: An action can have up to four parameters, depending on the selected action Type. The specific parameters available change based on the Type chosen, with certain Types having no applicable parameters at all.

qas.question: Can you provide an example of a parameter related to the Alarm action type?

answers.text: An example of a parameter related to the Alarm action type is the "Alarm" field, which includes a drop-down menu that displays all tones associated with the Alarm type. Additionally, the "Duration" parameter can be set to determine how long the alarm will sound.

qas.question: What happens to Parameters 2 and 4 when the Alarm action type is selected?

answers.text: When the Alarm action type is selected, Parameters 2 and 4 are not used. However, you can still set a Finish Delay, which determines if the routine should wait for the Alarm action to complete before proceeding to the next action.

qas.question: Which action type does not have any applicable parameters?

answers.text: The All-Call action type does not have any applicable parameters. Unlike other action types that may have specific parameters, the All-Call type is not associated with any additional settings.

qas.question: What is the function of the Finish Delay in an action’s parameters?

answers.text: The Finish Delay in an action's parameters determines whether the routine should wait for the completion of the current action before initiating the next action. This allows for better control over the timing and sequence of actions within a routine.

qas.question: What is the purpose of cloning an action in a routine?

answers.text: The purpose of cloning an action in a routine is to create a duplicate of an existing action for reuse without having to create a new one, simplifying the routine setup. The cloned action is placed at the end of the action list, and it can be edited to adjust parameters as needed.

qas.question: How can you edit a cloned action after cloning it?

answers.text: After cloning an action, you can edit it by accessing the action in the action list and modifying any of the parameters, such as duration, as needed. This allows you to customize the cloned action while keeping the original unchanged.

qas.question: What are the maximum number of parameters an action can have based on its type?

answers.text: An action can have up to four parameters, depending on the selected action type. However, some action types may utilize none or only a subset of these parameters, as seen with examples like Alarm, All-Call, and Check-In.

qas.question: What type of action parameters can be set for an Alarm action?

answers.text: For an Alarm action, the parameters that can be set are Parameter 1, which is the selected alarm tone, and Parameter 3, which is the Duration (the number of seconds for the action to continue, with a default of 86400 seconds or 24 hours). Additionally, a Finish Delay can be set to either No-Delay or Wait-Until-Done.

qas.question: What happens if you select All-Call as an action type in a routine?

answers.text: If you select All-Call as an action type in a routine, it must be the last action in the routine, and there are no applicable parameters for this action. Additionally, you can set a Finish Delay, either as No-Delay or Wait-Until-Done, which determines if the routine should wait until this action is completed before proceeding.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Finish Delay in action parameters?

answers.text: The Finish Delay in action parameters determines whether the routine should wait for the selected action to be completed before proceeding to the next action. It can be set to either No-Delay, allowing the routine to continue immediately, or Wait-Until-Done, which ensures that subsequent actions do not start until the current action finishes.

qas.question: In a Call-And-Announce action, what options are available for the Number to Call?

answers.text: In a Call-And-Announce action, the options available for the Number to Call include: 911, a station extension, a local 7-digit phone number prefixed with 98, a local 10-digit phone number prefixed with 98, and a long-distance 10-digit phone number prefixed with 981. If the specified number is not a station extension, at least one outgoing SIP trunk or Outside Line DAHDI port must be available.

qas.question: What is required for sending an Email action to a cellphone?

answers.text: To send an Email action to a cellphone, the cellular server provider must convert the email message to text. You need to enter the recipient's phone number in the specific email format for their carrier, such as <phone number>@txt.att.net for AT&T.

qas.question: How is the Duration parameter utilized in various action types?

answers.text: The Duration parameter specifies the number of seconds an action will continue before it stops. It is applicable to action types such as Alarm, Announcement, Audio Distribution Start/Stop, and others, with a default duration of 86400 seconds (24 hours) if not specified. For some actions, like Announcement, if the duration is reached, the announcement will stop regardless of its length.

qas.question: What should you consider when creating a routine involving multiple actions?

answers.text: When creating a routine involving multiple actions, you should consider the sequence in which actions are executed and how each action impacts subsequent actions. For example, ensure that an announcement follows an alarm appropriately, and account for any Finish Delays that may affect timing. Additionally, be mindful of any action type restrictions, such as certain actions needing to be the last in the routine.

qas.question: Which action type must always be the last action in a routine?

answers.text: The action types that must always be the last action in a routine include All-Call, Emergency-Call, Facility-Page, Multi-Site-All-Call, and Multi-Site-E-All-Call. These actions require the routine to conclude with them to ensure proper functionality.

qas.question: What does the Display-Msg action facilitate in a routine?

answers.text: The Display-Msg action facilitates the creation of routines for displaying emergency alerts or messages on selected zones or displays, including setting parameters like display time, priority, and message styles. It allows for variable usage, enabling dynamic messages based on call triggers or system events.

qas.question: What is the function of the Feature-Wait action in a routine?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action in a routine allows the routine to pause until a specified feature, such as 911 or an announcement, is completed. It can be set with a maximum wait time, where a value of 0 indicates to wait indefinitely until the feature finishes, ensuring the routine proceeds only when the action is complete.

qas.question: How can you specify a timeout for the Play-Ringtone action?

answers.text: To specify a timeout for the Play-Ringtone action, set the "Timeout (Seconds)" parameter. Leaving this parameter blank or setting it to 0 means there will be no timeout for the ringtone action.

qas.question: What is the use of variables like $caller in Display Messages?

answers.text: Variables like $caller in Display Messages are used to dynamically insert specific information into the displayed text, such as the ID or phone number of the caller triggering the routine. This allows for personalized and situation-specific messages to be created, enhancing the relevance and clarity of the displayed alerts or announcements.

qas.question: What is the correct format for sending a text message to an AT&T number using email?

answers.text: The correct format for sending a text message to an AT&T number using email is <phone number>@txt.att.net. Replace "<phone number>" with the actual 10-digit mobile phone number.

qas.question: What action type is used to send both email and text messages in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The action type used to send both email and text messages in the Nyquist system is the Email action Type. It allows for sending situation-specific messages to an email address and converts the email to text via the cellular server provider for cellphones.

qas.question: How does a cellular server provider facilitate the process of sending text messages via email?

answers.text: A cellular server provider facilitates the process of sending text messages via email by converting the email message into a text message format. This conversion occurs when the email is sent to a specific address format associated with the recipient's phone number and carrier, enabling the delivery of the message to the recipient's cellphone.

qas.question: What is important to consider when creating a routine involving multiple actions?

answers.text: When creating a routine involving multiple actions, it’s important to consider how one action impacts the others, ensuring that actions are sequenced appropriately. For example, if an announcement follows an alarm, the announcement must be the last action in the routine to avoid conflicts. Additionally, be aware that dashboard messages created during the routine will be deleted if the user disconnects the call.

qas.question: What is the condition for a Zone-Page announcement to be the last action in a routine?

answers.text: The condition for a Zone-Page announcement to be the last action in a routine is that it must follow all other actions in the routine. Additionally, any dashboard messages created during the routine will be deleted when the user disconnects the call.

qas.question: Which cellular carrier uses the format <phone number>@txt.att.net for sending text messages?

answers.text: The cellular carrier that uses the format <phone number>@txt.att.net for sending text messages is AT&T. This format allows email messages to be converted into text messages for AT&T cellphones.

qas.question: Can you provide the format for sending a text message to a Verizon phone number?

answers.text: To send a text message to a Verizon phone number, use the format `<phone number>@vtext.com` or `<phone number>@vzwpix.com`. Both formats will allow the email message to be converted to a text message by the cellular server provider.

qas.question: What happens to dashboard messages created during a routine when the user disconnects the call?

answers.text: When the user disconnects the call during a routine, any dashboard messages created during that routine will be deleted. It is important to ensure that the actions in the routine are planned accordingly, especially if announcements or messages are intended to be retained.

qas.question: What is the email format for sending a text message to a T-Mobile user?

answers.text: The email format for sending a text message to a T-Mobile user is <phone number>@tmomail.net. This format allows the cellular server provider to convert the email message into a text message.

qas.question: Are there different formats for sending messages to Verizon, and if so, what are they?

answers.text: Yes, there are two formats for sending messages to Verizon: you can use either <phone number>@vtext.com for standard text messages or <phone number>@vzwpix.com for picture messages.

qas.question: How can the selected zone be specified when using the Email action type?

answers.text: The selected zone can be specified when using the Email action type by ensuring that the "Zone" parameter is set to the desired zone in the action settings. This allows the Email action to be linked to a specific zone within the Nyquist system for announcements or alerts.

13.11.7.1 Check-Intercom, Intercom-Wait, Ring-Wait Action 
Types
If a routine’s trigger Type is Intercom-Call, the routine’s action Type 
could be Check-Intercom, Intercom-Wait, or Ring-Wait. Each of 
these action types depend on the status of the Callers – parameter 1 
for the trigger (see "Understanding Trigger Parameters” on page 395).
The Check-Intercom action Type checks to see if the trigger caller is 
on an active intercom call. If the trigger caller is on an active intercom 
call, the routine executes subsequent actions. If the trigger caller is 
not on an active intercom call, the routine terminates and remaining 
actions will not be executed. You may want a routine to execute a 
Check-Intercom action Type before executing Intercom-Wait to 
ensure that the trigger caller is on an active intercom call.
The Intercom-Wait action Type waits for the trigger caller’s call to 
finish. After the call finishes, the routine executes subsequent actions. 
If the call finishes before Intercom-Wait action Type is executed, the 
routine executes subsequent actions without delay.
The Ring-Wait action Type waits for the trigger caller’s ringing to 
finish. After the ringing stage of a call ends, the routine executes sub-
sequent actions. If the call is answered before the Ring-Wait action 
Type executes, the routine executes subsequent actions without 
delay.
A sample scenario using these three actions is a routine that is exe-
cuted by the Intercom-Call trigger Type. The routine contains actions 
to be performed to indicate a ringing call The routine waits for the 
ring to finish (Ring-Wait action Type). When the ring finishes, the rou-
tine executes additional actions and then checks to see if the call was 
answered (Check-Intercom action Type). If the call was not answered 
(no active intercom call), the routine terminates. Otherwise, it exe-
cutes additional actions before waiting for the call to finish (Inter-
com-Wait action Type), and then when the call is finished, the routine 
executes the remaining actions.

qas.question: What is the purpose of using the Email action Type in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Email action Type in the Nyquist system is used to send situation-specific messages to an email address outside the system and to send text messages to cellphones via cellular server providers. The text messages are delivered by converting the email into a format readable by the recipient's cellphone.

qas.question: How does a cellular server provider handle email messages sent as text messages?

answers.text: A cellular server provider converts email messages sent to specific formats into text messages for delivery to cellphones. Each carrier has a designated email format that forwards the message to the recipient's phone as an SMS.

qas.question: What format should be used for sending text messages to AT&T cellphones?

answers.text: To send text messages to AT&T cellphones, use the format: `<phone number>@txt.att.net`. This format allows the email to be converted into a text message by the cellular server provider.

qas.question: Why is it important to consider actions' impacts on other actions in a routine?

answers.text: It is crucial to consider actions' impacts on other actions in a routine to ensure that each action occurs in the correct sequence and timing, thereby preventing interruptions or missed messages. For instance, an announcement must follow an alarm only after the alarm has ended to ensure it is heard clearly.

qas.question: What must an announcement action do relative to an alarm action in a routine?

answers.text: An announcement action must be the last action in a routine if it follows an alarm action to ensure the alarm ends before the announcement begins. If not timed correctly, the announcement may not be heard if the alarm is still ongoing.

qas.question: What does the Check-Intercom action Type do in a routine?

answers.text: The Check-Intercom action Type checks if the trigger caller is currently on an active intercom call. If the caller is active, the routine continues to execute subsequent actions; if not, the routine terminates, and no further actions are executed.

qas.question: When does the Intercom-Wait action Type execute subsequent actions?

answers.text: The Intercom-Wait action Type executes subsequent actions after the trigger caller's intercom call finishes. If the call ends before the Intercom-Wait action Type is executed, the routine proceeds with subsequent actions without delay.

qas.question: What is the function of the Ring-Wait action Type in a call routine?

answers.text: The Ring-Wait action Type in a call routine pauses execution until the ringing stage of a call finishes. After the ring ends, the routine proceeds to execute subsequent actions, unless the call is answered before the Ring-Wait action executes, in which case the routine continues without delay.

qas.question: How can a routine be structured using Check-Intercom, Intercom-Wait, and Ring-Wait actions?

answers.text: A routine using Check-Intercom, Intercom-Wait, and Ring-Wait actions can be structured by first implementing a Ring-Wait action to wait for the ringing call to finish. After the ring ends, a Check-Intercom action verifies if the call was answered; if not, the routine terminates. If the call was answered, the Intercom-Wait action is executed to wait for the call to finish before executing any remaining actions.

qas.question: What happens if the call is answered before the Ring-Wait action Type is executed?

answers.text: If the call is answered before the Ring-Wait action Type is executed, the routine will execute subsequent actions without any delay. This means that the routine does not wait for the ringing to finish since the call has already been answered.

13.11.7.2 Check-In Action Type with Check In Set to Wait
When the routine includes a Check-In action Type and Check-In 
(parameter 1) is Wait, the routine pauses the execution of subse-
quent actions until the Check-in process is no longer active. When 
the Check-In process is Finished or you select Stop, Finish, or Reset, 
the routine resumes executing actions that follow a finished Check-In 
process such as: announcing Check-In completed to Admin Station 
speakers or displaying Check-in completion messages on web inter-
face dashboards or GA10PV displays. 
Check-In action Type with Check-In set to Wait does not differenti-
ate between the Check-in process moving to the Finished state or 
having been manually stopped or finished.
For more information about the Check-In process, see "Manage 
Check-In” on page 409.
13.11.7.3 Feature-Wait Action Type with 911
You may want to include the Feature-Wait action Type in a routine 
that is triggered by a 911 call to pause subsequent actions until the 
911 call ends. In this scenario, set Feature Wait (parameter 1 of the 
Feature-Wait action Type) to 911.
After the 911 call ends, the routine executes subsequent actions. The 
911 trigger Type can execute routines when any caller dials 911, so 
multiple routines (one for each active 911 call) could execute.
Note: The check and wait actions described in this section are 
always related to the caller that triggered the routine. The routine 
settings for Extension and Use Caller's Extension are not related 
to these wait actions; the check and wait actions will always be 
evaluated based on the trigger caller regardless of the routine's 
Extension or User Caller's Extension settings.
Note: If you want to execute routine Actions after all stations have 
checked in (Check-In status is Done), create a routine with trigger 
Type set to Check-In and Parameter 1 set to Done.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Check-Intercom action type?

answers.text: The Check-Intercom action type checks if the trigger caller is on an active intercom call. If the caller is active, the routine executes subsequent actions; if not, the routine terminates without performing any further actions.

qas.question: How does the Intercom-Wait action type function after an intercom call?

answers.text: The Intercom-Wait action type pauses the routine until the trigger caller's intercom call concludes. If the call finishes before the Intercom-Wait action is executed, the routine proceeds with subsequent actions without delay.

qas.question: What occurs if a call is answered before the Ring-Wait action type executes?

answers.text: If a call is answered before the Ring-Wait action type executes, the routine proceeds to execute subsequent actions without any delay. The Ring-Wait action does not hold up the execution of remaining actions in this scenario.

qas.question: How does the routine handle Check-In action types set to Wait?

answers.text: When the Check-In action Type is set to Wait, the routine pauses the execution of subsequent actions until the Check-In process is no longer active. Once the Check-In process is finished or manually stopped, the routine resumes and executes the following actions, such as announcing Check-In completion or displaying messages.

qas.question: What does the Feature-Wait action type do when triggered by a 911 call?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type, when triggered by a 911 call, pauses subsequent actions in the routine until the 911 call ends. After the call concludes, the routine proceeds to execute the following actions.

qas.question: How do check and wait actions relate to the trigger caller in a routine?

answers.text: Check and wait actions in a routine are directly related to the trigger caller, meaning they evaluate the status of the call or process associated with that specific caller. The execution of subsequent actions depends on whether the trigger caller is actively engaged in a call or process, regardless of the routine's broader settings for Extensions or User Caller's Extension.

qas.question: What should be configured if you want a routine to execute actions after all stations have completed their check-in?

answers.text: To execute actions after all stations have completed their check-in, configure a routine with the trigger Type set to Check-In and Parameter 1 set to Done. This ensures that the actions will only execute once the Check-In status is marked as Done for all stations.

qas.question: What happens if the trigger caller is not on an active intercom call while using the Check-Intercom action?

answers.text: If the trigger caller is not on an active intercom call while using the Check-Intercom action, the routine terminates, and the remaining actions will not be executed. This ensures that subsequent actions only proceed if the caller is actively engaged in an intercom call.

Extension or User Caller's Extension settings.
Note: If you want to execute routine Actions after all stations have 
checked in (Check-In status is Done), create a routine with trigger 
Type set to Check-In and Parameter 1 set to Done.

qas.question: What happens to the execution of subsequent actions when a Check-In action with the parameter set to Wait is used?

answers.text: When a Check-In action with the parameter set to Wait is used, the routine pauses the execution of subsequent actions until the Check-In process is no longer active, meaning it either completes or is manually stopped. Once the Check-In process is finished, the routine resumes executing the following actions, such as announcements or displaying messages.

qas.question: How does the routine respond after the Check-In process is finished or manually stopped?

answers.text: After the Check-In process is finished or manually stopped, the routine resumes executing subsequent actions, which may include announcing Check-In completion to Admin Station speakers or displaying completion messages on web interface dashboards or GA10PV displays. The routine does not differentiate between the Check-In process being finished or having been manually stopped.

qas.question: What is the purpose of using the Feature-Wait action Type with 911 in a routine?

answers.text: The purpose of using the Feature-Wait action Type with 911 in a routine is to pause subsequent actions until the 911 call ends. This allows for immediate responses or changes in the system based on the urgency of a 911 call, ensuring that no other actions are executed until the emergency call is completed.

qas.question: How does the routine evaluate wait actions in relation to the caller that triggered it?

answers.text: The routine evaluates wait actions based solely on the caller that triggered it, meaning the check and wait actions are aligned with the specific trigger caller regardless of the routine's Extension or Use Caller's Extension settings. This ensures that actions are paused or resumed in relation to the originating call, independent of any other settings.

qas.question: What trigger Type and Parameter 1 setting should be used to execute routine actions after all stations have checked in?

answers.text: To execute routine actions after all stations have checked in, use the trigger Type set to Check-In and set Parameter 1 to Done. This configuration ensures that actions will only execute once the Check-In status for all stations is complete.

qas.question: Does the Check-In action Type differentiate between the finished state and manual stopping of the Check-In process?

answers.text: No, the Check-In action Type does not differentiate between the Check-In process moving to the Finished state and being manually stopped or finished. The routine resumes execution of subsequent actions irrespective of how the Check-In process was concluded.

qas.question: Can multiple routines be executed in response to several active 911 calls?

answers.text: Yes, multiple routines can be executed in response to several active 911 calls, as the 911 trigger Type can initiate routines for each caller who dials 911. Each active 911 call can trigger its own set of actions independently.

qas.question: What actions does the routine perform after the 911 call ends?

answers.text: After the 911 call ends, the routine executes subsequent actions that were paused during the call. These actions are triggered by the Feature-Wait action Type set to 911, ensuring that any responses or notifications related to the incident can proceed once the call is completed.

13.11.7.2 Check-In Action Type with Check In Set to Wait
When the routine includes a Check-In action Type and Check-In 
(parameter 1) is Wait, the routine pauses the execution of subse-
quent actions until the Check-in process is no longer active. When 
the Check-In process is Finished or you select Stop, Finish, or Reset, 
the routine resumes executing actions that follow a finished Check-In 
process such as: announcing Check-In completed to Admin Station 
speakers or displaying Check-in completion messages on web inter-
face dashboards or GA10PV displays. 
Check-In action Type with Check-In set to Wait does not differenti-
ate between the Check-in process moving to the Finished state or 
having been manually stopped or finished.
For more information about the Check-In process, see "Manage 
Check-In” on page 409.
13.11.7.3 Feature-Wait Action Type with 911
You may want to include the Feature-Wait action Type in a routine 
that is triggered by a 911 call to pause subsequent actions until the 
911 call ends. In this scenario, set Feature Wait (parameter 1 of the 
Feature-Wait action Type) to 911.
After the 911 call ends, the routine executes subsequent actions. The 
911 trigger Type can execute routines when any caller dials 911, so 
multiple routines (one for each active 911 call) could execute.
Note: The check and wait actions described in this section are 
always related to the caller that triggered the routine. The routine 
settings for Extension and Use Caller's Extension are not related 
to these wait actions; the check and wait actions will always be 
evaluated based on the trigger caller regardless of the routine's 
Extension or User Caller's Extension settings.
Note: If you want to execute routine Actions after all stations have 
checked in (Check-In status is Done), create a routine with trigger 
Type set to Check-In and Parameter 1 set to Done.

13.11.7.4 Feature-Wait Action Type with Alarm
If you want to pause subsequent routine actions until the alarm fin-
ishes playing, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait 
(parameter 1) set to Alarm. If no alarm is playing when the Feature 
Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for an alarm. Instead, 
it continues executing subsequent actions.
If you want to ensure that the routine includes an active alarm, use 
Alarm as the trigger Type (see "Understanding Trigger Parameters” 
on page 395).
If you do not need the routine to wait until the alarm finishes, you can 
still use Feature-Wait as the action Type and Alarm as Feature Wait 
and set Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2) to the desired 
amount of time to wait.
13.11.7.5 Feature-Wait Action Type with Announcement
If you want all active Normal and Emergency announcements to 
complete before continue with subsequent routine actions, use the 
Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) set to 
Announcement.
This action will not allow you to specify which announcement type or 
which announcement to wait for. The Announcement trigger Type 
does allow you to specify an announcement type or number (see 
"Understanding Trigger Parameters” on page 395). However, if the 
routine uses Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait set to 
Announcement and multiple announcements start, then the routine 
will pause until all announcements have completed.
13.11.7.6 Feature-Wait Action Type with All-Call
If you want a routine to pause until an active All-Call page completes, 
use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) 
set to All-Call.
If no All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, 
the routine does not wait for an All-Call page. Instead, it continues 
executing subsequent actions.
If you want to ensure that the routine includes an All-Call page, use 
All-Call as the trigger Type.

you can still use Feature-Wait as the action Type and All-Call as

qas.question: What happens when the Check-In action Type is set to Wait in a routine?

answers.text: When the Check-In action Type is set to Wait in a routine, subsequent actions are paused until the Check-In process is no longer active. The routine resumes execution only after the Check-In is finished or manually stopped, and this does not differentiate between the two states.

qas.question: How does the Feature-Wait action type function when triggered by a 911 call?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type, when set to 911, pauses subsequent actions until the 911 call ends. This allows multiple routines to execute for each active 911 call, ensuring that the routine will evaluate based on the caller that triggered it, regardless of other routine settings.

qas.question: In what scenario would you use the Feature-Wait action type with the Alarm parameter?

answers.text: You would use the Feature-Wait action type with the Alarm parameter to pause subsequent routine actions until an active alarm finishes playing. If no alarm is playing when this action executes, the routine will continue without waiting for an alarm. This is useful for ensuring that critical announcement or response actions only occur after an alarm has completed.

qas.question: What is the outcome when multiple announcements are active and the Feature-Wait action type is set to Announcement?

answers.text: When multiple announcements are active and the Feature-Wait action type is set to Announcement, the routine will pause execution until all active announcements have completed. This action does not allow for the specification of which announcement type to wait for; it simply waits for all to finish.

qas.question: How does the routine behave if no All-Call page is playing when the Feature-Wait action executes?

answers.text: If no All-Call page is playing when the Feature-Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for an All-Call page and continues executing subsequent actions immediately. To ensure the routine involves an All-Call page, it must be set as the trigger Type.

qas.question: What trigger Type should be used to ensure that a routine includes an active alarm?

answers.text: To ensure that a routine includes an active alarm, you should use Alarm as the trigger Type. This will activate the routine when an alarm is playing, allowing for subsequent actions to be paused until the alarm finishes, as specified by the Feature-Wait action Type.

qas.question: Can the Feature-Wait action type with Announcement differentiate between types of announcements?

answers.text: No, the Feature-Wait action type with Announcement cannot differentiate between types of announcements. It will pause the routine until all active Normal and Emergency announcements are completed, without specifying which announcement type to wait for.

qas.question: What parameter setting can you use with Feature-Wait to limit the wait time for alarms?

answers.text: To limit the wait time for alarms using the Feature-Wait action type, set the Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2) to the desired amount of time. This allows the routine to continue executing subsequent actions after the specified wait time, even if the alarm has not finished playing.

qas.question: How does the routine's behavior change based on the Check-In status of the caller that triggered it?

answers.text: The routine's behavior is contingent on the Check-In status of the caller that triggered it. If the Check-In action type is set to Wait, it will pause subsequent actions until the Check-In process is either finished or manually stopped, without differentiating between those two states. For routines triggered by Check-In, setting Parameter 1 to Done allows actions to execute only after all stations have checked in successfully.

qas.question: What is the significance of the Maximum Wait Time in the context of Feature-Wait actions?

answers.text: The Maximum Wait Time parameter in Feature-Wait actions specifies the duration the routine will wait for a certain condition, such as an alarm or announcement, before executing subsequent actions. If the specified time elapses without the condition being met, the routine will continue executing subsequent actions regardless of whether the condition has finished. This allows for greater control over routine execution in scenarios where waiting indefinitely is not desired.

qas.question: What action type should be used to pause routine actions until an alarm finishes playing?

qas.question: How does the routine behave if no alarm is playing when the Feature-Wait action is executed?

answers.text: If no alarm is playing when the Feature-Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for an alarm and continues executing subsequent actions. To ensure an active alarm is included, the trigger Type should be set to Alarm.

qas.question: What trigger type should be used to ensure the routine includes an active alarm?

qas.question: How can you configure the routine to wait for a specified amount of time even if an alarm is not currently active?

answers.text: To configure the routine to wait for a specified amount of time even if an alarm is not currently active, use the Feature-Wait action Type and set Feature Wait (parameter 1) to Alarm. Then, set Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2) to your desired wait duration.

qas.question: What action type is used to ensure all announcements are completed before proceeding with subsequent actions?

answers.text: To ensure all active Normal and Emergency announcements are completed before proceeding with subsequent actions, use the Feature-Wait action type with Feature Wait set to Announcement. This will pause the routine until all announcements have been completed.

qas.question: Can you specify which announcement type to wait for when using the Feature-Wait action type with announcements?

qas.question: What happens if multiple announcements start while using the Feature-Wait action type set to Announcement?

answers.text: If multiple announcements start while using the Feature-Wait action type set to Announcement, the routine will pause until all active Normal and Emergency announcements have completed. The routine does not allow for specifying which announcement type or number to wait for, enforcing a wait for all.

qas.question: How does the Feature-Wait action type behave with All-Call pages in terms of routine execution?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type with Feature Wait set to All-Call pauses the routine until an active All-Call page completes. If no All-Call page is playing when the action executes, the routine continues executing subsequent actions without waiting.

qas.question: What trigger type ensures the routine includes an active All-Call page?

answers.text: The trigger type that ensures the routine includes an active All-Call page is "All-Call." This trigger will activate the routine only if there is an active All-Call page playing.

qas.question: If the routine does not need to wait for an All-Call page to finish, how can this be configured?

answers.text: To configure the routine so that it does not wait for an All-Call page to finish, use the Feature-Wait action Type and set Feature Wait (parameter 1) to All-Call. Additionally, set the Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2) to the desired amount of time to allow for waiting if needed.

qas.question: Which trigger type should you use to ensure the routine includes an Emergency All-Call page?

qas.question: What happens if no Emergency-All-Call page is active when executing the Feature Wait action?

answers.text: If no Emergency-All-Call page is active when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for an Emergency-All-Call page to play and continues executing subsequent actions.

qas.question: What parameter should be set to determine the maximum wait time for a Feature-Wait action?

answers.text: The maximum wait time for a Feature-Wait action should be set using action parameter 2, designated as Maximum Wait Time. This allows you to specify the desired amount of time to wait for the action before proceeding with subsequent tasks.

qas.question: In which scenario can the Feature-Wait action type with Facility-Page be applied?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type with Facility-Page can be applied in a routine that is specifically triggered by a facility page. It pauses subsequent actions until the facility page completes; if no facility page is playing, the routine continues without waiting.

qas.question: What occurs if no facility page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes?

answers.text: If no facility page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a facility page to play. Instead, it continues executing subsequent actions immediately. Only routines triggered by a facility page can use this action.

qas.question: Can a routine use the Feature-Wait action for types other than Facility Page?

answers.text: No, a routine can only use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait set to Facility-Page if it has the trigger Type set to Facility Page. However, it can also use Feature-Wait for other types like Disable-Audio and Emerg-All-Call under their specific conditions.

qas.question: What is the implication of setting the Maximum Wait Time during a Feature-Wait action?

answers.text: Setting the Maximum Wait Time during a Feature-Wait action specifies the maximum duration the routine will pause for the designated event (such as Disabling Audio, Emergency All-Call, or Facility Page) before proceeding to execute subsequent actions. If the specified event does not occur within that time frame, the routine continues execution regardless of whether the condition has been met.

qas.question: How does the routine's execution proceed if the Feature Wait action is not triggered by an active page?

answers.text: If the Feature Wait action is not triggered by an active page, the routine continues executing subsequent actions without pausing. This applies whether the action is related to Disable-Audio, Emerg-All-Call, or Facility-Page.
