13.11.7.7 Feature-Wait Action Type with Disable-Audio
If you want a routine to pause until audio is re-enabled, use the Fea-
ture-Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) set to Dis-
able-Audio. 
If audio is enabled when the Feature Wait action executes, the rou-
tine does not wait for audio to be disabled. Instead, it continues exe-
cuting subsequent actions.
13.11.7.8 Feature-Wait Action Type with Emerg-All-Call
If you want a routine to pause until an active Emergency All-Call page 
completes, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait 
(parameter 1) set to Emerg-All-Call.
If no Emergency-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait 
action executes, the routine does not wait for an Emergency-All-Call 
page. Instead, it continues executing subsequent actions.
If you want to ensure that the routine includes an Emergency-All-Call 
page, use Emerg-All-Call as the trigger Type.
If you do not need the routine to wait until the Emergency-All-Call 
page finishes, you can still use Feature-Wait as the action Type and 
Emerg-All-Call as Feature Wait and set Maximum Wait Time 
(action parameter 2) to the desired amount of time to wait.
13.11.7.9 Feature-Wait Action Type with Facility-Page
You can use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait 
(parameter 1) set to Facility-Page in a routine that is triggered by a 
facility page. The routine will pause subsequent actions until the facil-
ity page completes. If no facility page is playing when the Feature 
Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a facility page. 
Instead, it continues executing subsequent actions.
If you do not need the routine to wait until the facility page finishes, 
you can still use Feature-Wait as the action Type and Facility Page 
as Feature Wait and set Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2) 
to the desired amount of time to wait.
Note: Only routines with the trigger Type set to Facility Page can 
use this action.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Feature-Wait action Type when set to Disable-Audio?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action Type set to Disable-Audio pauses the routine execution until audio is re-enabled. If audio is already enabled when this action executes, the routine continues without waiting.

qas.question: How does the routine behave if audio is enabled during the execution of a Feature-Wait action with Disable-Audio?

answers.text: If audio is enabled during the execution of a Feature-Wait action with Disable-Audio, the routine does not wait for audio to be disabled and continues executing subsequent actions immediately.

qas.question: What does the Feature-Wait action Type do when configured to wait for an Emerg-All-Call?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action Type configured to wait for an Emerg-All-Call pauses the routine until an active Emergency All-Call page completes. If no Emergency All-Call page is playing when the action executes, the routine continues executing subsequent actions without waiting.

qas.question: How can you ensure that an Emergency All-Call page is included in the routine?

answers.text: To ensure that an Emergency All-Call page is included in the routine, use Emerg-All-Call as the trigger Type for the routine. This guarantees that the routine will include the Emergency All-Call page when it executes.

qas.question: What happens if no Emergency-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes?

answers.text: If no Emergency-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for an Emergency-All-Call page. Instead, it continues executing subsequent actions.

qas.question: How can you set a maximum wait time for a Feature-Wait action related to Emerg-All-Call?

answers.text: To set a maximum wait time for a Feature-Wait action related to Emerg-All-Call, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait parameter 1 set to Emerg-All-Call and specify the desired time in action parameter 2, Maximum Wait Time. This allows the routine to wait for the defined amount of time if there is no active Emergency All-Call page.

qas.question: In what scenario can you use Feature-Wait with Facility-Page?

answers.text: You can use Feature-Wait with Facility-Page in a routine that is triggered by a facility page to pause subsequent actions until the facility page completes. If no facility page is playing when the Feature-Wait action executes, the routine continues executing without waiting. Only routines with the trigger Type set to Facility Page can utilize this action.

qas.question: What is required for a routine using Feature-Wait with Facility-Page to pause correctly?

answers.text: For a routine using Feature-Wait with Facility-Page to pause correctly, the routine must be triggered by a facility page. Additionally, the Feature Wait (parameter 1) must be set to Facility-Page, allowing subsequent actions to pause until the facility page completes.

qas.question: How does the routine proceed if no facility page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes?

answers.text: If no facility page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a facility page to complete and continues executing subsequent actions. This behavior applies only to routines triggered by a facility page.

qas.question: What action parameter needs to be specified to set a maximum wait time for Facility-Page?

answers.text: To set a maximum wait time for Facility-Page, specify the Maximum Wait Time as action parameter 2 when using the Feature-Wait action Type with Facility-Page as Feature Wait. This allows the routine to continue executing subsequent actions after the specified wait time elapses if no facility page is currently playing.

13.11.7.10 Feature-Wait Action Type with Multi-Site-All-Call
If you want a routine to pause until a Multi-Site-All-Call page com-
pletes, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait (param-
eter 1) set to Multi-Site-All-Call.
If no Multi-Site-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait 
action executes, the routine does not wait for a Multi-Site-All-Call 
page. Instead, it continues executing subsequent actions.
If you want to ensure that the routine includes a Multi-Site-All-Call 
page, use Multi-Site-All-Call as the trigger Type.
This action will only wait on a Nyquist system that starts the Multi-
Site-All-Call. Remote sites that are included in a Multi-Site-All-Call 
only see a playing All-Call; they do not see it as a Multi-Site call. In 
this case, this action will have no affect.
If you do not need the routine to wait until the Multi-Site-All-Call 
page finishes, you can still use Feature-Wait as the action Type and 
Multi-Site-All-Call as Feature Wait and set Maximum Wait Time 
(action parameter 2) to the desired amount of time to wait.
13.11.7.11 Feature-Wait Action Type with Multi-Site-E-All-Call
If you want a routine to pause until a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call 
page completes, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature 
Wait (parameter 1) set to Multi-Site-E-All-Call.
If no Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page is playing when the Feature 
Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a Multi-Site Emer-
gency All-Call page. Instead, it continues executing subsequent 
actions.
If you want to ensure that the routine includes a Multi-Site Emer-
gency All-Call page, use Multi-Site-E-All-Call as the trigger Type.
This action will only wait on a Nyquist system that starts the Multi-
Site Emergency All-Call. Remote sites that are included in a Multi-Site 
Emergency All-Call only see a playing Emergency-All-Call; they do 
not see it as a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call. In this case, this action 
will have no affect.
If you do not need the routine to wait until the Multi-Site-Emer-
gency-All-Call page finishes, you can still use Feature-Wait as the 
action Type and Multi-Site-E-All-Call as Feature Wait and set Max-
imum Wait Time (action parameter 2) to the desired amount of time 
to wait.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Feature-Wait action type with Disable-Audio?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type with Disable-Audio is used to pause a routine until audio is re-enabled. If audio is already enabled when this action executes, the routine will not wait and will continue with subsequent actions.

qas.question: How does the routine behave if audio is enabled when the Feature Wait action executes?

answers.text: If audio is enabled when the Feature Wait action executes with the Disable-Audio parameter, the routine does not wait for audio to be disabled and continues executing subsequent actions.

qas.question: What should be set to ensure a routine pauses until an Emergency All-Call page completes?

answers.text: To ensure a routine pauses until an Emergency All-Call page completes, set the Feature Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) to Emerg-All-Call. Additionally, if you want to ensure the routine includes the Emergency-All-Call page, use Emerg-All-Call as the trigger Type.

qas.question: What happens if no Emergency-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes?

answers.text: If no Emergency-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for an Emergency-All-Call page and continues executing subsequent actions.

qas.question: How can you include a Facility-Page in a routine that uses the Feature-Wait action type?

answers.text: To include a Facility-Page in a routine using the Feature-Wait action type, set the Feature Wait (parameter 1) to Facility-Page. The routine will pause subsequent actions until the facility page completes; if no facility page is playing, it will continue executing without waiting. Only routines triggered by a Facility Page can use this action.

qas.question: What is the result of using Multi-Site-All-Call as the Feature Wait if there is no Multi-Site-All-Call page playing?

answers.text: If there is no Multi-Site-All-Call page playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine will not wait for a Multi-Site-All-Call page and will instead continue executing subsequent actions. This behavior is specific to the Nyquist system that initiates the Multi-Site-All-Call; remote sites only recognize it as a playing All-Call.

qas.question: What should be done to ensure a routine includes a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page?

answers.text: To ensure a routine includes a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page, use Multi-Site-E-All-Call as the trigger Type. This will guarantee that the routine waits for the Multi-Site Emergency All-Call to complete if it is active.

qas.question: How does the action function for a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call in remote sites?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action for a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call will only pause on a Nyquist system that initiates the call. Remote sites included in the Multi-Site Emergency All-Call will only receive the notification as a standard Emergency All-Call and will not recognize it as a Multi-Site call, rendering the Feature-Wait action ineffective at those locations.

qas.question: What action parameter can be adjusted to control the maximum wait time for feature waits?

answers.text: The action parameter that can be adjusted to control the maximum wait time for feature waits is the Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2). This parameter allows you to set the desired amount of time to wait before proceeding with subsequent actions.

qas.question: What action type should be used to pause a routine until a Multi-Site-All-Call completes?

answers.text: To pause a routine until a Multi-Site-All-Call completes, use the Feature-Wait action type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) set to Multi-Site-All-Call. If a Multi-Site-All-Call is not currently playing when the action executes, the routine will continue without waiting.

qas.question: What happens if no Multi-Site-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes?

answers.text: If no Multi-Site-All-Call page is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a Multi-Site-All-Call page and continues executing subsequent actions. The action only waits if a Multi-Site-All-Call page is actively playing at that moment.

qas.question: How can you ensure that a routine includes a Multi-Site-All-Call page?

answers.text: To ensure that a routine includes a Multi-Site-All-Call page, use Multi-Site-All-Call as the trigger Type. This guarantees that the routine will initiate the Multi-Site-All-Call during its execution.

qas.question: On which system does the Feature-Wait action wait for a Multi-Site-All-Call?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action waits for a Multi-Site-All-Call only on a Nyquist system that initiates the Multi-Site-All-Call. Remote sites included in the call will only experience a playing All-Call and will not see it as a Multi-Site call, thus the action will have no effect in those scenarios.

qas.question: What do remote sites see during a Multi-Site-All-Call, and how does that affect the action?

answers.text: Remote sites included in a Multi-Site-All-Call only see a playing All-Call and do not recognize it as a Multi-Site call. As a result, the Feature-Wait action will have no effect at these remote sites since they are not aware that a Multi-Site-All-Call is in progress.

qas.question: Can you set a Maximum Wait Time for the Feature-Wait action, and if so, how?

answers.text: Yes, you can set a Maximum Wait Time for the Feature-Wait action. This is done by using Feature-Wait as the action Type and specifying the desired duration in action parameter 2, while using either Multi-Site-All-Call or Multi-Site-E-All-Call as Feature Wait.

qas.question: What should be done to pause a routine until a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page completes?

answers.text: To pause a routine until a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page completes, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) set to Multi-Site-E-All-Call. Ensure that the routine is executed on a Nyquist system that initiates the Multi-Site Emergency All-Call for the action to have an effect.

qas.question: What occurs if there is no Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page playing during the Feature Wait action?

answers.text: If there is no Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page playing during the Feature Wait action, the routine does not wait for a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page and instead continues executing subsequent actions. This means the action has no effect in such scenarios.

qas.question: How can a routine ensure the inclusion of a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page?

answers.text: To ensure the inclusion of a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page in a routine, use Multi-Site-E-All-Call as the trigger Type. This guarantees that the Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page will be initiated as part of the routine.

qas.question: Under what conditions does the Feature-Wait action affect remote sites during a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action affects remote sites during a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call only when it is executed on a Nyquist system that initiates the Multi-Site Emergency All-Call. Remote sites that are part of the call only recognize it as an Emergency-All-Call and do not see it as a Multi-Site call, meaning the Feature-Wait action has no effect in that scenario.

If you want a routine to pause until a tone finishes, use the Feature-
Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) set to Tone.
If no tone is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the rou-
tine does not wait for a tone to start. Instead, it continues executing 
subsequent actions.
If you want to ensure that the routine includes the playing of a tone, 
use Tone as the trigger Type.
If you do not need the routine to wait until the tone finishes, you can 
sill use Feature-Wait as the action Type and Tone as Feature Wait 
and set Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2) to the desired 
amount of time to wait.
13.11.7.13 Feature-Wait Action Type with Zone
If you want all zone pages to complete before continuing with subse-
quent routine actions, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Fea-
ture Wait (parameter 1) set to Zone.
This action will not allow you to specify a zone. The Announcement 
trigger Type does allow you to specify a zone (see "Understanding 
Trigger Parameters” on page 395). However, if multiple routines trig-
gered by a zone page use Feature-Wait action Type with Feature 
Wait set to Zone and multiple zone pages start, then all routines 
triggered by the start of a zone page will pause until the multiple 
zone pages have completed.
13.11.8
Zones and Stations Parameters for Deleting 
Display Messages
If you set Parameter 1 of Display-Msg-Delete action Type to 
PARAM, the options used for Zones and Stations determine which 
messages, if any, a routine automatically deletes from the dashboard 
and NG-GA10PV video displays. For example, if you leave Zones 
blank and set Stations to All, then messages that have no zones 
defined but do have stations defined will be deleted.

qas.question: What action type should be used to pause a routine until a Multi-Site-All-Call page completes?

answers.text: To pause a routine until a Multi-Site-All-Call page completes, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) set to Multi-Site-All-Call. This action will ensure the routine waits for the completion of the Multi-Site-All-Call if it is currently playing.

qas.question: How does the Feature-Wait action behave if no Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page is playing?

answers.text: If no Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page is playing when the Feature-Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a page to start and continues executing subsequent actions. To ensure the routine includes a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page, Multi-Site-E-All-Call must be used as the trigger Type.

qas.question: What is the purpose of setting Maximum Wait Time in the Feature-Wait action?

answers.text: Setting the Maximum Wait Time in the Feature-Wait action allows the routine to pause for a specified duration, even if the condition (e.g., Multi-Site-All-Call, tone, etc.) is not currently playing. This enables control over how long the routine should wait before continuing with subsequent actions, ensuring it does not wait indefinitely.

qas.question: Can a routine triggered by a zone page continue while waiting for other zone pages to complete?

answers.text: No, a routine triggered by a zone page will not continue while waiting for other zone pages to complete if the Feature-Wait action Type is set to Zone. All routines triggered by the start of a zone page will pause until multiple zone pages have completed.

qas.question: How do remote sites perceive a Multi-Site-All-Call that they are included in?

answers.text: Remote sites included in a Multi-Site-All-Call only perceive it as a standard playing All-Call and do not recognize it as a Multi-Site call. Consequently, the Feature-Wait action will have no effect on these remote sites when it comes to waiting for the Multi-Site-All-Call.

qas.question: What must be set as the trigger Type to ensure a routine includes a Multi-Site-E-All-Call page?

answers.text: To ensure a routine includes a Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page, you must set Multi-Site-E-All-Call as the trigger Type. This will guarantee that the routine waits for the Multi-Site Emergency All-Call page to be active before proceeding.

qas.question: Which parameter determines the deletion of messages in the Display-Msg-Delete action for specific zones and stations?

answers.text: In the Display-Msg-Delete action Type, Parameter 1 set to PARAM determines which messages a routine will delete based on the specified options for Zones and Stations. Leaving Zones blank while setting Stations to All will result in the deletion of messages that have no defined zones but include defined stations.

qas.question: Is it possible to specify a zone when using the Feature-Wait action set to Zone?

answers.text: No, it is not possible to specify a zone when using the Feature-Wait action set to Zone. This action applies to all zone pages without the option to define a specific zone.

qas.question: What happens if no tone is playing when the Feature Wait action executes with Feature Wait set to Tone?

answers.text: If no tone is playing when the Feature Wait action executes with Feature Wait set to Tone, the routine does not wait for a tone to start and continues executing subsequent actions. To ensure a tone is played, Tone should be used as the trigger Type.

qas.question: How does the Feature-Wait action type differ when applied to tones versus Multi-Site-All-Calls?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type pauses a routine until a tone finishes when set to Tone, while it waits for a Multi-Site-All-Call page to complete only if an active Multi-Site-All-Call is playing; if not, the routine continues without waiting. Additionally, if a Multi-Site-All-Call page is not playing at the time of execution, the routine will not wait, whereas the tone-specific setting applies directly to the tone's completion.

messages, if any, a routine automatically deletes from the dashboard 
and NG-GA10PV video displays. For example, if you leave Zones 
blank and set Stations to All, then messages that have no zones 
defined but do have stations defined will be deleted.

qas.question: What is the purpose of using the Feature-Wait action type with a Tone?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type with a Tone is used to pause a routine until a tone finishes playing. If no tone is playing when this action executes, the routine will continue executing subsequent actions without waiting for a tone to start.

qas.question: How does the Feature-Wait action type behave if no tone is currently playing?

answers.text: If no tone is currently playing when the Feature-Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a tone to start and continues executing subsequent actions. To ensure a tone plays before pausing, Tone should be set as the trigger type.

qas.question: What must be done to ensure a routine waits until a tone finishes playing?

answers.text: To ensure a routine waits until a tone finishes playing, use the Feature-Wait action type with Parameter 1 set to Tone. Additionally, make sure that a tone is actively playing when the Feature Wait action executes; otherwise, the routine will not wait for a tone to start and will continue executing subsequent actions.

qas.question: Can you specify a zone when using the Feature-Wait action type with Zone?

answers.text: No, you cannot specify a zone when using the Feature-Wait action type with Zone. This action is designed to wait for all zone pages to complete without allowing for zone-specific selection.

qas.question: What occurs if multiple zone pages trigger routines using Feature-Wait with Feature Wait set to Zone?

answers.text: If multiple zone pages trigger routines using Feature-Wait with Feature Wait set to Zone, all routines triggered by the start of the zone pages will pause until all the multiple zone pages have completed. This ensures that all zone pages finish before any subsequent routine actions continue.

qas.question: How does Parameter 1 of the Display-Msg-Delete action type affect message deletion on dashboard and video displays?

answers.text: Parameter 1 of the Display-Msg-Delete action type determines the criteria for message deletion based on Zones and Stations. If Zones are left blank and Stations are set to All, the routine will delete messages that lack defined zones but have defined stations from the dashboard and NG-GA10PV video displays.

qas.question: What happens if Zones are left blank and Stations are set to All in the Display-Msg-Delete action?

answers.text: If Zones are left blank and Stations are set to All in the Display-Msg-Delete action, any messages that lack defined zones but have defined stations will be automatically deleted from the dashboard and NG-GA10PV video displays. This setting ensures that messages associated with all stations, regardless of zone specification, are removed.

qas.question: What action type should be used to pause a routine until a tone finishes?

answers.text: To pause a routine until a tone finishes, use the Feature-Wait action Type with Feature Wait (parameter 1) set to Tone. If no tone is playing when this action executes, the routine will continue without waiting for a tone to start.

qas.question: What happens if a tone is not playing when the Feature Wait action executes?

answers.text: If no tone is playing when the Feature Wait action executes, the routine does not wait for a tone to start and instead continues executing subsequent actions. To ensure a tone is played before proceeding, Tone should be used as the trigger type.

qas.question: How can you ensure a routine includes the playing of a tone?

answers.text: To ensure a routine includes the playing of a tone, use Tone as the trigger Type. This approach will ensure that the routine activates with the tone as a prerequisite before executing subsequent actions.

qas.question: If you do not need to wait for a tone to finish, what can you set the Maximum Wait Time to?

answers.text: If you do not need to wait for a tone to finish, you can still use the Feature-Wait action Type with Tone as Feature Wait and set the Maximum Wait Time (action parameter 2) to the desired amount of time you wish to wait before proceeding with subsequent actions. This allows the routine to continue without waiting for the tone's completion.

qas.question: What is the action type used to ensure all zone pages complete before proceeding?

answers.text: The action type used to ensure all zone pages complete before proceeding is the Feature-Wait action type with Feature Wait set to Zone. This action will pause subsequent routine actions until all triggered zone pages have finished.

qas.question: Can you specify a zone when using Feature-Wait with Feature Wait set to Zone?

answers.text: No, you cannot specify a zone when using Feature-Wait with Feature Wait set to Zone. This action will apply to all zone pages without the ability to limit it to a specific zone.

qas.question: What is affected when multiple routines are triggered by a zone page using the Feature-Wait action type?

answers.text: When multiple routines are triggered by a zone page using the Feature-Wait action type with Feature Wait set to Zone, all routines will pause until all the zone pages have completed. This means that the execution of subsequent actions in each routine will be delayed until the announcements associated with the zone pages finish.

qas.question: How does setting Parameter 1 of the Display-Msg-Delete action type to PARAM affect message deletion?

answers.text: Setting Parameter 1 of the Display-Msg-Delete action type to PARAM allows the routine to automatically delete messages based on the specified options for Zones and Stations. If Zones are left blank and Stations are set to All, messages without defined zones but with defined stations will be deleted from the dashboard and NG-GA10PV video displays.

qas.question: What happens to messages with no zones defined but stations defined when relevant parameters are set?

answers.text: If Parameter 1 of the Display-Msg-Delete action Type is set to PARAM with Zones left blank and Stations set to All, then messages that do not have zones defined but do have stations defined will be automatically deleted from the dashboard and NG-GA10PV video displays.

qas.question: What is the purpose of using the Feature-Wait action type with Tone?

answers.text: The Feature-Wait action type with Tone is used to pause a routine until a specified tone finishes playing. If no tone is playing when the action executes, the routine continues without waiting for a tone to start. This ensures that subsequent actions only execute after the tone has completed.

qas.question: When does a routine not wait for a tone to finish under the Feature-Wait action type?

answers.text: A routine does not wait for a tone to finish under the Feature-Wait action type if no tone is playing when the Feature Wait action executes; in this case, the routine will continue executing subsequent actions without waiting. To ensure a routine includes playing a tone, Tone should be used as the trigger type.

qas.question: How can you ensure a routine includes the playing of a tone?

answers.text: To ensure a routine includes the playing of a tone, use Tone as the trigger Type. This guarantees that the routine will wait for the tone to play before executing subsequent actions.

qas.question: What happens if you use Feature-Wait with Zone when multiple zone pages start?

answers.text: If you use Feature-Wait with Zone while multiple zone pages start, all routines triggered by the start of a zone page will pause until all the multiple zone pages have completed. This means that subsequent actions in those routines will not execute until every involved zone page has finished.

qas.question: How is the Parameter 1 setting of Display-Msg-Delete action type related to Zones and Stations?

answers.text: The Parameter 1 setting of the Display-Msg-Delete action type determines which messages are automatically deleted based on the defined Zones and Stations. If Parameter 1 is set to PARAM, the combination of specified Zones and Stations dictates which messages will be selected for deletion from the dashboard and NQ-GA10PV video displays. For instance, leaving Zones blank while setting Stations to All will delete messages with no defined zones but any defined stations.

qas.question: What criteria determine which messages get deleted when using the Display-Msg-Delete action?

answers.text: The criteria for deleting messages with the Display-Msg-Delete action depend on the combination of Zones and Stations settings. Messages are selected for deletion based on whether zones are defined, whether stations are defined, or if both criteria match the specified conditions in the routine. For example, if Zones are left blank and Stations are set to All, messages without defined zones but with any stations will be deleted.

qas.question: How can variables be utilized in text messages for the Admin Web UI dashboard?

answers.text: Variables can be added to text messages for the Admin Web UI dashboard, allowing them to be dynamically replaced with specific information when a routine is launched. For example, when the variable $date1 is used in a message, it will be replaced by the current date in the format YYYY-MM-DD at runtime.

qas.question: What format is the $date1 variable replaced with when a routine is launched?

answers.text: The $date1 variable is replaced with the current date in the format YYYY-MM-DD when the routine is launched.

qas.question: How does leaving Zones blank while setting Stations to All affect message deletion?

answers.text: Leaving Zones blank while setting Stations to All results in the deletion of messages that do not have any zones defined but are associated with any specified stations. Essentially, it targets messages without specific zone assignments while including all station-related messages.

qas.question: What is the result of setting both Zones and Stations parameters to selected values in terms of message deletion?

answers.text: When both Zones and Stations parameters are set to selected values, the routine will delete messages that match the specified zones and specified stations. This means only messages that have both the defined zones and the defined stations present will be selected for deletion. If a message does not meet both criteria, it will not be deleted.

13.11.10
Using Variables in Dashboard and NQ-
GA10PV Identifiers
You can use the following variables in the Identifier field (Parameter 
2) of Display-Msg, Display-Msg-Delete, Dash-Text, and Dash-

• $called
• $station
• $contact
• $facility

play-Msg action type:
• $calltypechar
• $calltypeshort
• $calltypelong
• $autobgcolor
• $autofontcolor
• $autopriority(E,U,N)
These variables allow you to set the priority and appearance of the 
NQ-GA10PV display messages for emergency, urgent, or intercom 
Note: This section describes variables that are only available for 
use in the Display-Msg action type if the routine trigger is Inter-
com-Call, Urgent-Call, or Emergency-Call.

qas.question: What is the purpose of using variables in text messages for the Admin Web UI dashboard and NQ-GA10PV?

answers.text: The purpose of using variables in text messages for the Admin Web UI dashboard and NQ-GA10PV is to dynamically replace placeholders with relevant data, such as dates, caller information, or call types, when a routine is triggered. This allows for personalized and context-specific messages to be displayed, enhancing the clarity and relevance of information communicated to users.

qas.question: How are messages selected for deletion based on certain zones and station configurations?

answers.text: Messages for deletion are selected based on the combination of defined zones and stations. If both are blank, no messages are selected; with defined zones and no specified stations, only those messages with the specified zones are deleted; and if both zones and stations are selected, only messages matching both criteria are deleted.

qas.question: What is the maximum character limit for messages displayed on the dashboard and NQ-GA10PV?

answers.text: The maximum character limit for messages displayed on the dashboard is 255 characters per message. For the NQ-GA10PV display, the limit is 4096 characters, though the actual limit may vary depending on font style and size.

qas.question: Which variables can be used in the Identifier field of Display-Msg and related action types?

answers.text: The following variables can be used in the Identifier field of Display-Msg, Display-Msg-Delete, Dash-Text, and Dash-Delete action types: $caller, $called, $station, $contact, $facility, $eventid, $eventname, and $zone. The maximum character length for an Identifier is 255 characters, and when using variables, the replaced names must not exceed this limit.

qas.question: What variable would be used to display the current date in YYYY-MM-DD format?

answers.text: The variable used to display the current date in YYYY-MM-DD format is `$date1`. When this variable is included in a text message, it is replaced by the current date in the specified format when the routine is launched.

qas.question: Which variables are specifically for setting the priority and appearance of messages in the Display-Msg action type?

answers.text: The variables specifically for setting the priority and appearance of messages in the Display-Msg action type are $autobgcolor, $autofontcolor, and $autopriority(E,U,N). These variables allow customization of the message's background color, font color, and priority level for emergency, urgent, or intercom calls.

qas.question: What happens to the message's background color when the variable $autobgcolor is used?

answers.text: When the variable $autobgcolor is used, the message's background color automatically changes to red for Emergency-Call, yellow for Urgent-Call, or adopts the font color specified in the Display-Msg action for Intercom-Call. It is important to note that $autobgcolor should not be used in conjunction with $autofontcolor.

qas.question: Is the $caller variable available for the routine trigger of Alarm?

answers.text: Yes, the $caller variable is available for the routine trigger of Alarm. It displays the extension number of the caller that triggered the execution of the routine, or the phone number if the call originates from outside the system.

qas.question: How does the variable $autopriority(E,U,N) change the message's priority?

answers.text: The variable $autopriority(E,U,N) modifies the message's priority based on the type of call triggered. The parameters E, U, and N represent the priorities for Emergency, Urgent, and Normal calls, respectively, with the format allowing the assignment of specific numeric values to these priorities (e.g., $autopriority(5,4,3) sets Emergency calls to priority 5). If the parameters are omitted, the default priorities will be set to 4, 3, and 2 for Emergency, Urgent, and Normal calls, respectively.

qas.question: Can the same variable be used in both the Identifier field and the Text field for Display-Msg actions?

answers.text: No, the same variable cannot be used in both the Identifier field and the Text field for Display-Msg actions. Variables allowed in the Identifier field include $caller, $called, $station, $contact, $facility, $eventid, $eventname, and $zone, while those specific to the Text field include $calltypechar, $calltypeshort, $calltypelong, $autobgcolor, $autofontcolor, and $autopriority(E,U,N).

qas.question: What is the maximum character length for an Identifier?

qas.question: Which variables are specifically applicable in the Text field of the Display-Msg action type?

qas.question: How do the variables affect the priority and appearance of display messages in NQ-GA10PV?

answers.text: The variables used in the Text field of the Display-Msg action type, specifically $calltypechar, $calltypeshort, $calltypelong, $autobgcolor, $autofontcolor, and $autopriority, determine the priority level and visual styling of the display messages for different call types, such as emergency, urgent, or intercom calls. By setting these variables, users can customize both the urgency indicated by the message and its appearance on the NQ-GA10PV display.

qas.question: In which routine triggers can the variables for Display-Msg action type be used?

answers.text: The variables for the Display-Msg action type can be used in the routine triggers of Intercom-Call, Urgent-Call, and Emergency-Call. These variables allow customization of the display messages specifically for these call types.

qas.question: Are there any limitations concerning the character length for the $facility and $zone variables when used in Identifiers?

answers.text: Yes, when using the $facility and $zone variables in Identifiers, the names that replace these variables must not exceed a maximum character length of 255 characters. This limitation applies to the entire Identifier as well.

qas.question: For which types of calls are the Display-Msg text variables applicable?

qas.question: What steps are involved in reordering actions in a routine?

answers.text: To reorder actions in a routine, select Routines from the navigation bar, then choose Actions for the desired routine. Click the Move icon next to the action you want to reposition and drag it to the desired location, and finally, select Done to complete the process.

qas.question: Why should care be exercised when reordering actions in a routine?

answers.text: Care should be exercised when reordering actions in a routine because some actions must be the last action in a routine to function correctly. Improper ordering may lead to unexpected behavior or failures in the routine's execution.

qas.question: How can you export routines for technical support or server import?

answers.text: To export routines for technical support or server import, first, add your server’s IP address to Chrome settings by navigating to chrome://settings/content/popups and selecting "Add." After that, you can export the routines to share with Bogen Technical Support or for later import to other servers.

qas.question: What needs to be done in Chrome settings to export multiple routines?

qas.question: Which actions must be the last action in a routine?

qas.question: How can you access the Routines section in the navigation bar?

qas.question: What icon do you use to move an action during reordering?

answers.text: To move an action during reordering, click the Move icon, which is represented by an unspecified icon (as indicated in the text with "()" next to the instructions). After clicking it, you can drag the action to the desired location.

qas.question: What steps must be taken to export routines for sharing with Bogen Technical Support?

answers.text: To export routines for sharing with Bogen Technical Support, first add your server’s IP address to Chrome settings by navigating to chrome://settings/content/popups, then selecting "Add." After configuring this setting, you can export the routines as needed.

qas.question: Why is it necessary to add your server’s IP address to Chrome settings before exporting multiple routines?

answers.text: It is necessary to add your server’s IP address to Chrome settings before exporting multiple routines to allow the browser to recognize and permit pop-up windows from that specific server. This ensures that the export process can proceed without being blocked by the browser's default security settings.

qas.question: What URL do you enter in the Chrome address line to access the pop-up settings?

answers.text: To access the pop-up settings in Chrome, enter the following URL in the address line: `chrome://settings/content/popups`. This will take you directly to the pop-up settings where you can modify them.

To import a routine:
Step 1
On the navigation bar, select Routines.

From the Import popup window that appears, select

are correct for the server since the server that created the routine 
will not have the same station, zone, or audio files as the server to 
which you are importing the routine. Imported routines must be 
enabled and the DTMF code will need to be changed if the same 
code is already being used on the server.

qas.question: What steps are involved in reordering actions within a routine?

answers.text: To reorder actions within a routine, select Routines from the navigation bar, choose the desired routine's actions, click the Move icon next to the action you want to move, and drag it to the new location. Finally, select Done to complete the reordering.

qas.question: How can a user export routines for support or later use?

answers.text: To export routines, a user should first ensure their server's IP address is added to Chrome settings. Then, they can navigate to Routines, select the desired routine(s), and click on Export, which will save a .sql file to the Downloads folder for sharing or later use.

qas.question: What must be done to Chrome settings before exporting multiple routines?

answers.text: To export multiple routines, you must first add your server’s IP address to Chrome settings. This can be done by navigating to chrome://settings/content/popups, selecting "Add," and entering the server's IP address in the popup.

qas.question: What file format is used when routines are exported from the server?

answers.text: Routines are exported from the server in the .sql file format. The exported file will be saved to the Downloads folder on the server.

qas.question: What is required after importing a routine to ensure it works correctly on the new server?

answers.text: After importing a routine, you must ensure that the parameters are correct for the new server, as the original server may have different stations, zones, or audio files. Additionally, the imported routine must be enabled, and the DTMF code should be changed if the same code is already in use on the new server.

qas.question: How does one import a routine from another Nyquist server?

answers.text: To import a routine from another Nyquist server, select "Routines" from the navigation bar, click on "Import," then choose the file you want to import using the popup window. After selecting the file, click "Import" and ensure that the parameters are correct for your server.

qas.question: Why is it important to verify parameters after importing a routine?

answers.text: It is important to verify parameters after importing a routine because the original server may have different station, zone, or audio files than the server to which the routine is imported. Ensuring that parameters are correct helps prevent functionality issues and conflicts, such as duplicate DTMF codes.

qas.question: What should be done if a DTMF code is already in use after routine import?

answers.text: If a DTMF code is already in use after importing a routine, you will need to change the DTMF code for the imported routine to avoid conflicts. Ensure that all other parameters are also checked for compatibility with the new server.

Managing Display Messages
The Display Message option allows you to create messages that will 
display on monitors connected to NQ-GA10PV devices in a selected 
zone, in multiple zones, or to specific devices. When creating the 
message, you can set several options, including when and how long 
the message is displayed and the appearance of the message. You 
can also remove messages from the message queue. 
The station’s Display Configuration option controls the overall 
appearance of the display (for example, what type of clock appears, 
whether an event or the date appears, and the background color of 
the screen). For information about setting the display configuration 
for an NQ-GA10PV, see "Configuring Intercom HDMI Module Display 
Options” on page 146. 
Figure 14-1, Example of Priority Message in Fullscreen

qas.question: What steps are involved in importing a routine to a Nyquist server?

answers.text: To import a routine to a Nyquist server, navigate to Routines, select Import, and choose the file you want to import. After selecting Import, ensure that the parameters are correct for your server, and make any necessary adjustments like enabling the routine and changing the DTMF code if there's a conflict.

qas.question: What must be verified after importing a routine to ensure compatibility with the current server?

answers.text: After importing a routine, you must verify that the parameters are correct for the current server, as it may not have the same station, zone, or audio files as the original server. Additionally, ensure that the routine is enabled and check the DTMF code, changing it if it conflicts with an existing code on the server.

qas.question: What options can be configured when creating display messages for NQ-GA10PV devices?

answers.text: When creating display messages for NQ-GA10PV devices, you can configure options such as the duration and timing of the message display, its appearance, and the ability to remove messages from the queue. Additionally, the overall display appearance can be controlled through the station’s Display Configuration options.

qas.question: How does the Display Configuration option affect the overall appearance of the display on NQ-GA10PV devices?

answers.text: The Display Configuration option on NQ-GA10PV devices determines the overall appearance of the display by controlling elements such as the type of clock shown, whether to display an event or the date, and the background color of the screen. These settings ensure that the visual output aligns with user preferences and operational requirements.

qas.question: What should be done if the DTMF code of an imported routine is already in use on the server?

answers.text: If the DTMF code of an imported routine is already in use on the server, you will need to change the DTMF code of the imported routine to avoid conflicts. Make sure to verify and update this code after importing the routine.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Display Message option for NQ-GA10PV devices?

answers.text: The Display Message option for NQ-GA10PV devices allows users to create and send messages that display on connected monitors in selected zones or specific devices. Users can customize various settings, including the timing and appearance of the messages, while overall display features are controlled separately through the Display Configuration settings.

qas.question: How can you access the Display Message creation page?

answers.text: To access the Display Message creation page, select "Dashboard" from the navigation bar and then choose "Display Message" under the Tones/Announcements section. This will take you to the Display Message page where you can complete the options for your new message.

qas.question: What steps are involved in creating a display message?

answers.text: To create a display message, first navigate to the Dashboard and select Display Message under Tones/Announcements. Complete the necessary options for the new message and then select Send.

qas.question: Can display messages be added through routine actions, and where can I find more information about that?

answers.text: Yes, display messages can be added through routine actions. More information on this can be found in the section titled "Adding an Action," located on page 404.

qas.question: What must be configured to change the overall appearance of the NQ-GA10PV display?

answers.text: To change the overall appearance of the NQ-GA10PV display, you must configure the station's Display Configuration options. This includes settings for the type of clock displayed, whether to show an event or date, and the background color of the screen.

qas.question: Where can you find details on setting the display configuration for the NQ-GA10PV?

answers.text: Details on setting the display configuration for the NQ-GA10PV can be found in the section titled "Configuring Intercom HDMI Module Display Options," specifically on page 146. This section covers the overall appearance of the display, including clock type, event or date display, and background color options.

qas.question: What options can be set for a display message before sending it?

answers.text: Before sending a display message, you can set options such as when the message will be displayed, how long it will appear, and the appearance of the message itself. These options are distinct from the overall display configuration, which controls features like the clock and date.

Text
Type the message that is to appear on the

Select the mode for setting the message’s 
expiration. Options are:
• Display Time. Uses Display Time (sec-
onds) to set the expiration.

time to Never. You must use the Remove 
Message button remove a message from

• Date/Time. By default, the current date 
and time appears in the Date/Time field.
Display Time 
(seconds)
Appears only if Expiration Mode is set to 
Display Time. Sets the length of time for the 
message to be displayed before it expires. 
Time can range from 1 to 99999.
Date/Time
Appears only if Expiration Mode is set to 
Date/Time. By default is set to the current 
date and time. To change the date, select the 
calendar and pick the date and time. 
Zones
Select the zone or zones. Messages will be 
sent to the display devices in the selected 
zones.
Stations

and any stations that belong to the specified

Used to identify the message so it can be 
deleted by a Routine action.
Priority
Select the message priority, which can range 
from 0 (Lowest) to 6 - (Fullscreen). Priority 
6 - (Fullscreen) is the highest priority, and 
when a message is assigned this priority, 
only the messages with this priority appear 
on the display with the Scheduled Event 
Name and Date being temporarily removed. 
If Priority 5 (Exclusive) is selected, the 
Scheduled Event Name and Date remain on 
the display, but all other messages with

Font
Select the down arrow to view a list of avail-
able fonts and then select the desired font

Linux Libertine

Enter the desired font size.

qas.question: What are the steps to create a display message on the dashboard?

answers.text: To create a display message on the dashboard, select "Dashboard" from the navigation bar, then choose "Display Message" under Tones/Announcements. Complete the options for the new message and select "Send" to finalize.

qas.question: Which HTML tags can be used to format text in display messages?

answers.text: You can format text in display messages using the following basic HTML tags: <b> for bold, <i> for italic, and <u> for underline.

qas.question: What are the available options for setting a message’s expiration?

answers.text: The available options for setting a message’s expiration are: **Display Time**, which uses a specified duration (in seconds) for the message to be shown; **Manually Removed**, which sets the message to never expire unless manually deleted; and **Date/Time**, allowing the user to set a specific expiration date and time.

qas.question: How can the display time for a message be set?

answers.text: The display time for a message can be set by selecting "Display Time" in the Expiration Mode and then entering the desired duration in seconds (ranging from 1 to 99999) in the Display Time field. This option will only appear if the Expiration Mode is set to Display Time.

qas.question: What options are available for selecting zones when sending a message?

answers.text: When sending a message, you can select one or more specific zones to which the message will be sent. The message will be delivered to the display devices located in the chosen zones.

qas.question: How does the Priority setting affect the display of messages?

answers.text: The Priority setting determines the visibility of messages on the display. A message with Priority 6 (Fullscreen) will exclusively appear, hiding all other messages, while Priority 5 (Exclusive) allows the scheduled event name and date to remain visible while removing messages of lower priorities.

qas.question: What methods can be used to select background colors for display messages?

answers.text: Background colors for display messages can be selected using a color picker, entering a hex color code (e.g., #000000 for black), or inputting an RGB color value (e.g., rgb(0,0,0) for black). Additionally, color alias names (e.g., red, blue) can also be used.

qas.question: Which fonts are available for formatting message text?

answers.text: The available fonts for formatting message text are Comic-Relief, Courier-Prime, Gelasio, Liberation Sans, and Linux Libertine.

qas.question: How can font colors be chosen for message text?

answers.text: Font colors for message text can be chosen by using a color picker, entering a hex color code (e.g., #000000 for black), entering an RGB color (e.g., rgb(0,0,0) for black), or entering a color alias name (e.g., red, blue, etc.).

qas.question: What are the ways to input color values when creating a display message?

answers.text: When creating a display message, you can input color values using three methods: by using a color picker, entering a hex color (e.g., #000000 for black), or specifying an RGB color (e.g., rgb(0,0,0) for black). Additionally, you can use color alias names (e.g., red, blue, etc.).

14.3
Removing Messages
The Remove Message window allows you to remove any message 
from the display message queue. It is also the only way to expire a 
message that was created using Manually Removed as the Expira-
tion Mode.
To remove a message:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Select the Remove icon next to the message that you 
want to delete.
Step 3
Select Delete Selected.
14.4
Removing an Event Name from a Display
If you create a scheduled event with Display Event Name enabled, 
the event remains on the display that is connected to an NQ-GA10PV 
until the next scheduled event replaces it. 
Figure 14-3, Remove Message

qas.question: How can colors be selected for display messages in the GA10PV Display Configuration?

answers.text: Colors for display messages in the GA10PV Display Configuration can be selected through three methods: by configuring background, text, and time colors in the Display Configuration settings, by setting background and font colors for individual messages from the dashboard, or by using the Display-Msg routine action Type. Users can choose colors using a color picker, entering a hex code, entering an RGB value, or using a predefined color alias.

qas.question: What are the methods to configure individual message colors?

answers.text: You can configure individual message colors by selecting "Display Message" from the dashboard to set background and font colors, or by using the Display-Msg routine action Type to specify colors for messages. Both methods allow color selection through a color picker, hex codes, RGB values, or predefined color alias names.

qas.question: What options are available for selecting font colors?

answers.text: Font colors can be selected using a color picker, by entering a hex color code (e.g., #000000 for black), by entering an RGB color (e.g., rgb(0,0,0) for black), or by using a color alias name (e.g., red, blue). When using a color alias, spaces are not allowed, and only default color aliases are accepted.

qas.question: What are the steps to select a font style for a display message?

answers.text: To select a font style for a display message, place your cursor in the "Add Styles" box and choose either Bold or Italic. If no selection is made, the font style will remain as Regular.

qas.question: How does the system respond when a color alias name is entered?

answers.text: When a color alias name is entered, the corresponding hex color code is displayed in the text portion of the color field, and the color swatch changes to reflect the selected color. Spaces are not permitted in the alias name, and only the default color aliases can be used.

qas.question: What is the function of the Remove Message window?

answers.text: The Remove Message window allows users to delete any message from the display message queue, and it is the only method to expire a message created with "Manually Removed" as the expiration mode. Users can select the Remove icon next to the desired message and confirm deletion by selecting "Delete Selected."

qas.question: What are the steps to remove a message from the display message queue?

answers.text: To remove a message from the display message queue, navigate to the Dashboard and select the Remove icon next to the desired message. Then, confirm the action by selecting "Delete Selected."

qas.question: How is an event name removed from a display when the Display Event Name is enabled?

answers.text: An event name is removed from a display when the Display Event Name is enabled by being replaced with the next scheduled event. Until that happens, the currently displayed event name remains until it is superseded by a new scheduled event.

qas.question: What is the hex color code for black?

answers.text: The hex color code for black is #000000. It can also be represented using RGB as rgb(0,0,0).

qas.question: What color alias corresponds to the hex code #ffff00?

answers.text: The color alias that corresponds to the hex code #ffff00 is "yellow." This color alias is part of the default color aliases listed in the documentation.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Remove Message window?

answers.text: The Remove Message window allows users to delete messages from the display message queue and is the only method to expire messages created with Manually Removed as the Expiration Mode. This feature enables effective management of displayed messages.

qas.question: How can you access the dashboard to remove a message?

answers.text: To access the dashboard, select "Dashboard" from the navigation bar. Once on the dashboard, you can proceed to remove a message by selecting the Remove icon next to the desired message.

qas.question: What action must you take to delete a message from the display message queue?

answers.text: To delete a message from the display message queue, navigate to the Dashboard, select the Remove icon next to the message you wish to delete, and then click on Delete Selected.

qas.question: How does the expiration mode "Manually Removed" affect message removal?

answers.text: The "Manually Removed" expiration mode requires messages to be explicitly deleted using the Remove Message window, as these messages do not expire automatically. This means users must follow a specific process to remove such messages from the display message queue.

qas.question: What happens to a scheduled event with Display Event Name enabled after the next scheduled event?

answers.text: After the next scheduled event occurs, the previous event with Display Event Name enabled will be replaced on the display connected to an NQ-GA10PV. This means that only the most recent scheduled event will remain visible.

qas.question: Which device is mentioned in relation to displaying event names?

answers.text: The device mentioned in relation to displaying event names is the NQ-GA10PV. It displays scheduled events with the Display Event Name enabled until the next scheduled event replaces it.

qas.question: What icon do you need to select to initiate the message removal process?

answers.text: To initiate the message removal process, you need to select the Remove icon next to the message that you want to delete. After selecting the icon, you can then choose "Delete Selected" to confirm the removal.

15Manage Check-In
447
Manage Check-In
Manage Check-In allows you to quickly obtain status of specific areas 
– such as classrooms, offices, or breakrooms – within a facility during 
a check-in event. Examples of check-in events include:
• Weather related shelter in place
• Safety related lockdown
• Fire evacuation (Teacher performs check-in to indicate room has 
been evacuated.)
• Room occupancy (Teacher checks room in with start of each class 
period.)
During a check-in event, users check in by initiating a Normal call to 
their assigned Admin Station, such as the front office, using either 
their Nyquist phone or a digital or analog call switch associated with 
their intercom speaker or station.
During Check-In, a Normal call initiated by a station to the Admin 
Station places a station in checked-in status. Additional Normal calls 
made following a check-in are processed as Normal calls to the 
Admin Station.
You can also elect to enable audio feedback that tells the staff 
member they have successfully checked in.
Calls made as part of the Manage Check-In process are not applied 
towards the system’s Current Call Count. Urgent and Emergency calls 
can still be placed by stations and are not included as part of Manage 
Check-In. 
As long as Privacy Mode is not enabled and a room’s device allows 
two-way transmission, you can select to use Spy Mode to listen to 
the room.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Remove Message window?

answers.text: The Remove Message window allows users to delete any message from the display message queue, serving as the only method to expire messages created with "Manually Removed" as the expiration mode. This feature is essential for managing messages displayed on the connected system.

qas.question: How can a user delete a message from the display message queue?

answers.text: To delete a message from the display message queue, the user must go to the Dashboard and select the Remove icon next to the desired message. Then, they should click on "Delete Selected" to remove the message.

qas.question: What happens when a scheduled event with Display Event Name enabled occurs in the system?

answers.text: When a scheduled event with Display Event Name enabled occurs, the event name is displayed on the connected NQ-GA10PV until the next scheduled event replaces it. To clear the event name from the display manually, another scheduled event with the Name set to No-Event must be created.

qas.question: How can you clear an event name from the display connected to an NQ-GA10PV?

answers.text: To clear an event name from the display connected to an NQ-GA10PV, create another scheduled event with the Name set to "No-Event." This will replace the current event name on the display.

qas.question: What are some examples of check-in events mentioned in the context?

answers.text: Examples of check-in events include weather-related shelter-in-place situations, safety-related lockdowns, fire evacuations (where teachers indicate a room has been evacuated), and room occupancy checks at the start of each class period.

qas.question: How do users check in during a check-in event?

answers.text: During a check-in event, users check in by initiating a Normal call to their assigned Admin Station using either their Nyquist phone or a digital or analog call switch associated with their intercom speaker or station. This call places the station in checked-in status without affecting the system's Current Call Count.

qas.question: What type of calls are placed during the Manage Check-In process?

answers.text: During the Manage Check-In process, users initiate a Normal call to their assigned Admin Station, which places the station in a checked-in status. Additional Normal calls made after the initial check-in are also processed as Normal calls to the Admin Station. Urgent and Emergency calls can still be placed but are not included in the Manage Check-In count.

qas.question: Is there a feature for audio feedback during the check-in process?

answers.text: Yes, there is a feature for audio feedback during the check-in process. It notifies staff members that they have successfully checked in.

qas.question: Do calls made during the Manage Check-In count towards the system's Current Call Count?

answers.text: No, calls made during the Manage Check-In process do not count towards the system's Current Call Count. Only Urgent and Emergency calls are excluded from this stipulation.

qas.question: When can Spy Mode be used during the Manage Check-In process?

answers.text: Spy Mode can be used during the Manage Check-In process as long as Privacy Mode is not enabled and the room's device allows for two-way transmission. This feature allows users to listen to the room while checking in.

15.1
Viewing Check-In Status
For administrators, the Manage Check-In feature provides a color-
coded view of what classrooms have checked in, classrooms or sta-
tions that are not part of the check-in process, and those that should 
check-in but have not yet done so. 
To view check-in status:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Under Calling/Paging, select Manage Check-In.
A separate tab appears so that you can toggle the 
dashboard and Manage Check-In views.
The status of each station appears in a color-coded box. The follow-
ing table explains the use of colors to describe status:
Note: You can also use the Maps feature to view check-in status. 
For more information, see "Using Maps for Check-In” on page 375.
Figure 15-1, Manage Check-In
Table 15-1, Color-coded Check-In Status
Color
Status
Green
Checked in
Red
Not checked in
Gray
Check-in is not expected because the station 
is either on the vacant or excluded lists.

qas.question: What types of events can trigger the Manage Check-In feature?

answers.text: The Manage Check-In feature can be triggered by events such as weather-related shelter in place, safety-related lockdowns, fire evacuations, and room occupancy at the start of each class period.

qas.question: How do users initiate a check-in during an event?

answers.text: Users initiate a check-in during an event by making a Normal call to their assigned Admin Station, such as the front office, using either their Nyquist phone or a digital or analog call switch associated with their intercom speaker or station. This call places the station in a checked-in status.

qas.question: What does a Normal call signify during the Manage Check-In process?

answers.text: During the Manage Check-In process, a Normal call initiated by a station to the Admin Station signifies that the station is now in a checked-in status. Subsequent Normal calls made after this check-in are processed as regular calls to the Admin Station, not affecting the system's Current Call Count.

qas.question: Can audio feedback be enabled during the check-in process, and what does it indicate?

answers.text: Yes, audio feedback can be enabled during the check-in process. This feedback indicates to the staff member that they have successfully checked in.

qas.question: How are calls made during Manage Check-In counted in relation to the system’s Current Call Count?

answers.text: Calls made during the Manage Check-In process are not applied towards the system’s Current Call Count. This means that these calls do not contribute to the total count of active calls in the system. Urgent and Emergency calls, however, can still be placed and are not included in the Manage Check-In count.

qas.question: What is the function of Spy Mode during the check-in process?

answers.text: Spy Mode allows users to listen to a room during the check-in process, provided that Privacy Mode is not enabled and the room's device supports two-way transmission. This feature enables administrators to monitor situations in real-time without the need for direct communication.

qas.question: How can administrators view the check-in status of classrooms?

answers.text: Administrators can view the check-in status of classrooms by selecting the Dashboard from the navigation bar and then clicking on Manage Check-In. This displays a color-coded status for each station, with green indicating checked in, red for not checked in, and gray for stations that are not expected to check in.

qas.question: What color represents a station that has checked in?

answers.text: Green represents a station that has checked in. This color indicates that the station is active in the check-in process during events such as shelter in place or fire evacuations.

qas.question: What does a gray status box signify in the context of check-in?

answers.text: A gray status box signifies that check-in is not expected for that station because it is either on the vacant or excluded lists. This means the station is not required to participate in the check-in process during the event.

qas.question: Is there an alternative feature to view check-in status aside from the dashboard?

answers.text: Yes, an alternative feature to view check-in status is the Maps feature, which allows users to see check-in status visually. For more information, refer to the section titled "Using Maps for Check-In" on page 375.

15.1.1
Starting Check-In
You can manually start the Check-In procedure from the Admin Web 
UI. Check-In can also be started via the Routines feature (see "Using 
Routines” on page 381.)
Check-In does not play any audio instruction announcements or send 
any text instructions to web interface stations or GA10PV display sta-
tions. If you want audio instruction announcements or text instruc-
tions on web interface stations or GA10PV display stations, set up a 
routine that includes audio instructions in an announcement or text 
instructions to be sent to web interface dashboards and GA10PV dis-
plays. The routine can be triggered by a Check-in Start, or the Check-
in can be started by the routine.
To manually start Check-In:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Under Calling/Paging, select Manage Check-In.
Step 3
On the Manage Check-In page, select Start.
When Check-In starts, the Start button changes to a Stop button and 
the red squares that represent occupied classrooms or areas begin 
changing to green squares as staff members begin checking in.
15.1.1.1 Station Check-In
During Check-In, a Normal call placed by a station to the Admin Sta-
tion places a station in check-in status. 
Figure 15-2, Manage Check-In When Idle

qas.question: What color indicates that a station has checked in?

answers.text: The color that indicates a station has checked in is green. In the color-coded status, green represents stations that have successfully completed the check-in process.

qas.question: How can an administrator view check-in status?

answers.text: An administrator can view check-in status by selecting "Dashboard" from the navigation bar and then choosing "Manage Check-In" under Calling/Paging. The status of each station is displayed in color-coded boxes, indicating whether they are checked in (green), not checked in (red), or excluded from the check-in process (gray).

qas.question: What does a gray status box signify for a station?

answers.text: A gray status box signifies that check-in is not expected for the station because it is either on the vacant or excluded lists. This indicates that the station is not part of the check-in process.

qas.question: What additional information is displayed on the Manage Check-In window?

answers.text: The Manage Check-In window displays the status of the check-in process (Active), the number of stations that have checked in and those that have not, the number of vacant stations, the date and time check-in started, and whether check-in has been manually stopped or completed.

qas.question: What feature allows administrators to use Spy Mode on a station?

answers.text: Administrators can use Spy Mode on a station through the Manage Check-In feature, provided that the privacy feature has not been activated and the station device allows two-way transmission. This functionality enables real-time monitoring of check-in status.

qas.question: Which stations are typically excluded from the check-in process?

answers.text: Stations typically excluded from the check-in process include those assigned to hallway speakers or amplifiers, as well as areas scheduled to be vacant when the check-in procedure begins. These exclusions ensure that only relevant stations participate in the check-in status updates.

qas.question: How can you manually start the Check-In procedure from the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: To manually start the Check-In procedure from the Admin Web UI, first select "Dashboard" from the navigation bar. Then, under "Calling/Paging," choose "Manage Check-In" and click the "Start" button on the Manage Check-In page.

qas.question: What happens to the Start button when Check-In begins?

answers.text: When Check-In begins, the Start button changes to a Stop button. Additionally, the red squares representing occupied classrooms or areas start changing to green squares as staff members begin checking in.

qas.question: What color do the squares representing occupied classrooms change to when staff check in?

answers.text: The squares representing occupied classrooms change to green when staff members check in. Initially, they appear red until checked in.

qas.question: What type of announcements are not played during the Check-In process?

answers.text: During the Check-In process, no audio instruction announcements or text instructions are played to web interface stations or GA10PV display stations. If these types of announcements are desired, a routine must be set up separately to incorporate them.

qas.question: What occurs when a Normal call is placed by a station to the Admin Station during Check-In?

qas.question: Where can the Manage Check-In option be found within the navigation bar?
