15.1.1
Starting Check-In
You can manually start the Check-In procedure from the Admin Web 
UI. Check-In can also be started via the Routines feature (see "Using 
Routines” on page 381.)
Check-In does not play any audio instruction announcements or send 
any text instructions to web interface stations or GA10PV display sta-
tions. If you want audio instruction announcements or text instruc-
tions on web interface stations or GA10PV display stations, set up a 
routine that includes audio instructions in an announcement or text 
instructions to be sent to web interface dashboards and GA10PV dis-
plays. The routine can be triggered by a Check-in Start, or the Check-
in can be started by the routine.
To manually start Check-In:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Under Calling/Paging, select Manage Check-In.
Step 3
On the Manage Check-In page, select Start.
When Check-In starts, the Start button changes to a Stop button and 
the red squares that represent occupied classrooms or areas begin 
changing to green squares as staff members begin checking in.
15.1.1.1 Station Check-In
During Check-In, a Normal call placed by a station to the Admin Sta-
tion places a station in check-in status. 
Figure 15-2, Manage Check-In When Idle
451
After a station has successfully checked in, additional Normal calls 
will go through as normal calls to the Admin station. Stations can still 
place Urgent or Emergency calls during the Check-in process, even if 
the station has not checked in. 
If audio prompt feedback is enabled and a station checks in, the 
caller hears a confirmation prompt. If audio feedback is disabled, sta-
tions checking in with digital call switches will still see a ringing status 
(flashing green) for about 2 seconds while checking in. Stations 
checking in with IP phones will notice a call lasting about 2 seconds 
before automatic hang up.
A VoIP Speaker Only station that does not have a call switch can still 
participate in the check-in process if an I/O controller Input contact is 
connected to a switch present in the room that contains the VoIP 
Speaker Only station. In this case, the I/O controller Input contact 
closure can trigger a Routine that performs a check-in.
In this scenario, the routine Trigger Type is set to Input-Contact-
Closed (see "Understanding Trigger Parameters” on page 395) and 
the routine Action Type is Check-In with Station set to the VoIP 
Speaker Only station extension (see "Understanding Action Parame-
ters” on page 406).
If a station with call switch is configured to only place Urgent or 
Emergency calls, the station cannot participate in the Check-in pro-
cess. This station should either be added to the Exclusion List (see 
"Managing Exclusion and Vacancy Lists” on page 454). Or if you wish 
to include the station in the Check-in process, the station’s CoS con-
figuration should be changed to allow Normal calls to be placed by 
the station (see "Editing CoS Parameters for a Station” on page 66). 
15.1.1.2 Check-In Done and Finish
After all stations included in the Check-In process have checked in, 
the Manage Check-In Status changes to Done. 
Since stations that were not expected to check in may do so, check-in 
is not completed until you select the Finish button.
Selecting the Finish button can trigger a routine if you have a routine 
that uses Check-In as the trigger Type and Finished as Check-In. 
(See "Understanding Trigger Parameters” on page 395 for more infor-
mation.)

qas.question: What are the steps to manually start the Check-In procedure from the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: To manually start the Check-In procedure from the Admin Web UI, first select "Dashboard" from the navigation bar. Then, under "Calling/Paging," choose "Manage Check-In" and click the "Start" button on the Manage Check-In page.

qas.question: How does the status of a station change during the Check-In process?

answers.text: During the Check-In process, the status of a station changes from unoccupied (represented by a red square) to checked-in (indicated by a green square) as staff members check in. If a normal call is placed to the Admin Station by a station during Check-In, that station enters check-in status, and upon successful check-in, it resumes normal call functionality.

qas.question: What happens if audio feedback is enabled during a station's Check-In?

answers.text: If audio prompt feedback is enabled during a station's Check-In, the caller hears a confirmation prompt upon successfully checking in. If audio feedback is disabled, the station will still show a ringing status for about 2 seconds while checking in.

qas.question: Can a VoIP Speaker Only station participate in the Check-In process without a call switch?

answers.text: Yes, a VoIP Speaker Only station can participate in the Check-In process without a call switch if an I/O controller Input contact is connected to a switch present in the room. The Input contact closure can trigger a routine that performs the check-in.

qas.question: What should be done if a station can only place Urgent or Emergency calls and needs to participate in Check-In?

answers.text: If a station can only place Urgent or Emergency calls and needs to participate in Check-In, it should either be added to the Exclusion List or its CoS configuration should be changed to allow Normal calls. This adjustment will enable the station to participate in the Check-In process.

qas.question: When does the Manage Check-In Status change to Done?

answers.text: The Manage Check-In Status changes to Done after all stations included in the Check-In process have checked in. However, check-in is not considered complete until the Finish button is selected, as stations not expected to check in may still do so.

qas.question: What action should be taken to complete the Check-In process after all expected stations have checked in?

answers.text: To complete the Check-In process after all expected stations have checked in, select the Finish button on the Manage Check-In page. This action is necessary to finalize the Check-In status, as it is not completed automatically even if all expected stations have checked in.

qas.question: How can a routine be triggered after finishing the Check-In process?

answers.text: A routine can be triggered after finishing the Check-In process by having a routine that uses Check-In as the Trigger Type and is set to Finished as Check-In. Selecting the Finish button in the Manage Check-In process activates this routine.

452
15.1.2
Stopping the Check-In Process
You can end an active Check-In process by selecting the Stop button 
on the Station Check-in view. An active Check-In process can also be 
stopped by a Routine action. 
When stopping Check-In via a routine, the Action Type is Check-In 
and the Check In option is Stop (see "Understanding Action Parame-
ters” on page 406). 
After the Check-in process has been stopped, all Normal station calls 
resume as normal calls to the Admin Station, and the Check-in pro-
cess Status becomes Idle. 
15.1.3
Resetting the Check-In Process
During either an active or idle Check-In process, you can clear all sta-
tion check-in statuses and allow all Normal calls to resume as normal 
calls to the Admin Station by selecting the Reset button on the Sta-
tion Check-in view. You can also reset the Check-In process by a Rou-
tine action. When resetting Check-In via a routine, the Action Type is 
Check-In and the Check In option is Reset (see "Understanding 
Action Parameters” on page 406). 
15.1.4
Using Spy Mode
You can use Spy Mode to listen to a station as long as Privacy Mode 
is not enabled and the station device allows two-way transmission.
This feature adds a step toward verifying that the room’s occupants 
are safe.
To activate Spy Mode:
Step 1
If not already on your dashboard, select Dashboard 
from the navigation bar.
Step 2
Under Calling/Paging, select Manage Check-In.
Figure 15-3, Listen In, or Spy Mode, Button

qas.question: What types of calls can stations place during the Check-in process?

answers.text: During the Check-in process, stations can still place Urgent or Emergency calls, regardless of whether they have checked in. Normal calls can only be placed by stations that are configured to allow them; otherwise, those stations cannot participate in the Check-in process.

qas.question: How does a VoIP Speaker Only station participate in the Check-in if it lacks a call switch?

answers.text: A VoIP Speaker Only station can participate in the Check-in process without a call switch by connecting an I/O controller Input contact to a switch in the room. This Input contact closure can trigger a routine that performs a check-in for the VoIP Speaker Only station.

qas.question: What happens after all stations in the Check-In process have checked in?

answers.text: After all stations included in the Check-In process have checked in, the Manage Check-In Status changes to Done. The check-in is considered complete only after the Finish button is selected, which may trigger a routine if configured accordingly.

qas.question: How can an active Check-In process be stopped?

answers.text: An active Check-In process can be stopped by selecting the Stop button on the Station Check-in view. Additionally, it can be stopped by a Routine action where the Action Type is Check-In and the Check In option is set to Stop.

qas.question: What is the effect of selecting the Reset button during an ongoing Check-in process?

answers.text: Selecting the Reset button during an ongoing Check-in process clears all station check-in statuses and allows all Normal calls to resume as normal calls to the Admin Station. This action effectively stops the Check-in process and changes its status to Idle.

qas.question: What requirements must be met for a station to use Spy Mode?

answers.text: For a station to use Spy Mode, Privacy Mode must not be enabled, and the station device must allow two-way transmission. This ensures that the occupants of the room can be safely monitored without their knowledge.

qas.question: What must be done to include a station that only places Urgent or Emergency calls in the Check-in process?

answers.text: To include a station that only places Urgent or Emergency calls in the Check-in process, you must either add the station to the Exclusion List or change its CoS configuration to allow Normal calls. This adjustment enables the station to participate in the Check-in process.

qas.question: How can audio prompt feedback be affected by the Check-in process configuration?

answers.text: Audio prompt feedback during the Check-in process is influenced by whether it is enabled or disabled for a station. If audio feedback is enabled, callers receive a confirmation prompt upon checking in; if it is disabled, stations will only see a ringing status for about 2 seconds during the check-in attempt.

qas.question: What condition leads to the Check-in Status changing to Done?

answers.text: The Check-in Status changes to Done after all stations included in the Check-In process have successfully checked in. However, check-in is not considered complete until the Finish button is selected, as stations not expected to check in may still do so.

qas.question: How can a routine trigger a Check-in event?

answers.text: A routine can trigger a Check-in event by setting the routine Trigger Type to Check-In and the Action Type to Check-In with the corresponding station. This allows the routine to initiate the check-in process for the specified station when the defined conditions are met.

qas.question: What icon should be selected to monitor a station on the Manage Check-In page?

answers.text: To monitor a station on the Manage Check-In page, select the Listen In icon for the desired station. This allows you to listen in on the station while it is checking in.

qas.question: How do you initiate the check-in process after selecting the station to monitor?

answers.text: To initiate the check-in process after selecting the station to monitor, select the Listen In icon for the desired station on the Manage Check-In page. Once the dial pad appears, dial 978 to start the check-in.

qas.question: What permissions are required for a user to utilize the check-in process?

answers.text: To utilize the check-in process, a user must have appropriate permissions assigned. These permissions can be managed by following the guidelines provided in the section "Assigning and Editing Permissions."

qas.question: What steps are involved in configuring check-in options?

answers.text: To configure check-in options, access the Dashboard, select Manage Check-In, then click Configure. Complete the configuration options and select Save to apply the changes.

qas.question: What happens if Spy Mode monitoring is attempted on a station in Privacy Mode?

answers.text: If Spy Mode monitoring is attempted on a station set to Privacy Mode, it cannot be used. The station in Privacy Mode will not allow any monitoring through the Spy Mode feature.

qas.question: How do stations appear on the Admin Station’s Check-In page when added to the Exclusion List or Vacancy List?

answers.text: Stations added to the Exclusion List appear gray on the Admin Station’s Check-In page and should always be excluded from the check-in process. Stations on the Vacancy List also appear gray but can still check in, typically indicating areas that may be vacant during the check-in process.

qas.question: What is the primary purpose of the Exclusion List in the check-in process?

answers.text: The primary purpose of the Exclusion List in the check-in process is to ensure that specific stations are always excluded from participating in the check-in procedure. These stations will appear gray on the Admin Station’s Check-In page and cannot check in under any circumstances.

qas.question: Can a station on the Vacancy List still check in during an emergency?

answers.text: Yes, a station on the Vacancy List can still check in during an emergency. While these stations are typically vacant and may not check in, they are permitted to do so in emergency situations.

qas.question: What does the "Enabled" option specify in the Check-In Configuration Options?

answers.text: The "Enabled" option in the Check-In Configuration Options specifies whether the Manage Check-In feature can be used. If set to Disabled, users can configure options but cannot initiate the check-in process.

qas.question: What effect does enabling audio prompts and confirmation messages have during the check-in process?

answers.text: Enabling audio prompts and confirmation messages during the check-in process means that audio files will play at stations when users perform check-ins, providing feedback through prompts and confirmations. If disabled, no audio cues will play, and stations will only indicate a check-in status through visual indicators, like a flashing green status for digital call switches or a brief call duration for IP phones.

qas.question: How do stations behave when audio feedback is disabled during check-in?

answers.text: When audio feedback is disabled during check-in, stations using digital call switches will display a ringing status (flashing green) for about 2 seconds while checking in. For IP phones, the call will last approximately 2 seconds without any audio prompts or confirmation messages.

qas.question: What types of stations can be added to the Vacancy List?

answers.text: Stations that can be added to the Vacancy List typically include classrooms or areas that normally participate in the check-in process but may be vacant at the time check-in is initiated. During an emergency, these stations can still check in despite being on the Vacancy List.

qas.question: What differentiates the Exclusion List from the Vacancy List in the check-in process?

answers.text: The Exclusion List contains stations that should always be excluded from the check-in process, while the Vacancy List includes stations that normally check in but may be vacant during the check-in process. Stations on the Vacancy List can still check in if necessary, such as in emergency situations, whereas those on the Exclusion List cannot.

15.3
Creating and Using Multiple Check-In Routines
You can create check-in routines for multiple purposes and to ensure 
that the vacancy and exclusion lists are accurate. 
You should create separate routines for drills and each type of emer-
gency check-in. For example, a fire drill could use audio explaining 
that it was a drill and would not include an actual 911 call where a 
routine used for evacuating during an actual fire could include a 911 
call. In this scenario, the word “drill” should appear in the name.
If you want to create routines for accurate exclusion and vacancy lists, 
use descriptive names such as “Fire Drill Period 1.” Each routine 
should include a Check-In action Type that uses Vacancy-Add and a 
separate Check-In action Type that uses Vacancy-Delete.

qas.question: What is the main difference between stations on the Exclusion List and those on the Vacancy List?

answers.text: Stations on the Exclusion List are always excluded from the check-in process and typically include locations not physically in a classroom, such as hallway speakers or appliances. In contrast, stations on the Vacancy List generally check in but may be vacant at the time of the check-in, allowing them to still indicate occupancy during emergencies.

qas.question: How can stations on the Vacancy List still check in during emergencies?

answers.text: Stations on the Vacancy List can still check in during emergencies to notify administrators of their occupancy status, even if they are typically unoccupied. This functionality allows for accurate situational awareness, like when a normally vacant classroom becomes a temporary shelter during an emergency.

qas.question: What types of stations should be included in the Exclusion List?

answers.text: The Exclusion List should include stations that are not physically located in a classroom, such as hallway speakers. Additionally, it should comprise stations assigned to appliances like power amplifiers and MMPAs, which do not participate in the check-in process.

qas.question: What are the steps to add a station to the Exclusion List via the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: To add a station to the Exclusion List via the Admin Web UI, navigate to the Dashboard, select Manage Check-In under Calling/Paging, click on Configure, add the desired station(s) to the Exclusion List, and then select Save.

qas.question: How can you remove a station from the Exclusion List using a routine?

answers.text: To remove a station from the Exclusion List using a routine, edit a routine that has Check-In as an Action Type. For Check In, select Exclude-Delete, choose the stations you want to remove, and then select Save.

qas.question: What options are available for configuring audio prompts in the Manage Check-In process?

answers.text: In the Manage Check-In process, you can enable audio prompts and confirmation messages, which will play audio files for feedback during check-in. When audio feedback is disabled, checking in will result in a flashing green ringing status for digital call switches or a brief call duration for IP phones, without any audio prompts.

qas.question: How do you add a station to the Vacancy List via the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: To add a station to the Vacancy List via the Admin Web UI, select "Dashboard," then navigate to "Manage Check-In." On the Manage Check-In page, select "Configure," add the desired station or stations to the Vacancy List, and then select "Save."

qas.question: What naming conventions should be used for creating multiple check-in routines?

answers.text: When creating multiple check-in routines, use descriptive names that clearly indicate their purpose, such as including the type of drill or emergency (e.g., "Fire Drill Period 1"). This helps ensure clarity and accuracy in managing the vacancy and exclusion lists for different scenarios.

qas.question: Why is it important to create separate routines for drills and actual emergencies?

answers.text: Creating separate routines for drills and actual emergencies is important to ensure clear communication and appropriate responses during each scenario. For example, a fire drill routine can include audio prompts indicating it's a practice, while an actual emergency routine may incorporate emergency calls, such as contacting 911, to ensure immediate assistance. This differentiation helps prevent confusion and ensures that the correct procedures are followed in critical situations.

qas.question: What actions should be included in a routine to maintain accurate exclusion and vacancy lists?

answers.text: To maintain accurate exclusion and vacancy lists, a routine should include a Check-In action type that uses both Vacancy-Add for stations expected to be vacant and Vacancy-Delete for stations that are no longer vacant. Descriptive names should be used to clearly differentiate the routines based on their purpose, such as identifying drills or emergencies.

qas.question: How can a station be deleted from the Vacancy List through a routine?

qas.question: Why is it recommended to create separate check-in routines for different purposes?

qas.question: What naming convention should be used for routines that include drills?

qas.question: What are the main components of a log file created by the Manage Check-In feature?

qas.question: How can users export the check-in log file?

answers.text: Users can export the check-in log file by using the Export button, as referenced in the section about "Using System Log Files." Additionally, they can copy the displayed log file information and paste it into another application.

qas.question: What information does each logged event in the check-in log contain?

answers.text: Each logged event in the check-in log contains a date and time stamp, the station extension that created the event, and optional event-related information. This structure allows for easy tracking and documentation of check-in activities.

15.4
Check-In Log and Call Detail Records
Manage Check-In writes data to a log file (see "Using System Log 
Files” on page 315) and creates a Call Detail Record (see "Viewing Call 
Detail Records” on page 319). You can export and print the check-in 
log file using the Export button (see "Exporting a Log File” on

Each logged event starts with a date and time stamp, followed by the 
station extension that created the event, and ending with optional

Figure 15-5, Example of Check-In Routine Action
459
2019-04-26 15:40:31 - 100 Start
The following event types are logged:
• Start
• Check-in
• Stop
• Reset
• Done
• Vacancy Add
• Vacancy Delete
• Exclude Add
• Exclude Delete
The Done event includes the elapsed time for the Check-in process 
(amount of time between Check-in Start and Done). The extension 
will always be 000 because this event is created by the system and 
not a specific station. For example:
2019-04-26 15:43:32 - 000 Done (elapsed time: 0h:3m:10s) 
On the Call Detail Records, the detail record Type is set to Check in 
when a station checks in.

16Managing Alerts
461
Managing Alerts
You can use Alert Filters and routines to manage if and how specific 
Emergency Alert System (EAS) events appear on the video display 
connected to the NQ-GA10PV. Your Nyquist server reads these EAS 
events, which include non-weather-related alerts, from the NWS.
To display EAS events:
Step 1
Decide which alerts you want to monitor and enable 
filters for those alerts, such as severity, certainty, and 
urgency (see "Alert Filters Configuration” on page 462).
Step 2
Create a routine (see "Adding a Routine” on page 387).
Step 3
Create an action for the routine that uses Display-Msg 
for the action Type (see "Actions” on page 402).
Step 4
Ensure the Text for the action contains the variables for 
the alerts you want to display (see "Setting Variables for 
the Display Message” on page 466).
16.1
Understanding Event Types
The EAS has created specific event types for monitoring that include:
• Weather-Related Events, such as a Tornado Warning
• Non-Weather-Related Events, such as a Shelter in Place Warning 
for non-weather situations 
Note: Nyquist can only display weather or other emergency alerts 
from the National Weather Service (NWS) if your Nyquist server 
has an Internet connection and has access to necessary websites 
(see "Whitelisted Web Addresses” on page 3).

qas.question: What types of events are logged by the Manage Check-In feature?

answers.text: The Manage Check-In feature logs the following event types: Start, Check-in, Stop, Reset, Done, Vacancy Add, Vacancy Delete, Exclude Add, and Exclude Delete. Each logged event includes a date and time stamp, the station extension that created the event, and optional event-related information. The Done event also records the elapsed time for the Check-in process.

qas.question: How is the elapsed time for the Check-In process recorded in the Check-In log?

answers.text: The elapsed time for the Check-In process is recorded in the Check-In log under the Done event, which logs the amount of time between the Check-In Start and Done. This entry always shows the extension as 000, indicating it is created by the system, for example: "2019-04-26 15:43:32 - 000 Done (elapsed time: 0h:3m:10s)."

qas.question: What are the steps to display Emergency Alert System (EAS) events using a Nyquist server?

answers.text: To display Emergency Alert System (EAS) events using a Nyquist server, first enable filters for the desired alerts based on severity, certainty, and urgency. Then, create a routine and an action that uses Display-Msg for the action type, ensuring the text contains the relevant variables for the alerts to be displayed.

qas.question: Which filters can be applied to monitor specific EAS alerts?

answers.text: To monitor specific EAS alerts, you can apply filters based on severity, certainty, and urgency. These filters allow you to decide which alerts you want to enable for display on the video connected to the NQ-GA10PV.

qas.question: What command is used to create an action for displaying messages in the EAS routine?

answers.text: To create an action for displaying messages in the EAS routine, use the action type "Display-Msg." Ensure that the text for the action contains the relevant variables for the alerts you want to display.

qas.question: What types of events does the EAS classify for monitoring?

answers.text: The Emergency Alert System (EAS) classifies events for monitoring into two main types: Weather-Related Events, such as Tornado Warnings, and Non-Weather-Related Events, such as Shelter in Place Warnings for non-weather situations.

qas.question: What is required for the Nyquist server to display alerts from the National Weather Service (NWS)?

answers.text: For the Nyquist server to display alerts from the National Weather Service (NWS), it must have an Internet connection and access to the necessary whitelisted websites.

qas.question: What is indicated by the extension number "000" in the Done event log?

answers.text: In the Done event log, the extension number "000" indicates that the event was created by the system rather than a specific station. This means that the Done log entry does not correspond to any particular user or device that initiated the check-in process.

Managing Alerts
You can use Alert Filters and routines to manage if and how specific 
Emergency Alert System (EAS) events appear on the video display 
connected to the NQ-GA10PV. Your Nyquist server reads these EAS 
events, which include non-weather-related alerts, from the NWS.
To display EAS events:
Step 1
Decide which alerts you want to monitor and enable 
filters for those alerts, such as severity, certainty, and 
urgency (see "Alert Filters Configuration” on page 462).
Step 2

Step 3

16.1
Understanding Event Types
The EAS has created specific event types for monitoring that include:
• Weather-Related Events, such as a Tornado Warning
• Non-Weather-Related Events, such as a Shelter in Place Warning 
for non-weather situations 
Note: Nyquist can only display weather or other emergency alerts 
from the National Weather Service (NWS) if your Nyquist server 
has an Internet connection and has access to necessary websites 
(see "Whitelisted Web Addresses” on page 3). 
462
• Administrative Events, such as an Administrative Message
Event types are categorized as:
• Advisory. An event that is not life-threatening but could cause 
inconvenience.
• Warning. An event that poses a significant threat to public safety 
or property and has a high probability of occurrence or is occur-
ring. 
• Watch. Conditions are favorable for the event occurring; does not 
mean the event will occur but it is possible.
• Emergency. An event that by itself would not kill or injure or 
cause property damage, but indirectly may cause other things to 
happen that result in a hazard. 
• Statement. A message containing follow up information to a 
warning, watch, or emergency.
• Message. Non-weather related messages, such as an Amber Alert.
• Test. An administrative event for a monthly or weekly test of the 
emergency alert system.
The specific criteria for issuing an emergency alert is dependent your 
location. 
16.2
Alert Filters Configuration
The Common Alerting Protocol (CAP) is an international standard 
format for emergency alerting and public warning. It is designed for 
all hazards related to weather events, earthquakes, tsunami, volca-
noes, public health, power outages, and many other emergencies. 
Note: Non-Weather-Related Events and Administrative Events are 
only provided if the EAS has supplied that information to the NWS. 
Therefore, local Amber Alerts and Shelter in Place Warnings for 
non-weather situations may not be provided in your area.

qas.question: What types of alerts can the Nyquist server display from the National Weather Service (NWS)?

answers.text: The Nyquist server can display weather-related events such as Tornado Warnings, non-weather-related events like Shelter in Place Warnings, and administrative messages from the National Weather Service (NWS). However, the availability of certain alerts, especially non-weather-related ones, depends on whether the EAS has supplied that information to the NWS.

qas.question: How can you enable filters for monitoring specific Emergency Alert System (EAS) events?

answers.text: To enable filters for monitoring specific Emergency Alert System (EAS) events, first decide which alerts to monitor based on severity, certainty, and urgency. Then, configure the alert filters using the appropriate settings in the system as outlined in the "Alert Filters Configuration" section.

qas.question: What is the purpose of creating a routine in managing alerts for the Nyquist server?

answers.text: Creating a routine in managing alerts for the Nyquist server allows you to define specific actions that will be triggered when certain EAS events occur. This helps in customizing the response to alerts by utilizing filters for criteria like severity and urgency, ensuring that the appropriate messages are displayed on the video display connected to the server.

qas.question: Which variables should be included in the action for the Display-Msg type?

answers.text: The action for the Display-Msg type should include variables for the specific alerts you want to display, such as the alert's severity, certainty, urgency, and event type (e.g., weather-related or non-weather-related events). These variables help convey the relevant information pertaining to the emergency alert.

qas.question: What are the different event types categorized by the EAS, and how do they differ?

answers.text: The EAS categorizes event types into Advisory (non-life-threatening but inconvenient), Warning (significant threat to safety or property), Watch (conditions favorable for an event), Emergency (indirect hazards), Statement (follow-up information), Message (non-weather related alerts like Amber Alerts), and Test (administrative events for system checks). Each type differs primarily in the level of threat and urgency they convey to the public.

qas.question: What does the term "Common Alerting Protocol (CAP)" refer to in the context of emergency alerts?

answers.text: The Common Alerting Protocol (CAP) is an international standard format for emergency alerting and public warning, designed to address all hazards related to various emergencies such as weather events, earthquakes, and public health issues. It facilitates the issuance and dissemination of alerts, ensuring consistent communication during emergencies.

qas.question: Under what conditions can the Nyquist server display non-weather-related events?

answers.text: The Nyquist server can display non-weather-related events, such as Shelter in Place Warnings, only if the Emergency Alert System (EAS) has supplied that information to the National Weather Service (NWS). Additionally, the server must have an Internet connection and access to the necessary whitelisted websites.

qas.question: What is the significance of a "Test" event type within the EAS framework?

answers.text: A "Test" event type within the Emergency Alert System (EAS) framework serves as an administrative measure to verify the functionality and readiness of the alert systems. These tests are typically conducted on a monthly or weekly basis to ensure that the system can effectively disseminate emergency alerts when necessary.

• Administrative Events, such as an Administrative Message
Event types are categorized as:
• Advisory. An event that is not life-threatening but could cause 
inconvenience.
• Warning. An event that poses a significant threat to public safety 
or property and has a high probability of occurrence or is occur-
ring. 
• Watch. Conditions are favorable for the event occurring; does not 
mean the event will occur but it is possible.
• Emergency. An event that by itself would not kill or injure or 
cause property damage, but indirectly may cause other things to 
happen that result in a hazard. 
• Statement. A message containing follow up information to a 
warning, watch, or emergency.
• Message. Non-weather related messages, such as an Amber Alert.
• Test. An administrative event for a monthly or weekly test of the 
emergency alert system.
The specific criteria for issuing an emergency alert is dependent your 
location.

16.3
Setting Variables for the Display Message
You can use the following variables in the Text field of a Display-
Msg to have NWS alerts automatically appear on the video display 
connected to the NQ-GA10PV:
• $alerts
• $auto_resize
The $auto_resize variable must be immediately followed by a number 
in parentheses, for example, $auto_resize(20). In this example, 
Nyquist automatically resizes the display message by decreasing the 
font size if needed to better fit the message to the screen but will 
keep the font size to at least 20. 
The $alerts variable is also immediately followed by parameters in 
parentheses. The available parameters are:
• AUTO_FIND_COUNTY. Automatically discovers the county code 
associated with the Nyquist server’s public IP address. 
• AUTO_COMPRESS_<Integer>. Automatically compresses the 
display message if the number of lines in the message exceeds the 
<Integer> value. For example, AUTO_COMPRESS_15 will cause 
messages that contain more than 15 lines to be compressed by 
removing end-of-line characters (lines will run together, separated 
by a space instead of end-of-line). The resulting message will per-
haps be more difficult to read than the original. Use this option if 
Note: The font size will automatically resize to 20 if the Alert mes-
sage has these following parameters:
• Priority is smaller than 6.
• Text length is longer than 1500 characters.
• The text has more than 500 capital letter characters.
The font size also automatically resizes to 20 if needed, even if the 
$auto_resize variable is not specified.
Note: This option is not recommended if the server’s physical 
location is in a different county from your facility, if your server 
resides in the cloud, or if you are tracking alerts for multiple facili-
ties and those facilities are not in the same county. Instead, find 
and use your county code.

qas.question: What are the different types of event categories defined for emergency alerts?

answers.text: The different types of event categories defined for emergency alerts are Advisory, Warning, Watch, Emergency, Statement, Message, and Test. Each category signifies varying levels of threat and urgency, ranging from non-life-threatening advisories to significant threats requiring immediate action.

qas.question: How is the Common Alerting Protocol (CAP) relevant to emergency alerting?

answers.text: The Common Alerting Protocol (CAP) is an international standard format for emergency alerting and public warning, designed to address various hazards including weather events, earthquakes, and public health emergencies. It standardizes the way alerts are issued and communicated, ensuring consistency and clarity in the information provided to the public during emergencies.

qas.question: What specific criteria dictate the issuance of an emergency alert in a given area?

answers.text: The specific criteria for issuing an emergency alert depend on the location, as local authorities determine the circumstances under which alerts are triggered. Factors include the severity, certainty, urgency, and response needed for various event types, which may vary by jurisdiction. Non-weather-related and administrative events are only issued if provided by the Emergency Alert System (EAS) to the National Weather Service (NWS).

qas.question: What permissions are necessary to configure alert filters in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: To configure alert filters in the Nyquist system, you must have Edit permissions. Without these permissions, you will not be able to enable and set the Alert Filters Configuration.

qas.question: Which variables can be used in the Text field of a Display-Msg for NWS alerts?

answers.text: The variables that can be used in the Text field of a Display-Msg for NWS alerts are **$alerts** and **$auto_resize**. The $auto_resize variable must be followed by a number in parentheses (e.g., $auto_resize(20)), while the $alerts variable requires parameters in parentheses such as **AUTO_FIND_COUNTY** and **AUTO_COMPRESS_<Integer>**.

qas.question: What does the Urgency element indicate in an emergency alert?

answers.text: The Urgency element in an emergency alert indicates the time frame within which responsive action should be taken. It includes values such as Immediate (action needed right away), Expected (action needed soon), Future (action needed in the near future), Past (no longer needed), and Unknown (urgency not known).

qas.question: How does the $auto_resize variable function in display messages?

answers.text: The $auto_resize variable in display messages automatically adjusts the font size to fit the message on the screen, ensuring it does not drop below a specified size (e.g., $auto_resize(20) means the font size will decrease but remain at least 20). This resizing occurs if the message exceeds the screen limits while maintaining readability.

qas.question: What are the available values for the Severity element in emergency alerts?

answers.text: The available values for the Severity element in emergency alerts are: Extreme (extraordinary threat to life or property), Severe (significant threat to life or property), Moderate (possible threat to life or property), Minor (minimal to no known threat), and Unknown (severity unknown).

qas.question: Can non-weather-related emergency event alerts be provided in all areas?

answers.text: No, non-weather-related emergency event alerts, such as local Amber Alerts and Shelter in Place Warnings, may not be provided in all areas. Their availability is dependent on whether the Emergency Alert System (EAS) has supplied that information to the National Weather Service (NWS).

qas.question: What action should be taken if the Urgency of an alert is marked as ‘Immediate’?

answers.text: If the Urgency of an alert is marked as 'Immediate', responsive action should be taken immediately. This indicates that prompt measures are required to ensure safety or address the event.

16.3
Setting Variables for the Display Message
You can use the following variables in the Text field of a Display-
Msg to have NWS alerts automatically appear on the video display 
connected to the NQ-GA10PV:
• $alerts
• $auto_resize
The $auto_resize variable must be immediately followed by a number 
in parentheses, for example, $auto_resize(20). In this example, 
Nyquist automatically resizes the display message by decreasing the 
font size if needed to better fit the message to the screen but will 
keep the font size to at least 20. 
The $alerts variable is also immediately followed by parameters in 
parentheses. The available parameters are:
• AUTO_FIND_COUNTY. Automatically discovers the county code 
associated with the Nyquist server’s public IP address. 
• AUTO_COMPRESS_<Integer>. Automatically compresses the 
display message if the number of lines in the message exceeds the 
<Integer> value. For example, AUTO_COMPRESS_15 will cause 
messages that contain more than 15 lines to be compressed by 
removing end-of-line characters (lines will run together, separated 
by a space instead of end-of-line). The resulting message will per-
haps be more difficult to read than the original. Use this option if 
Note: The font size will automatically resize to 20 if the Alert mes-
sage has these following parameters:
• Priority is smaller than 6.
• Text length is longer than 1500 characters.
• The text has more than 500 capital letter characters.
The font size also automatically resizes to 20 if needed, even if the 
$auto_resize variable is not specified.
Note: This option is not recommended if the server’s physical 
location is in a different county from your facility, if your server 
resides in the cloud, or if you are tracking alerts for multiple facili-
ties and those facilities are not in the same county. Instead, find 
and use your county code.
467
you want to ensure that messages will fit on the screen. You may 
need to experiment to determine a suitable value for <Integer>. 
You can combine this option with the $auto_resize variable.
• <County-Code>. Displays weather alerts for the specified county. 
For example, the county code for Orange County, Florida, is 
FLC095.  
• INCLUDE_CODES. Displays, the Severity, Certainty, Urgency and 
Response codes on the Alerts header for each alert displayed on 
the NQ-GA10PV display (see Figure 16-2, “Sample Alert With Ele-
ments Defined,” on page 464).
• INCLUDE_COUNTY. Displays the county code on the Alerts head-
ers. This is useful if you have several Alert related routines that use 
different county codes.
• INCLUDE_INSTRUCTIONS. Displays instructions that came with 
the weather alerts. If you want to display the exact instructions 
provided by the NWS, then add the INCLUDE_INSTRUCTIONS 
option. Instructions are usually obvious (like seek shelter, stay 
indoors, stay hydrated). However, instructions can be verbose and, 
while they can provide valuable information, verbose instructions 
could cause the messages to be too large to display properly.
Note: Font sizes are set in the Display Message options (see "Cre-
ating a Display Message” on page 438). For weather alerts, the fol-
lowing settings are recommended for the Liberation Sans font:
• 30 - When not using the AUTO_COMPRESS_<Integer> option 
of the $alerts variable and not using the $auto_resize variable. A 
font size of 30 will ensure that the actual lines from the NWS 
will fit on each line displayed.
• 65 - When using AUTO_COMPRESS_15 and $auto_resize(25) 
variable.
• 40 - When using AUTO_COMPRESS_25 and $auto_resize(25) 
variable.
• 70 - When using AUTO_COMPRESS_<Inter> and $auto_resize 
variable with display message priority of 6.
Note: County codes are available at: https://alerts-v2.weather.gov/
counties.
468
• REPEAT_<Integer>. Automatically repeats the alert processing 
and re-displays any resulting alerts every <Integer> seconds. Pre-
vious alerts are automatically removed from displays. This option 
provides a convenient way to check for and display alerts at a reg-
ular interval without having to create a routine loop and without 
having to worry about deleting previous or expired alerts. When 
this option is used, no subsequent actions will be executed in the 
Routine that executes the Display-Msg action. Since alert pro-
cessing requires Internet access processing, Bogen recommends a 
minimum <Integer> value of 60 seconds. Using less than 60 sec-
onds may significantly impact your network and Nyquist server 
processing utilization.
• UPDATE_CACHE. Nyquist caches the found county code so the 
system does not have to search more than one time. 
If your county code changes, you can include the option 
UPDATE_CACHE along with AUTO_FIND_COUNTY to have the 
system discover the county code and cache the new value. 
Note: You should delete the UPDATE_CACHE option after use; 
otherwise, the Nyquist system searches for the county code each 
time alerts are retrieved.
469
A sample alert string is:
$alerts(FLC095,INCLUDE_CODES,AUTO_COMPRESS_15,REPEAT_60) 
This string will display alerts for county code FLC095 (Orange County, 
Florida) every 60 seconds including the Severity, Certainty, Urgency, 
and Repose codes, while automatically compressing alerts that have 
more than 15 lines.
16.4
Demonstration Alerts
Several demonstration, or sample, Alerts are available for display. 
These samples represent typical alerts sent by the NWS for various 
alert types.
You can access these by replacing the <County-Code> with 
ALERT_DEMO<number> where <number> is replaced with a number 
between 1 and 20 (for example, ALERT_DEMO10). Bogen recom-
mends that you try each demonstration alert to get familiar with the 
alert format, the available $alerts options, and the font sizing.
Figure 16-3, How Parameters Affect Display

qas.question: What variables can be used in the Text field of a Display-Msg to show NWS alerts on the NQ-GA10PV?

answers.text: The variables that can be used in the Text field of a Display-Msg to show NWS alerts on the NQ-GA10PV are $alerts and $auto_resize. The $alerts variable supports parameters like AUTO_FIND_COUNTY, AUTO_COMPRESS_<Integer>, and specific county codes, while $auto_resize is used to automatically adjust font sizes based on the specified number in parentheses.

qas.question: How does the $auto_resize variable function in relation to font size adjustments?

answers.text: The $auto_resize variable automatically adjusts the font size of the display message to ensure it fits on the screen, with a specified minimum size indicated in parentheses (e.g., $auto_resize(20)). If adjustments are needed, the font size will decrease but will not go below the specified minimum, helping to maintain readability while accommodating longer messages.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the AUTO_FIND_COUNTY parameter within the $alerts variable?

answers.text: The AUTO_FIND_COUNTY parameter within the $alerts variable automatically discovers the county code associated with the Nyquist server's public IP address. This function helps ensure that the correct weather alerts for the relevant county are displayed without needing to manually specify the county code.

qas.question: How does the AUTO_COMPRESS_<Integer> option affect the display of alert messages?

answers.text: The AUTO_COMPRESS_<Integer> option compresses the display message by removing end-of-line characters when the number of lines in the message exceeds the specified <Integer> value. This causes the lines to run together, separated by spaces, which may make the message more difficult to read. For example, using AUTO_COMPRESS_15 will compress alerts that contain more than 15 lines.

qas.question: What font size settings are recommended for different scenarios involving weather alerts?

answers.text: Recommended font size settings for weather alerts using the Liberation Sans font are: 30 when not using AUTO_COMPRESS or $auto_resize; 65 with AUTO_COMPRESS_15 and $auto_resize(25); 40 with AUTO_COMPRESS_25 and $auto_resize(25); and 70 when using AUTO_COMPRESS with a display message priority of 6.

qas.question: How can you include specific county-related information in the displayed alerts?

answers.text: To include specific county-related information in the displayed alerts, use the $alerts variable followed by the county code in parentheses, such as $alerts(<County-Code>). You can also include options like INCLUDE_COUNTY to display the county code on alert headers and AUTO_FIND_COUNTY to automatically discover the county code based on the Nyquist server’s public IP address.

qas.question: What does the REPEAT_<Integer> parameter do regarding alert display frequency?

answers.text: The REPEAT_<Integer> parameter automatically reprocesses and redisplays alerts every <Integer> seconds. This option removes previous alerts from the display and allows for regular updates without needing to create a continuous routine loop, although it is recommended to use a minimum value of 60 seconds to avoid impacting network performance.

qas.question: What effect does the UPDATE_CACHE option have on county code discovery?

answers.text: The UPDATE_CACHE option allows Nyquist to cache the found county code, so it doesn't need to search for it more than once. If the county code changes, including UPDATE_CACHE with AUTO_FIND_COUNTY enables the system to discover and cache the new county code, but it should be removed afterward to prevent unnecessary searches during future alert retrievals.

qas.question: What should you do if your county code changes while using the UPDATE_CACHE option?

answers.text: If your county code changes while using the UPDATE_CACHE option, include the UPDATE_CACHE along with AUTO_FIND_COUNTY to discover and cache the new county code. After updating, you should delete the UPDATE_CACHE option to prevent the system from searching for the county code each time alerts are retrieved.

qas.question: How can you access demonstration alerts for familiarization with the format and options?

answers.text: To access demonstration alerts for familiarization with the format and options, replace the <County-Code> with ALERT_DEMO<number>, where <number> is between 1 and 20 (e.g., ALERT_DEMO10). This allows you to try each demonstration alert and understand the available $alerts options and font sizing.

qas.question: What does the example alert string display for county code FLC095?

answers.text: The example alert string for county code FLC095 displays alerts every 60 seconds that include the Severity, Certainty, Urgency, and Repose codes. Additionally, it automatically compresses alerts that have more than 15 lines.

qas.question: How often will alerts for FLC095 be displayed according to the string?

qas.question: What information is included in the alerts for FLC095?

qas.question: What functionality does the AUTO_COMPRESS_15 parameter provide?

answers.text: The AUTO_COMPRESS_15 parameter automatically compresses alerts that exceed 15 lines in length. This functionality helps manage the display of lengthy alerts by reducing their visual footprint while maintaining essential information.

qas.question: How can a user access demonstration alerts?

answers.text: A user can access demonstration alerts by replacing <County-Code> with ALERT_DEMO<number>, where <number> is between 1 and 20 (e.g., ALERT_DEMO10). This allows the user to view various sample alerts sent by the NWS to familiarize themselves with the alert format and available options.

qas.question: What is the range of numbers that can replace <number> in the demonstration alert format?

qas.question: Why does Bogen recommend trying each demonstration alert?

answers.text: Bogen recommends trying each demonstration alert to familiarize users with the alert format, the available $alerts options, and font sizing. This hands-on experience helps users understand how the system displays alerts and how to customize them effectively.

qas.question: What do the acronyms ANS, ASB, and ATA stand for?

answers.text: ANS stands for Ambient Noise Sensor, ASB stands for Analog Station Bridge, and ATA stands for Analog Telephone Adapter. These acronyms are used in contexts related to telecommunications and audio processing.

qas.question: What does CODEC mean in the context of the acronyms and abbreviations listed?

answers.text: CODEC stands for Coder-Decoder. It refers to a device or software that encodes or decodes audio and video data, enabling compression and decompression for efficient transmission and playback.

qas.question: What does "CoS" refer to in the provided acronyms?

answers.text: "CoS" refers to "Class of Service." It is a term used in networking and telecommunications to categorize data packets based on their priority or type of service, helping manage traffic and ensure quality of service.

qas.question: What does the acronym ANS stand for?

answers.text: The acronym ANS stands for Ambient Noise Sensor. It is a device used to detect and measure ambient noise levels in an environment.

qas.question: What is the meaning of the abbreviation FXO?

answers.text: FXO stands for Foreign Exchange Office. It refers to a telephony interface used to connect a telephone line from a public switched telephone network (PSTN) to a private branch exchange (PBX) or a voice gateway.

qas.question: Define CoS in the context of the listed acronyms.

answers.text: In the context of the listed acronyms, CoS stands for "Class of Service." It refers to a set of permissions and features assigned to a communication station, determining the types of calls that can be made or received and the privileges available to users within a telecommunications system.

qas.question: What protocol does DHCP refer to?

answers.text: DHCP stands for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. It is a network management protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses and other network configuration parameters to devices on a network, allowing them to communicate effectively within an IP network.

qas.question: How is NAT defined in network terminology?

answers.text: Network Address Translation (NAT) is a technique used in networking to modify the IP address information in IP packet headers while in transit across a router or firewall. It enables multiple devices on a local network to share a single public IP address, helping to conserve IP addresses and enhance security by hiding internal IP addresses from external networks.

qas.question: What functionality does the term VoIP represent?

answers.text: VoIP, or Voice over Internet Protocol, represents a technology that allows the transmission of voice communications and multimedia sessions over the Internet using packet-switched protocols. It enables users to make phone calls through the Internet instead of traditional phone lines, offering increased flexibility and often reduced costs.

qas.question: What does the acronym SMTP stand for?

answers.text: SMTP stands for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol. It is a protocol used for sending email messages between servers and is a key component of the email transmission process.

qas.question: Explain the significance of RAID in data storage.

answers.text: RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) is significant in data storage as it combines multiple disk drives into a single unit, enhancing performance and providing redundancy. This not only increases data access speeds but also protects against data loss by duplicating data across drives, ensuring reliability and fault tolerance.

qas.question: What is the primary function of a PCIe interface?

answers.text: The primary function of a PCIe (Peripheral Component Interconnect Express) interface is to serve as a high-speed communication pathway between the motherboard and peripheral devices, such as graphics cards, storage devices, and network cards. It provides significantly increased bandwidth compared to older interfaces, enabling faster data transfer and improved overall system performance.

qas.question: What does the abbreviation SSL refer to in network security?

answers.text: SSL stands for Secure Sockets Layer, which is a standard security protocol that enables encrypted communication between a web server and a browser. It ensures data transmitted over the internet remains secure and private, helping to protect sensitive information such as credit card numbers and personal data.

qas.question: How does SIP relate to session management in telecommunications?

answers.text: Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is a signaling protocol used for initiating, maintaining, and terminating real-time communication sessions in telecommunications, such as voice and video calls. SIP facilitates session management by establishing the parameters of the communication, handling user registration, and negotiating media types and transport protocols during the session setup process.

qas.question: What is the purpose of a TURN server in networking?

answers.text: A TURN (Traversal Using Relays around NAT) server assists in establishing audio, video, and data streaming connections between clients that are behind NAT (Network Address Translation) or firewall restrictions. It relays media traffic between clients when direct peer-to-peer communication is not possible, ensuring connectivity in challenging network environments.

qas.question: Describe the role of a CPU in a computing system.

answers.text: The Central Processing Unit (CPU) acts as the brain of a computing system, executing instructions from programs by performing basic arithmetic, logic, control, and input/output operations. It interprets and processes data, coordinating all tasks necessary for the system's functionality and overall performance.

qas.question: What does the acronym HTTP signify in web communication?

answers.text: HTTP stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol. It is the foundation of data communication on the World Wide Web, enabling the transfer of hypertext documents and facilitating web browsing by allowing clients (like browsers) to communicate with servers.

qas.question: What does the abbreviation DNS stand for, and what is its function?

answers.text: DNS stands for Domain Name System. Its function is to translate human-readable domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers use to identify each other on the network.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used to start an alarm?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to start an alarm is *91{DTMF-Code}, where {number} specifies the alarm to be activated.

qas.question: How is a tone specified to be activated using DTMF?

answers.text: A tone is activated using DTMF by dialing *96 followed by the DTMF-Code that specifies the desired tone. This command allows the manual activation of tone signals as per the defined codes.

qas.question: What is the DTMF code format for calling an extension via speaker?

answers.text: The DTMF code format for calling an extension via speaker is simply `<extension>`. This allows for intercom or auto-answer calls, depending on the station's Class of Service (CoS) assignments.

qas.question: How do you place a long-distance call using the DTMF system?

answers.text: To place a long-distance call using the DTMF system, dial 981AAANNNNNNN, where AAA is the area code and NNNNNNN is the local number you wish to reach. Ensure that your station's Class of Service (CoS) assignments allow for long-distance calling.

qas.question: What DTMF code allows a user to join a conversation at a specific extension?

answers.text: The DTMF code that allows a user to join a conversation at a specific extension is *#<extension>. This code is subject to the station's Class of Service (CoS) assignments.

qas.question: What does the * sign before an extension indicate in dial codes?

answers.text: The * sign before an extension in dial codes indicates that the call will ring the specified extension's phone (telephonic, ringing) rather than using intercom or auto-answer features. It's part of the dial code format that defines how the call is routed based on the class of service (CoS) assignments.

qas.question: How does the CoS affect the use of feature dial codes?

answers.text: The Class of Service (CoS) determines which feature dial codes a user can access. Specific CoS assignments restrict the ability to activate alarm signals, place calls to any station, or join conversations, thereby limiting the functions available to each user based on their assigned permissions.

answers.text: To manually activate tone signals using DTMF codes, you dial *96 followed by the specific DTMF code corresponding to the desired tone. This allows you to initiate the specified tone signal.

qas.question: What is the difference between calling an extension with and without the asterisk (*)?

answers.text: Calling an extension with an asterisk (*) activates the ringer of the extension, causing it to ring normally, while calling an extension without the asterisk directly initiates an intercom call, allowing for a two-way conversation without ringing. The asterisk indicates the type of call being made, differentiating between ringing and direct communication modes.

qas.question: Which code is used to join a conversation at a specific extension?

answers.text: The code used to join a conversation at a specific extension is *#<extension>. This code allows a user to connect to an ongoing call at the designated extension.

qas.question: How can you place a long-distance call using DTMF codes?

answers.text: To place a long-distance call using DTMF codes, dial 981AAANNNNNNN, where AAA is the area code and NNNNNNN is the number you wish to reach. Ensure your station's Class of Service (CoS) assignments allow for long-distance calling.

qas.question: What does the notation "CoS" stand for in the context of feature dial codes?

answers.text: In the context of feature dial codes, "CoS" stands for "Class of Service." It refers to the permissions and restrictions assigned to a station, determining which features can be used based on the user's assigned class.

qas.question: What does the code *#<extension> accomplish in the system?

answers.text: The code *#<extension> is used to join an ongoing conversation at the specified <extension> in the system. This feature is governed by the station's Class of Service (CoS) assignments, which determine access permissions.

qas.question: Can you specify the format for a long-distance call with area code using DTMF codes?

answers.text: To make a long-distance call with an area code using DTMF codes, the format is: 981AAANNNNNNN, where AAA represents the area code and NNNNNNN represents the local number.

qas.question: How can a user join a conversation at a specific extension?

answers.text: To join a conversation at a specific extension, a user can dial *#<extension>. This command allows them to connect to the ongoing call at that extension.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF code 970?

answers.text: The DTMF code 970 is used to access the Call Forwarding Menu. This menu allows users to manage their call forwarding settings, including enabling or disabling various types of call forwarding options.

qas.question: What DTMF code can be used to place an emergency call to a designated Admin station?

answers.text: The DTMF code to place an emergency call to a designated Admin station is ****. This code allows users to quickly connect with the Admin station in case of an emergency.

qas.question: How can a call be parked during an active call?

answers.text: To park a call during an active call, you can dial the DTMF code #72. After parking, the call can be retrieved using the assigned parked call extension, typically between 21-29.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF code #1 when transferring a call?

answers.text: The DTMF code #1 is used for blind transfer during a call. When this code is dialed followed by the extension number, it transfers the call to the specified extension without waiting for the recipient to answer.

qas.question: What DTMF code should be dialed to cancel call forwarding?

answers.text: To cancel call forwarding, dial the DTMF code **975**.

qas.question: What is the format to place a long distance call using the DTMF codes?

answers.text: To place a long distance call using the DTMF codes, use the format 981AAANNNNNNN, where AAA is the area code and NNNNNNN is the phone number.

qas.question: How can a user check the call forwarding status as a caller?

answers.text: A user can check the call forwarding status as a caller by dialing 976. This provides the status of call forwarding for the user who is calling.

qas.question: What extension range is typically used for picking up parked calls?

answers.text: The typical extension range used for picking up parked calls is 21-29. This range can be customized through the Admin Web UI in the System Parameters.

qas.question: How can a user cancel call forwarding?

answers.text: A user can cancel call forwarding by dialing 975. This command will stop all call forwarding settings currently in effect.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used to park a call during a conversation?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to park a call during a conversation is #72. After entering this code, the call will be placed in a parking lot, and the extension number assigned to the parked call will be provided.

qas.question: How do you pick up a parked call using an extension?

answers.text: To pick up a parked call, dial the parked call's extension (usually in the range of 21-29) that was provided when the call was parked using the #72 command. The parking lot extensions can be modified through the Admin Web UI if needed.

qas.question: What DTMF code initiates a blind transfer to another extension?

answers.text: The DTMF code that initiates a blind transfer to another extension is #1 followed by the extension number. This can be done during an active call.

qas.question: Which code allows a caller to check call forwarding status for all users?

answers.text: The code to check call forwarding status for all users is **977**. This allows users to view the call forwarding status of all extensions within the system.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the code 970 in the context of call forwarding?

answers.text: The code 970 serves as the Call Forwarding Menu, allowing users to access options related to call forwarding features. From this menu, users can set up, modify, or check the status of their call forwarding settings.

qas.question: How can a user place a 911 emergency call using a different code than 98911?

answers.text: A user can place a 911 emergency call using the code 911, in addition to 98911. Both codes connect to emergency services.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used for call forwarding when no answer occurs?

answers.text: The DTMF code used for call forwarding when no answer occurs is 973{extension}. This code initiates the call forwarding settings for an extension specifically for situations when the call is not answered.

qas.question: What is the default range of extensions for parked calls?

answers.text: The default range of extensions for parked calls is from 21 to 29. These extensions can be modified through the Admin Web UI under System Parameters.

qas.question: What are the dial patterns for placing local calls with and without an area code?

qas.question: How do you access the Call Forwarding Menu?

answers.text: To access the Call Forwarding Menu, dial 970. This will take you to the options for managing your call forwarding settings.

qas.question: What is the function of the code 971{extension} in Call Forwarding?

answers.text: The code 971{extension} in Call Forwarding is used to set up All-Calls Forwarding (CFALL) to a specified extension. This allows all incoming calls to be redirected to the designated extension without any conditions.

qas.question: How can you cancel Call Forwarding?

answers.text: To cancel Call Forwarding, dial 975. This will disable any active Call Forwarding settings for your extension.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used to park a call during a conversation?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to park a call during a conversation is #72. After dialing this code, the system will provide an extension where the call is parked.

qas.question: How do you pick up a parked call using its extension?

answers.text: To pick up a parked call, dial the parked call’s extension number (by default, extensions 21-29) that was provided when the call was parked. Ensure you use the corresponding parked extension number for the specific call you want to retrieve.

qas.question: What code is used for a blind transfer during a call?

answers.text: The code used for a blind transfer during a call is DTMF: #1<extension number>. This allows the caller to transfer the call directly to the specified extension without announcing the call.

qas.question: What is the DTMF code to place a blind transfer during a call?

answers.text: The DTMF code to place a blind transfer during a call is #1 followed by the extension number (DTMF: #1<extension number>).

qas.question: How can a user cancel Call Forwarding?

answers.text: A user can cancel Call Forwarding by dialing 975. This action will deactivate any active call forwarding settings on their extension.

qas.question: What is the method to park a call during an ongoing conversation?

answers.text: To park a call during an ongoing conversation, press DTMF code #72. This will park the call, and you can later retrieve it by dialing the parked call's extension, which is typically between 21-29.

qas.question: Which DTMF code enables "whisper mode" during call monitoring?

answers.text: The DTMF code that enables "whisper mode" during call monitoring is 5. This mode allows a user to speak privately to a monitored call without the parties on the call hearing the whisper.

qas.question: How can a user pick up a call that is parked using the default system configuration?

answers.text: To pick up a parked call using the default system configuration, dial the parked call's extension, which is typically between 21-29. This extension is provided when the call is parked using the DTMF code #72.

qas.question: What action does DTMF code **0 perform in the conferencing system?

answers.text: DTMF code **0 launches the system playback of a list of created conferences, which includes the conference number and the extension that created each conference. This function is accessible to users with Conference Admin or Conference User class of service (CoS).

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF code *2 during an attended transfer?

answers.text: The DTMF code *2 is used to complete an attended transfer while dropping out of the call. This means that the original caller is connected to the new party, and the transferring party disconnects from the call entirely.

qas.question: How can the status of Call Forwarding be checked for all users?

answers.text: To check the status of Call Forwarding for all users, dial DTMF: 977. This will provide the Call Forwarding status for all extensions.

qas.question: What is the procedure to enable "spy mode" during call monitoring?

answers.text: To enable "spy mode" during call monitoring, dial 978 followed by the extension you wish to monitor, and then press DTMF 4 during the monitoring call. This will mute the monitored party while allowing the monitoring user to hear the conversation.

qas.question: How do you create or enter a dynamic conference using DTMF?

answers.text: To create or enter a dynamic conference using DTMF, dial **{number}, replacing {number} with the conference number. This action requires appropriate permissions based on your user role as either Conference Admin or Conference User.

answers.text: The DTMF command that enables "whisper mode" during call monitoring is DTMF: 5.

qas.question: What is the DTMF code to create or enter a dynamic conference?

answers.text: The DTMF code to create or enter a dynamic conference is **{number}, where {number} represents the specific conference number. This function is available to users with Conference Admin or Conference User privileges.

qas.question: What can a user do with the DTMF code **0?

answers.text: The DTMF code **0 launches system playback of the list of created conferences, including the conference number and the extension that created each conference. This function is available to users with the Conference Admin or Conference User Class of Service (CoS).

qas.question: How does "spy mode" monitoring differ from regular monitoring?

answers.text: "Spy mode" monitoring allows the user to listen to a call or location without being heard by the parties on the call, effectively muting the monitoring party. In contrast, regular monitoring does not specify whether the monitoring party can be muted or heard, potentially allowing input from the monitoring party during the call.

qas.question: Under what condition can spy mode monitoring not be used?

answers.text: Spy mode monitoring cannot be used on a station that has been set to Privacy Mode. This restriction ensures that calls at those stations remain private and unmonitored.

qas.question: What DTMF code is utilized to swap to the other party during an attended transfer?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to swap to the other party during an attended transfer is *4. This allows the user to switch between the parties involved in the call.

qas.question: Which monitoring function is indicated by the DTMF code 978 followed by an extension?

answers.text: The DTMF code 978 followed by an extension indicates the function to monitor a call or location at the specified extension. This requires the user to have the appropriate Class of Service (CoS) for monitoring calls or locations.

permanent zone number for the saved announcement by updating 
Play to Zone after the recorded announcement has been saved.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used to complete an attended transfer while staying in the call?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to complete an attended transfer while staying in the call is *3. This allows the caller to transfer the call while remaining connected to the conversation.

qas.question: How can a user launch the system playback of a list of created conferences?

answers.text: A user can launch the system playback of a list of created conferences by dialing **0. This will provide a list that includes the conference number and the extension that created each conference.

qas.question: Which DTMF code enables "spy mode" during call monitoring?

answers.text: The DTMF code that enables "spy mode" during call monitoring is DTMF 4. This mode allows the user to silently monitor the call without being heard by the parties on the call.

qas.question: What happens if the conference owner enters 0000 as the password?

answers.text: If the conference owner enters 0000 as the password, the conference will be deleted. If an Admin station user enters 0000 as the password but is not the conference owner, they will be prompted for the system password.

qas.question: How can a user record a message using DTMF?

answers.text: A user can record a message using DTMF by dialing *990, which initiates the message recording process (CoS: All-Call Paging). After recording, the message will be saved with a DTMF code corresponding to its row ID, which can be changed later in the web interface.

qas.question: What is the DTMF code for an Emergency All-Call Page?

answers.text: The DTMF code for an Emergency All-Call Page is either **#0911** or **951**. Both codes are part of the Class of Service for Emergency All-Call.

qas.question: How can a user page to a specific zone using DTMF?

answers.text: A user can page to a specific zone by dialing `#{Zone}`, where `{Zone}` represents the desired zone number. This action requires appropriate Class of Service (CoS) privileges for Zone Paging.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used to initiate a complete attended transfer after a call has started?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to initiate a complete attended transfer after a call has started is *2. This code completes the attended transfer and drops out of the call.

qas.question: What are the options for enabling call monitoring during a call?

answers.text: During a call, you can enable call monitoring with the following options: DTMF 4 to activate "spy mode" (mute), DTMF 5 for "whisper mode," and DTMF 6 for "barge mode." "Spy mode" allows silent monitoring, "whisper mode" lets the monitor talk to the call participant without them hearing the caller, and "barge mode" enables the monitor to join the conversation.

qas.question: How can a user modify the Play to Zone setting for a recorded announcement?

answers.text: A user can modify the Play to Zone setting for a recorded announcement by accessing the web interface Announcements view after the announcement has been saved. In this interface, the user can update the Play to Zone field to define a permanent zone number for the announcement.
